fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst: Liz Jones gave Jeremy Langmead his first ever job. Now, they both edit their own women's magazines, and share gossip, glamour and even next month's cover story. But the one thing they'll never agree on is Abba
fields.trailText: Liz Jones gave Jeremy Langmead his first ever job. Now, they both edit their own women's magazines, and share gossip, glamour and even next month's cover story. But the one thing they'll never agree on is Abba.
fields.body:
Liz Jones: I was employing people to work on Mirabella magazine in 1989 when I first met Jeremy. He came for an interview while he was still at St Martin's [College of Art & Design], so I expected him to turn up with a mohican and tartan skirt, but he arrived in a three-piece tweed suit with a little briefcase. He seemed very prim and proper at first, but underneath he's very funny. At first, Jeremy and I had a bit of a communication problem. He has a strange way of pronouncing things, so for quite a few weeks I couldn't understand what he was saying.

Jeremy has extraordinarily expensive tastes. Even when he was a student and was paid virtually nothing, he always bought designer clothes. Even now he will still buy an amazing piece of art made of dandelion heads or a Prada fur coat, rather than pay his electricity bill.

We are both into clothes and minimalism, and Jeremy is absolutely my best friend, even though we like very different music. His taste in music is terrible - he just likes Abba and the Pet Shop Boys, and he's never liked hip-hop. We go to lots of parties together. We went to the Puffy concert, and the sight of him among all those hip-hop people made me cry with laughter.

One thing about Jeremy is that people do take advantage of him, because he's too soft and kind, and that's the main thing I try and protect him from. In turn, he protects me from men. I'm too soft with them, so he vets my boyfriends. If I turn up at a club and my boyfriend is there with another person, I'll ring Jeremy and cry, which is how the column Single File in The Sunday Times came about, because every week I would either cry down the phone or make him laugh at my escapades, so he said, 'You need to write this down.'

He lives around the corner from me in Hackney, and now I'm editing Marie Claire he's in the next-door office as editor of Nova magazine. We help each other out. And, of course, I absolutely trust him. He'd never go behind my back and take a cover story.

Jeremy Langmead: When Liz doesn't know people, she doesn't understand what they are saying, so when I first started working at Mirabella we never understood each other. When we go out together now, it's like going to the United Nations as a translator, because she gets nervous and gets this tunnel hearing and vision, and I have to make Liz and her world connect with people in the normal world.

When Mirabella folded, we both ended up working at The Sunday Times and eventually I edited Style and Liz was my deputy. We socialise a fair amount together because we still both like pop music and glamour gigs. We have very different tastes in music, so we'll go to Puff Daddy or Madonna because it's an event rather than for the music. Right now it's all work and no play - I'm at Nova five days a week.

I'll always be grateful to Liz because she gave me my first ever job, but also she makes me laugh a lot. Whenever I have a problem, personal or professional, I know I can ring her. Liz is very eccentric - kind of odd, in a nice way - so she's always interesting because she's sort of in another world.

We are very similar in a lot of ways: we are both quite anal, both control freaks, and obsessed with our houses being tidy and perfect - in a minimalist way. The other thing I've shared with Liz has been her 'Oh, why haven't I got a boyfriend', and for years I tried to find her one. She'd say: 'Oh, I've found this bloke who's quite good looking, can you check him out?' Eventually I said, 'Listen, why not make some money out of it and do a column for Style.' But then, of course, once the column started, she got a boyfriend.

For all those years, I couldn't understand why she didn't have a boyfriend. She's so extraordinarily fussy, so I'd introduce her to someone, but if he hadn't heard of one of the rappers she was keen on, then that was it - so I gave up in the end. When she found one, it was such a big relief: I felt like one of those Jewish mothers in a Woody Allen film when the son announces he's going to get married. I had the same 'oy vay' at last, hallelujah, phew.

fields.headline: Diplomatic Relations
fields.standfirst: Ben Stiller has the most traumatic weekend of his life staying with his future in-laws in Meet The Parents. Michael Holden knows the feeling well
fields.trailText: Ben Stiller has the most traumatic weekend of his life staying with his future in-laws in Meet The Parents. Michael Holden knows the feeling well
fields.body:
Since the birth of cinema nothing has served movie-makers better than universal fear. Beverly Hills is built on it. Dark fears keep Hollywood in light lunches all year round. In the 1920s, everyone lived in fear of being lashed to train tracks by moustachioed fiends, and they got the movies they deserved. In the 70s it was sharks. Lately it seems the thing that really unnerves are in-laws.

Meet The Parents has taken America by storm in much the same way as actual storms have over here. Now the movie is upon us too and, as universal fear films go, this is a humdinger. Most of us know deep down we are unlikely to be eaten by a shark, but meeting one's in-laws is a downer of global dimensions. Confronting the parents of someone you are in all likelihood having regular sex with remains a horror that Hollywood can only hint at.

Friends tried recently to milk the scary dad-in-law gag and gave us Bruce Willis, who is to true fear what Peter Cushing would have been to action movies had anyone made the mistake of giving him a vest and a pistol. For genuine in-law movie greatness we must look to Annie Hall and Christopher Walken's demented brother-in-law to steal the scene. But dark as it may be, Annie Hall is a fairy tale compared to what many of us have lived through, or will have to live through.

Meet The Parents centres on the dynamic between father-in-law (Robert De Niro) and would-be suitor (Ben Stiller). While Bob pulls all his best wiseguy death-threat faces, poor Ben digs himself ever deeper in his attempts to be accepted. De Niro's character was in the CIA; Stiller's is an idiot.

The premise is very funny indeed. Which is dandy, but misses the point that families often aren't. It was Princess Diana who, while on the receiving end of perhaps the most public and grotesque in-law crisis in human history, said that "families should spend more time talking and less time in front of the television". Though our other Royle Family's crude harmony seems to refute all that, the truth remains that meeting your in-laws is for most of us the most Shakespearean snakepit of psycho-sexual trauma life will ever throw at us.

Everyone has an in-law story. Some are even urban myths. Like the girl who having excused herself from dinner to visit the bathroom finds herself in just that. A room with a bath and no toilet. Too shy to go back and explain the precise nature of her needs, she opts to use the sink. As she perches upon it, the sink collapses beneath her weight. Rushing to investigate, the family are confronted by the dazed girl urinating before them in a pile of porcelain and broken plumbing. If you had a pound for every time that story's done the rounds you could afford a decent sink.

In my day, it was a minor miracle and welcome talking point if you dated anyone who had two parents. But no matter how many places are set at the table, it will always be an evening of separate agendas. Forget the generation gap, this is the perception canyon. This is not Seven Brides For Seven Brothers; this is When Families Collide. You foresee an uncomfortable evening, while in their minds they are feeding a sex criminal. They smell treachery and kidnap. They think you are an idiot. That's just the way it goes. There are exceptions of course, but people tend to marry them. A poll of my own half-buried remembrances and those closest to me unearthed a catalogue of mishaps, mind-games and outright horror that laid all fiction to waste.

My own de facto mother-in-law and I were on very different schedules during her and her second husband's month-long stopover in our tiny flat. As I would return in the early morning from a night of being young, she would emerge vengeful from the restless sleep of the elderly. "I lived through the war!" was her 6am catchphrase. "First the Nazis, and now you!"

On one occasion, myself and an associate consumed a bottle of Scotch intended for her husband. To defuse the row I made a pass at her and the room did indeed fall silent. On the one occasion I didn't wake her up, I forgot she was there and got into bed with her (an in-law classic). Somehow we remain the best of friends.

On a visit to my beloved's homeland, I made the acquaintance of her gay father, then ensconced for reasons of his own in a cabin just south of the Arctic circle.

One morning before breakfast he suggested we should take a walk in the woods. Five hours later as the sun went down we were still walking. I begged him to get us out, build a snow hole, anything to help us through the Arctic night. He just smiled and walked us back to civilisation with minutes to spare. By saying nothing, he was of course saying several very profound things at once. He may have abandoned heterosexuality, he may live a long way away, but in my mind he is very much her father. And I am an idiot.

The first person I asked for a story came up with this beauty. Leaving his girlfriend's bedroom he is confronted by a snide remark from her habitually drunken dad, who is sitting by the fire. Not being one to take such things lying down, he attacks the father, both men become drenched in supermarket whisky and burst into flame. She moves out. I didn't ask anyone else.

All of which neatly ignores those times when things run smoothly, just as such amusing anecdotes fail to address all those girlfriends and boyfriends who genuinely needed saving from truly bad parents. And let's hear it for all those wise old owls who have watched their little angels elope with subhuman suitors whose true awfulness their children couldn't see. Add to that the fact that many of us will have to suffer as parents what we once went through as children and it's clear what a miracle it is that the human race abides marriage and family at all. The fact that we survive these things, let alone make comedy blockbusters about them, is testament to the adaptability and courage of the species. Ben Stiller, faced with little more than a lie detector test and some stern reactionary backchat, doesn't know he's born.

 Meet The Parents is out on Friday

webTitle: Wonder woman: stars stripes and satin tights

fields.headline: Stars, stripes and satin tights
fields.standfirst: After the cinema success of Charlie's Angels, the heat is on to cast a new Wonder Woman. But this crime-busting pin-up has a rather less wholesome past, reports Stephanie Theobald
fields.trailText: After the cinema success of Charlie's Angels, the heat is on to cast a new Wonder Woman. But this crime-busting pin-up has a rather less wholesome past, reports Stephanie Theobald
fields.body:
I always preferred Wonder Woman in her Diana Prince army secretary disguise. A sparkling pair of green cat's eyes peering out starchily from behind librarian's glasses - how sexy was that? The only frisson to be had from Wonder Woman herself was the tiny scar on Lynda Carter's upper lip (which showed up better in red lipstick) and the moment when she had to sneak off behind a rock and transform herself into the superheroine. The moment happened in a clap of thunder and a frantic whizz round and was so obviously a metaphor for masturbation, even though her final look - the red boob tube, the stars and stripes hot pants - was not a patch on the lingerie section of the Freeman's catalogue.

Les Daniels' Wonder Woman, The Complete History - brought out to celebrate Wonder Woman's 60th birthday - adds an interesting dimension to the story. If you were looking for masturbatory fantasies, then Wonder Woman of the early 1940s was where it was at.

Despite the fact that Wonder Woman of the time had thighs like a rugby player, the comic was accused of inciting men to immorality. In virtually every issue there was a page devoted to Wonder Woman wearing bondage - her little red boots chained to her bullet-proof bracelets in some dungeon, Wonder Woman tying up a new breed of baddie Amazon with her magic girdle, that sort of thing.

The creator of the comic strip, a psychologist called William Moulton Marston, replied to his critics that he was not obsessed with sadomasochism at all. He insisted that "women are exciting for this one reason - it is the secret of women's allure - women enjoy submission, being bound". Dr Marston was a bit of a queer fish. He became a minor celebrity when he invented the lie detector, which he later claimed also worked as a love detector. His machine - with all its black bands and leather straps and electronic pulses - looks more like something you would find in a dominatrix dungeon. In 1941, when the first issue of Wonder Woman hit the comic stores, he claimed that he had created her as part of the war effort as "psychological propaganda for the new type of woman who should rule the world". He wrote that, as political and economic equality became a reality, "women would use sexual enslavement to achieve domination over men".

Yet Moulton hid his fantasies well. Wonder Woman wasn't just some leather SM "top" seeking to make "bottoms" of all of mankind. She was full-on ancient Greek mythology: the daughter of the queen of the Amazons, Hippolyta, who was given life and great powers by the Olympian gods. Living on Paradise Island, where no men were allowed, she came to America to help fight the second world war as Diana Prince.

Then, in 1943, a US army sergeant wrote a fan letter to Marston saying that he enjoyed Wonder Woman because, "I am one of those odd, perhaps unfortunate, men who derive an extreme erotic pleasure from the mere thought of a beautiful girl chained or bound." The letter was sent immediately to the head of All-American Comics, who ordered Marston to "cut down the use of chains by at least 50% to 75%". He enclosed a list of methods which could be used to keep women confined without the use of chains.

Yet the persona of Wonder Woman continued to be radical for her time. Unlike wimpy Batgirl and Supergirl, she had powers that almost rivalled those of Superman. Bullets bounced off her wristbands, she could stun people with her tiara, throw her golden girdle around villains to make them tell the truth and had the ability - although only in the TV series - to mimic the exact sound of another's voice.

In the late 60s, a scriptwriter called Dennis O'Neil decided to strip her of her mortal powers and make her a regular, promiscuous Mary Quant chick around town, "in keeping with the feminist agenda of the day". The cover of the first "liberated" Wonder Woman comic shows Diana Prince out of her army duds, parading around in a mini dress against a backdrop of purple psychedelic swirls and a sinister-looking gay hairdresser in love beads doing her hair. But whereas in the UK Diana Rigg in her kinky outfits was going great guns, the American audience disliked the swinging 60s Wonder Woman. She was turned back into the all-American pin-up.

And then came Lynda Carter. The first TV series, shown on ABC in 1975, was set in the 40s during a glamorised version of the second world war. Carter, now 49, describes it as "more campy" than the second CBS series, which was set in the modern day.

"I really hadn't played camp before and they sort of wanted me to," she tells Daniels. "Superman camped it up pretty big and I never really did. I tried to play her like a regular woman who just happened to have superhuman powers."

In fact, Carter did camp very well. Even the story of how she got the role has something camp to it. Before Wonder Woman, Carter was simply a 5ft 9in former Miss World USA. She took the role because she couldn't pay her rent.

One of the campest moments is the episode where she leaps into a runaway car rolling down a hill. With her characteristic look of earnest spunkiness, she puts her red boot down to try and stop it - which she finally does, wearing the heel to convenient flat by the time she gets to the bottom.

Carter says she has no regrets. She recognises that WW was "strictly an adolescent fantasy" as opposed to a feminist icon. Still, she recently escaped a speeding ticket when the cop recognised her.

But life after WW has proved hard. Lynda says on one of her internet fan-sites that she would like to act with John Travolta, Mel Gibson, Emma Thompson, Kristin Scott Thomas and Sean Connery. Alas, aside from a couple of undistinguished TV series in the US, Wonder Woman remains the pinnacle of her career. She now lives in Washington with her lawyer husband Robert Altman and her two children, aged 11 and 12. There, she has become Funder Woman, her chosen causes being the Democratic party and breast cancer. She is also spokeswoman for an American contact lens conglomerate and has produced her own video, Lynda Carter: Secrets To Perfect Make-up.

Naturally, in the light of the Charlie's Angels movie, there is talk of making a Wonder Woman film. Names being thrown around include Sandra Bullock, Mariah Carey, Catherine Zeta Jones, Madonna and Kristen Johnston. The time certainly seems right. Sixty she may be, but looking at the lyrics to the TV theme tune, the whole concept remains uncannily Spice Girlish:
"Wonder Woman! Wonder Woman!
All the world is waiting for you
And the power you possess,
In your satin tights,
Fighting for your rights
And the old red, white and blue. . ."

Alas, aside from a couple of undistinguished TV series in the US, Wonder Woman remains the pinnacle of her career. She now lives in Washington with her lawyer husband Robert Altman and her two children, aged 11 and 12. There, she has become Funder Woman, her chosen causes being the Democratic party and breast cancer. She is also spokeswoman for an American contact lens conglomerate and has produced her own video, Lynda Carter: Secrets To Perfect Make-up. Naturally, in the light of the Charlie's Angels movie, there is talk of making a Wonder Woman film. Names being thrown around include Sandra Bullock, Mariah Carey, Catherine Zeta Jones, Madonna and Kristen Johnston. The time certainly seems right. Sixty she may be, but looking at the lyrics to the TV theme tune, the whole concept remains uncannily Spice Girlish: "Wonder Woman! Wonder Woman! All the world is waiting for you And the power you possess, In your satin tights, Fighting for your rights And the old red, white and blue. . ."

webTitle: Culture shock for islanders as Canvey caught in the headlights

fields.headline: Culture shock for islanders as Canvey caught in the headlights
fields.standfirst: Adam Sills  visits the team of the moment and finds them struggling to handle the fuss
fields.trailText: Adam Sills visits the team of the moment and finds them struggling to handle the fuss.
fields.body:
Facing a mirror in the Canvey Island dressing room, Steve Tilson puts a final hair in place and prepares to face the television cameras again. Canvey play Southend in the second round of the FA Cup tomorrow and the midfielder, who formerly played for the opposition and is now their youth development officer, is in demand.

He is not alone. Canvey, situated at the mouth of the Thames in Essex only five miles from Southend, have been engulfed by publicity since their extra-time win at Port Vale set up the tie with their neighbours, and on Tuesday, before the club's FA Trophy game against Harlow Town, the strain was beginning to show.

In the boardroom, a chat with Canvey's secretary Frances Roche was curtailed so that she could respond to yet another media inquiry; in the three-seat press box the reporter from the Echo wondered how he would fill a 12-page supplement; outside, those queueing for Cup tickets looked bemused as cameras followed their every move. Meanwhile, as his players got changed for the match, Canvey's manager Jeff King told them not to let their minds wander to Southend.

"To be honest, I've had enough of all the attention," King admits later, having seen his side complete a 2-0 win. "I'm not used to it and I've probably had more than anyone. It's tired me out and I'll be pleased to get the game going. It's been bloody hard and it's become a much bigger occasion than I thought it would be. Having said that, I am very excited about it."

He is not alone. "It's a great game for the whole of Essex," says Tilson. "It's brilliant there's so much interest, although it has been tiring. I got home from Port Vale at 4.30 in the morning and was in work by nine. I didn't get anything done because the phone didn't stop ringing and I was shattered."

This is the first time the tiny club have reached the Cup's second round, although they missed out in 1995 only after losing a replay at Brighton.

Since 1994, when they were languishing in the Essex Senior League, King has guided them up four steps of the football pyramid to the Ryman Premier League. They are riding high again this season, and if they finish top they will be playing in the Conference next year. But they have never been under such an intense spotlight.

"To think that seven or eight years ago we were watched by one man and his dog on a ploughed field," says Canvey's coach Glenn Pennyfather, who like Tilson played more than 230 games for Southend. "It's been a meteoric rise."

This has been reflected off the field too. The dressing rooms and boardroom at Canvey's Park Lane ground were rebuilt in the summer, and the £50,000 the club expect to make from the tie will ensure everything else is eventually up to Conference standards.

Canvey even have a full-time employee now, their commercial manager Keith Johnson, who took up his post in May. "I'm trying to make the club more professional off the field," he says. "We have a new programme, match and kit sponsors and the Gulls Phone Line. We will build a new clubhouse next year and will increase the profile of the club shop."

That should not be difficult: the shop is currently a tiny hut lit by yellow and blue bulbs, Canvey's colours. Recently, though, business for Jan Edwards, who has run the shop for 10 years, has been brisk. Sales of replica shirts, calendars and hats have exploded and videos of the first game against Port Vale, in which Canvey recovered from 4-2 down in the 89th minute to draw 4-4, sold out within days.

The chairman Ray Cross credits the club's rise to its "island mentality". "The secret is a brilliant manager and coach and the fact the club works together, we all work as one. We all have our little jobs to do and we get on and do them."

For Cross that includes selling tickets for tomorrow's match and dealing with a perennial problem for potential giantkillers: where to stage the tie. The debate about the decision to move the game to Southend's Roots Hall continued to rage among the 238 fans present on Tuesday and the club's oldest supporter, 92-year-old Mark Hogg, was not alone in condemning the switch.

"We were drawn at home and we should play at home," Canvey's former outside-right and groundsman says. "It doesn't matter how big a gate we have, but it's now all about money. It's spoilt it."

King agrees but says: "Having seen the size of the occasion I'm not sure even Southend's ground can hold it." A sell-out is guaranteed and for Penny-father, Tilson and the six other ex-Southend players on Canvey's books, tomorrow cannot come quickly enough.

Sadly, as in all FA Cup fairytales, there is a fall guy. Mick Bodley, a former Southend captain, misses the tie through suspension after being sent off two weeks ago. Canvey cheekily inquired about moving the tie to last night so the defender would still have been eligible. A carol concert at Roots Hall ruled that option out.

Yet the Islanders remain confident. "Never discount us," says Roche. "We won't be overawed, so 3-1 to us," predicts Edwards. "It'll be very tight," says Tilson, "but I'll go for 2-1 to us, then in the third round I'll be happy with Man United away."

The man from the Echo dare not contemplate that. He, though, like the rest of the club, now believes that anything is possible.

webTitle: Why Wembley still may not be the answer

fields.headline: Why Wembley still may not be the answer
fields.trailText: By now it should be clear that the new Wembley is proceeding roughly along the lines of the Bernard Cribbins ditty Hole in the Ground.
fields.body:
By now it should be clear that the new Wembley is proceeding roughly along the lines of the Bernard Cribbins ditty Hole in the Ground.

"Don't build it there, build it elsewhere,

"You're building it round when it ought to be square . . ."

In other words, 13 months after Lord Foster's grand design for a modern 90,000-seat stadium was unveiled, the scheme has been so bedevilled by controversy, confusion and financial misgivings that the Football Association has found it necessary to conduct an urgent reappraisal of an enterprise whose immediate raison d' tre has not been helped by the failure to secure the 2006 World Cup.

In November 1999 it was reckoned that building another Wembley and including in the development an hotel, offices and banqueting and conference facilities would cost £475m. But in a short space of time the estimate has soared to £660m, and even the revised completion date of 2004 now looks highly optimistic.

When parking space for the demolition team becomes a matter for the high court, it seems reasonable to assume that not all is going to plan. No wonder the FA is having second thoughts about creating a modern Xanadu in an otherwise unremarkable London suburb, so that the sponsors of the LDV Vans Trophy can watch and dine in a manner to which they are doubtless accustomed.

It goes without saying that the pivotal role of chairman of Wembley National Stadium Limited, the subsidiary company the FA created to supervise the project, needed to be filled by someone with not only business acumen but exceptional tact and diplomacy, given the number of other bodies involved. So the job went to Ken Bates, the Chelsea chairman.

Given his transformation of Stamford Bridge from a part-modernised dust bowl to a nearly-completed top-quality Premier League stadium with restaurants and hotels attached, Bates was to some extent a logical choice.

Yet the bullish qualities which saved Chelsea from developers may not have been wholly what was required here. Even at the time it seemed a bit like putting General Patton, rather than Eisenhower, in charge of Operation Overlord.

Bates remains at the helm, albeit steering a tighter course, after yesterday's meeting of the FA board, but the nub of the argument about the new Wembley is not about him or whether his vision of a national stadium is merely Chelsea Village writ large.

It surely concerns more fundamental issues: the wisdom of siting the stadium at Wembley and, more broadly, the desirability of having a national football stadium at all.

The original stadium might have been knocked down after the 1925 British Empire Exhibition closed, had not Arthur Elvin turned it into a luxury venue for greyhound racing. There was even a dance floor to ensure that not only the growlers could indulge in a bit of slow, slow, quick, quick, slow.

"A vast white elephant, a rotting sepulchre of hopes and the grave of fortunes" was how one newspaper described the Wembley scene of 75 years ago.

Certainly the Empire Stadium did not seem much of a business proposition given that it would host only one football match, the FA Cup final, annually and another, the England-Scotland game, every two years.

Rather more matches are played at Wembley now but as Bob Stubbs, the chief executive of WNSL, said recently: "You can't charge a lot of money [for seats in the new stadium] without having the restaurants and bars and other top-class facilities that those customers would expect."

Fair enough, but attempting to squeeze these wonders into a location trapped by Greater London clutter always did seem illogical. Whatever shape it eventually takes, the new Wembley, with its limited parking facilities, will rely more than ever on rail and tube services which are already less reliable than they were when the old Wembley was built, while those who do drive there will still have to negotiate the idiosyncrasies of 1930s road planning.

When the French planned a new stadium in Paris for the 1998 World Cup they did not rebuild Parc des Princes, which is trapped by traffic at St Cloud, but sited Stade de France at St Denis, which can be reached in 15 minutes from the city centre by road or rail.

The sheer size of London argues against a similar idea here, which may be why those who planned the National Exhibition Centre, with its hotels, conference halls and vast car parks, built it outside Birmingham rather than inside Brent.

The FA needs a national stadium for income but with Old Trafford now seating nearly 68,000, Arsenal planning a new ground of comparable size, Newcastle United housing more than 50,000 and Sunderland just under, the idea of a football venue used just for internationals and cup finals is open to question.

That said, a new Wembley football stadium, minus the accoutrements, might be the answer at a more acceptable cost. After all, a cut-price refurbishment of the existing stadium of dog-ends would have been unthinkable. The surviving twin towers would then have become as much a monument to flawed thinking as the stump of rusting iron - a failed Edwardian attempt to recreate the Eiffel Tower - which preceded them.

webTitle: Venables talks up his players' mood

fields.headline: Venables talks up his players' mood
fields.trailText: Terry Venables trotted out yesterday for his first training session as Middlesbrough's head coach.
fields.body:
Terry Venables trotted out yesterday for his first training session as Middlesbrough's head coach and met a typical north-east welcome of driving rain, freezing wind and a black sky.

Not as cosy as a warm TV studio. And he soon had the players back inside the club's lavishly equipped, £7m complex at Hurworth, near Darlington, to prepare for today's derby meeting with Sunderland at the Stadium of Light.

With less than 30 hours before kick-off, Venables believed talking was more important than physical work and he arrived with something to say to players who have managed only one point from their last 24. With the manager Bryan Robson lookingrelaxed beside him, he later said he already pinpointed weaknesses. "I've been watching a lot of videos in the last 10 days. I purposely looked at the games with the worst results and I could see where players need to be helped," he said.

"There are four or five things particularly that have to be sorted. That's where you start. Then you try to maximise the things they do well and hope you solve the problems.

"I've seen strengths and weaknesses. But the players lack confidence and I can't paint a different picture, that's the way we are at the moment."

The former England coach was at the complex early for talks with Robson after a "terrible" journey from Austria - Manchester United's game against Sturm Graz - to Teesside. "I got here last night and Bryan and I met really early today. Bryan has set the team up and reaction from the players has been good, but it's only one morning, my first.

"We discussed a few things and they are concerned about the situation, as you would expect, but there's a good attitude. I want to try to make everyone feel better. You have to go into things thinking you can achieve them. You have to be positive. I'm optimistic and think the players will be fine."

Venables will watch the first half today from a seat in the stand, then move pitch-side. "I like to look at the first half from on high because half-time is very important for coaches. So I want to see exactly what I can get most from at half-time. And then I'll be on the bench because I want more of an involvement, to make changes or whatever."

They have no fully-fit strikers and the Sunderland manager Peter Reid yesterday confessed he consequently had no idea about Middlesbrough's formation. "He's not the only one," joked Venables.

fields.headline: Pele returns Maradona volley
fields.trailText: The Fifa World Player of the Year Gala has been overshadowed by an unseemly spat between the two players commonly regarded as the best ever to grace the game.
fields.body:
The Fifa World Player of the Year Gala has been overshadowed by an unseemly spat between the two players commonly regarded as the best ever to grace the game.

Pele and Diego Maradona have become locked in a war of words as they vie for the best player of the century accolade, which is being presented at the ceremony in Rome on Monday night.

The Brazilian responded to criticism from Maradona by asserting that not only was the 1986 World Cup winner not the best player ever but that he was ranked behind a handful of Brazilian and Argentine greats.

"Socrates, Rivelino, Romario, Tostao . . ." he ticked off. "I think that if Maradona wants to speak with Pele, he has to speak to them first."

"After speaking with them, Maradona should ask permission of [Alfredo] Di Stefano or [Jose Manuel] Moreno," he added, referring to two former Argentine greats.

Maradona, responding to reports in the Spanish press that he had won the internet poll to decide the award winner, said he considered Pele to be over-rated.

"They say he has played in World Cups but nobody explains that he did not play in 1962 [Pele missed the final through injury] and in England he played a game and a half," he said.

"They are judging me for the 12 years I played in Europe, something Pele did not do. Let's be serious: don't compare me with him any more."

Zinedine Zidane, meanwhile, looks like picking up the world player of the year award on Monday for the second time in three years, with Rivaldo and Luis Figo also shortlisted.

Nacional won the first leg of the Uruguay championship final 1-0 against their bitter rivals, who had 10 players suspended following the league game on November 26.

fields.headline: Francis misses vital statistic
fields.trailText: Trevor Francis will become the most successful manager in Birmingham City's history if his promotion-chasers defeat Wimbledon at home today.
fields.body:
Trevor Francis will become the most successful manager in Birmingham City's history if his promotion-chasers defeat Wimbledon at home today.

His elevation to the top of the managerial pile is based on the number of wins his teams have recorded since he took over in 1996. Another win will take his tally to 94, one more than the late Bob Brocklebank achieved in 1949-54.

For once Francis has been taken by surprise, even though he is a man who pays a lot of attention to statistics. He knows, for example, that his team have played 41 games and earned 82 points since the turn of the year. "That's an average of two points a game, which is usually enough to clinch automatic promotion," he said.

"I spend a lot of time studying statistics because I find them useful. But the fact that I was in sight of this particular record escaped me. I knew that if we qualified for the play-offs again this season I would probably reach a century of wins, but that was about it."

Perhaps even more surprising, given the high turnover of managers in the First Division and a run-in or two with the club's directors, is the fact that Francis is still there to challenge the record.

"When I arrived I said expectations were too high and it was unrealistic to think about promotion," he said. "The playing side of the club needed a thorough overhaul and I've largely been allowed to do that. There have been some differences between me and the board but the majority of reports of problems have been inaccurate. Now, after Dario Gradi, I'm the First Division's longest-serving manager."

Survival has resulted in Francis, the club's most celebrated player, making his mark as a manager and heading a list of predecessors that includes Sir Alf Ramsey, Stan Cullis and Ron Saunders.

But it is not enough. "It remains my burning ambition to get this club into the Premiership," he said. "That's something Bob Brocklebank did not achieve."

"That's an average of two points a game, which is usually enough to clinch automatic promotion," he said. "I spend a lot of time studying statistics because I find them useful. But the fact that I was in sight of this particular record escaped me. I knew that if we qualified for the play-offs again this season I would probably reach a century of wins, but that was about it." Perhaps even more surprising, given the high turnover of managers in the First Division and a run-in or two with the club's directors, is the fact that Francis is still there to challenge the record. "When I arrived I said expectations were too high and it was unrealistic to think about promotion," he said. "The playing side of the club needed a thorough overhaul and I've largely been allowed to do that. There have been some differences between me and the board but the majority of reports of problems have been inaccurate. Now, after Dario Gradi, I'm the First Division's longest-serving manager." Survival has resulted in Francis, the club's most celebrated player, making his mark as a manager and heading a list of predecessors that includes Sir Alf Ramsey, Stan Cullis and Ron Saunders. But it is not enough. "It remains my burning ambition to get this club into the Premiership," he said. "That's something Bob Brocklebank did not achieve."

fields.headline: Ferguson reveals his ideal role
fields.trailText: The prospects of Sir Alex Ferguson staying on at Manchester United after retiring as manager hardened yesterday.
fields.body:
The prospects of Sir Alex Ferguson staying on at Manchester United after retiring as manager hardened yesterday when he echoed the chief's executive Peter Kenyon's message that the Scot will not be lost to Old Trafford after his hugely successful reign.

It appears that only Fergusons's precise role and title in an "upstairs" post has yet to be decided when he stands down as manager at the end of next season after 16 years in charge.

Ferguson, 58, has already been offered a position as head of United's renowned youth development but he was offering few clues to his future job other than ruling out involvement on the senior footballing side. An ambassadorial role, travelling the world in promotion of the United brand name is another possibility.

"It will certainly not be team manager, but hopefully something will be worked out between the club and myself," he said. "I think I've picked the right moment to retire, but equally so I would love to stay on in any capacity which does not interfere with the football."

Kenyon has been discussing the manager's future for weeks and on Thursday revealed he "could guarantee" Ferguson "will carry on in some capacity."

Newcastle hope to usher in the new year by reuniting Internazionale's Brazilian striker Ronaldo with his former manager Bobby Robson.

Ronaldo, who played under Robson at PSV Eindhoven and was later signed by him at Barcelona, is recovering from knee ligament damage but would apparently welcome the chance to regain match fitness during a loan at St James' Park.

"There is no point at the moment because he is still injured," said Newcastle's manager yesterday. "But I know he would love to come here and play for me to try and recover his fitness." Robson has been scouring Europe for a short-term replacement for Alan Shearer, out with tendinitis.

Moves for Blackburn's Egil Ostenstad and Ronaldo's £13m Inter team-mate Robbie Keane were rejected, prompting him to turn to the Brazilian.

Coventry, who, sold Keane in August, were also knocked back in their attempt to bring the forward back and Gordon Strachan had a discouraging message for other suitors including Leeds.

"We heard he might be going out on loan," said Strachan. "But we were told there was no chance of him going anywhere except to an Italian club."

Harry Redknapp insists Aston Villa must reduce their asking price for Gareth Southgate from £10m and added he "could be interested at £5m-£6m" if the England defender is to move to West Ham. Southgate himself questioned Villa's valuation, saying that at £10m, "I am not realistically expecting clubs to queue up."

Neil Lennon completed his £5.7m move from Leicester to Celtic yesterday with a tribute to Martin O'Neill, who reciprocated by putting the midfielder in the squad for the Dundee match today.

Liverpool concluded the £5.5m deal for the Croatian Igor Biscan even though Gérard Houllier said there was a risk. Houllier is not sure the midfielder from Dinamo Zagreb will hold down a first-team place in the near future.

fields.headline: Collymore's cue from Chinaglia
fields.trailText: Jim reads Stan a book about the man scored the goal that secured Lazio's first title.
fields.body:
It has been a golden autumn for football books. First comes Tony Cascarino's autobiography, riddled with self-doubt and fears of growing old, an antidote to the parade of false modesty that is the standard footballer's story.

Ever since the book's revelation, incidentally, that Cascarino dyed his hair close to contract negotiation time in order to maintain the illusion of youth, it has been impossible to look at older players without the gaze straying to their hairline. This week I spoke to John Collins of Fulham, who must have wondered why I refused to maintain eye contact, so busy was I seeking out evidence to suggest the deep blue blackness of his barnet was the result of doing a Cascarino.

This week sees the publication of the Giorgio Chinaglia story: Arrividerci Swansea (Mainstream, £9.99). It is an odd title, you might think, for a book about the man who was once the highest-paid player in the world, scored the goal that secured Lazio's first title in 1974 and wound up owning the Roman club - except, it transpires, that in 1966 he was given a free transfer by Swansea Town, as City were then known.

His dad had emigrated to Wales from Tuscany when Giorgio was nine and later the lad was taken on by Swansea when they were in the depths of the Third Division (it is good to know that in the world of football some things do not change).

The book, written, without Chinaglia's authority, by the Welsh journalist Mario Risoli, contains an exhaustive analysis of what went wrong in Swansea. Inverting the usual stereotype of shirking Britons and obsessive Italians, the main problem seemed to be an attitude to training and preparation that was wayward to say the least.

Gambling, womanising, turning up for matches 10 minutes before kick-off after spending the previous night on the Swansea tiles was just the start of it. But, somehow, the moment he flew back to Italy, everything went right, the goals, international caps and zillions of lire poured in.

Here lies the answer to the Stan Collymore puzzle. If he wants ever to fulfil his potential, Stan should take off that invisible man headgear he was wearing this week after an altercation in a night-club, get a few numbers off Benito Carbone and head off to Italy - pronto. Then he could write his autobiography entitled Arrividerci Stafford, Palace, Southend, Forest, Liverpool, Villa, Leicester, Bradford and counting.

fields.headline: Ball stokes the fires
fields.standfirst: Jim White on a long-overdue windfall :  Ball stokes the boilers of 1966 gravy train
fields.trailText: A long-overdue windfall as Ball stokes the boilers of the 1966 gravy train
fields.body:
N ever a day goes by, Alan Ball is fond of saying, without somebody, somewhere, reminding him about winning the World Cup in 1966. And, if anyone ever forgets, Ball is not slow to remind them to remind him. This week, at the home of corporate entertaining, Lord's cricket ground, Ball launched another aide- mémoire to those who might have put that July day nearly 35 years ago to the back of their mind. At an annual fee of £1,966, the 1966 World Cup winners sporting club will allow up to 1,966 members to rub shoulders - at sporting events, at dinners, at race meetings - with the great men who captured the Jules Rimet trophy all that time ago, or at least those who are still around.

"As a nation I don't think we salute our heroes sufficiently," says Jimmy Tarbuck, the club's first honorary member, who was guest speaker at the launch of Ball's brainchild. "Bobby Moore was scandalously ignored during his lifetime. I remember I once asked an FA high-up why Moore wasn't used as an ambassador for the English game. And you know what he said? 'Oh, we can't take him anywhere, everyone would want to talk to him.'"

Indeed it is a strange oddity about 1966 that it has taken so long for the players to be in a position to exploit their celebrity. Moore - whose image, being carried aloft on his team-mates' shoulders, is used as the club's logo - died long before being a World Cup winner was a passport to financial security. In the years before he died in 1993 the greatest captain in the English game was scrabbling round for a living as a match analyst on local radio and as sports editor of the Sunday Sport. Now being a World Cup winner is a career in itself.

"It is quite amazing how it has taken off, I'd say in the last five years," says Ray Wilson, the team's left-back. "In the early days I'd never get that much attention. Now I get invites from all over to do this and that. I've retired now but this could be a full-time job. I really enjoy it. You could say I revel in it."

And Wilson, who spent his footballing afterlife as an undertaker, is probably the least in demand of the winning team. "I've always tended to keep a low profile," he says, standing in a corner of the room as Ball conducts several television interviews at once. "The after- dinners are not my scene, frankly I'm not very good at that. But big Jack [Charlton], he's the king is big Jack. The reason he couldn't be here today is that he's probably at a function that was booked a year, 18 months back."

Now the 10 surviving members of the team, together with the 11 other squad members, have taken advantage of the huge boom in sports-based business entertaining to sell themselves as a brand. There is, they believe, a huge demand to watch football, cricket and racing while paying for the company of the boys of '66, though presumably there will be more of a premium on attending the first day of the Ashes Test at Lord's with Jack Charlton than, say, watching Derby against Coventry after lunch with John Connelly.

W hat these former players are doing is taking advantage of their growing celebrity to earn the kind of money few of them enjoyed at the time, and quite right too. Margaret Thatcher charges £500 for a photograph with an adoring fan, and there are many who would suggest that these guys did more for the nation than she ever did. And the great good fortune for the class of '66 is that their victory has not been matched; the ever-lengthening gap makes their achievement all the more marketable.

"Obviously if our boys had won it since it would be different," says Wilson "but we're the ones still here, we're the ones who did it and, to be honest, it doesn't look like anyone else English is going to win it for quite some time."

What has shaken Wilson recently is not so much the financial possibilities now opening up, as the emotional resonance that still lingers around the team.

"It's been quite amazing and here's the proof of it," he says. "We all went on this cruise in the summer and what was amazing to all of us was how much it still meant to the people we met and how they had no problems in showing it. You know, I honestly think all this is to do with memories getting better as you get older."

And, luckily for him, there are ever more of us out here prepared to pay to relive them.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.standfirst: Head east for the nickname nirvana
fields.trailText: •Mention of non-league nicknames last week prompted Mark Harris to send us some of his favourites from the Dr Martens League Eastern Division (which suggests that he may have taken a slightly unhealthy interest in the whole subject). Today, for example, the Brickies will play the Nuts and Bolts as Sittingbourne meet Ashford Town in what is bound to be a workmanlike encounter. Witney Town are the Blanketmen (not an easy one to work into a catchy chant), Spalding United the Tulips and Stamford the Daniels, presumably after Daniel Lambert, who died in the town in 1809 weighing nearly 53 stone. A more fitting role model for an ambitious football club it would be hard to imagine.
fields.body:
Mention of non-league nicknames last week prompted Mark Harris to send us some of his favourites from the Dr Martens League Eastern Division (which suggests that he may have taken a slightly unhealthy interest in the whole subject). Today, for example, the Brickies will play the Nuts and Bolts as Sittingbourne meet Ashford Town in what is bound to be a workmanlike encounter. Witney Town are the Blanketmen (not an easy one to work into a catchy chant), Spalding United the Tulips and Stamford the Daniels, presumably after Daniel Lambert, who died in the town in 1809 weighing nearly 53 stone. A more fitting role model for an ambitious football club it would be hard to imagine.

And while we're on the subject, congratulations to Ryman League Third Division side Lewes (the Rooks, since you ask), who overturned Brighton 3-0 in the Sussex Senior Cup last week. Appropriately, since the town is now almost permanently under water, their ground is the Dripping Pan.

War stories, part three. The seemingly permanent presence of the second world war in the minds of our top football managers was revealed yet again this week as Terry Venables alarmingly compared the appointment of Sven-Goran Eriksson to the Allies checking out the availability of Field Marshal Erwin Rommel. Next week: Bobby Robson on Bomber Harris and the long-ball game.

"I hope the 'no smoke without fire' merchants will let an innocent man get on with his life and resume his managerial career," said Southampton's chairman Rupert Lowe this week, noting that the David Jones case had cost the Saints up to £750,000 in dual salaries and legal bills.Fine words. But why was his managerial career interrupted in the first place? Lowe said in January: "The allegations against David may also affect the club's commercial relationships."

If Ipswich find their determined progress comes to an abrupt halt around this time of year, it won't be the first time for George Burley. In an interview with the Town fanzine Those Were The Days, Burley's former defensive partner Russell Osman recalls: "I remember the day that he turned up for the Christmas party and walked through the glass doors at the Belstead Brook Hotel. And that was at the start of the function. He sort of didn't realise the doors were shut."

Crystal Palace suddenly find themselves in the position of having more money than they know what to do with. That seems to be the only explanation for the fact that Neil Ruddock's shirt for the game against Wimbledon on Tuesday night bore the legend "Razor" on the back instead of his name. He was fined £100 by the Football League for breaching regulations. Well worth it, I'm sure you'll agree.

Tomorrow's FA Cup clash between Southend and Canvey Island has predictably brought out all the tired old cliches about Essex geezerdom. And we're certainly not going to be left out. In an interview with the Non-League Paper this week, Alec Stock reminisced about Southend's manager Dave Webb. "When I was at Bournemouth I bought him from Leicester and he was wheeling and dealing even then," Stock recalls. "One of the first things he said to me was: 'You don't know anybody who wants to buy a crane, do you?'"

A national newspaper reports that Sven-Goran Eriksson "is in for a terrible shock when he finally arrives at Lancaster Gate". He certainly is: the FA has moved to Soho Square.

webTitle: Richardson keeps the lifeboats on board

fields.headline: Richardson keeps the lifeboats on board
fields.standfirst: Roy Collins finds the Coventry chairman determined not to ditch his manager despite six defeats in seven games
fields.trailText: After nine years behind the tiller of the good ship Coventry City the chairman Bryan Richardson believes he has become an expert at differentiating between the odd patch of choppy water and the signs of an impending iceberg.
fields.body:
After nine years behind the tiller of the good ship Coventry City the chairman Bryan Richardson believes he has become an expert at differentiating between the odd patch of choppy water and the signs of an impending iceberg.

Despite six defeats in seven Premiership games he insists this is not an occasion to man the lifeboats. And, with the certainty of a nautical man, he predicts calmer waters ahead, given the conditions crucial to both mariners and footballers, a bit of good fortune and a sail full of wind.

Richardson, who in times like these, sees his job as steadying the ship, says: "The mood is surprisingly good. You would expect me to say that but, having been round this little block a few times before, you get to recognise the signs when it is serious. The atmosphere is not quite right and people can't quite look you in the eye. There's none of that at the moment."

At most other clubs there would probably be a cry of man overboard or, more precisely, manager overboard. Chelsea cast Gianluca Vialli adrift after five games this season because they feared they would again miss out on a Champions League place. Bradford's chairman Geoffrey Richmond fired Chris Hutchings after 12.

The Coventry manager Gordon Strachan's job, though, is as secure as Lord Falconer's, Richardson not even feeling tempted to bring in El Saviour to help him with coaching duties. Richardson laughs at the thought of how a volatile man like Strachan might respond to being told he was to share his office, even if it were someone with the powers of El Tel.

"I don't think he would like it," says Richardson in a massive understatement. "I don't want to talk about other clubs but the Middlesbrough situation does seem amazing to me and I don't know how Bryan Robson can get his head round it. It seems that the Middlesbrough board have lost faith but we haven't."

Nor, it would seem, have more than a handful of fans called for Strachan's head. "The majority of fans are saying, 'Hold on, Gordon was the greatest thing since sliced bread this time last year and Sky TV nicknamed us The Entertainers because of the bucket load of goals we scored at home.' So we've all got to show some common sense."

It is not a quality for which football clubs and trigger-happy chairmen are renowned, though Richardson points out that even Doug Ellis at Aston Villa managed to keep the safety catch on when John Gregory went nine games without a Premiership win last season.

One of those games was a 2-1 defeat at Coventry, after which a fan pushed a pad and pencil into Gregory's face for an autograph. According to Richardson, as the fan walked away with the signature, but minus his pen, Gregory called after him. The fan replied: "Keep the pen 'cos you'll need it for signing on."

Sunderland have also bene fited, he says, from refusing to sack Peter Reid after relegation from the Premiership in 1997. But it is increasingly difficult for chairmen to hold their nerve when Premiership status is worth millions in TV revenue and when Coventry, like many other clubs, are pouring millions more into redevelopment.

Richardson says: "We have committed ourselves to maintaining our status by spending £170m on our new stadium, which will have a retractable roof, a retail park, a leisure park and state-of-the-art facilities. It would be a shame to play Nationwide football in that."

The 40,000 all-seater stadium, due to be completed in May 2003, is, he says, funded independently, so it is not a case of selling a player to buy bricks. But Coventry have also invested so heavily in players that the footballing balance is £30.6m in the red.

"We've spent an awful lot on players", he says, "and, though you can go on mortgaging against the future by using next year's TV money, you've got to pay it back in the end. It is difficult enough to run things on 20,000 attendances."

Richardson, who works full time at Highfield Road, has as accurate a grasp on the club's human assets as their financial ones. Of 50 professionals at the club, he says, only three are over 30 and 39 of them are 23 or under.

But he still believes the club's greatest human asset is Strachan. "He's a football man through and through. After he has coached the first team he goes off in the afternoon to train the kids and he's even out on Sunday mornings with the Under-10s and Under-9s. With the greatest of respect, I don't think you'd find George Graham or Sir Alex Ferguson doing that."

fields.bodyText: After nine years behind the tiller of the good ship Coventry City the chairman Bryan Richardson believes he has become an expert at differentiating between the odd patch of choppy water and the signs of an impending iceberg. Despite six defeats in seven Premiership games he insists this is not an occasion to man the lifeboats. The atmosphere is not quite right and people can't quite look you in the eye. There's none of that at the moment." It seems that the Middlesbrough board have lost faith but we haven't." Nor, it would seem, have more than a handful of fans called for Strachan's head. fields.headline: Football transfers given extra time
fields.standfirst:
EU looks for a compromise to save small clubs
Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: A world away from qualified majority voting, EU leaders yesterday granted a stay of execution to professional football's transfer system, backing Brussels' efforts to work out a compromise with the sport's authorities. But they warned that any agreement must comply with community law.
fields.body:
A world away from qualified majority voting, EU leaders yesterday granted a stay of execution to professional football's transfer system, backing Brussels' efforts to work out a compromise with the sport's authorities. But they warned that any agreement must comply with community law.

The British delegation, which has campaigned against radical changes to a system that, says the European commission, flagrantly contravenes EU laws on fair competition and the free movement of labour, said it was satisfied with the declaration in Nice "on the specific characteristics of sport".

"This is probably the first summit we've attended where Rio Ferdinand had been raised in the margins," said a Downing Street spokesman. "I mean West Ham have put a fair amount of investment into Rio Ferdinand you know, and they have got £18m out of it. Good for them."

Tony Blair and the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, intervened jointly in the long-simmering dispute earlier this year, arguing that the abolition of transfer fees would endanger smaller clubs because their best players could be poached without any compensation.

Leading football figures fear that the game will be plunged into chaos if Mario Monti, the European Commission's competition commissioner, outlaws existing rules, prompting a free-for-all as players move between clubs at will.

A British government adviser said the football authorities are trying to reach a compromise. "Our position remains that, while of course we acknowledge the competition rules of the union, transfer fees play an important part in the viability of clubs, particularly small clubs. The commission, we believe, knows that and recognises that and wants to preserve it."

The Nice declaration will take some of the heat off Fifa, football's international governing body, which is under pressure from the commission to come up with satisfactory new rules before the present regulations are outlawed.

The commission said earlier this week that it was hopeful of finding a satisfactory solution. It recognised that the stability of contracts was important, it said, but underlined that Fifa rules "must respect the overriding EU principle" that workers should have freedom of movement.

British delegation officials said yesterday that they were "absolutely happy" with the Nice declaration, which was "fully in line" with the joint Anglo-German statement. Mr Blair and Mr Schröder said last month that while the current system was not perfect, "a radical reform could have a negative impact on the structures of football in Europe".

"Clubs must be able to rely on a system that gives them sufficient opportunity to train young players, build up their teams and keep the game healthy at all levels," the leaders said, adding that they hoped the commission would be sympathetic to the special needs of professional football.

fields.headline: Fortress Britain
fields.standfirst: Madonna's pre-marriage visit to a Scottish castle this week has put the spotlight on high living.  Paul Gogarty checks out places where those not born to it can also live like a lord, or a rock star
fields.trailText: Madonna's pre-marriage visit to a Scottish castle this week has put the spotlight on high living. Paul Gogarty checks out places where those not born to it can also live like a lord, or a rock star.
fields.body:
My wife's idea of a weekend escape was certainly seductive. A castle would be somewhere we could literally pull up the drawbridge on children and work. However, an earlier experience had made me wary of barbarian hoteliers whose castle conversions more closely resemble nasty pubs than sumptuous fortresses.

Rather than a Victorian folly with crenellated knobs on, we wanted a real castle with roaring fires, a bedroom with a proper-sized bed, heavenly food and power showers. My wife's research turned up several around the country. We plumped for Amberley Castle, not far from Arundel in West Sussex.

On arrival, we felt a huge sense of relief. Amberley indisputably is a real Norman castle with 60ft walls built of sandstone blocks shipped from Caen, sturdy towers waving the flag of St George and a dungeon where miscreants or non-paying guests could be cast. It may not have a drawbridge, but it does have a portcullis that drops down when the last of the staff leave at night.

We drove across the dry moat and beneath the black teeth of the portcullis into a grassed inner courtyard. Inside the battlements, the 900-year-old manor house wall was a mosaic of suspended flower baskets. The lawns were graced by yew and cypress topiary and flanked by pretty flower beds, and the adjacent ruins would provide a perfect setting for meditations on the art of ageing gracefully.

Our room was in the south tower, which had been added in 1377 along with the ramparts as fortification against French pirates and marauding peasants. All the hotel's rooms, we discovered, were named after Sussex castles and ours, Pevensey, had a leaded window deeply recessed into the sandstone wall and overlooking the moat. A rear door in the bathroom opened on to a stone spiral staircase that led up on to the ramparts.

We crept upstairs to the lichen-stained battlements. In the 14th century, a village girl named Emily had thrown herself and her baby to their deaths from this wall, spurned by the bishop who had fathered her son (the bodies were found buried in the adjacent vicarage by a BT cable layer).

A castle needs a ghost, particularly if it's to attract the Americans, and Amberley, with a consummate feel for marketing, would appear to have several. One night when the former hotel house manager stayed in the Charles II Room (Charles once overnighted here while escaping to France), she experienced a feeling of suffocation, as if someone were lying on top of her. And no, she had not simply forgotten someone was sharing the bed with her.

We took off for a pre-dinner walk across the marshland of Amberley Wildbrooks. The valley is one of the loveliest in West Sussex, the nature reserve bordered in the west by the wildly meandering River Arun. Often the valley floods during this period (and this year worse than ever) and it takes on a desolate beauty as memorable as when dressed in its softer summer mantle of wild meadow flowers.

The Queen's Room Restaurant upstairs was formerly a private chapel and has a vaulted ceiling that was built in 1165. At the far end of the room there is a mural, only recently discovered beneath layers of plaster, depicting a hunt by King Charles II and Catherine of Braganza. The room was dressed in crisp white tablecloths laden with Wedgwood plates and heavy silver cutlery.

The liver was accompanied by grilled tomatoes, aubergine, a copse of broccoli and roasted new potatoes. My wife chose the oven-roasted breast of corn-fed chicken served with a tarragon and Grand Marnier sauce. Sitting in the bay window, we looked out over the fountain and lawns, watching night thicken and floodlights gently warm the curtain walls.

After breakfast the next morning, one of the hotel's receptionists drove us up to the top of Kithurst Hill so we could make the three-mile walk along the South Downs Way back to Amberley. The chalky path cut through a rumpled quilt of wheat and rape. A glider drifted aimlessly above, and to our left a thousand crows swirled like a tornado across a wheat field.

After an hour, we dropped down off the ridge into the village of Amberley where flint walls and raised thatched cottages led us to a pub terrace overlooking the water meadows. Late on Sunday afternoon, we found ourselves at Arundel Castle, a vast pile that prompted us to fantasise about winning the Lottery and joining the clan of new barbarian hoteliers. First, we would have to serve eviction orders on the Duke of Norfolk.

On second thoughts, maybe we should just book into Amberley again.

The practicals

Double rooms at Amberley Castle (01798 831992) cost from from £145 a night. Breakfast costs from £12.50, three-course evening menu £45, Sunday lunch around £25. Two-night half-board castle breaks start from £380 for two. Arundel Castle (01903 882173) is open April 1 until the last weekend in October, Sunday-Friday. Admission costs £7.50.

Other castles that earn their keep as hotels

Ackergill Tower
near Wick, Caithness, tel: 01955 603556

A castellated manor house a caber toss from the beach. It also operates on private lets. Although it can accommodate a total of 48 in its 25 bedrooms, you only need 16 to have the complete run of the place. Basically, the staff will fit round whatever your party wants - including driving you out in the Land Rover for picnics or taking you on boat trips. They'll also arrange shooting, golf or fishing and even fix you up with kilts. At dinner, you'll get a bit of Burn's recited before tucking into fresh Scottish produce.

Price: you need 16 people able to fork out around £265 each per night (full board) excluding VAT. Sporrans, entertainment and alcohol cost extra.

Balfour Castle
Shapinsay, Orkney, tel: 01856 711282

The most "northerly castle-hotel in the world", Balfour is as remote as it gets. It boasts 10 miles of private coastline and two private islands uninhabited apart from seals, gulls, sheep, assorted duck and you. Furnished as it was 150 years ago, the Victorian castle consists of 52 rooms, eight bedrooms of which - along with the library, drawing room, conservatory and large dining room - the Zawadski family rents out as party lets.

Price: A private let requires a minimum booking of eight people paying £94 each a night for half-board; extra guests - it can sleep a maximum of 16 - pay £77.50. Alternatively, it can be booked on a self-catering basis at £550 per day.

Culzean Castle
Maybole, Perthshire tel: 01655 884455

Slip the visitors ogling the castle's crenallations by making a dash for your top-floor apartment in this Robert Adam-designed castle. Once the holiday bolt-hole of Eisenhower, it's now let out by the National Trust for Scotland with six bedrooms, drawing room and dining room.

Price: Rooms cost from £200 a couple, including breakfast (dinner £45 including house wine). Alternatively, the entire apartment can be rented from £1,400 a night.

Dundas Castle
South Queensferry,West Lothian, tel: 0131-319 2039

One of Scotland's most beautiful castles with views across the River Forth. Located just six miles from Edinburgh, it comes with 14th-century keep, vaulted Great Hall, billiard hall, library and drawing room, plus nine luxury double bedrooms, all with private bathrooms.

Price: The castle requires a minimum four-double room booking for exclusive use from £1,600 + VAT, including breakfast. Additional rooms from cost from £150 a night. Evening meals from £30 a head up.

Gwydir Castle
Llanrwst, Gwynedd LL26 OPN, tel: 01492 641687

One of the most romantic of the North Wales castles, this is a Grade I-listed early Tudor courtyard house set in 10 acres of gardens in the Conwy Valley. Originally the home of the Wynn family and Queen Elizabeth I's cousin Katherine Tudor, it is still a private home. But two antique-filled rooms are available: the King's Room and the Duke of Beaufort's chamber.

Price: £75 per night for the King's Room; £60 per night for the Duke of Beaufort's chamber. Prices are for two people per room and include breakfast.

Langley Castle
Hexham, Northumberland tel: 01434 688888

From the outside, Langley Castle looks exactly as it did in 1352. Inside, however, the eight guest rooms have modern comforts including, in some cases, Jacuzzis and saunas (there's a further 10 rooms in adjacent buildings). Situated in 10 acres of wooded grounds in the Tyne valley, close to Hadrian's Wall and historic Hexham.

Price: Double rooms from £165 a night B&B.

Lumley Castle Hotel
Chester-le-Street, Co Durham, tel: 0191-389 1111

Beautifully preserved 14th-century castle sitting above the River Wear, it is the ancestral home of the Earl of Scarborough.

Price: Rooms cost from £135 per couple in the converted stable block or £185 in the more atmospheric main building. The price includes breakfast at weekends though not in the week.

Skibo Castle
Dornoch, Sutherland, Scotland IV25 3RQ, tel: 01862 894600

Originally home to the Scottish-born American philanthropist and industrialist Andrew Carnegie, Skibo could be host to the wedding of the new millennium if Madonna and Guy Ritchie tie the knot here later this month. It is set in 7,500 acres and is home to The Carnegie Club - a private residential golf and sporting club with more than 500 members. Activities include 4x4 off-road driving, riding, sailing, fishing, clay-pigeon shooting, falconry, archery, tennis and croquet.

Price: Guests are able to visit once prior to membership; thereafter they must become a member at an annual cost of £3,000 plus VAT. Non-member rates of £580 + VAT per room based on double occupancy inclusive of activities except riding, spa and off-road driving.

Thornbury Castle
near Bristol, tel: 01454 281182

Encircled by its own vineyard with panoramic views over the Severn into Wales, Thornbury was once the weekend retreat of Henry VIII and Anne Boleyn (he cleared the way by beheading the owner). Relaxed atmosphere, panelled walls, tapestries, heraldic shields ... you get the picture.

Price: Small twins or doubles start from £130 a night including breakfast; large four-poster de luxe rooms with fireplaces from £260 per night.

And one in the Republic ...

Luttrellstown Castle
Castleknock, near Dublin, tel: 00 353 1 808 9900

Sit in a clawfoot bath in your bedroom and stare out across the 560-acre estate. There's plenty to do out of the tub, too: exploring the Gothic folly, angling, boating and there's even a heated pool and all-weather tennis court.

Price: The entire castle, with 14 double bedrooms in all, has to be booked rather than individual rooms. Winter rate from I£4,000; rising to I£6,000 a night after March. The price includes breakfast; lunch can be arranged from IR£30 a head and dinner from IR£48.
