fields.headline: You want to help. But who gets your money?
fields.standfirst: Fundraising costs and admin expenses can take a large slice out of the cash you give to a good cause. Phillip Inman looks at who keeps what
fields.trailText: Fundraising costs and admin expenses can take a large slice out of the cash you give to a good cause. Phillip Inman looks at who keeps what.
fields.body:
Anyone tempted to put some money aside in a savings plan feels safer knowing that financial watchdogs are protecting their interests while performance tables point them to the best deals.

But a donation to charity this Christmas is likely to be made based on a confusing array of claims about how effective the charities are at translating donations into services. There is little regulation of almost 95% of the sector.

Some charities translate little more than 50% of their income into services and use fundraising methods that rely on highly paid professional staff and armies of paid fundraisers, while other well-known charities claim a 100% record and say every £1 donated is £1 spent on services.

Yet much of the difference in the charities lies not in their ability to run a tight ship, but in the way they account for their fundraising costs and admin expenses.

Despite the confusion, charities are resisting public demands to introduce performance tables that rank how well they spend their cash.

The main organisation representing charities, the National Council for Voluntary Organisations, says it receives calls every week asking for lists that rank the performance of charities, but argues they would be misleading.

"We've had lots of calls asking for league tables showing how efficient and effective charities are, but they are so different - the way they operate and the sectors they operate in - that any attempt to establish a uniform standard is going to be problematic and we don't think it will be the right solution," a spokesman for the organisation says.

A recent survey commissioned by the Media Trust, which helps charities promote themselves, shows that charities are fighting a rising tide of opinion.

The survey found that more than two in three people would welcome league tables rating charities by efficiency and performance.

A debate last month staged by the trust, and supported by the Guardian, rejected the proposition that there were too many charities, but accepted that initiatives were needed to help people make informed choices between them. The trust is looking at ways to stimulate new interest in performance ratings.

Problems arise when, for instance, someone wants to make a one-off donation to a children's charity. There are four major children's charities - Barnardo's, the Children's Society, NCH (formerly National Children's Homes) and the NSPCC - and a host of smaller charities such as Childline and Kidscape. Then there are umbrella organisations that advertise for funds such as Children's Promise, the government-backed millennium appeal that was relaunched last week for a second run this Christmas. All four of the larger children's charities are part of Children's Promise along with Comic Relief and BBC Children in Need, themselves umbrella organisations.

Should potential donors give to Children's Promise or spend a little more time choosing a specific charity? According to Children's Promise it doesn't matter. The promise in the title refers to passing on every £1 donation and making sure it is spent directly on services. It says £19m has been collected so far. To keep the promise going, the NSPCC ring fences specific projects to be funded directly with Children's Promise money.

Children's Promise can make the claim because the £3m cost of the project so far is borne by Marks & Spencer. Likewise, the NSPCC strips out the overheads usually attached to the projects that get Children's Promise money.

Consequently, the £1 donation resulting in £1 for services is only possible after a simple, yet effective, accounting exercise. The Marks & Spencer cash is called "sponsorship" and the cost of fundraising, two full-time staff, four part-time staff, printing, postage and other expenses are taken out of the equation. M&S might have donated the £3m to charity rather than spending it on administration. With this in mind, if Children's Promise accounted for its activities like most other large charities it would say that 85p in every £1 is sent to the charities and 15p spent on expenses.

The most generous interpretation of the NSPCC's annual report is that it also manages to spend 85p in the £1 on its various projects.

NSPCC finance director John Graham agrees that if all the normal costs associated with funding projects are put together under normal accounting practices, the NSPCC services funded by the Children's Promise get 85% of 85p, which means that 72p in every £1 finds its way to the front line. The total would be less than 50p if the definition of NSPCC projects was limited to children's services and stripped out fundraising, lob bying and education costs.

Other charities are keen to attract the public's attention with claims that administration costs are paid for by "someone else" and therefore every £1 donated is £1 spent on services.

Streetsmart was founded four years ago to support the homeless in London at Christmas. The charity was set up by William Seighart, owner of Forward Publishing, who is critical of charities that waste money on administration.

It has been successful at targeting diners at the capital's many upmarket restaurants for voluntary cash donations. Diners simply add £1 to their bill and the restaurant passes it on to the charity. The cash is used to buy sleeping bags, blankets and provide hot meals, following consultation with the major charities about what homeless people need.

Until this year the charity was run from Mr Seighart's offices and depended on the time voluntarily put in by staff. But its success has encouraged the trustees to expand out of London and this year restaurants in Manchester, Bristol and Glasgow will take part. The move was made possible by an £80,000 donation by Barclays towards administration costs, including a full-time director. Last year the charity raised more than £150,000 and this year it is hoped the figure will reach £250,000.

Like Children's Promise, Mr Seighart claims that every £1 donated is spent on services for the homeless. But like Children's Promise, the claim can only be sustained if the public discount Barclays offer to underwrite the administration costs. Factoring in the costs of the operation doesn't take away from the benefits the charity can bring, it just makes Streetsmart like other charities and gives a more representative picture of its operation. Assuming the charity achieves its targets, for every £1 donation the charity can spend 68p.

Mr Seighart says the Barclays donation allows the charity to make even more money. "It's hard saying no to an offer like that," he says. "The charity was becoming too big for staff at Forward to carry out in work time and out of hours. It was becoming a full-time job."

He denies that separating out the administration expenses misleads the public into thinking the charity is more efficient than he claims.

Likewise, a spokesman for Children's Promise says: "We are generating seven times the money put into the scheme by M&S, which is a great achievement."

Mr Graham says the public is confused by the large number of children's charities and the Children's Promise campaign offers a chance for them to club together. He also points out that smaller charities are often even less efficient than their larger cousins because economies of scale are not available to them.

Oxfam, which was recently criticised on the BBC Watchdog programme for using paid fundraisers rather than volunteers to canvass passers by, argues that the public must realise the days of volunteers rattling tins are over.

"All charities need to spend money to make money," says a spokeswoman. "The brutal truth is that charities are operating in a very competitive market."

The charity, which has seen its income stagnate at £124m in the past couple of years, says it costs £30 for every person recruited through face-to-face fundraising. "It's well worth it when they give at least £2 per month and very few people cancel their direct debits."

Charities must spend more, sometimes just to stand still, after a steep fall in voluntary donations during the 1990s. The NCVO says the decline has halted in the past year. But the need for charities to go in search of bolder marketing messages is still there. The government wants everyone to give more to charities. More information about the ways charities work might do the trick.

In the spotlight

Christmas is a time when many of the 175,000 small charities with an income under £2,000 knock on doors and shake tins often for local good causes.

But before potential donors think about contributing they should consider that regulation of the tiddlers of the charity world is extremely light.

The Charity Commission, which regulates the sector, says its resources are focused on larger charities that account for 98%of the £24bn income to charities.

That means the likes of the Wellcome Trust, Imperial Cancer Research Fund and Salvation Army are put under scrutiny to the exclusion of small charities.

The commission is revamping its monitoring and investigations procedures and with large increases in government funding is overhauling its computer systems. In 2002 it plans to spend a further £1m on monitoring charities out of an extra £4.5m grant.

But the focus is still on larger charities. New accounting practices mean all registered charities with an income of £10,000 plus must submit annual accounts and reports, which are publicly available.

However, 12% of charities above the threshold have failed to send in their accounts for March 2000 as have 5% with incomes over £250,000. Nearly 12,000 charities showed "potential concern", the commission says and more than1,200 cases were referred for further advice or to consider whether investigations should be undertaken. There are no figures showing how many investigations are in progress, but in the past two years 76 charities have seen their bank accounts frozen among 333 sanctions.

Deliberate malpractice accounted for 19%of cases, fund-raising problems for 35%and maladministration for 41%.

The value of a pay packet donation

Although charities such as Oxfam reckon it's worth using paid fundraisers for face-to-face interviews at £30 per recruit, you could save the charity the expense and make regular donations directly from your pay packet.

If you give money in the street it comes from your net income that has been taxed. The government's tax efficient payroll giving scheme can almost double the charity contribution of a top-rate taxpayer because it comes from an employee's gross salary.

Hundreds of companies have signed up to the scheme that charities hope will become the backbone of their funding arrangements. They reckon it could regularly bring an extra £60m to their coffers each year and significantly increase the in volvement of donors. Donations have been slipping among the under 30s, while the number of householders in their 20s giving cash has fallen from 25% in 1978 to 17.4% in 1998.

In response, the government announced this year that the previous tax-free limit of £1,200 per year on charitable donations through payroll would be abolished. It also said the government would top up all payroll donations by 10% until April 2003.

Self-employed workers and pensioners without a company scheme can make tax-efficient donations to charity from their gross salary using the government's GiftAid scheme. They need to contact each charity and fill in a form that would allow them to claim the tax back. A £78 donation would be worth £100 to the charity after it claimed the tax back. But they miss out on the 10% top-up that is part of payroll giving.

Also, charities can only claim back tax on GiftAid contributions at the basic rate rather than the higher 40%. Higher-rate donors must reclaim the 18% difference from the Inland Revenue through self-assessment forms.

For both schemes, a £10 donation taxed at 40% saves £4. The donation, therefore, costs £6. A £10 donation made through payroll goes to the charity from gross salary and is then bumped up by a further £1 from the government, thus giving rise to an £11 donation which only costs £6.

fields.headline: Wacky Baku
fields.standfirst: It's too weird to be the new Prague but exotic enough to be a setting for a Bond film. Charlotte  reports
fields.trailText: It's too weird to be the new Prague but exotic enough to be a setting for a Bond film. Charlotte Higgins reports.
fields.body:
Baku is not the new Prague. It's too weird, too dishevelled, too industrial and the electricity and water cut out too often. And yet it's an exciting city to explore, easy and fun to negotiate on foot. It is true that reliable city maps are thin on the ground. But it's fine, honestly.

And I found that, if in doubt, I could always orient myself by Fountain Square (though the fountains rarely work), the central, café-filled hub of town whence radiate smart, western-style shopping streets. Or by the windswept sea-front, with its wide, olive-and-cypress fringed promenade, shady tea gardens and quaint, concrete-bound network of stagnant waterways called, imaginatively, Little Venice.

But sometimes it's fun to lose yourself. I did so, comprehensively, in the city's labyrinthine old town, which has well-preserved medieval walls. Tucked inside is the Shirvanshah's Palace, one of the city's main sights. It's a complex of living quarters, mausolea plus a handsome mosque and minaret dating from the 15th century. (If you paid attention to The World is Not Enough, James Bond's last adventure partly set in Baku, you may have received the impression that Azerbaijan is an Orthodox country. Not so - its national religion is a relaxed form of Shiite Islam.)

When you wend your way down the hill from the palace towards the Caspian, you won't miss the other big landmark: a fairytale, ancient colossus called, with utter romance, Maiden's Tower. There's a boring story that suggests its name means merely that the tower was virgin, in other words impregnable to attack. There are much better versions involving suicidal princesses. Whatever, it has great views from the top and really is impressive - its blank, minimal keep and slab-like buttress give it an almost modernist look.

Dotted right round the foot of Maiden's Tower are scenes of terrible temptation, in the form of carpet shops, all of them delicious caves bright with textile treasure. It helps to be a confident bargainer (dollars are rug-currency, and my haggling companions seemed to be knocking the traders down to about half their asking price).

Best of all in Baku, I liked aimless afternoons in the streets left from its last oil-boom - in the late 19th-century, when the city expanded like crazy and Nobels and Rothschilds came to make, or increase, their fortunes. These entrepreneurs built street after street of mansions. They may be dusty and dilapidated now, many having been split into tiny apartments during the Soviet era. But they are still elegant, with their frighteningly cantilevered, first-floor balconies that look as if they are clinging on to their host buildings only through the willpower of the great twisted vines that struggle up from the streets below.

Those oil millionaires also built an irrigation system for Baku, which means that though the city is slap-bang atop a desert, there are oleanders and olives and pleasant parks in the city.

The best sight in Baku, though, is an acreage of spoiled, exhausted oil fields on the shore of the Caspian Sea. The deathly anti-forest of lop-sided, angular derricks have the look of one of those first world war paintings of exploded woods in Paschendaele or Ypres. It's strangely beautiful - even though it's an environmental nightmare.

Now there's a new oil boom underway, offshore, and right by this field there's a foreign rig being assembled - called Qurtulus, which is Azeri for rebirth. And oil may mean rebirth for this country, which still bears so heavily the scars of post-Soviet ructions.

After all that, it was good to sit and eat. Azeri food is not a million miles from Turkish or Persian - lots of lamb kebabs for my meat-eating friends and for me, a lone vegetarian, delicious "aubergine caviar", yoghurt soups, salads with tarragon and basil and chives, and tomatoes to make your mouth water. There are quantities of real, cheap caviar, too. After dinner, you can sample the joys of the Chechen-run nightclub, Mosaic, or toast your friends in Azeri brandy and splendid vodka.

Azerbaijan has so much fresh produce because, you see, the country contains not just deserts and oil-fields but rolling hills and lush valleys too. I marvelled at all this fruitfulness in the city's Taza Bazaar, a cascade of higgledy-piggledy stalls selling peppers and paprikas, saffron and walnuts and pomegranates. (Plus nails, screws, doorknobs and strip lights. And, at one stall, a captive buzzard gave me a gimlet stare.)

There's a beautiful opera house, too. The Kirov and Bolshoi pay the odd visit, but you can also see works by Azerbaijan's national composer, Hajibeyov, who infused his Romantic pieces with echoes of mugam, the country's traditional folk idiom. Charles de Gaulle stopped over for a performance on his roundabout way to Moscow to see Stalin in 1944, which must be a recommendation. Since the season hadn't started, I opted instead to see a Russian pop star called Zemfira, who was playing the Palace of Hand Games. She was terrific.

Back to those lush valleys. I was ferried by tourbus to Quba, a town north of Baku. When you get there, you're in verdant orchard lands where the pretty, turquoise-painted clapboard houses are surrounded by apple trees and vineyards gone to seed, and the roadsides are stacked with buckets of aubergines, tomatoes, apples and cucumbers - a shock to the eye after the miles and miles and miles of satanic industrial dereliction you pass en route over the flat, greyish desert.

For a real adventure, I was able to call on the services of my friend with a Neva - a sturdy, uncomplaining, Russian four-wheel drive that seemed able to negotiate any obstacle in its path. Which it needs to, for to venture off the main roads, which are pitted and pockmarked enough, is a tricky business. Plus signposts are as rare as hen's teeth and the maps don't help much. The man with the Neva was a demon at the wheel, and took me south of the city, on the road to Gobustan, where there are all sorts of wonders.

When you leave the city, out in the desert are twin mountains where the Zoroastrians laid out their dead to be picked over by carrion. In the lee of these heights we paid our respects at a graveyard for dead Soviet tanks, next to a sad old cemetery for orthodox Russians. Farther on you can visit a lunar hillside covered with prehistoric cave paintings; and there are mud volcanoes, funny old craters that fart natural gas and chuck great globules of mud at you.

Beyond the mud volcanoes, and beyond the main road, lies an isolated caravanserai and mosque guarded by a lady with an impressive embonpoint. She warned us that the place was only to be visited by those with pure thoughts. Putting aside our worries on that point, we investigated this Silk Route stop-off, then exchanged pleasantries with two nice blokes who were bleeding and skinning a decapitated sheep.

We then spurred the Neva on to tackle a great brown-and-rust-coloured hill, following the route of an oil or gas pipeline (everywhere we went seemed to be following the route of a pipeline). We scaled the final few hundred yards on foot, where we found our very own slurping and burping mud volcanoes.

Feeling on top of the world (indeed, I would have been able to see the Caucasus ranges proper had it not been such awful weather), I felt that I loved these scarred mountains, these bruised and ugly plains.

The practicals

Getting there: The Online Travel Company (0870 8870100) is offering three-night, room-only stays in the Hyatt Regency Baku, including return scheduled flights with BA from London Heathrow, for £719 until December 31. Extra nights cost £60pp. Prices are based on two people sharing. The Online Travel Company will organise visas at a separate cost.

What to read: Azerbaijan with Georgia by Mark Elliott (Trailblazer, £12.99) is an excellent guidebook with useful maps that make exploring in and around Baku possible. It is much more detailed than the new but disappointing Georgia, Armenia and Azerbaijan (Lonely Planet, £12.99). Azerbaijan Diary: A Rogue Reporter's Adventures in an Oil-rich, War-torn, Post-Soviet Republic, by Thomas Goltz (ME Sharpe, £22.50) is a gripping, first-hand account of the country post independence.

More information: The Azerbaijan International magazine produces informative themed issues on cultural matters.

Places to see, things to eat and drink

Museums

State Art Gallery
Opposite the Philharmonia building. Partly housed in a crumbling, elegant oil mansion built by the Rothschilds, it contains Azeri and western art. Entry: 12,000 manat (7,000 manat to £1).

Carpet and Applied Art Museum
The vast former Lenin Museum now contains a world-class collection of textiles. English-speaking guide available. Entry: 12,000 manat.

Gobustan Archaeological Museum
The museum itself is a decrepit one-room place, with hilarious life-sized models of cave women. But Gurban Aleskerov, the warden, will give you a fabulous tour of the prehistoric petroglyphs scattered around the mountain nearby.

Where to eat and drink

It's worth bearing in mind that Azerbaijan is a cash-based society - even quite smart restaurants won't take credit cards, though the western hotels will. Most places take either dollars or manat.

Karavanserai
A fabulously atmospheric restaurant set off a leafy courtyard. The stone walls are hung with Azeri carpets. The food is traditional Azeri - lots of lamb, lots of aubergine. Don't miss the kutab, a thin pancake filled with herbs or meat. About $15 per head.

Dostlar
At the top corner of Fountain Square, this mid-range restaurant has pleasant tables outside under the trees. Wash down your kebabs with Xirdalan, the local beer. About $5 per head.

Intergrand Turk
Around the corner from the Azerbaijan International Office on Alizade Street. There are lots of cheap Turkish cafés in Baku that make useful lunch stops. This one has nice lentil soup. Lunch menu about $4-6 per head.

Bar 103
On Neftchilar, near Maiden's Tower. From the outside, a grandiose oil mansion (the very one where Charles de Gaulle stayed). Inside, a little bit of New York bardom, with martinis you could drown yourself in, at about $6 each.

Favourite
On Fountains Square, where you can watch the young and beautiful of Baku strut their stuff. About 5,000 manat for a beer.
fields.bodyText: Baku is not the new Prague. It's too weird, too dishevelled, too industrial and the electricity and water cut out too often. And yet it's an exciting city to explore, easy and fun to negotiate on foot. It is true that reliable city maps are thin on the ground. But it's fine, honestly. And I found that, if in doubt, I could always orient myself by Fountain Square (though the fountains rarely work), the central, café-filled hub of town whence radiate smart, western-style shopping streets. Or by the windswept sea-front, with its wide, olive-and-cypress fringed promenade, shady tea gardens and quaint, concrete-bound network of stagnant waterways called, imaginatively, Little Venice. But sometimes it's fun to lose yourself. I did so, comprehensively, in the city's labyrinthine old town, which has well-preserved medieval walls. Tucked inside is the Shirvanshah's Palace, one of the city's main sights. It's a complex of living quarters, mausolea plus a handsome mosque and minaret dating from the 15th century. (If you paid attention to The World is Not Enough, James Bond's last adventure partly set in Baku, you may have received the impression that Azerbaijan is an Orthodox country. Not so - its national religion is a relaxed form of Shiite Islam.) When you wend your way down the hill from the palace towards the Caspian, you won't miss the other big landmark: a fairytale, ancient colossus called, with utter romance, Maiden's Tower. There's a boring story that suggests its name means merely that the tower was virgin, in other words impregnable to attack. There are much better versions involving suicidal princesses. Whatever, it has great views from the top and really is impressive - its blank, minimal keep and slab-like buttress give it an almost modernist look. Dotted right round the foot of Maiden's Tower are scenes of terrible temptation, in the form of carpet shops, all of them delicious caves bright with textile treasure. It helps to be a confident bargainer (dollars are rug-currency, and my haggling companions seemed to be knocking the traders down to about half their asking price). Best of all in Baku, I liked aimless afternoons in the streets left from its last oil-boom - in the late 19th-century, when the city expanded like crazy and Nobels and Rothschilds came to make, or increase, their fortunes. These entrepreneurs built street after street of mansions. They may be dusty and dilapidated now, many having been split into tiny apartments during the Soviet era. But they are still elegant, with their frighteningly cantilevered, first-floor balconies that look as if they are clinging on to their host buildings only through the willpower of the great twisted vines that struggle up from the streets below. Those oil millionaires also built an irrigation system for Baku, which means that though the city is slap-bang atop a desert, there are oleanders and olives and pleasant parks in the city. The best sight in Baku, though, is an acreage of spoiled, exhausted oil fields on the shore of the Caspian Sea. The deathly anti-forest of lop-sided, angular derricks have the look of one of those first world war paintings of exploded woods in Paschendaele or Ypres. It's strangely beautiful - even though it's an environmental nightmare. Now there's a new oil boom underway, offshore, and right by this field there's a foreign rig being assembled - called Qurtulus, which is Azeri for rebirth. And oil may mean rebirth for this country, which still bears so heavily the scars of post-Soviet ructions. After all that, it was good to sit and eat. Azeri food is not a million miles from Turkish or Persian - lots of lamb kebabs for my meat-eating friends and for me, a lone vegetarian, delicious "aubergine caviar", yoghurt soups, salads with tarragon and basil and chives, and tomatoes to make your mouth water. There are quantities of real, cheap caviar, too. After dinner, you can sample the joys of the Chechen-run nightclub, Mosaic, or toast your friends in Azeri brandy and splendid vodka. Azerbaijan has so much fresh produce because, you see, the country contains not just deserts and oil-fields but rolling hills and lush valleys too. I marvelled at all this fruitfulness in the city's Taza Bazaar, a cascade of higgledy-piggledy stalls selling peppers and paprikas, saffron and walnuts and pomegranates. (Plus nails, screws, doorknobs and strip lights. And, at one stall, a captive buzzard gave me a gimlet stare.) There's a beautiful opera house, too. The Kirov and Bolshoi pay the odd visit, but you can also see works by Azerbaijan's national composer, Hajibeyov, who infused his Romantic pieces with echoes of mugam, the country's traditional folk idiom. Charles de Gaulle stopped over for a performance on his roundabout way to Moscow to see Stalin in 1944, which must be a recommendation. Since the season hadn't started, I opted instead to see a Russian pop star called Zemfira, who was playing the Palace of Hand Games. She was terrific. Back to those lush valleys. I was ferried by tourbus to Quba, a town north of Baku. When you get there, you're in verdant orchard lands where the pretty, turquoise-painted clapboard houses are surrounded by apple trees and vineyards gone to seed, and the roadsides are stacked with buckets of aubergines, tomatoes, apples and cucumbers - a shock to the eye after the miles and miles and miles of satanic industrial dereliction you pass en route over the flat, greyish desert. For a real adventure, I was able to call on the services of my friend with a Neva - a sturdy, uncomplaining, Russian four-wheel drive that seemed able to negotiate any obstacle in its path. Which it needs to, for to venture off the main roads, which are pitted and pockmarked enough, is a tricky business. Plus signposts are as rare as hen's teeth and the maps don't help much. The man with the Neva was a demon at the wheel, and took me south of the city, on the road to Gobustan, where there are all sorts of wonders. When you leave the city, out in the desert are twin mountains where the Zoroastrians laid out their dead to be picked over by carrion. In the lee of these heights we paid our respects at a graveyard for dead Soviet tanks, next to a sad old cemetery for orthodox Russians. Farther on you can visit a lunar hillside covered with prehistoric cave paintings; and there are mud volcanoes, funny old craters that fart natural gas and chuck great globules of mud at you. Beyond the mud volcanoes, and beyond the main road, lies an isolated caravanserai and mosque guarded by a lady with an impressive embonpoint. She warned us that the place was only to be visited by those with pure thoughts. Putting aside our worries on that point, we investigated this Silk Route stop-off, then exchanged pleasantries with two nice blokes who were bleeding and skinning a decapitated sheep. We then spurred the Neva on to tackle a great brown-and-rust-coloured hill, following the route of an oil or gas pipeline (everywhere we went seemed to be following the route of a pipeline). We scaled the final few hundred yards on foot, where we found our very own slurping and burping mud volcanoes. Feeling on top of the world (indeed, I would have been able to see the Caucasus ranges proper had it not been such awful weather), I felt that I loved these scarred mountains, these bruised and ugly plains. The practicals Getting there: The Online Travel Company (0870 8870100) is offering three-night, room-only stays in the Hyatt Regency Baku, including return scheduled flights with BA from London Heathrow, for £719 until December 31. Extra nights cost £60pp. Prices are based on two people sharing. The Online Travel Company will organise visas at a separate cost. What to read: Azerbaijan with Georgia by Mark Elliott (Trailblazer, £12.99) is an excellent guidebook with useful maps that make exploring in and around Baku possible. It is much more detailed than the new but disappointing Georgia, Armenia and Azerbaijan (Lonely Planet, £12.99). Azerbaijan Diary: A Rogue Reporter's Adventures in an Oil-rich, War-torn, Post-Soviet Republic, by Thomas Goltz (ME Sharpe, £22.50) is a gripping, first-hand account of the country post independence. More information: The Azerbaijan International magazine produces informative themed issues on cultural matters. Places to see, things to eat and drink Museums State Art Gallery Opposite the Philharmonia building. Partly housed in a crumbling, elegant oil mansion built by the Rothschilds, it contains Azeri and western art. Entry: 12,000 manat (7,000 manat to £1). Carpet and Applied Art Museum The vast former Lenin Museum now contains a world-class collection of textiles. English-speaking guide available. Entry: 12,000 manat. Gobustan Archaeological Museum The museum itself is a decrepit one-room place, with hilarious life-sized models of cave women. But Gurban Aleskerov, the warden, will give you a fabulous tour of the prehistoric petroglyphs scattered around the mountain nearby. Where to eat and drink It's worth bearing in mind that Azerbaijan is a cash-based society - even quite smart restaurants won't take credit cards, though the western hotels will. Most places take either dollars or manat. Karavanserai A fabulously atmospheric restaurant set off a leafy courtyard. The stone walls are hung with Azeri carpets. The food is traditional Azeri - lots of lamb, lots of aubergine. Don't miss the kutab, a thin pancake filled with herbs or meat. About $15 per head. Dostlar At the top corner of Fountain Square, this mid-range restaurant has pleasant tables outside under the trees. Wash down your kebabs with Xirdalan, the local beer. About $5 per head. Intergrand Turk Around the corner from the Azerbaijan International Office on Alizade Street. There are lots of cheap Turkish cafés in Baku that make useful lunch stops. This one has nice lentil soup. Lunch menu about $4-6 per head. Bar 103 On Neftchilar, near Maiden's Tower. From the outside, a grandiose oil mansion (the very one where Charles de Gaulle stayed). Inside, a little bit of New York bardom, with martinis you could drown yourself in, at about $6 each. Favourite On Fountains Square, where you can watch the young and beautiful of Baku strut their stuff. About 5,000 manat for a beer.

fields.headline: Ask a fellow traveller
fields.standfirst: Pat Lacey suffers from a damaged eardrum and wants to know if the device called Earplanes would make flying bearable
fields.trailText: Pat Lacey suffers from a damaged eardrum and wants to know if the device called Earplanes would make flying bearable.
fields.body:
I have used Earplanes (bought at Boots for £4.49 a pair) for the past couple of years and, while the pain on descent does not disappear altogether, it is bearable and much less frightening. I have been told by my doctor that there is nothing wrong with my eardrums and I am probably just unlucky to have very narrow passageways connecting parts of the inner ear, which causes a greater build up of pressure.
Joan Winship

My teenage son tried Earplanes a couple of years ago, but they did not prevent the pain. Perhaps the only solution would be a strong painkiller taken during the flight.
Susan Manville

I bought a pair of Earplanes, having seen them advertised in Guardian Travel. Total relief of pain! However, I did experience "popping" in my ears after removing them on terra firma. I would not now fly without them.
Liz O'Brien

Since using Earplanes, the pain has not been so severe, although I have had some discomfort. I suffer from catarrh, which I am told is the reason for the pain. I don't know if they work with a damaged eardrum.
Philip Muzlish

I, too, have a damaged eardrum and have suffered dreadfully on landing, but this year, flying to Crete, I wore Earplanes and they really work.
Mary Crabtree

My family tried out Earplanes for the first time this year. None of us suffered any of the usual pain and we would thoroughly recommend them, as long as you don't mind looking slightly ridiculous with blue plastic cones sticking out of your ears.
Penny Bradnum

This week's question

We are planning a trekking trip to Nepal in October/November 2001. We intend to organise our own flights, and our own time either side of a trek. However, we would like to arrange the trek from the UK well in advance. Can anyone recommend a good company that does not exploit its sherpas?
Joanna Bird

fields.headline: When Sam met Santa
fields.standfirst: These days anyone can go to the top and bottom of the world for a day. Six-year-old Samuel and his mum Maev Kennedy see where Santa lives up north
fields.trailText: These days anyone can go to the top and bottom of the world for a day. Six-year-old Samuel and his mum Maev Kennedy see where Santa lives up north.
fields.body:
As we walked home from the child minder's on a sodden, muggy London night, Samuel kept stopping in his tracks and peering up at my face to check this was not some sadistic wind-up. On Sunday morning he finally felt it was safe to believe it. Frankly, there could be no conceivable reason for being in Birmingham airport at 5.45am, other than because we really were about to fly to Lapland and visit Father Christmas.

For days he had been studying his Advent calender, and the Christmas cards in the post office window, glitter frost and snow ladled on to log cabin and fir tree. Samuel was born in 1994, and has never seen proper snow. He helped build one snowman, three years ago in Ireland, and it was frankly a slush and mud affair. "Will it look just like that, really?" he said. It would, I promised - and it did, but it was a close run thing.

The plane crew had also overdosed on glitter glue. None had ever crewed a day trip to Father Christmas before. From the check-in staff to the baggage handlers and the guys wheeling the boarding steps, they chortled, they cavorted, they photographed one another, they put on reindeer horns and twined tinsel around their heads, necks, the crowd barriers, the emergency exits.

"We are experiencing a slight delay before take off," the captain announced, "because we have just been informed that it is snowing on the runway at Ivalo." The crew cheered wildly. The children did their best to calm them down, but the crew sang, danced up and down the aisle, organised snowman art competitions and pick-your-own-key carol concerts, all the three and a half hours to the Arctic Circle.

The holiday reps conferred urgently outside the loos. Faced with the beseeching eyes and trembling lower lip - and that was just the captain in his Santa Claus hat - they gave in. The entire crew, instead of being left behind for seven hours in the very small town of Ivalo, could also come to find Father Christmas in the forest.

Samuel found me tediously childish as a travelling companion. "I can see something flashy out there," he said, as the plane came down towards Ivalo through a slab of cloud. "Could it be Rudolf?" I asked, nauseatingly. "I think it might be the runway, actually," he said, pityingly.

A small child at the back of the plane shouted that she could see reindeer. "Sweet," her parents said fondly but soon the whole left side of the plane was yelling. And there they were indeed, two reindeer waiting for us on the Tarmac, outside the the endearing terminal building - not a phrase I have ever used before in my travelling life - with a huge log fire blazing in a dashing modern concrete fireplace, and candles flickering on all the tables.

The light was already draining away as we moved to the dressing hall, the levelling ground. Young and old, tall and small, fat and sleek, all emerged in inch-thick, padded-bottom, one-piece thermal suits looking equally ludicrous, but certainly warm. In fact hot. Lapland did look like the calendar, but the snow came with two days to spare before the first of Advent. The country was under a frayed sheet rather than a thick blanket. We were 200km north of the Arctic Circle, and there were still shrubs, and running water. It was cold outside, but not atrociously cold at -3C. Not, in fact, cold enough.

Father Christmas is a very important person in Lapland. In the 30-minute coach journey from airport to forest, six cars passed us. In the gathering darkness, there were trees and snow, a scatter of cabins, one village, a sign for a husky dog farm, and nothing else. Between winter closing in and the start of the skiing season proper, there are only three sources of employment: state administrative work, reindeer farming and Father Christmas.

His industry began as far back as the 1960s, with a small post office in a little town in the Arctic Circle, which accepted letters on his behalf from children all over the world. This year the post office in Rovaniemi expects to handle up to a million pieces of Christmas post, and it is now surrounded by Santa's Village, larger than the original town, with hotels, cafés, pink-knuckle rides - including a mechanical sleigh ride to the elves' workshop - and dozens of souvenir shops.

The snow is not just pretty: hundreds of jobs depend on it. The Father Christmas market is now considerably bigger than the conventional skiing market, with dozens of operators, and jumbo jet loads of visitors from around the globe. Transun, which specialises in day trips and very short breaks, got in on the act eight years ago, and will send 14,000 people this year, all in the 24 days of Advent. Its days in the forest have to be organised like military manoeuvres, with the plane-load sorted on to separate coaches and sent off to different parts of the forest, so that everyone gets sleigh rides and husky dogs and hot salmon, but not in the same order.

There is no Plan B, a spokesman said this week. "We did have a few very anxious moments - if the snow hadn't come, we would have had no option but to cancel. You can't send people to slop around in the mud all day."

Once in the forest, the machinery driving the whole operation was admirably hidden. The coach dropped us and went away, leaving a startling silence, apart from the yapping huskies and the hissing sound which meant you were about to be mown down by a cross-country skier. The dogs snapped and quarrelled and bumped into one another. They weren't yet in training, our young sledge driver explained.

"By now we should have a metre of snow, at least. When they are used to it, they can go 50 miles without getting tired. But this year, for so long there has been no snow so they cannot work. All summer I work at all sorts of jobs, and I dream of snow. But this winter is very strange."

By the end of the dog-sledge ride complete darkness had fallen and the path to the next stop was marked with candles sunk into the snow between the banks of black trees. Flakes of frost were falling, glittering like diamonds where they crossed the light of the flames. It was ludicrously, almost intolerably pretty. The children trudged along the path in silence, stooping occasionally to grab a mitten full of snow too soft and new to make proper snowballs.

All sensible children, unless their brains have been rotted by too much Jingle Bells in the shopping malls, greet Father Christmas with a mixture of greed and terror. Samuel is no exception, but in Finland this is a particularly proper approach. Their Santa is a creature of the pagan mid-winter mutated by two centuries of marketing: Finnish children believe he lives high up in the Arctic Circle in a remote valley called Korvatunturi, because that's where a hugely popular radio drama in 1927 said he lived.

The winter is stupendously dark and long, and there are still wolves in the forest. Their Father Christmas comes on Christmas Eve, knocks on the window, and demands to know if all the children in the house have been good - and everyone knows of some house where he didn't get a satisfactory response and went away again with his sack. His cloven hoof is not quite concealed under his scarlet robes: his name is Joulupukki, the Yule Buck, a name that still carries the howl of something ancient out in the dark trees.

Before he grew a long white beard and a benevolent twinkle, Joulupukki was a huge, terrifying horned creature, demanding instead of giving presents. So when we entered his hot, little wooden cabin in the clearing in the forest, full of flickering shadows and dark corners in the candlelight, it was very sensible to praise the light and fear the darkness.

In the brightest corner, between the Christmas tree and the log-burning stove, sat a very large man with a very large beard, a sack of presents and a bucket of reindeer bells. He was also kind enough to keep a large roll of kitchen paper on the wooden bench inside the door, possibly because he also knows about the problem of steamed-up glasses.

The grown-ups hung back, as shy suddenly as the children. The large man already had the letters by his side, on the piled reindeer skin rugs, from the children who had written in advance. Samuel's effort was accepted with great courtesy. Each child was greeted gravely, had a beautiful bell - a proper heavy bell, with a horse-shoe nail clapper - on a red and yellow felt thong hung around their neck; had a brief chat; and was given a small package. It seemed indecorous, though mandatory, when each posed for a photograph.

The captain watched, yearning. When all the children were dispatched for hot berry juice in the back room, he pleaded for a bell. They were for the children, the large man said. Could he buy one, the captain asked. Certainly not, the large man said - but he unbent enough to allow all the hostesses to sit on his knee in turn and have their photographs taken.

The packages turned out to contain beautiful blue braid-trimmed caps. Any little boy who thought they were slightly sissy could discuss it with Nils, the reindeer herder outside by the log fire, a giant of a man carrying a large knife, and dressed in brilliantly embroidered blue wool from head to foot, topped off with an identical cap.

Ahead of us lay another walk through the forest, a snowmobile ride to lunch in a wooden cabin - it was somewhere around teatime Lapland time, and somewhere around lunchtime Birmingham time, and a very long time since breakfast - and one last log fire blazing in a clearing in a copse of birch trees. This, for many of the children, including Samuel, was the highlight of the entire day: not the short ride in boat-shaped sledges drawn by reindeer, but a chance at last to play in the snow.

On the long flight back, the crew was still singing, still organising competitions, but most of the children slept as if drugged.

In truth, I am the wrong source for a dispassionate account of this. I have been so unhinged about Christmas that my family has called me Mary Christmas since I was a child. Samuel carefully considered the long, exhausting day. "Actually, I didn't not like any of it," he said finally.

What we remembered, back at home and reading the next bedtime chapter of the Hobbit, was the monochrome landscape, the white snow and the great black forest.

When he was asleep, and I went to put the bins out on another December night of torrential rain and unnerving warmth, what I remembered was the fierce earnestness of the guide: "Of course always there will be snow, there is no question. Christmas in Lapland without snow, it is unthinkable." And the fear in the voice of the young reindeer sledge driver, once again disentangling the traces fouled by his team, awkward because they had only been working for a week instead of a month: "This has been a terrible winter, terrible. I can never remember such a winter."

The practicals

Maev and Samuel Kennedy went to Lapland for a day with Transun (0870 4444747), which offers a variety of day-trips and longer stays visiting Father Christmas in the Arctic Circle. All-inclusive packages start from £319 a head with flights from around the country including Birmingham (December 10), Leeds (December 16 and 17), Humberside (December 19), Newcastle (December 16 and 17) and Stansted (December 20 and 24).

The winter is stupendously dark and long, and there are still wolves in the forest. Their Father Christmas comes on Christmas Eve, knocks on the window, and demands to know if all the children in the house have been good - and everyone knows of some house where he didn't get a satisfactory response and went away again with his sack. His cloven hoof is not quite concealed under his scarlet robes: his name is Joulupukki, the Yule Buck, a name that still carries the howl of something ancient out in the dark trees. Before he grew a long white beard and a benevolent twinkle, Joulupukki was a huge, terrifying horned creature, demanding instead of giving presents. So when we entered his hot, little wooden cabin in the clearing in the forest, full of flickering shadows and dark corners in the candlelight, it was very sensible to praise the light and fear the darkness. In the brightest corner, between the Christmas tree and the log-burning stove, sat a very large man with a very large beard, a sack of presents and a bucket of reindeer bells. He was also kind enough to keep a large roll of kitchen paper on the wooden bench inside the door, possibly because he also knows about the problem of steamed-up glasses. The grown-ups hung back, as shy suddenly as the children. The large man already had the letters by his side, on the piled reindeer skin rugs, from the children who had written in advance. Samuel's effort was accepted with great courtesy. Each child was greeted gravely, had a beautiful bell - a proper heavy bell, with a horse-shoe nail clapper - on a red and yellow felt thong hung around their neck; had a brief chat; and was given a small package. It seemed indecorous, though mandatory, when each posed for a photograph. The captain watched, yearning. When all the children were dispatched for hot berry juice in the back room, he pleaded for a bell. They were for the children, the large man said. Could he buy one, the captain asked. Certainly not, the large man said - but he unbent enough to allow all the hostesses to sit on his knee in turn and have their photographs taken. The packages turned out to contain beautiful blue braid-trimmed caps. Any little boy who thought they were slightly sissy could discuss it with Nils, the reindeer herder outside by the log fire, a giant of a man carrying a large knife, and dressed in brilliantly embroidered blue wool from head to foot, topped off with an identical cap. Ahead of us lay another walk through the forest, a snowmobile ride to lunch in a wooden cabin - it was somewhere around teatime Lapland time, and somewhere around lunchtime Birmingham time, and a very long time since breakfast - and one last log fire blazing in a clearing in a copse of birch trees. This, for many of the children, including Samuel, was the highlight of the entire day: not the short ride in boat-shaped sledges drawn by reindeer, but a chance at last to play in the snow. On the long flight back, the crew was still singing, still organising competitions, but most of the children slept as if drugged. In truth, I am the wrong source for a dispassionate account of this. I have been so unhinged about Christmas that my family has called me Mary Christmas since I was a child. Samuel carefully considered the long, exhausting day. "Actually, I didn't not like any of it," he said finally. What we remembered, back at home and reading the next bedtime chapter of the Hobbit, was the monochrome landscape, the white snow and the great black forest. When he was asleep, and I went to put the bins out on another December night of torrential rain and unnerving warmth, what I remembered was the fierce earnestness of the guide: "Of course always there will be snow, there is no question. Christmas in Lapland without snow, it is unthinkable." And the fear in the voice of the young reindeer sledge driver, once again disentangling the traces fouled by his team, awkward because they had only been working for a week instead of a month: "This has been a terrible winter, terrible. I can never remember such a winter." The practicals Maev and Samuel Kennedy went to Lapland for a day with Transun (0870 4444747), which offers a variety of day-trips and longer stays visiting Father Christmas in the Arctic Circle. All-inclusive packages start from £319 a head with flights from around the country including Birmingham (December 10), Leeds (December 16 and 17), Humberside (December 19), Newcastle (December 16 and 17) and Stansted (December 20 and 24).

fields.headline: Somewhere for now
fields.trailText: UK | Belgium | Tahiti
fields.body:
Europe

UK: The five-star Grand Hotel, Eastbourne (01323 412345) is extending its 125th birthday celebrations until December 22. Excluding Saturday nights, a deluxe twin/double room costs £125 per night (normal price £152) including a glass of champagne on arrival, full English breakfast, use of health club and a souvenir copy of the History of the Grand.

UK: Edale Youth Hostel (01433 670302) in the Peak District is hosting a four-night New Year activity holiday starting December 29. Activities include hillwalking, climbing, caving, orienteering and archery. For evening entertainment there will be a night abseil, treasure hunt and a New Year's Eve party. Full-board accommodation costs £200 per adult, £130 per child aged nine-18. See YHA for other breaks.

France: Spend Christmas at the two-star Hôtel La Romantica with indoor swimming pool near Honfleur. The price, £189pp based on two sharing, includes return ferry crossings Portsmouth-Le Havre and three nights' half board with a celebratory meal on Christmas Eve. Inntravel (01653 629000).

Belgium:Travelscene (020-8424 9648) is offering two- and three-night breaks at the five-star Sheraton Hotel, Brussels, for £199pp and £219pp respectively between December 15 and 31. Price includes first-class travel by Eurostar and B&B.

Italy: Start the year healthier and thinner after a seven-day Christmas or New Year spa package from Thermalia Travel (020-7483 1898). The package costs £1,290 and includes full-board accommodation at the Grand Hotel Terme Abano near Venice, five treatments including fangotherapy (mud), ozone baths and a full body massage, gala Christmas lunch or New Year's Eve dinner, return flights to Venice and transfers.

Portugal: Book through The First Resort for seven nights' self-catering in the Algarve from £119pp departing December 14.

Africa

Kenya: Leave on December 15 for a 15-day Faces of Kenya camping safari, including eight days' game viewing at Masai Mara, Samburu, Amboseli, Lake Nakuru, Lake Bororia and Lake Naivasha. The price, £685pp, includes one night's hotel accommodation, the rest camping. Kitty for meals £160. Flights extra. Guerba (01373 826611).

Pacific

Tahiti: Tropical Island Retreats (01444 239999) has cut £720 from the cost of a seven-night stay at the Beachcomber Park Royal hotel for departures between January 1-14. There is a spa, tennis courts, waterports, sunset cruises and scuba diving. The new price, £1,185, includes return scheduled flights, all transfers and room-only accommodation. Overwater bungalows cost an extra £90pp per night.

fields.headline: Somewhere in Britain
fields.trailText: Building blocks | Rink link | Snow Dome
fields.body:
Building blocks

Father Christmas's red velvet coat is one of the few things not built of primary-coloured bricks at Legoland. You'll find the man either in his grotto (£2.50), patting heads at the dusk illuminations or on stage at the Peter Pan Christmas Show, included in the entry fee along with the excellent squeaky-clean rides. Open daily, 10am-6pm. £18/£15. Windsor, Berks (01753 626111).

Rink link

Skate on the UK's largest open-air ice rink, in the shadow of Edinburgh Castle, and glide into the Winter Wonderland Fair next door. Colourful stalls, mulled wine, rides and crafts, plus special skating performances from the pros. Daily until Jan 7. Mon-Wed noon-8pm, Thur 10pm, Fri/Sat 10am-10pm, Sun 8pm. £5/£4/family £15. East Princes Street Gardens, Princes St, Edinburgh (0131-473 3800).

Snow Dome

Snowscape is The Dome's final fling. You can skate on a specially designed ice-rink where snow falls every day. A Winter Carnival parade of samba, singers and Santa weaves among the crowds. Daily throughout December. 9am-8pm; Christmas Eve, Boxing Day 10am-6pm, NY Eve 9am. £20/£15 (£1 per head Christmas Eve). 1 Drawdock Road, London SE10 (0870 606 2000).

Christmas Ryde

Wightlink FastCat departs Portsmouth 10.20am and 11.20am. Transfer to an electric train at Ryde, and alight at Smallbrook Station where the IOW Steam Railway puffs along to Havenstreet Station and Santa's Grotto. December 8/9/16/17 and 20-24. £13/£7 (£14/£9 closer to Christmas); £5 for under-5s. Info and tickets: Chief Gnome (01983 884871).

Wilde at art

Oscar Wilde and the Art of his Times celebrates the cultural and artistic life of the 19th-century literary heavyweight and wit. Open Mon, Tues, Thurs-Sat, 10am-6pm, Wed 8pm, Sun noon-6pm. £7/£5. Barbican Art Gallery, Level 3, Barbican Centre, Silk Street, London EC2 (020-7638 8891).

Millennium centurion

Tour the Roman remains of Corbridge fort, then watch the children trying on armour with a Roman soldier and making yuletide crafts in the museum attached to the site. Sun, noon-4pm. £2.80/£1.40. Nr Hexham, Northumberland (01434 632349).

Santa trail

A trail of clues around the ruined 19th-century Witley Court, past lake, woodland walks and fountains, leads children to Father Christmas and a present from the Christmas tree. Plenty of refreshments to warm the adults.December 9/10/16/17, 10am-4pm. £3.50/£1.80 (under 5s free). Great Witley, Nr Worcester, Worcestershire (01299 896636).

fields.headline: Pole vaulter
fields.standfirst: Ken Haley takes a day trip to the end of the world
fields.trailText: Ken Haley takes a day trip to the end of the world.
fields.body:
The pilot's reassuring voice came over the public address system as our Qantas 747 lumbered down the runway at Sydney airport: "We'll be taking off in a southerly direction." We could have reached our destination by going north, but it would have taken a lot longer.

Watch check: 8.20am. Our Sunday outing had begun. We were off to Antarctica. Ice. Cold. Sleds. Dogs. Huts. South Pole. Shackleton. Bold Roald Amundsen. Great Scott.

By any standards, we were an unusual mix: 80 Japanese - all prizewinners in a sweet-company competition - and a few assorted Western tourists for whom the next 12 hours would realise a lifelong dream.

Even the safety instructions offered something new as the screen demonstration (with Japanese subtitles) showed us how to don polar suits in the event of an unscheduled layover.

For the first four hours of the excursion - most of which was a beeline from cloud-covered Hobart to France's Dumont d'Urville base - we could have been anywhere.

Aeroplane breakfasts don't come much better (although I'm told it's possible to have an omelette with roast tomato and bacon in the comfort of your own home), but what makes the outbound journey memorable is the opportunity to digest the science and history of the seventh continent as presented by those who have lived and worked there.

There were four specialists on this particular flight: Pat Quilty, geologist and retired chief of the Australian Antarctic programme; Polar Medal-winner Syd Kirkby, who has surveyed more Antarctic territory than any other polar explorer; Di Patterson, the first woman appointed to run an Antarctic research station; and Warren Papworth, who knows more about emperor penguins than the penguins themselves.

Instead of inflight movies, we were entertained, awed and painlessly educated by live commentaries from our experts and a radio hook-up with the sub-Antarctic base at Macquarie Island.

Until roughly 160 million years ago, Antarctica was part of Gondwanaland - and then for reasons that are a bit mysterious, the party was over. It split up into what became the continents we know today.

I asked the bearded Papworth whether the scientific bases from 18 nations kept in close communication with one another (yes, safety in numbers), and had they agreed a single time zone, given that they were scattered around 360 degrees of separation.

Yes again, said Papworth: "It's centred on the Australian base of Davis, south of the Indian Ocean, which can be quite inconvenient for people on the opposite side of the ice - over at Mawson we call it Davis Bastard Time."

A few minutes before noon (Sydney Mean Bastard Time), Captain Dennis urged us all to bring out the compasses we'd been asked to stow. As I placed mine (a US army-surplus job bought in a Saigon market) on the lift-out tray, the needle veered away from north-south and began to spin wildly. We were passing directly over the South Magnetic Pole. Unlike the geographic Pole, its magnetic cousin is nomadic, moving about 6km a year.

As I peered through my window to the Southern Ocean below, the outermost floes were visible directly beneath the wing, resembling pieces of a vast natural jigsaw.

Then came something that looked much more out of place, a ship. Opposite it, alone on an island of ice, was an orange building, part of Dumont d'Urville.

Then we struck east along the coast before turning south over the Ross Ice Shelf, a sweeping gulf more than four times the size of Britain.

By the end of these middle four hours of the journey, we had seen crevasses - dark gashes in alabaster-white terrain - rills; curved-wall white cliffs falling into the sea like the folds of a tablecloth; tongues; powder ice; blue ice (even the scientists don't know what makes it so); and many varieties of glacier including drumlins (oval-shaped ridges), piedmonts (those at the foot of a mountain), cirques (hollow cavities on steep slopes) and, not least, your ordinary, merely magnificent rivers of ice sliding into the sea.

All this grandeur largely offsets any disappointment at not seeing a penguin, let alone a colony. The reasons are sound enough: to fly as low as you would need to see them well, the plane would have to buzz their rookeries (endangering their equanimity as well as, possibly, their long-term survival) and risk crashing into the plateau.

Due to an incorrect flight-path entry in the onboard computer, the first age of Antarctic tourism ended tragically in 1979, when a New Zealand passenger plane crashed into Erebus, the second mightiest Antarctic peak, and 257 lives were lost. The current tours began seven southern summers ago. As the charter organisers are at pains to point out, a lot was learned from the tragedy of 1979.

We seemed to glide down the massive gulf flanked on one side by the Transantarctics. Captain Dennis said it was "one of the loveliest mountain ranges on the surface of the Earth". As this was his 17th Antarctic encounter, he should know. But for me, the highlight of this unforgettable day trip was the concatenation of frozen cones whose most majestic peak, Mount Minto, soars more than 4,000m above the Ross ice shelf.

All too soon, it was time to bank around in a half-circle and embark on the final four hours back to Sydney and civilisation.

This is one trip that can certainly be recommended to those who want to spend "the real millennium" somewhere different: seats are still available on the New Year's Eve flight to the land where the sun truly never sets - well, not at this time of year anyway.

From November to February, the "season" for doing Antarctica, the weather is remarkably consistent: outside air temperature is around freezing but as sunny as the Costa del Sol in August (sunglasses are a highly-recommended accessory).

Because you won't be putting down anywhere, the journey is classed as a domestic flight, so - sad to say - you won't get an Antarctic stamp in your passport. But, by way of compensation, you will receive a handsome commemorative certificate declaring that you have crossed the Antarctic continent, "thereby joining the exclusive group of travellers who have achieved this feat".

Think of it: you, Robert Scott and Captain Lawrence ("I am just going outside and may be some time") Oates. Oh, and 17,000 other passengers carried on these charters since 1994, including 330 of us on that Guy Fawkes Day flight. Plus the crew and those Antarctic "experts" - scientists who have actually sunk their boots into the mushy substance 10,000ft below your feet.

The practicals

Prices from Sydney and Melbourne range from £308 (centre seat) to £1,279 (A$3,365). For special New Year's Eve flight, add £76. For Adelaide flight, add £38. The next flights depart Sydney and Melbourne Dec 31, Sydney Jan 14, Melbourne Jan 21, Adelaide Jan 28 and Sydney Feb 11. For reservations from Britain, contact: Connections Worldwide (01494 473173), World Market Travel (01225 486800), Travel Australia (01603 488664), Quest Worldwide Travel 020-8547 3322) or visit Antarctica Flights.

The stark truth about Antarctica

 Area: 14 million sq km, 99% ice-covered.

 More than two-thirds of the world's fresh water is trapped as ice in the Antarctic. If it all melted, global sea level would rise by about 65m.

 The largest iceberg ever recorded measured 210km by 97km.

 The Lambert Glacier is the largest in the world, 40km wide and 400km long.

 Lowest recorded tempera ture: -89.6C at USSR's Vostok station (July 1983).

 Annual mean temperature: -49C. Very mean.

 On average, the South Pole is 30C colder than the North Pole.

 Highest peak: Vinson Massif (5,140m).

 Antarctica is both the lowest continent (on basis of average height of the rock beneath the ice) and the highest (on basis of average height of the ice plateau).

 Antarctica is also the windiest continent. The average wind speed recorded at Mawson is 67km/h. The highest wind speed ever recorded was a gust of 327km/h at Dumont d'Urville in July 1972.

 Antarctica is actually a desert, receiving about the same precipitation (less than 50mm a year) as the Sahara.

 In summer, more daily solar radiation is received in Antarctica than at the Equator.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Esther Walsh
fields.trailText: My number one recommendation for accommodation and tours when staying in Hawaii is a place on the Big Island called Arnotts Lodge. I have to admit I didn't stay at Arnotts Lodge but we did two tours with them and honestly wished I had stayed there. For Hawaii, it is very cheap and if you stay at the Lodge the day trips are half price.
fields.body:
Hi Milly

Hope that all is going well with you. I have been to the Hawaii twice. First one was a typical girly holiday when I was 21 and I visited Oahu, Maui, Kauai and The Big Island. fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Cut-price Dome | Eurocheques end | Clot gel launched
fields.body:
Cut-price Dome

Christmas Eve entrance to the Dome in London has been cut to £1 and on Boxing Day the price has been reduced to £10. Dome ticket line 0870 6062000..

Eurocheques end

British banks are reminding their customers that they will stop issuing eurocheques from the end of the year and that banks abroad have been told that eurocheques issued by UK banks should not be cashed after that date.

Clot gel launched

A new gel has been launched to help prevent blood clots caused by sitting in cramped planes. Circulation Gel stimulates blood circulation thus reducing the risk of in-flight deep-vein thrombosis, according to the Watermark Group which supplies "onboard products" to over 70 airlines.

Chunnel birthday

The breakthrough in the Channel Tunnel was completed 10 years ago this week. The Chunnel now accounts for 11% of total visits by UK residents abroad and 12% of overseas residents' visits to the UK. Day trip fares to France start at £15. Eurotunnel.

New England choice

A new guide to New England - Connecticut, Maine, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, Rhode Island and Vermont - has been produced. It includes highlights of cuisine and things to do across the year as well as skiing and festivals. Tel: 0906 5588555 (£1 per minute, minimum two minutes).

YHA success

The YHA Penycwm, near Solva, which has a five-star rating for budget accommodation, has been judged the best place to eat off the beaten track by the Red Book - Eat Well in Wales. Room price for a couple is £28.

YHA Penycwm, Whitehouse, Penycwm, Haverfordwest Pembrokeshire SA62 6LA. Tel: 01437 721940.

Showtime

The Holiday Show 2001 will be held at the NEC near Birmingham between February 23-25. Over 300 exhibitors will be attending.

Express times

The Heathrow Express will run every 30 minutes on Christmas Day between 5.10am and 11.40pm. On Boxing Day, it will run every 15 minutes until 11.40pm. There is a normal service every 15 minutes on New Year's Day. Anyone checking in skis, snowboards or golf clubs at London's Paddington Station will receive free travel to the airport. This offer is valid until February 1.

fields.headline: Flying in comfort
fields.standfirst:
Does anyone know if the device called Earplanes really works? I suffer excruciating pain due to a damaged eardrum even when descending mountain roads in a car, so I have never dared to fly though I would really like to.
Pat Lacey
fields.trailText: Does anyone know if the device called Earplanes really works? I suffer excruciating pain due to a damaged eardrum even when descending mountain roads in a car, so I have never dared to fly though I would really like to.
fields.body:
 I have used Earplanes (bought at Boots for £4.49 a pair) for the past couple of years and, while the pain on descent does not disappear altogether, it is bearable and much less frightening. I have been told by my doctor that there is nothing wrong with my eardrums and I am probably just unlucky to have very narrow passageways connecting parts of the inner ear, which causes a greater build up of pressure.
Joan Winship

 My teenage son tried Earplanes a couple of years ago, but they did not prevent the pain. Perhaps the only solution would be a strong painkiller taken during the flight.
Susan Manville

 I bought a pair of Earplanes, having seen them advertised in Guardian Travel. Total relief of pain! However, I did experience "popping" in my ears after removing them on terra firma. I would not now fly without them.
Liz O'Brien

 Since using Earplanes, the pain has not been so severe, although I have had some discomfort. I suffer from catarrh, which I am told is the reason for the pain. I don't know if they work with a damaged eardrum.
Philip Muzlish

 I, too, have a damaged eardrum and have suffered dreadfully on landing, but this year, flying to Crete, I wore Earplanes and they really work.
Mary Crabtree

 My family tried out Earplanes for the first time this year. None of us suffered any of the usual pain and we would thoroughly recommend them, as long as you don't mind looking slightly ridiculous with blue plastic cones sticking out of your ears.
Penny Bradnum

webTitle: Tim Lennox: A mobile phone | Belgian chocolate | Favourite   records

fields.headline: Tim Lennox never travels without...
fields.trailText: A mobile phone | Belgian chocolate | Favourite records
fields.body:
A necessity: A mobile phone or a GameBoy. I need toys to keep me busy. There is always time to kill when you are travelling. I'm obsessed by the Internet at the moment so a WAP phone allows me to browse.

A luxury: Belgian chocolate. It is a great comforter. The first day abroad, before I meet anyone from the club, is often quite boring. Nine times out of 10, I am alone and sit in my hotel bedroom eating chocolate, watching TV, or surfing the Net.

A memento: I always take a small bag of rare, favourite records in my hand-luggage. Stuff that I know will work wherever I'm DJ-ing.

If only: A hovering record case that would follow me around. I tend to take about 200 records with me so my case is pretty heavy. I don't check the case in when I check in, but have to hand it in later to go in the hold, so that means carrying it for miles. Also, if I invented a hovering case, I'd make a fortune as every other DJ would want one, too.

 Tim Lennox's show on Galaxy Radio goes out Sundays at Midnight. He regularly DJs at Eden, Slinky, Golden, Cream and Progress.

fields.headline: Netjetters
fields.trailText: Hundreds of people e-mailed our Netjetters with advice after they set off last week on their six-month trips around the world. The trio, an 18-year-old gap student, a fed-up 28-year-old civil servant and a 51-year-old divorced mother of three, are keeping in touch with Netjetters each week and taking advice from web users around the world.
fields.body:
Hundreds of people e-mailed our Netjetters with advice after they set off last week on their six-month trips around the world. The trio, an 18-year-old gap student, a fed-up 28-year-old civil servant and a 51-year-old divorced mother of three, are keeping in touch with Netjetters each week and taking advice from web users around the world.

Sue Stubbings, the 51-year-old from Cambridge, has landed in Bombay and is finding it all very strange. Her first e-mail back starts: "Tired, bewildered and in sensory overload just about sums up how I am feeling. The flight and journey was all pretty uneventful, but then I hit India ... It certainly is a culture shock to come to Bombay as the first stop on my trip, but I have survived my first day and am getting into the swing of it slowly ... It is great to read the e-mails. I hope to respond to some when I have settled down a bit. Is it still raining back there? I am hungry - time to test out my constitution."

Sue has been getting e-mail from people who identify with her. Liz Mailer wrote: "I'm glad you're proving that backpacking round the world is not just for gap-year kids. I don't have any practical advice to offer as it's a while since I did much exotic travel, but I did go to Nepal about 16 years ago and had a terrific time. It's an incredibly beautiful and fascinating country and a lot different to India. So hope you have a marvellous time - I'll be following you on the website (and maybe in real life when my kids have grown up)."

Among the advice offered to Sue is: "When in Mumbai, eat at Vithal's (5 AK Naik Marg) on the street behind McDonald's outside the VT station, and try a Bels with a pot of tea - a snack with mung beans and curd."

A woman living in Mumbai (e-mailed by her mum in Lancashire) suggested finding Juhu Beach on a good map.

Another recommended that when in Kathmandu, where Sue is heading, the Kathmandu Guest House is the best place to stay and the only place where you don't have to give the rickshaw driver instructions.

Stuart and Lucie McKenzie wrote: "Do try to get to Jaisalmer, really worth the bus trip over the desert. Stay in the Hotel Jaisal Castle and watch the sun go down over the desert as the owner does his musical accompaniment to a cool beer. Have the stuffed paratha and curd for breakfast!! Really jealous, have lots of fun."

We have yet to hear from 18-year-old Milly Newman who is in Vancouver (she has let her mother know she arrived safely). Meanwhile Vancouverites have warmed to the task of giving her advice with thousands of words of guidance. Here is some of it, from Doug Mercer:

1 Jump on a bus and head to Whistler. The drive on the Sea-Sky highway is gorgeous, and Whistler's a cool place (although getting a bit too commercial).

2 Go to a restaurant at The Eatery (on Broadway Ave), in Kitsilano, and order a sushi combo plate. Yes, sushi! Trust me, it's awesome.

3 If you want to buy CDs, go to A&B Sound on Seymour St, downtown, where you'll find the cheapest CDs in the world.

4 Check out the Capilano suspension bridge. A bit touristy, but gorgeous nonetheless.

5 Check out the Museum of Anthropology at the University of British Columbia - some really cool artefacts and it'll give you a good sense of the lay of the land and its peoples before we whiteys found our way out here.

6 Catch a flick at the IMAX cinema at Canada Place.

7 Catch the bus on the corner of Granville and Broadway that'll take you to the ferry terminal where you'll then jump on the ferry to Schwartz Bay and bus it to Victoria. Nice place. Have a great time tumbleweeding around, enjoy the city.

Daniel Beedon said: "Don't even think of missing one of the crepe cafés on Robson Street. Excellent food, loads of fillings and great people. Go for banana and chocolate."

Sam Rowbury has made contact from New York, where he is wandering around thinking he's on the set of Cagney and Lacey or Hill Street Blues.

He has been getting advice about how to sort out his head - one of the reasons he has taken the trip. Teresa wrote: "Remember, you're on a trip to see the world and experience everyone's world, so just chill and enjoy. Do not bring your world with you. Stress is a waste of energy on any part of this trip."

Simon wrote: "Travel is lonely, hot, cold, frustrating, tiring. Travel is getting lost, panic rising when familiarity is only unfamiliarity - English (both spoken and physical) is non-existent, and creature comforts a dream away. Travel is quiet and excitement rolled together. Stillness and distance combined. Travel is solitary haunting existence experienced. Congratulations and enjoy your prize. I hope it gets you what you want from it."

But there are also some practical words. Mike's advice was: "You absolutely have to check out The Peculier Pub on Bleeker Street in the West Village when you're here - more beers than you can shake a stick at, including more than a few from Blighty. Also right next door to Terra Blues, so if you're into blues grab yourself a skinful at the Peculier, and head next door. And if you're into seafood head to the Upper East Side to Mo's Caribbean (2nd Avenue on the corner of 76th Street) - frozen margaritas and popcorn shrimp to die for."

To read our Netjetters' diaries, to hear them in their own words, see the photographs they are sending back and to read the advice - or send some of your own - go to Netjetters.
