fields.headline: Stocking fillers
fields.standfirst: Ros Taylor finds the best travel presents for Christmas
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor finds the best travel presents for Christmas
fields.body:
Gift vouchers are a perfect web purchase, but not all web retailers have realised it. Perhaps it's because only the more sophisticated checkouts allow you to redeem them online. It would be good to see all the low-cost airlines offering vouchers, but here's a selection of travellers' gifts that you can buy this Christmas.

The Worst-Case Scenario Survival Handbook
£4.99 (+postage)
Find out how to escape from a rampaging bear, survive a night on a bare mountain and fly a jet - all ideal post-Bond-movie fodder for fantasists. Currently Amazon's top-seller and consequently half price. Bear in mind that books bought as gifts incur VAT, so it may be cheaper to send them on yourself rather than pay the extra 17.5%.

£10, £20 or £50 flight vouchers to Go destinations
Unfortunately, it isn't possible to buy Go vouchers online and the telephone number isn't easy to find on the site (it's 0870 6076543). You can't redeem them online either.

Romer Compass
£14
This site specialises in branded outdoor kit. Consequently, it isn't cheap but will be appreciated by keen walkers, skiers and mountaineers. The cheapest items can be found in the Stocking Fillers section, and include whistles, first-aid kits, fleecy hats and an espresso maker for the less arduous sort of camping trip. Plus socks, of course.

Five large bars of Kendal Mint Cake
£4.95 (+£1 postage)
A friendly site for unpretentious walkers and climbers who want to buy their kit at a reasonable price. The Christmas gift suggestions include a blue boilersuit, top-quality wellies and mess tins.

Summer Festival Pack
£100 (reduced from £140)
No one planning to attend Glastonbury this year will know that you saved £40 on the tent, two sleeping bags, camp mats and bag. And delivery is free to boot. The summer walking pack (rucksack, poles, map case) is also on offer.

Supermatch Flexi Lighter
£18.50
The Supermatch FlexiLighter is, in truth, little more than a well-designed gas lighter, but its bendy stalk does allow you to ignite wicks in awkward places. And unlike a match, it won't burn your fingers. Plenty of similar gadgetry is available, including torches, flasks, vehicle kits and travel clocks.

Children's Map of the World
£4.99
A colourful version showing oversized ships and famous places. Stanfords also sells globes (some inflatable), reproductions and even a Unesco map of the seabed.

An evening or day at the Sanctuary, London
£35-£200
The Covent Garden spa is accepting orders until 1pm on December 23 for delivery by Christmas. Evening membership is £35 and offers the use of a swimming pool, whirlpool, sauna, steamroom and the Koi Carp Lounge. More expensive options involve Swedish massage, facials and lunch. Gift vouchers (£5-£100) can be bought here too.

fields.headline: Sneaker Balls
fields.trailText: Twist the balls open and leave them overnight in your pongy ski boots, trainers, gloves or gym bag. Next morning, they will smell like roses.
fields.body:
These trainers might launch me round the track like a rocket but they certainly are a bit whiffy, especially when you take them out of a suitcase. I've got just the solution. Stick a couple of these Sneaker Balls inside.

These rather bizarre looking golf balls with smiley faces? How is that going to help? All you do is twist the ball open and leave them overnight in your pongy ski boots, trainers, gloves or gym bag. Next morning, they will smell like roses, or more precisely like "orange vanilla", "wild berry" or "fresh and clean".

How long do they last? Up to six months. And the patented TX-3 odour blocker is said to deal with even the most severe nasty smells.

Why haven't I seen them before? You might have in the US, Canada, Australia or France, where they've sold 25 million pairs, but they've only just come to the UK.

Expensive? They cost £3.99 a pair from Avieda. Call 01799 526065 for stockists.

Don't they make walking rather uncomfortable? I don't think you've quite got the idea.

fields.headline: Wembley: Timetable of a farce
fields.trailText: 1998
fields.body:
1998

March 11: Wembley Stadium is sold for £103m to a Football Association/English Sports Council consortium ending months of wrangling.

July 24: Officials confirm that the famous Twin Towers will be demolished as part of the redevelopment programme.

July 29: Plans for the new stadium are officially unveiled. The impressive stadium design offers 'vastly improved facilities, superb spectator views and a huge arch, three times the height of the Twin Towers which will be visible across the whole of London'. Work is expected to start in the summer of 1999.

1999

December 2: Culture Secretary Chris Smith orders a re-design which would allow the Olympics to be held in an arena for which the proposed cost is now £475m.

December 22: Smith orders Wembley to be developed as a football-only venue and tells stadium officials to repay £20m of their £120m Sport England lottery grant.

2000

July 6: WNSL officials insists the redevelopment will go ahead despite England losing their 2006 World Cup bid.

fields.trailText: Your guide to the cheapest flights around
fields.body:
Six top destinations

Paris: £103
British Airways from Birmingham. Must be bought at least three days before departure. Valid for departures January 1 - December 31. Minimum stay one Saturday night, maximum one month. Trailfinders (0121-236 1234).

Hong Kong: £388
Cathay Pacific from Heathrow. Must be booked by January 15. Valid for departures February 1 - 28. Minimum stay three nights, maximum one month. Going Places Direct (0161-908 7967).

New York: £218
KLM from Manchester via Amsterdam. Must be booked by December 14. Valid for departures until December 13, then January 15 - March 15. No minimum stay, maximum one year. Thomas Cook Flights Direct (0870 7520066).

Amsterdam: £89
British Midland from Heathrow. Valid for departures until December 30. Minimum stay one Saturday night or two other nights. Going Places Direct (0161-908 7967).

Los Angeles: £245
Continental Airlines from Gatwick. Must be booked by December 11. Valid for departures until December 14, then December 25 - March 15. Minimum stay one Saturday night, maximum one month. Quest Travel (0870 4430745).

Sydney: £529
Japan Air Lines from Heathrow via Tokyo or Osaka. Overnight stay necessary on return flight. Airline pays for hotel. Valid for departures January 14 - April 30. No minimum stay, maximum one year. Far East Travel Centre (020-7437 8164).

The pick of the rest

Miami: £229
US Airways from Gatwick via Philadelphia or Charlotte. Must be booked by December 14. Full payment required when booking. Valid for departures January 5 - March 15. Minimum stay one Saturday night, maximum one month. Airline Network (01772 727272).

Venice: £120
British Airways from Heathrow. Must be booked by December 15. Valid for midweek departures December 25 - March 31 (weekend £130). Minimum stay one Saturday night, maximum one month. Thomas Cook Flights Direct (0870 7520066).

And the rail alternative

Paris/Brussels: £50 (Lille £45)
Same-day return. Must be bought at least one day before travel. Valid for departures any day, December 11 - January 7, then Saturdays and Sundays only, January 8 - February 11. Eurostar (08705 186186).

fields.headline: Return of the white suit
fields.standfirst: This time Bell has to run on his own merits
fields.trailText: This time Bell has to run on his own merits.
fields.body:
The man in the white suit has fast become a fixture in the House of Commons. Scan the chamber and you can always pick him out. People have got used to him being there and he admits he has come to like it. Now Martin Bell has let it be known that he would like to stay on in Westminster. He cannot remain as the member for Tatton, the seat he wrested from the sleaze-ridden Neil Hamilton in 1997, because he promised voters there that he would only serve one term as their MP. So he has had to go seat-hunting, lighting yesterday upon the Essex constituency of Brentwood and Ongar. Apparently Tories there approached Mr Bell to be their knight in a shining white suit amid some unusual claims that the local Conservative association had been infiltrated by 200-odd evangelical Christians.

Should Mr Bell do it? Of course he should. If he likes the MP's life, he has every right to try to extend it. He has already made something of a contribution in Westminster, speaking wisely on the Balkans, acting as a useful conscience on questions of party funding and parliamentary propriety and breaking the monotony of Westminster by serving as the chamber's only true independent. If he went, it would be the Commons' loss.

For all that, there is no reason for the former BBC war correspondent to be treated differently from any other independent seeking a seat at the next election. Mr Bell won Tatton in special circumstances: sleaze had so discredited Mr Hamilton, that the Liberal Democrats and Labour withdrew from the contest to allow the white suit a clear run. Bizarre accusations of evangelical entryism in Brentwood hardly amount to the same desperate need for Mr Bell's services: Labour and the Lib Dems are under no obligation to withdraw, especially when the latter have a decent chance of winning. So Mr Bell cannot run as the consensus candidate of anti-sleaze this time he will have to run on his own merits. And in that effort, we wish him luck.

webTitle: Bell called in on fight over safe Tory seat

fields.headline: Bell called in on fight over safe Tory seat
fields.trailText:
Martin Bell, the white-suited independent MP for Tatton, was hailed as "Ethics Man"
         yesterday as he announced his intention of fighting a Tory-held Essex seat allegedly
         infiltrated by a charismatic Christian church at the next election.
fields.body:
Martin Bell, the white-suited independent MP for Tatton, was hailed as "Ethics Man" yesterday as he announced his intention of fighting a Tory-held Essex seat allegedly infiltrated by a charismatic Christian church at the next election.

Amid Conservative allegations that he had been swayed by arguments of religious bigotry, the former BBC correspondent said he would contest Brentwood and Ongar - the Tories' sixth safest seat - unless voters inexplicably withdrew their support before then.

His decision came after he received 200 letters from voters of all parties anxious that the local Conservative association - and its MP, Eric Pickles - could be in danger of being manipulated by a wealthy evangelical sect, 119 of whose members had joined the party after the local council turned down their planning application.

The Peniel Pentecostal Church is run by a former insurance salesman turned evangelical bishop. He has reportedly said the unemployed should starve, and described Muslims as "vile people". The church has dismissed these allegations as "foul lies".

Mr Bell yesterday said he deeply regretted his promise during the 1997 election not to stand for Tatton a second time and his return to Westminster now looks set to be a struggle. Labour and the Liberal Democrats said they would not give him a clear run.

Mr Bell, who beat disgraced former minister Neil Hamilton in 1997 on an anti-sleaze ticket, stressed he was not accusing Mr Pickles of sleaze. But he said Conservative Central Office had been negligent when an inquiry concluded the local party was not guilty of malpractice despite the church members joining one branch on one day. "I do believe there was a problem of democratic process in the links between the Peniel Pentecostal Church and the Conservative association. Alarm bells should have been ringing."

He criticised Central Office for not interviewing lead witnesses, many of whom split from the party and formed the Independent Conservative Association. He said: "I think it's very hard to conclude this was a full investigation."

"This is not a question of sleaze, it's a question of democracy. In Tatton, although it seemed like sleaze, it was a question of democracy. What I was doing then I am doing now."

Tory Central Office - which spent the past week trying to encourage Mr Bell to stand against disgraced Labour MP Geoffrey Robinson - rallied around Mr Pickles, with the shadow Cabinet Office minister, Andrew Lansley, arriving in the constituency to lend him the party's "unequivocal support".

Michael Parrish, the local association chairman, accused Mr Bell of succumbing to the arguments of breakaway Tories that "have developed into religious bigotry and Nazism". Mr Pickles, who has a 9,600 majority, denied his association was unduly influenced. The controversy was due to "a personality dispute".

But Tony Donnelly, chairman of the breakaway Independent Conservative Association which first begged Mr Bell to stand, said: "The bishop has got Eric Pickles in a checkmate position ... but we have got a white knight. We're calling him our Ethics Man."

webTitle: Who lost their heart in Venice?

fields.headline: I lost my heart in... Venice
fields.standfirst: John Julius Norwich
fields.trailText: John Julius Norwich
fields.body:
Why: Because when I went there at the age of 16 I thought instantly that this was the most magical place I'd ever seen in my life. It was love at first sight. We arrived at about 11am and only stayed there until about 6pm. As we left, dusk was falling, the lights were coming on and the parties were beginning. I remember to this this day sitting in the gondola and having this aching sense of regret at leaving Venice.

What's the best thing: Almost every building is beautiful. Because it has been cut-off from the mainland, it has developed in entirely its own way and is quite different from every other Italian city. It is a pedestrian city. You won't see a car all the time you are there. Yet it still functions in the modern world.

My perfect day: I would begin with a lovely breakfast in front of the Pitti Palace hotel where you sit on a raft right out in the canal. Then I would set off on a long walk to a bit of Venice I don't know so well, dropping in at the occasional church. I'd have a nap after lunch and go out again at about 4pm when the heat had died down. In the evening I would have dinner outside and watch the whole of Venice passing by. It would be autumn - September or October.

My advice: Make sure that you get a room looking out on to the water or on to a square not on to the back alleys. Then you should get away from St Mark's Square and aim to get lost. It's easy to do but with a good map you will find it easy to get back. Also, whatever the cost, you should take a gondola trip once. Do it at night and ask to go through the little canals. On a summer's night, it is the most beautiful thing you will ever do in your life.

How do I get there: Ryanair (08701 569569) flies Stansted to Venice for £14 one way. For other fares, see Tickets to Ride.

 Still More Christmas Crackers by John Julius Norwich is published by Viking at £16.99.

webTitle: Travel: Where to ski for Christmas

fields.headline: White Christmas?
fields.standfirst: Roger Bray finds out what's still available over the festive season
fields.trailText: Roger Bray finds out what's still available over the festive season.
fields.body:
For the keen skier, the merest flurry of snow can make the thought of retrieving skis or snowboard from the attic too much to resist. Word from the mountains has been mixed but far from discouraging.

Heavy early storms have brought good early skiing to much of North America, where Colorado resorts such as Vail and Winter Park report a base of around two feet and Canada's Whistler claims more than three. Conditions in the Alps remain patchy, though some runs are already open in the higher areas. As the Christmas and New Year holidays loom, what are the options for a late escape?

Make your own way to the Alps and you should still find self-catering accommodation. Motours (01892 677777) has some studios available for Christmas at Brides Les Bains and Val Thorens for £309 and £484 respectively, including a SeaFrance crossing. Eurotunnel costs £25 extra. Motours says New Year has not proved as popular and there is still plenty of space in the main resorts. It is even getting discounts from apartment operators in Avoriaz, Belle Plagne and Alpe d'Huez. That brings the price of a holiday in an apartment sleeping five in Avoriaz, including crossings, down from £979 to £799, for example.

And Erna Low (020-7584 2841) has knocked 20% off the price of some self-drive holidays to France. It can offer two-room apartments in Belle Plagne or Avoriaz starting on December 30 at £170 or £190 respectively for each of four sharing.

Family holiday specialist Ski Esprit (01252 618300) has some space at New Year with flights from Manchester on December 31. Barring air-traffic control or weather problems, customers should reach their accommodation by mid afternoon. It can offer a choice of chalets in Morzine, a small-town resort with big skiing.

It has considerably more atmosphere than some of the high, French purpose-built resorts and is connected to the vast Portes du Soleil lift network on the Franco-Swiss border. Packages start at £710 for adults and £355 for children. That's a week's half-board with wine thrown in - though there is no dinner on the chalet staff's day off - with high teas for children and a night's baby-sitting.

Panorama (01273 427777) says Christmas sold out so quickly that it has precious little left. But for those looking for some serious New Year's Eve partying, it can offer a week's half-board at the three-star Hotel Sauze in Italy's Sauze d'Oulx with a flight from Gatwick on December 31 for £369 - based on two sharing a room. Night life in Sauze was so riotous that it became known as "Benidorm on Snow". Lately, it has been promoting a more sober image, but even so it is probably not best recommended to those seeking a quiet glass of champagne at midnight and a sound night's sleep.

Pas de la Casa in Andorra can be lively, too. The firm can offer a week's half-board with departures on December 31 from Stansted for £349 or from Bristol for £379.

First Choice (0870 7543477) has very few holidays left over Christmas, though it can offer a week's B&B in Mayrhofen, with a flight from Birmingham on December 23 for £379. It also has space in Andorra's Pas de la Casa for one week, half-board, leaving Glasgow on the same day and for the same price. And for those prepared to fly from Gatwick on Christmas Eve, it can also offer a week's half-board in the French resort of Serre Chevalier for £389.

First Choice says finding something for New Year is a little easier, "particularly if you are flexible on where you want to go since some resorts are full". For example, it has self-catering holidays in the Trois Vallées at Les Menuires, with a flight from Newcastle on December 29, for £389 and at La Plagne, also in France and departing from Bristol the following day, for £399. It can also offer a week in Austria's St Wolfgang, with a flight from Birmingham on December 30, for £479.

Andorra and Italy's Cervinia and Livigno are good choices for early intermediate skiers, and Thomson (0870 6061470) has one-week packages available to all three. Departure to Cervinia is on Christmas Eve from Gatwick, so you'll need to check ahead to find somewhere to eat out. The holiday costs £295 in a studio for four.

Or, perhaps better, you can go for half-board in Livigno, also with a flight from Gatwick, but on December 23. Flights to Andorra are from Bristol and from Manchester to Toulouse on New Year's Eve. Holidays are self-catering and cost £279, £299 or £369, depending on the standard of accommodation. The firm is offering free drinks and food at a New Year bash.

Christmas in Colorado is on offer from Crystal Holidays (0870 848 7000). A week in a chalet at Breckenridge, Vail, Winter Park or Steamboat costs £749. Flights are with United Airlines from Heathrow, leaving on December 20 - so you should have enough time to get over jet leg and adjust to the altitude in time to enjoy a festive dinner.

Departures from Leeds/Bradford, Manchester, Teesside, Belfast, Edinburgh or Glasgow are available for a supplement of £39 to cover domestic flights. Accommodation is in chalets and the price, which is based on two sharing a room, includes breakfast, afternoon tea and three-course evening meals with wine.

Crystal also has chalet space in Selva, in the Italian Dolomites, with a flight on Christmas Eve from Gatwick. For New Year, it has some packages available to Sauze d'Oulx. They include a week's half-board from £399. Flights are available from Gatwick on New Year's Eve and, for an extra payment, from other airports - but there is no single supplement. Crystal also has space at a "Club Hotel" in Bardonecchia, with afternoon tea and wine with dinner included in a full-board deal, for £479. Departure is from Gatwick, also on December 31.

Ski Independence (0870 5550555) says it can find Christmas flights to Colorado "provided you come back before New Year". It is also still possible to fly to Vancouver - jumping-off point for Whistler - via US airports. The firm has eight-night chalet holidays in Canada's up-and-coming Fernie or Colorado's Winter Park, with scheduled flights departing between December 19 and 23 inclusive, for £819.

It can also offer one-week packages to Vail (The Chateau, £1,398) and Breckenridge (The Village, £1,279) - these prices include free domestic connecting flights to Heathrow from regional airports - and to Whistler (The Coast, £1,386).

The drinks bill could be heavy, but the attractive resort of Åre in northern Sweden would otherwise be perfect. Its relatively gentle slopes are not for those in search of steep thrills but if the snow is good the village should have a real Christmas-card look. Neilson (08705 141414) has one-week half-board holidays there, with a flight on December 24 from Heathrow for £565.

Neilson says it is "very nearly sold out" for the whole holiday period but it still can still offer New Year breaks in two other destinations with departures on December 30. They are Jasper in Canada (two weeks, room only, with a flight from Gatwick, for £609) and Livigno - one week, B&B, with a departure from Manchester for £399.

In Bulgaria, on the other hand, the drinks bill will be extremely modest. Inghams (020-8780 4444) is full for Christmas but can offer a half-board holiday for £358 at the Bulgarian resort of Borovets, with flights from Manchester or Birmingham on December 30. It also has chalet space left in Selva. Departures are on the same day from Manchester or Exeter, and the price is £657.
fields.bodyText: For the keen skier, the merest flurry of snow can make the thought of retrieving skis or snowboard from the attic too much to resist. Word from the mountains has been mixed but far from discouraging. Heavy early storms have brought good early skiing to much of North America, where Colorado resorts such as Vail and Winter Park report a base of around two feet and Canada's Whistler claims more than three. Conditions in the Alps remain patchy, though some runs are already open in the higher areas. As the Christmas and New Year holidays loom, what are the options for a late escape? Make your own way to the Alps and you should still find self-catering accommodation. Motours (01892 677777) has some studios available for Christmas at Brides Les Bains and Val Thorens for £309 and £484 respectively, including a SeaFrance crossing. Eurotunnel costs £25 extra. Motours says New Year has not proved as popular and there is still plenty of space in the main resorts. It is even getting discounts from apartment operators in Avoriaz, Belle Plagne and Alpe d'Huez. That brings the price of a holiday in an apartment sleeping five in Avoriaz, including crossings, down from £979 to £799, for example. And Erna Low (020-7584 2841) has knocked 20% off the price of some self-drive holidays to France. It can offer two-room apartments in Belle Plagne or Avoriaz starting on December 30 at £170 or £190 respectively for each of four sharing. Family holiday specialist Ski Esprit (01252 618300) has some space at New Year with flights from Manchester on December 31. Barring air-traffic control or weather problems, customers should reach their accommodation by mid afternoon. It can offer a choice of chalets in Morzine, a small-town resort with big skiing. It has considerably more atmosphere than some of the high, French purpose-built resorts and is connected to the vast Portes du Soleil lift network on the Franco-Swiss border. Packages start at £710 for adults and £355 for children. That's a week's half-board with wine thrown in - though there is no dinner on the chalet staff's day off - with high teas for children and a night's baby-sitting. Panorama (01273 427777) says Christmas sold out so quickly that it has precious little left. But for those looking for some serious New Year's Eve partying, it can offer a week's half-board at the three-star Hotel Sauze in Italy's Sauze d'Oulx with a flight from Gatwick on December 31 for £369 - based on two sharing a room. Night life in Sauze was so riotous that it became known as "Benidorm on Snow". Lately, it has been promoting a more sober image, but even so it is probably not best recommended to those seeking a quiet glass of champagne at midnight and a sound night's sleep. Pas de la Casa in Andorra can be lively, too. The firm can offer a week's half-board with departures on December 31 from Stansted for £349 or from Bristol for £379. First Choice (0870 7543477) has very few holidays left over Christmas, though it can offer a week's B&B in Mayrhofen, with a flight from Birmingham on December 23 for £379. It also has space in Andorra's Pas de la Casa for one week, half-board, leaving Glasgow on the same day and for the same price. And for those prepared to fly from Gatwick on Christmas Eve, it can also offer a week's half-board in the French resort of Serre Chevalier for £389. First Choice says finding something for New Year is a little easier, "particularly if you are flexible on where you want to go since some resorts are full". For example, it has self-catering holidays in the Trois Vallées at Les Menuires, with a flight from Newcastle on December 29, for £389 and at La Plagne, also in France and departing from Bristol the following day, for £399. It can also offer a week in Austria's St Wolfgang, with a flight from Birmingham on December 30, for £479. fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Esther Walsh
fields.trailText: Hope everything is going OK. I agree with the recommendation that you received on the Kathmandu Guest House.
fields.body:
Hi Sue,

Hope everything is going OK.

I agree with the recommendation that you received on the Kathmandu Guest House. I travelled to Nepal about five years ago with my husband and another couple, and we organised all our tours through a company called Himalayan Encounter (from memory they have a spot near or even within the grounds at the Guest House).

In the Guardian travel questions this week, someone asked the question about Nepal to the effect what company could they approach to do a trek that treats its porters very well. What I SHOULD have asked (to my eternal shame I didn't) is the following, and you may agree with me. If you are going beyond the snowline or even near to it, check out how well your porters will be equipped. We found that the senior porters did have decent gear but generally speaking the majority did not. We did get near to the snowline but had to turn back since it was lower than expected - hence the trek was shortened, but we weren't complaining. However, we did have to spend one freezing night there. We were OK, but the majority of our porters passed an uncomfortable night. I look back upon that one night with some shame; it was far too cold for the porters. Good luck!

fields.headline: Trekking in Nepal
fields.standfirst:
We are planning a trekking trip to Nepal in October/November 2001. We intend to organise our own flights, and our own time either side of a trek. However, we would like to arrange the trek from the UK well in advance. Can anyone recommend a good company that does not exploit its sherpas?
Joanna Bird
fields.trailText: We are planning a trekking trip to Nepal in October/November 2001. We intend to organise our own flights, and our own time either side of a trek. However, we would like to arrange the trek from the UK well in advance. Can anyone recommend a good company that does not exploit its sherpas?
fields.body:
 Classic Journeys (33 High Street, Tibshelf, Alfreton, Derbyshire, DE55 5NX, tel: 01773 873497) is concerned about the wellbeing of its porters and also sensitive to the need to protect the local environment and preserve Nepalese cultural traditions and way of life.
Richard Willmott

 Rinzin Tamang (Yogesh) (GPO Box 8974 CPC 289 Kathmandu, Nepal, www.Karmatreks.com, email: yogi-trek@hotmail.com) started his trekking career with one of the well-known companies, and about three years ago set up on his own, realising that a large proportion of the money paid by trekkers never reached local pockets. On my trek, one porter was his friend, the other his brother-in-law. I certainly felt that neither of them was being exploited. All arrangements were made by email or post before leaving the UK, although no payment was made until reaching Nepal, and the cost was less than the rate for similar treks advertised in the UK.
Davis Clarke

 Next year, I will be making my fifth trek with Yogesh Tamang.
Simon Furze

 Muir's Tours (non-profit), Reading, tel: 0118 9502281 (www.nkf-mt.org.uk, email: info@nkf-mt.org.uk).
 The Nepal Trust (Scottish charity), Moray, Scotland, tel: 01343 810358 (www.thenepaltrust.demon.co.uk, email: admin@thenepaltrust.demon.co.uk).
 Tribes Travel, Suffolk tel: 01728 685971 (www.tribes.co.uk, email: ctg@tribes.co.uk).

 For flight bookings, I recommend North South Travel - a travel agency contributing profits towards support for projects in the developing world.
Roy Dey-Graff

Every trekker with Nepalese Trails has their own individual porter to carry a bag which must weigh no more than 15kg. With so many porters, everyone can walk at their own pace. And they are very competitively priced.
Marnie Sweet

 Nepalese Trails has a passion for Nepal and its people. Their porters have become their friends, and are treated with great care and respect.
Cath Webley

 Tenji Sherpa is the ideal soluation. Tenji is one of several brothers who have formed a small family trekking company based in Kathmandu, called Sherpa Brothers. You can contact him at tsherpa@mos.com.np and discuss your requirements. He can arrange everything and in all probability will accompany you on the trek, hence no middlemen. He and I recently trekked in the Solu Khumbu, and largely due to his care and expertise, I had a memorable, inexpensive time among his own Sherpa people.
Al Parrott

 I belong to the U3A Travel Network which organises educational and cultural tours for its members. The group has run tours in Nepal, Tibet and Bhutan using a tour company in Kathmandu run by an ex-Gurhka called Ram Prasad Gurung. I met Ram earlier this year when I was in Kathmandu and he is knowledgeable and flexible. He uses Gurhka guides from his home town of Pokhara and will tailor a tour to suit anyone, and is prepared to organise tours anywhere on the Indian sub-continent.
Dennis Johnson

 Narayan Gurung took us on a marvellous trek in Nepal a couple of years ago and we are still in touch. He speaks excellent English and can be reached by email at lalman@wlink.com.np. Alternatively his address is GPO Box 11629, Kathmandu, Nepal. You don't need to use a trekking company to trek around much of Nepal. Most of the main trekking routes have plenty of accommodation available, and by using it you are putting money into the local economy. For the Everest trek, just get the bus from Kathmandu to Jiri, then employ local porters who can be hired on the spot from nearby villages, for wages that we would consider derisory. Try the village of Kenja, a day's walk from Jiri where the Everest trek starts. Walk there yourself or send a messenger. By employing people from the villages, you give new opportunities and much needed cash to some of the poorest people on earth. It's all cheaper and easier than you think; food and accommodation are available everywhere and the route is simple to follow. You just need someone to carry your kit. Get good maps and a guidebook; travel light and don't demand too many western 'luxuries'. Finally, don't be tempted to shorten the distance by flying to Lukla. Walk there instead, it will get you fit and acclimatise you gradually, thus avoiding the potential for altitude sickness.
Rob Widders

 I would highly recommend a Canadian trekking company called Everest Trekking owned by Gord Konantz. The company organizes treks through Nepal and Tibet. Gord and his wife Gail are usually present on most of the treks. The Nepal operations are run by Tashi Sherpa, a professional mountain climber who lives with his family in Kathmandu. I travelled with Everest Trekking three years ago through the Annapurna area. We were asked to bring any used clothing we had along with us, so that it could be distributed among the sherpas and guides after our trek. The guides were thrilled with this. Check out their website at www.everesttrekking.com. It provides further information on their community work in Nepal.
Ann Pawluk

 We did exactly this a few months ago. We booked our trekking and other activities (including local transport, hotels, and visit to Chitwan Park) directly with Gorkha Treks. We gave them outline itinerary and they quoted all inclusive price. Write to Mr DB Gurung, at dbgurung@mos.com.nep. We were particularly pleased that our porters were not overloaded at any stage of the trek. This was definitely not the case with some other parties we saw. This was a great holiday in a beautiful country with marvellous people - we can't wait to go again!
Fred and Jill Brotherton

 I have twice enjoyed a memorable trekking holiday with Roama Travel of Shroton, Blandford, Dorset. It is a small family business (ABTA registered) whose daughter is married to a Nepali with offices in Kathmandu. This year I trekked/camped alone with 10 Nepalis for 12 days and saw only four tourists. Camping is the only way to see Nepal. Avoid the more popular tea house treks that stick to well worn trails. They have no fixed itineraries, but will arrange anything you like. Intimate knowledge of Nepal and all profits go to support charities and schools in Nepal. Contact Bill Norman at roama@city2000.net.
David Patten

 I can thoroughly recommend a local company - Gurudongma Tours & Treks. It's run by a delightful retired Lieutenant General, Jimmy Singh, and is very efficient and also friendly, ecologically sound and very good to all the staff they employ. Also all your money goes to help local people. They operate all over the Eastern Himalaya. You can contact them on gurutt@dte.vsnl.net.in, or at Gurudongma House, Hilltop Road, Kalimpong, West Bengal, India.
Maureen Blake

 I have trekked in Nepal twice with Richard and Shari Ravensdale who own Five Valleys Treks and run a small charity, Trekaid, which supports Tibetan refugee villages in Nepal. Their sherpas are employed on a salaried basis all year round, the head sherpa is also a co-director of the firm. Prices are very reasonable, probably partly due to using Aeroflot! Contact at 2 Somerset Cottages, Stoke Village, Plymouth, tel: 01752-567617.
Pam Scroop

 I would recommend Joanna contact Lama Parivar, Kay and David White, email kay@lamaparivar.freeserve.co.uk. They can arrange treks with either full services, or only a porter and guide. We went on a trek some years ago with them, from Lukla towards Everest, and were impressed by their organisation, which is a joint Anglo/Nepalese one. The Sherpas were part of the team, not exploited labour. Kay White is also raising money and supplies for a village in the mountains.
Denis Bates

 I recommend that you contact Carl Harrison, PO Box 2109, Kathmandu, Nepal, email carl@bighills.wlink.com.np. Carl has been organising treks in Nepal for several years and specialises in treks for individuals.
Norman Hargreaves

 We recommend Nepalese Trails at Random Cottage, Pentre, Llanfyllin, Powys, SY22 5LE, Wales. Tel: 01691 648851. Email neptrail@hotmail.com. We had a great holiday earlier this year, and Barry and Bridget are very caring of their porters, many of whom have been with them for some years. They speak the language and support local schools and other projects.
Keith & Pat Williams

 I can heartily recommend Summit Trekking, based in Kathmandu. I trekked with them two years ago, and found them to be an excellent company. The sherpas were fantastic, and well looked after. The company was booked by Scope for their sponsored treks, which is a recommendation in itself. You will find Summit Trekking at the Summit Hotel (PO Box 1406), Kupondol Height, in the Lalitpur district, or email summtreck@trekking.wlink.com.np.
Doug Stratton

 I and several friends have just returned from Nepal. We did all the arranging from this end by email with a Nepali sirdar we had met on a previous trip. We too were concerned about the exploitation - especially of porters who often are poorly equipped for higher altitudes and often totally uninsured by the company. These are concerns that you must sort out before going. Our group of 11 people from the UK flew out with Qatar Airways. All our porters were well equipped and very happy! A trip like this (we climbed a peak in the 22-day trek and then went to North India for a week) doesn't need to cost an arm and a leg - our total was about £1,500 and we didn't rough it. Contact Saroj Neupane of Beyond the Limits Trekking in Kathmandu. Email blimits@ntc.net.np.
Chris Walker

 Two years ago, after I retired, my husband and I went on a three-month round-the-world trip, which we organised with the help of Trailfinders. Our final destination was Kathmandu. We weren't fit enough for proper Himalayan two-three week treks but we wanted to walk in the hills around Kathmandu Valley. We had acquired our own driver by chance at the airport, and if he couldn't arrange something for us, he knew someone who could. He took us to Galaxy Trekking and Expedition Ltd on Durbar Marg (it's upstairs so not easily spotted). The staff were very helpful and one spoke excellent English. We booked a two-day 'mini' trek to Nagarkot and back, with a night in a small hotel overlooking the Himalayas, three meals, transport to and from the start and finish point, and a Sherpa guide, Sanu Gurung, just for us. Sanu was patient, courteous without being deferential, informative, with good English and a sense of humour. Our outward trek was only for about 4 hours, with a "lunch break" in the middle. We'd only put water and biscuits in our small rucksack with basic overnight things, to keep the weight down, though Sanu insisted on carrying it! We have corresponded with Sanu since, and last year he decided to set up his own company - Naturel and Trekking and Expedition(P) Ltd which also arranges safaris, whitewater rafting etc. The address is PO Box 20560, Thamel, Bhagawati Bahal, Kathmandu, tel 423283 and 4116804, fax: 00977-1-423283, email natureland@htp.com.np.
Janet Blackburn

 My husband is Nepali, and although now living in England he has worked as a trekking guide in the Annapurna region of Nepal for 10 years. Naturally, he is acutely aware of the issues facing both porters and guides and spent quite some time supporting the rights of porters. We would recommend that the only way to really guarantee the fair treatment of your guides and porters is to communicate directly with them and find out about their pay and conditions and support them further if necessary. We would be very happy to offer you any further information or first hand advice about trekking or travelling in Nepal in general. We can also recommend highly experienced and reliable independent guides to you if you decide to arrange a trek from this country without using an agency.
Sam and Guru Sharma mountaingurus@yahoo.com.

 I strongly recommend Yogesh Tamang who arranges tailor-made treks. See www.karmartreks.com or contact yogi_trek@hotmail.com. I am travelling with Yogesh for the fifth time in September for three weeks in the Langtang area.

 I have been trekking three times in Nepal, and recommend Wilderness Experience Pvt. Ltd, GPO. Box 4065, Gyaneshor, Kathmandu, Nepal; tel: 977-1-417832, fax 977-1-417243; email wildex@ecomail.com.np, www.cadvision.com/wilderness. They are experienced, reliable and efficient.
John Vernon

 I can thoroughly recommend Nilgiri Treks and Mountaineering if you want to organise a supported trek in Nepal. I have used them twice and am hoping to organise another trek with them in Autumn 2001. Several friends have also used them both for trekking and for climbing. Da Gombu Sherpa is the owner (he is a UIAGM Guide with high altitude experience) and he can be contacted by email at Chereme@gombu.wlink.com.np.

 I would like to recommend Pasang Lama as a good reliable guide for trekking in Nepal. Pasang takes great care of the local environment, and makes sure that he spreads trekker's income around, by ensuring that money for food and accommodation goes directly to people in local villages. He also pays his sherpas and porters at well above the minimum rate, ensures they are properly clothed, and that the porters carry less than the recommended amount. Porters and sherpas will also eat the same food as their trekking clients. He can be contacted in Nepal on plama@plama.wlink.com.np or in the UK on mcarrott@lineone.net.

 We did a DIY trekking and touring trip to Nepal late last year. Our trek was organised by Lhakpa Sherpa and his UK contact Pat Steel. The organisation was faultless. As well as saving a lot on commercial prices we felt that we were making a worthwhile contribution to Lhakpa's village community. Pat Steel can be contacted on 015395 64122.
Caroline Eustace

Sublime Treks and Excursions Limited is a Kathmandu-based trekking company started by a group of local people from the Helambu region of Nepal. Apart from paying a fair wage, it is one of the few Nepalese companies that invests in training its staff and provides free schooling to the porters' children. They have an office in the UK at 3 Park Road, Shipley, BD18 2JU, W Yorks, tel 01274 593551) or email GoNepal@aol.com.
Gopal Lama

 Nuru Jangbu Sherpa is a young man setting up his own trekking business. His email address is nurusherpa@hotmail.com. I went trekking with Explore Worldwide in 1999 and he was one of the sherpas for the trip. I would recommend him highly.
Hilary Bagshaw

Rob Widders  I would highly recommend a Canadian trekking company called Everest Trekking owned by Gord Konantz. The company organizes treks through Nepal and Tibet. Gord and his wife Gail are usually present on most of the treks. The Nepal operations are run by Tashi Sherpa, a professional mountain climber who lives with his family in Kathmandu. I travelled with Everest Trekking three years ago through the Annapurna area. We were asked to bring any used clothing we had along with us, so that it could be distributed among the sherpas and guides after our trek. The guides were thrilled with this. Check out their website at www.everesttrekking.com. It provides further information on their community work in Nepal. Ann Pawluk  We did exactly this a few months ago. We booked our trekking and other activities (including local transport, hotels, and visit to Chitwan Park) directly with Gorkha Treks. We gave them outline itinerary and they quoted all inclusive price. Write to Mr DB Gurung, at dbgurung@mos.com.nep. We were particularly pleased that our porters were not overloaded at any stage of the trek. This was definitely not the case with some other parties we saw. This was a great holiday in a beautiful country with marvellous people - we can't wait to go again! Fred and Jill Brotherton  I have twice enjoyed a memorable trekking holiday with Roama Travel of Shroton, Blandford, Dorset. It is a small family business (ABTA registered) whose daughter is married to a Nepali with offices in Kathmandu. This year I trekked/camped alone with 10 Nepalis for 12 days and saw only four tourists. Camping is the only way to see Nepal. Avoid the more popular tea house treks that stick to well worn trails. They have no fixed itineraries, but will arrange anything you like. Intimate knowledge of Nepal and all profits go to support charities and schools in Nepal. Contact Bill Norman at roama@city2000.net. David Patten  I can thoroughly recommend a local company - Gurudongma Tours & Treks. It's run by a delightful retired Lieutenant General, Jimmy Singh, and is very efficient and also friendly, ecologically sound and very good to all the staff they employ. Also all your money goes to help local people. They operate all over the Eastern Himalaya. You can contact them on gurutt@dte.vsnl.net.in, or at Gurudongma House, Hilltop Road, Kalimpong, West Bengal, India. Maureen Blake  I have trekked in Nepal twice with Richard and Shari Ravensdale who own Five Valleys Treks and run a small charity, Trekaid, which supports Tibetan refugee villages in Nepal. Their sherpas are employed on a salaried basis all year round, the head sherpa is also a co-director of the firm. Prices are very reasonable, probably partly due to using Aeroflot! Contact at 2 Somerset Cottages, Stoke Village, Plymouth, tel: 01752-567617. Pam Scroop  I would recommend Joanna contact Lama Parivar, Kay and David White, email kay@lamaparivar.freeserve.co.uk. They can arrange treks with either full services, or only a porter and guide. We went on a trek some years ago with them, from Lukla towards Everest, and were impressed by their organisation, which is a joint Anglo/Nepalese one. The Sherpas were part of the team, not exploited labour. Kay White is also raising money and supplies for a village in the mountains. Denis Bates  I recommend that you contact Carl Harrison, PO Box 2109, Kathmandu, Nepal, email carl@bighills.wlink.com.np. Carl has been organising treks in Nepal for several years and specialises in treks for individuals. Norman Hargreaves  We recommend Nepalese Trails at Random Cottage, Pentre, Llanfyllin, Powys, SY22 5LE, Wales. Tel: 01691 648851. Email neptrail@hotmail.com. We had a great holiday earlier this year, and Barry and Bridget are very caring of their porters, many of whom have been with them for some years. They speak the language and support local schools and other projects. Keith & Pat Williams  I can heartily recommend Summit Trekking, based in Kathmandu. I trekked with them two years ago, and found them to be an excellent company. The sherpas were fantastic, and well looked after. The company was booked by Scope for their sponsored treks, which is a recommendation in itself. You will find Summit Trekking at the Summit Hotel (PO Box 1406), Kupondol Height, in the Lalitpur district, or email summtreck@trekking.wlink.com.np. Doug Stratton  I and several friends have just returned from Nepal. We did all the arranging from this end by email with a Nepali sirdar we had met on a previous trip. We too were concerned about the exploitation - especially of porters who often are poorly equipped for higher altitudes and often totally uninsured by the company. These are concerns that you must sort out before going. Our group of 11 people from the UK flew out with Qatar Airways. All our porters were well equipped and very happy! A trip like this (we climbed a peak in the 22-day trek and then went to North India for a week) doesn't need to cost an arm and a leg - our total was about £1,500 and we didn't rough it. Contact Saroj Neupane of Beyond the Limits Trekking in Kathmandu. Email blimits@ntc.net.np. Chris Walker  Two years ago, after I retired, my husband and I went on a three-month round-the-world trip, which we organised with the help of Trailfinders. Our final destination was Kathmandu. We weren't fit enough for proper Himalayan two-three week treks but we wanted to walk in the hills around Kathmandu Valley. We had acquired our own driver by chance at the airport, and if he couldn't arrange something for us, he knew someone who could. He took us to Galaxy Trekking and Expedition Ltd on Durbar Marg (it's upstairs so not easily spotted). The staff were very helpful and one spoke excellent English. We booked a two-day 'mini' trek to Nagarkot and back, with a night in a small hotel overlooking the Himalayas, three meals, transport to and from the start and finish point, and a Sherpa guide, Sanu Gurung, just for us. We'd only put water and biscuits in our small rucksack with basic overnight things, to keep the weight down, though Sanu insisted on carrying it! Janet Blackburn  My husband is Nepali, and although now living in England he has worked as a trekking guide in the Annapurna region of Nepal for 10 years. Naturally, he is acutely aware of the issues facing both porters and guides and spent quite some time supporting the rights of porters. We would be very happy to offer you any further information or first hand advice about trekking or travelling in Nepal in general. We can also recommend highly experienced and reliable independent guides to you if you decide to arrange a trek from this country without using an agency. Sam and Guru Sharma mountaingurus@yahoo.com.  I strongly recommend Yogesh Tamang who arranges tailor-made treks. See www.karmartreks.com or contact yogi_trek@hotmail.com. I am travelling with Yogesh for the fifth time in September for three weeks in the Langtang area.  I have been trekking three times in Nepal, and recommend Wilderness Experience Pvt. Ltd, GPO. Box 4065, Gyaneshor, Kathmandu, Nepal; tel: 977-1-417832, fax 977-1-417243; email wildex@ecomail.com.np, www.cadvision.com/wilderness. They are experienced, reliable and efficient. John Vernon  I can thoroughly recommend Nilgiri Treks and Mountaineering if you want to organise a supported trek in Nepal. I have used them twice and am hoping to organise another trek with them in Autumn 2001. Several friends have also used them both for trekking and for climbing. Da Gombu Sherpa is the owner (he is a UIAGM Guide with high altitude experience) and he can be contacted by email at Chereme@gombu.wlink.com.np.  I would like to recommend Pasang Lama as a good reliable guide for trekking in Nepal. Pasang takes great care of the local environment, and makes sure that he spreads trekker's income around, by ensuring that money for food and accommodation goes directly to people in local villages. He also pays his sherpas and porters at well above the minimum rate, ensures they are properly clothed, and that the porters carry less than the recommended amount. Porters and sherpas will also eat the same food as their trekking clients. He can be contacted in Nepal on plama@plama.wlink.com.np or in the UK on mcarrott@lineone.net.  We did a DIY trekking and touring trip to Nepal late last year. Our trek was organised by Lhakpa Sherpa and his UK contact Pat Steel. The organisation was faultless. As well as saving a lot on commercial prices we felt that we were making a worthwhile contribution to Lhakpa's village community. Pat Steel can be contacted on 015395 64122. Caroline Eustace Sublime Treks and Excursions Limited is a Kathmandu-based trekking company started by a group of local people from the Helambu region of Nepal. Apart from paying a fair wage, it is one of the few Nepalese companies that invests in training its staff and provides free schooling to the porters' children. They have an office in the UK at 3 Park Road, Shipley, BD18 2JU, W Yorks, tel 01274 593551) or email GoNepal@aol.com. Gopal Lama  Nuru Jangbu Sherpa is a young man setting up his own trekking business. His email address is nurusherpa@hotmail.com. I went trekking with Explore Worldwide in 1999 and he was one of the sherpas for the trip. I would recommend him highly. Hilary Bagshaw

fields.headline: Back to basics
fields.standfirst: Roly Smith explores the Holy Mount of Mow Cop where primitive Methodism was born
fields.trailText: Roly Smith explores the Holy Mount of Mow Cop where primitive Methodism was born.
fields.body:
One cold May Sunday in 1807, a Stoke-on-Trent wheelwright named Hugh Bourne climbed to the windswept 335m summit of Mow Cop, on the borders of Staffordshire and Cheshire, to launch the Primitive Methodist movement.

Bourne, his brother and his friend William Clowes of Burslem were anxious to return to a far simpler form of religious observance, and they invited a number of like-minded friends to that first "camp meeting" of the new order. The meeting is said to have lasted for between 12 and 14 hours, and was the precursor of many similar mass gatherings on this well-known viewpoint.

A century later, more than 70,000 of Bourne's disciples gathered to worship here at what had become their "Holy Mount".

Mow Cop is certainly an inspiring place, with its extensive westward views over the broad Cheshire Plain as far as the Berwyn Mountains of North Wales, north-east to the hills of the Peak and southwards as far as the dark conifers of Cannock Chase and the dim outlines of the Shropshire Hills. Nearer at hand, the huge white saucer of the Jodrell Bank radio telescope is prominent in the broad green plain below. To the north are the tower blocks of Stockport and Manchester, beyond wooded Alderley Edge, and the airliners coming in and out of Manchester International Airport.

Our walk starts at the car park near the summit and descends through woodland to the Ackers Wood railway crossing in the plain below the hill, and follows the towpath of the Macclesfield Canal before climbing up to Mow Cop again via the hamlet of Mount Pleasant.

The mock-gothic folly castle that tops the hill was built in 1754 by the local squire, Randle Wilbraham, to adorn the eastern skyline as seen from his home three miles to the west at Rode Hall. The folly takes the form of a two-storey circular tower alongside a gothic-arched curtain wall.

Earlier, the hilltop of Mow Cop had been used as the site for a beacon lit to warn of the coming of the Spanish Armada in 1588, linking The Wrekin in Shropshire with the next beacon on Alderley Edge.

From the car park, head north for a few yards following the Gritstone Way and Mow Cop Trail signs on the broad track towards residential Wood Street. Turn right on crossing the road and then immediately left, where a signpost points towards the strange pinnacle of the Old Man of Mow.

This isolated, leaning splinter of gritstone was left by the quarrymen in the quarry just to the north of the tower. It is strange how many prominent British hills - such as the Old Man of Coniston in the southern Lake District and the Old Man of Storr on Skye - take the epithet "Old Man". Perhaps it is a recognition of the measure of affection that local people have for these important and familiar local landmarks.

The track leads past the strange pinnacle of the Old Man on the right, and in a few yards, just before an ugly radio mast, a yellow waymark points downhill to the left, across a muddy field and then steeply down through the oaks and hollies of Roe Park Woods. Emerging from the woodland at a stile, bear right around a farm to eventually reach a metalled lane leading to the Ackers railway crossing.

Take care crossing the line and enter Yew Tree Lane, turning right at the junction into New Road to reach the bridge over the Macclesfield Canal. Descend left down to the towpath on the far side of the bridge (No 85).

The Macclesfield Canal was begun in 1826 and took five years to build. The 28-mile waterway linked the Peak Forest Canal at Marple to the Trent and Mersey Canal at the Hardings Wood Junction, and is part of the famous "Cheshire Ring", much used by pleasure-cruising narrowboats.

Turn right and follow the canal towpath south for about 2.4km, with the tower of Mow Cop prominent on the hill away to the left and passing the fine, red-brick Georgian facade of Ramsdell Hall on the opposite bank. Just past the Heritage Narrow Boats Marina at Kent Green, take the stile on the right just before bridge No 87 and turn left on reaching the road. Follow this road under the railway line and up the hill towards the village of Mount Pleasant.

At the top of the hill, the road (Mount Pleasant Road) turns sharply right. After about 90m, take the track on the left known as The Brake. This soon turns into a footpath which goes straight and steeply up the hill on a raised embankment, with fine views across the Cheshire Plain behind, towards Mow Cop village. You emerge on to a rough track where you turn left and then right up steps which lead up by the side of the imposing red-brick Primitive Methodist Memorial Chapel.

Before his death at the age of 80, Bourne had seen more than 5,000 chapels established and the congregation of Primitive Methodists rise to more than 100,000.

Cross Woodcock Lane and pass the village Post Office and Stores on the left, turning left into the High Street and back to the car park at Mow Cop in about 350m.

In 1932, the Primitive Methodist movement merged with the parent church, and five years later, more than 10,000 Methodists attended a service at Mow Cop when the summit was formally handed over to its present owners, the National Trust.

The practicals

This 9km walk, which will be featured in the forthcoming AA Walks through Britain's History, involves a descent and ascent of about 182m, mainly on field and woodland paths, lanes and canal towpaths. The paths, especially descending down to the canal, can be very boggy.

Parking is at the National Trust car park beneath the folly at Mow Cop, which is about two miles west of Biddulph. The best map is the Ordnance Survey 1:25,000 Explorer No 258, Stoke-on-Trent and Newcastle-under-Lyme. The nearest tourist information centre is at the Town Hall in Congleton High Street (01260 271095).

For refreshments, try the thatched Bleeding Wolf pub at Scholar Green on the A34 between Congleton and Newcastle-under-Lyme (01782 782272) or the aptly-named Cheshire View on Top Station Road, Mow Cop (01782 514211).

webTitle: Sikh policeman's record payout in 'hate mail' case

fields.headline: Sikh policeman's record payout in 'hate mail' case
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: An Asian police officer wrongly accused of sending racist hate mail to himself received record damages yesterday of £150,000 for being discriminated against on racial grounds.
fields.body:
An Asian police officer wrongly accused of sending racist hate mail to himself received record damages yesterday of £150,000 for being discriminated against on racial grounds.

Sikh Metropolitan police sergeant Gurpal Virdi was awarded the sum, £110,000 more than the previous record at an employment tribunal remedy hearing, at the London central employment tribunal courts.

Mr Virdi, 41, from Cranford in Middlesex, was dismissed in March this year after he was accused of sending hate mail to himself and 12 other ethnic minority police officers from London's Ealing division.

An employment tribunal in August found there was no evidence he had sent the letters, and that he was the victim of racial discrimination by the Met. Next year Mr Virdi will take the Met to a tribunal claiming unfair dismissal.

Mr Virdi was dismissed following an internal disciplinary hearing, where it was alleged he sent the racist messages in December 1997 and January 1998. They carried a message telling the officers to leave the force and were signed with the initials of the National Front. Six similar letters were received by civilian staff.

The tribunal heard that the messages were allegedly linked to his computer, and as a result, he was suspended in April 1998 after police investigated and searched his home.

During the investigation the tribunal found that Mr Virdi was treated differently from a white officer, PC Jackie Bachelor, who was also a suspect, and that the Met had searched his home and tried to entrap him in a taped personnel interview.

webTitle: Crunch day looms for Finance One chief

fields.headline: Crunch day looms for Finance One chief
fields.standfirst: Businessman accused of causing the 'Asian contagion' faces extradition hearing
fields.trailText: Walking around the exercise yard at Brixton prison, Pin Chakkaphak studiously avoided eye-contact with fellow inmates. He had been warned by warders that if the circle stopped moving it would mean a fight was going to break out. Not reassuring for a 50-year-old banker whose experience of a struggle was confined to the boardroom.
fields.body:
Walking around the exercise yard at Brixton prison, Pin Chakkaphak studiously avoided eye-contact with fellow inmates. He had been warned by warders that if the circle stopped moving it would mean a fight was going to break out. Not reassuring for a 50-year-old banker whose experience of a struggle was confined to the boardroom.

But Mr Chakkaphak did not feel much safer during the 23 hours a day he had to spend in his cell. He realised the only weapon he had was a weighty book on e-commerce should he need to fend off his fellow prisoner - locked up for violence - who inhabited the top bunk bed. "I made sure I always slept with one eye open but at least I could see the Millennium Wheel out of the window," says Mr Chakkaphak.

Brixton prison is not the expected destination of a Wharton business school graduate. But neither did Mr Chakkaphak imagine when he was studying in Pennsyvania he might one day be held part-responsible for the domino effect of the region's financial crisis - the Asian contagion.

The Thai government claims the former financier caused the economic slump in its country, ripped off £35m and ran the authorities a merry dance across the world in his attempt to evade justice.

On Tuesday the former head of Finance One, once the most successful finance house in Thailand, will face his accusers as extradition proceedings begin at Bow Street magistrates court in central London.

Mr Chakkaphak's difficulties had their origins during 1996 when the currency crisis began to unfold in south-east Asia. The central Bank of Thailand had entered into a desperate defence of the baht against speculators. There followed a run on deposits at the publicly-quoted Finance One which ended with its collapse in March 1997.

By the autumn of the following year the company was facing charges it had lent money to two subsidiaries without doing proper credit analysis. By August 1999 the public prosecutor in Thailand was accusing Mr Chakkaphak and others of embezzling money.

Fearing years of court wrangling, Mr Chakkaphak fled to Hong Kong. But when Thai investigators arrived there they discovered he had been tipped off and had left for Britain. It was not long before Scotland Yard was knocking on the door of his wife's London flat and Mr Chakkaphak soon found himself behind bars.

Now out on bail, Mr Chakkaphak comes over as bright and humorous. He was raised in Thailand but educated in the US.

"The ruling Democrats face election on January 6 and are being blamed for a failing economy. They need to find scapegoats and who better to pin it on than a high-profile financier like myself," he says pointing out that Finance One had to send regular and detailed briefings of its activities to the Thai central bank each month.

Mr Chakkaphak admits his profile was too high for his own good. He owned a fleet of Ferraris, gossip magazines linked him with Miss Thailand and his company was one of the most successful in Asia.

He had been voted boss of the year, was chairman of the association of finance companies, and seemed the ultimate beneficiary of a rampant tiger economy. He established Finance One with equity of $1m in 1979. By the early 1990s it was worth $2.5bn.

Mr Chakkaphak denies holding £35m, claiming his wealth died with Finance One, saying he and his three children are living on his wife's savings. The Thai financier insists he is innocent of all charges but admits he pushed the company to its regulatory limits.

"I never stepped over the line. But I did what is normal business practice in the US and the west - to do as much as you can within the limits of the law."

The Thai financier insists he is innocent of all charges but admits he pushed the company to its regulatory limits. "I never stepped over the line. But I did what is normal business practice in the US and the west - to do as much as you can within the limits of the law."

webTitle: Fed chief must earn every cent of his corn

fields.headline: Fed chief must earn every cent of his corn
fields.standfirst: Greenspan the great interventionist treads a nimble line to avoid spooking the US economy
fields.trailText: Greenspan the great interventionist treads a nimble line to avoid spooking the US economy
fields.body:
Like a match report when your team wins, Alan Greenspan's speeches always reward a rereading. This week's address to an American conference of bankers by the Federal Reserve chairman was no exception. Investors' first reading prompted a record one-day rise in the Nasdaq index of 10%. Second thoughts were much, much gloomier.

Greenspan is circumspect in his authority as the financial world's most powerful individual. His pronouncements tend to reflect the audience's own prejudices and predispositions back to them.

That is not to say that Greenspan's words are impenetrable, just suitably guarded. His milieu is, after all, replete with uncertainty. And, for all his ability to influence the economy's future, he is unable to determine it. Over the years he has strived to maximise the visibility of economic policy without allowing corporates and individuals to forget how risky the world really is. No easy task when the desire to make a fast buck is so prevalent.

This week's speech took the slowdown in the American economy as its subject. The switchback reaction of the US stockmarket reflected confusion about the extent of the deceleration. Day one's euphoria celebrated impending interest rate cuts. Day two's hangover focused on impending profit warnings.

Greenspan had nothing overt to say on the speed with which the US will grow in 2001. In the third quarter of this year America's economy expanded at a rate of 2.4%. Until a few years ago this would have been regarded as normal. Now, the technology revolution has created expectations that the normal rate of growth is more like 4% to 5% a year. So the recent pace looks disappointing.

Signs are, moreover, that activity is less buoyant than in the third quarter. The national association of purchasing managers' monthly survey has suggested a softening rate of growth throughout 2000. Now it's hinting at outright sogginess. The Federal Reserve's open market committee meets for its regular interest rate debate next week. Nearly all observers believe the next move in rates is down, some say as early as next week.

Greenspan's latest language is intriguing. In describing the recent downswing in the tech industries he talks of "some overreaching" and "some disappointment". He cites "some aspiring entrepreneurs [who] entered the tail end of a short-term boomlet". The message is that nothing's occurring that should be surprising, nor is so widespread as to suggest the whole game is over.

Although the great interventionist - witness 1987 and 1998 - Greenspan is at heart a believer in the self-correcting mechanisms of the capitalist system. Why, then, one might ask, is this process of reassessment taking place now? In large part, it appears to be the expected byproduct of the economy's transition to a more sustainable balance in the growth of demand and supply.

He's clearly sensitised though, in particular because the slowdown is not confined to the new economy. As Greenspan himself points out, housebuilding has cooled, new car sales and those of other consumer durables have slowed, and data on hours worked give an early signal that the tourniquet constricting the labour market is beginning to loosen.

Economies readily fall victim to virtuous and vicious circles. During expansion phases positive forces reinforce each other and an economy's participants are suffused with a warm feeling of well-being. The reverse is true of downturns where bogeymen appear to lurk around every corner and the economy spooks itself.

The vicious circle now threatening to take hold of the US has various elements. These include the effect on personal wealth of falling share prices; the increased cost of credit to ventures perceived to be disproportionately risky; scepticism about the likely commercial viability of many new technologies; and introspection brought on by the presidential election debacle.

Vicious circle
Of particular concern to Greenspan is evidence from US banks that bad debts are increasing. In part this is a function of failing dot.coms, but not exclusively so. There is no suggestion that the banking system is about to be brought down by a collapse in its asset base, but the marginal effect on a slowing economy could be substantial. The circle could become more vicious. Interest rate cuts would work in the opposite direction, but would be unlikely by themselves to correct a tailspin.

The day after Greenspan's speech, the largest US domestic bank, Bank of America, surprised investors with a profits warning. Although it is reported that the bank has around 10% of its loans outstanding to the hi-tech TMT sectors, it has alsohit bad debt problems in the old economy.

It will take some time to turn round a "supertanker" such as Bank of America. In the meantime expect it to cut peripheral activities and further tighten lending conditions. Not great news for the US economy - especially as Citibank, the world's biggest, has a much greater proportion of its loan book extended to TMT companies.

It looks then as if next year Greenspan will once again earn every cent of his salary (raised only this week). Bond markets show an expectation of rates falling from their 6.5% level. The trick, as ever, will be for the Fed to finesse the reductions. Next week seems unlikely, but remember surprise is one of the most powerful weapons in the Greenspan armoury.

Edmond Warner is chief executive of Old Mutual Securities

edmondw@omsecurities.co.uk

fields.headline: John Lennon? What a phoney!
fields.standfirst: Working-class hero? My arse! He was about as working class as a Wilmslow dentist. Sexy? He was hideous
fields.trailText: Working-class hero? My arse! He was about as working class as a Wilmslow dentist. Sexy? He was hideous
fields.body:
I don't normally feel the need to return to the scene of a hate-crime - once I've dissed 'em, they stay dissed - but in John Lennon's case, I will make an exception. John Lennon! Even his name makes me feel nauseous. Was one human being, with the possible exception of Jeffrey Archer, ever such an all-weather compendium of lies, boasts and eye-watering phoniness? It's actually quite hard to think of a person you can't stand one damned thing about - even Jeffrey Archer's good for a cheap laugh - but Lennon takes the booby prize every time.

I would have let the old geezer rest in pieces if there hadn't been this recent flurry of sentimental activity around his remains. The Beatles Anthology book comes out and cretins queue all night for it. That album gets to number one. George Michael, whose once-sharp brain must surely have been well bleached by the bright brazen sun of La-La Land, buys Lennon's piano partly "to keep it out of tiny hands in Tokyo" and partly because Imagine was - ahem - the greatest song ever written, casting a giant shadow over today's bonsai bands. Liam Gallagher, Mr Brains Trust himself, names his kiddie after his all-time hero, while, in a Putative Project of truly sumptuous grotesquerie, plans for Yoko Ono and Michael Jackson to bring a Yellow Submarine musical to the West End stage in 2002 are announced.

To cap it all, any swot lucky enough to be blessed with BBC Choice can tonight experience "an evening of programmes dedicated to one of the greatest singer-songwriters and one of the most influential political artists of modern times". Yes, be still my beating heart as the Professional Widow introduces such toe-tapping classics as Instant Karma, Power To The People and No9 Dream (bet you can't whistle that one). There's also an ass-sucking documentary, Gimme Some Truth, in which (according to a reverent BBC press release) "an American fan turns up on Lennon's doorstep saying that he needs to talk to him because he believes that Lennon's lyrics were written specifically for him. He is invited into the house for something to eat." For some reason, this piece of writing made me hoot with laughter, so I just wanted to share it with you. And, as the cherry top, there's a long, lingering look at the "Lennon Shrine" in New York's Central Park, containing interviews with "the thousands of people who make a pilgrimage to the shrine on the anniversary of his death". And every one of them nuttier than his killer Mark Chapman, I'll be bound.

Lennon; what a phoney! For a start - working-class hero? My arse. The Marianne Faithfull cover version was more heartfelt! Lennon was about as working class as a Wilmslow dentist, unlike Paul, George, and Ringo. That's why the tosser was at art school in the early 50s, for Pete's sake! (And, on the subject of Petes, who was it insisted that the original Beatles drummer, Pete Best, be sacked because he was too good-looking and all the girls screamed at him? Right first time.)

Someone once said that pop stars must be either sexy or profound; when you get the pair, you've hit the jackpot. Lennon was neither. Imagine's lyrics could have come out of a stoned fortune cookie or maudlin Christmas cracker, and generally appeals to vicious go-getters who'd sell their best pet to a torture lab if the price was right. But more seriously, he wasn't sexy in the least - he was hideous, even when young. Those piggy little eyes, that thin, curtain-twitching little mouth, the voice a tight whine of ill-temper - ugh! If he was anything like as unattractive, whiny and boring as a child as he was as an adult, I'm not surprised his mother - Julia, by all accounts an attractive, intelligent, high-spirited woman who must have felt she'd given birth to a switched baby - ran away and left him with his Aunt Mimi. (See that early giveaway as to his manicured roots, by the way; working-class people never refer to their mother's sister as "Aunt"; she is invariably "Auntie".)

The young adult Lennon was an appealing chap, too: this is the man, remember, who, in front of a packed dressing room, shouted "QUEER JEW" in response to Brian Epstein fussing, "Now what shall I call this autobiography of mine?" He was crap during the Beatles - everyone knows that Paul wrote 99% of all the decent songs - and crap after the Beatles. He was always the weakest link. I'll take the spirit and soul of Ringo's Back Off Boogaloo and It Don't Come Easy over the smug platitudes of Woman or Starting Over, any day.

Ah, the Yoko years! Move over Romeo and Juliet, Dante and Beatrice and Jimmy and Janette Krankie, and let this pair of lovers show you how it's really done! In reality, of course, their alliance was a fetid mess of domestic violence, drug addiction and mutual adultery - hey, if I'd wanted that, I could have got it at home. After the initial provincial excitement of copping off with a "Jap", as Lennon so frequently referred to his lady love, I think it fair to say that there wasn't even a great deal of physical attraction - on either side, and who can blame either one after seeing that album cover? ("Couldn't Paul and Linda strip off instead?" said the sweet, vague Sir Joe Lockwood, head of EMI at the time Two Virgins was released. "They're so much prettier .") "I don't believe in Beatles - the dream is over," Lennon once sang. "I just believe in me - Yoko and me." I'd bet any money that the Yoko Dream turned out to be emptier and phonier than the Beatles Dream. But when Lennon wanted to turn back, he was too afraid of losing face. Instead, he swaddled himself in ("Imagine no . . .") possessions; at the height of their swinishness, the Ono-Lennons kept a whole apartment in the Dakota building, just below the one they lived in, for the exclusive occupation of their fur coats - just to keep them at the right temperature. Forget sex and drugs; that's probably the most decadent, vile pop star antic I've ever come across in my life.

Yet still the legend lives. But that doesn't make it legit. Lennon famously got into trouble for saying in the 60s that the Beatles were "bigger than Jesus" - pathetically, he also apologised when this statement threatened to damage their sales in the God-bothering US South. And, of course, it was a ridiculous thing to say - for a start, Jesus had better songs and he didn't go about calling people "Queer Jews". A far better comparison would be with the Queen Mother, about whom it is equally impossible to imagine the BBC ever making even a slightly critical programme. In the long run, I think that's what John Lennon will turn out to be: a Queen Mum body double, a dry run for the big one - the man who united one nation under a vale of tears.
