fields.headline: Young Woman, Jean-Honore Fragonard (c1769)
fields.trailText: · View the work online
fields.body:
· View the work online

Artist: Jean-Honoré Fragonard (1732-1806) was the last rococo painter. He was trained by Boucher and van Loo, the masters of this 18th-century style, and by the more realist Chardin. He worked to all kinds of commissions, including one to paint an aristocrat's mistress. This resulted in his cheeky masterpiece The Swing (1767), in the Wallace Collection. He ended his days in poverty after the French Revolution.

Subject: An unknown woman.

Distinguishing features: This young woman is whipped up in a frenzy of quick, rough brushstrokes, her face the only part of the painting that looks finished; her rouged cheek and red lips, her eyes looking directly at us, are pointedly real, breaking out of the fictive world of paint. It's a passionate sketch, her clothes a blur of brown and white, sensuous, first-impression brushstrokes.

The painting is oily, fluid, erotic; we are taken closer to this woman than we expect in a portrait, into a tactile world of direct sensory contact. It's disconcerting - her presence as powerfully alive as someone in a Rembrandt portrait. Fragonard elides the visual and tangible, and the raw, wet look of his paint seems to caress his subject.

Fragonard is a flamboyantly erotic artist. Like the early 18th-century French painter Watteau, the greatest exponent of the curly, fluent style known as the rococo, he slips constantly between representation and metaphor. Watteau painted pastoral scenes of masked love and dreamy seductions. But where Watteau implies sex, Fragonard paints it directly in scenes of voyeurism, the man looking up his mistress's skirt in The Swing, or a secret liaison in The Stolen Kiss (c.1766). There's a graphic explicitness to his art, yet, at the same time, he's a true rococo artist in his enjoyment of textures, silks and lace for their own sake.

In this painting, the way the paint is stippled and roughened on the white lace collar makes you unconsciously feel the texture of lace. Other paintings by Fragonard dive into masses of soft green leaves and woodland shadows, a theatre for reverie. Here, there is no setting other than a creamy olive backdrop, and the fantasy takes place in the way the woman is painted. She herself is a pastoral landscape in which the painter loses himself in brownish hues, rivulets of paint, a forest of brushstrokes.

Fragonard's pleasure in painting this woman is such that he does not seem to want it to end. The portrait's unfinished appearance - though it is intended to be shown as it is - gives it the feeling of a secret compact between artist and subject. The painting is suspended in the midst of feeling; it's spontaneous, alive, and makes you think of 18th-century ideas of nature, the cult of Rousseau, Marie-Antoinette dressed as a shepherdess. The young woman's hair is unkempt, her social mask dropped, she's without the wigs and finery of the court.

Yet there's more to it than that, a teasing, mysterious quality, heightened by the bizarre joke Fragonard played on art historians by giving the painting a false signature - his own has since been found underneath. The great scholar of French painting Pierre Rosenberg identified it as a Fragonard in 1974. Fragonard's secretiveness in this painting, as well as his lightness of touch, make for a sentiment the opposite of that we associate with rococo art. Here we see an early Romantic sensibility emerging, a desire to capture the essence rather than the social façade of a person, the flux of life rather than a mask.

Inspirations and Influences: The quick, unfinished brushing of this portrait is a source for Impressionism. Fragonard was a model for at least one Impressionist painter, Pierre-Auguste Renoir (1841-1919); see, for example, Little Blue Nude (c.1878-9) currently in Impression at The National Gallery. Renoir shares Fragonard's unapologetic, sensual pleasure in paint as soft as cotton wool.

Where is it? Dulwich Picture Gallery, College Road, London SE21 (020-8693 5254).

fields.headline: Lord Aldington
fields.standfirst: Tory grandee vindicated in the courts over war crimes allegations
fields.trailText: Tory grandee vindicated in the courts over war crimes allegations
fields.body:
Lord Aldington, who has died aged 86, had three distinguished careers, in the army, politics and big business, His tragedy was that for more than a decade, his life was overshadowed by being the target of obsessionals with friends in high places.

His pursuit, by Count Nikolai Tolstoy and his helpmates, was for allegedly being an accomplice to the murder, by Soviet troops and Tito's Yugoslav partisans, of Nazi-aiding Cossacks and anti-Tito Ustachi - for which Aldington had little, if any, responsibility. It was as if he was being tormented when the real targets should have been Winston Churchill and Harold Macmillan.

For seven years after Aldington won a record £1.5m damages (plus £500,000 costs) in his 1989 libel action against Tolstoy, the count avoided payment by making appeals to 15 courts in Britain and Europe, including a ruling by the European Court of Human Rights that the size of the award violated his right to freedom of expression. He did this, while continuing to live in his big house, and send his children to expensive schools, because of the support of Tory rightwingers, including Aldington's own leader in the Lords, Lord Cranborne.

It began to look as though Aldington was being persecuted for having been too close to the deputy Conservative leader, RA "Rab" Butler, in the early 1960s, and a friend of Edward Heath.

Until he collided with Tolstoy, Aldington could have been judged the happiest, and most decorated and appreciated, of Tory establishmentarians, with a near-perfect curriculum vitae. Born Toby Low, he was the son of Colonel Stuart Low, who died in action in 1942; he sailed through Winchester school and New College, Oxford, where he read jurisprudence, and was called to the bar in 1939.

Having joined the King's Royal Rifle Corps in 1934, he was called up immediately and served in Greece, where he won the DSO, then in Crete, the western desert and Tunisia with the Rangers. In 1943, he joined the Eighth Army staff for the Sicilian campaign (MBE) and served as a lieutenant colonel on the staff of 13 Corps in Italy. In 1944, he was appointed brigadier on the general staff of 5 Corps for the final assault from Italy on Austria.

It was these last May days in Austria, before Low returned home to stand for parliament, that saw the messy aftermath of the Yalta agreement of February 1945, signed by Churchill, Roosevelt and Stalin. It was agreed that those Soviet citizens and Yugoslavs who had fought for the Nazis would be turned over to Soviet troops and Yugoslav partisans in exchange for British prisoners liberated by both.

There were 70,000 Cossacks and Yugoslav Ustachi in the British zone of Austria, with long and bloody trails behind them. Low was the departing chief-of-staff to Field Marshal Alexander, in charge of operations in food-short Austria. Under Macmillan's orders - as Churchill's minister resident in the Mediterranean - Alexander turned over all the ex-Soviets and ex-Yugoslavs, despite his doubts about 11,000 women and children, to a slaughter that began almost immediately.

Having left behind this carefully-shrouded event within days of its beginning, Low began his next two careers. He was elected Conservative MP for Blackpool North in June 1945, when Labour's Clement Attlee replaced Winston Churchill as prime minister. A year later, he began what was to be a successful business career as a director of Grindlay's Bank.

As soon as Churchill returned to power in 1951, Low became parliamentary secretary to the Ministry of Supply, then minister of state at the Board of Trade, and a privy counsellor in 1954. Knighted in 1957, he was made chairman of the select committee on nationalised industry. Two years later, he became deputy Conservative party chairman. In 1962, he became Lord Aldington, and was free to launch his business career untrammeled.

Almost as a one-man show, Aldington linked together all the elements of the establishment, political and economic. In 1964, he became chairman of Grindlay's Bank, and of GEC. In 1971, he joined the BBC general advisory council, and became chairman of Sun-Alliance and the Port of London Authority. In 1972, he became co-chairman, with Jack Jones, of the joint special committee on the ports industry, cutting overmanning massively. He became chairman of Westland in 1977.

He remained always a one-nation Tory, who had supported Rab Butler rather than Harold Macmillan. As a pro-European, he was a friend and backer of Edward Heath (and was happy to praise him when I was writing Heath's biography in 1971-72).

But although normally loyal, Aldington expected his critical judgment to be taken seriously. He was chairman of the Lords' select committee on overseas trade when, in 1985, it judged that Britain was not doing well enough in manufactured exports, which angered the chancellor, Nigel Lawson. When, 15 months later, an obedient Lord Lucas of Chilworth tried to sneer at Aldington's committee findings, he stalked out of the chamber in high dudgeon, with Lord Whitelaw signalling whips to try to soothe him.

It was in the mid-1980s, when Aldington was over 70 and winding down his business career, that misdirected lightning struck. He had earlier ignored Tolstoy's books, Victims Of Yalta (1977) and The Minister And The Massacres (1986), which claimed that, back in 1945, Macmillan had wanted to please Stalin by handing over the Cossacks.

What put the fat in the fire was the intervention of another obsessionalist, the property developer Nigel Watts, who was fighting Sun-Alliance over a disputed insurance claim on his brother- in-law, who had renewed his insurance without disclosing that he was at death's door. Having read The Minister And The Massacres, Watts drew up a leaflet vastly exaggerating the wartime role of Aldington, who had been chairman of Sun-Alliance.

Ten thousand copies of this leaflet, somewhat toned down by Tolstoy, were circulated to politicians, the press and Aldington's friends. It was so damaging that Aldington had to sue Watts, but Tolstoy insisted on being sued as well.

The establishment, which had facilitated an inquiry by Brigadier Cowgill - which cleared Macmillan - also made it easier for Aldington to have access to the necessary files. He had only to write to the then defence secretary, George (now Lord) Younger to see the material he needed.

After the nine-week trial, and Tolstoy's years of prevarication on payment, Aldington tried to end it all by offering to accept £300,000, but Tolstoy insisted on martyrdom. He was backed by continuing support from Tory right- wingers, the latest of whom was Lord (Bernard) Braine, who accused then then foreign secretary, Douglas Hurd, of participating in an establishment plot against Tolstoy.

Events relating to the long-running cases punctuated Aldington's last decade. In April 1995, Watts was jailed for 18 months after repeating the libellous claim that Aldington was a war criminal in a pamphlet. At the end of the hearing, Aldington said plaintively: "I do feel my family and I are entitled to some relief sometime."

Of course, Toby Aldington had other interests, some local, some international. As deputy lieutenant of Kent, in March 1993 he tried to ensure that British Rail's plans for the channel tunnel kept to their promise of not splitting the community of Willesborough, near his home at Knoll Farm, Ashford. In the big debate on the Maastricht Bill in June 1993, he identified with Lord Whitelaw, and others of that generation, who believed that only a closer European Union could avoid another war.

He is survived by his wife Araminta, two daughters and a son.

 Toby Austin Richard William Low, Lord Aldington, politician, businessman, born May 25 1914; died December 7 2000

fields.headline: Old Parsonage Hotel, Oxford
fields.trailText: Vast, ancient oak door opens into a cosy lounge and restaurant elaborately decorated with hundreds of framed portraits.
fields.body:
Address: 1 Banbury Road, Oxford OX2 6NN.
Tel: 01865 310210.
Web address: Oxford Hotels Restaurants

First impressions: Vast, ancient oak door opens into a cosy lounge and restaurant elaborately decorated with hundreds of framed portraits. No suprise to discover that parts of the building date from 1660. These were Oscar Wilde's digs while a student at Oxford, too.

What are the rooms like? Variable, but ours was large with separate lounge area, overlooking a quiet courtyard and neighbouring St Giles' church. Decor floral in the best sense of the word; comically enormous television.

The bed test: Comfortable and wide but curiously short - perhaps they date from 1660, too. Guests longer than 6ft could have problems.

The bathroom test: Gleaming ensuite, stacked with a vast quantity of complimentary soaps and shampoos and sufficient towels for twice as many guests.

The restaurant: Perfect eggs, sausages and black pudding more than made up for slightly erratic breakfast service; for lunch - surrounded by visiting parents treating their Oxford student children to a meal - a splendid menu particularly distinguished by the guinea fowl and the Thai green curry with monkfish.

The lounge: A country pub - of the better variety - despite city-centre location.

What is there to see within walking distance? Oxford. Central position means everything's in easy reach - the Pitt Rivers museum of anthropology is metres away, and the hotel will organise a behind-the-scenes tour of Oxford colleges.

How much a night? Doubles from £150; deluxe 17th-century rooms and those with lounge areas will set you back more.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
Pubmaster gets a mistress
Pubs group Pubmaster yesterday changed ownership in a deal that valued its 2,000 plus pubs at around £550m. Pubmaster's owners, private equity firms Bridgepoint Capital, BC Partners and PPM Ventures, sold the firm to an acquisition vehicle called Pubmistress backed by German bank WestLB and two property companies, St Modwen Property and Rotch Property Group.
fields.body:
Pubmaster gets a mistress
Pubs group Pubmaster yesterday changed ownership in a deal that valued its 2,000 plus pubs at around £550m. Pubmaster's owners, private equity firms Bridgepoint Capital, BC Partners and PPM Ventures, sold the firm to an acquisition vehicle called Pubmistress backed by German bank WestLB and two property companies, St Modwen Property and Rotch Property Group.

The companies did not divulge the price, but industry sources said it was sold for around £550m, four years after it became subject of a £171m management buy-out from its earlier owners Brent Walker.

Based in Hartlepool, Pubmaster has around 2,000 tenanted pubs across England, Wales and Scotland selling around 340,000 barrels of beer per annum and producing rental income of around £22m per annum.

Breathe chokes on free access
Breathe yesterday became the latest internet service provider to close down its free unmetered access saying its business model was no longer viable.

"The decision will affect a small number of the total dial-up user base and has been taken as a result of the excessive use over recent months which has become unsustainable," it said.

Breathe follows companies including LineOne and Altavista in abandoning plans to offer free unmetered access. Internet companies increasingly believe the only way to now provide unmetered access is to charge users a monthly subscription fee.

Mayborn jobs go in China play
Mayborn, the British manufacturer and distributor of fabric dyes and baby products, said it would lose 220 jobs in relocating certain processes to China. Mayborn said the redundancies will arise at its UK plant at Cramlington, Northumberland. Shares of Mayborn, which have outperformed its sector by 47% so far this year, were down 5.6% at 50.5p.

Shareholders besiege EM.TV
Shareholders in Germany's EM.TV have filed complaints against the company, according to the Munich state prosecutor.

The shareholders are angry that a week ago the group warned that it would fall far short of earlier forecasts of earnings this year, only weeks after saying it was still on course to hit its targets.

EM.TV, which owns the rights to the Muppets and a 50% stake in the company which owns the rights to Formula One racing, said that it had always acted in good faith.

£5m boost for New Look
Tom Singh, the multi-millionaire founder of the New Look fashion chain, yesterday donated £5m worth of his own shares to top managers, giving them added incentive to boost the group's flagging share price. Singh is granting potentially lucrative options to 101 directors and senior managers so that they have a vested interest in rebuilding investor confidence in the retailer, battered by a drop in sales and the departure of chief executive Jim Hodkinson in May.

fields.body: Colgan has an instantly attractive, smiling voice but she should never have been allowed to read her own book. Fiction demands professional performance. To top it all, she tells us within two minutes that her narrator chracter is a Surrey girl who spent her childhood in Woking. Colgan speaks broad Ayrshire. Orion could surely have shelled out for an actor for a bestseller.

fields.headline: Et cetera
fields.standfirst: Steven Poole  on new non-fiction: The Mystery of the Aleph, Letters from Prison,  The Road Since Structure
fields.trailText: Steven Poole on new non-fiction: The Mystery of the Aleph, Letters from Prison, The Road Since Structure
fields.body:
The Mystery of the Aleph

Amir D Aczel

(Four Walls Eight Windows, £16.99)
Buy it at BOL

Weird stuff, infinity. There are exactly as many numbers between zero and one as there are between zero and 20, or zero and five million. Aczel's refined pop-maths antennae enable him to explain such bizarreries with pleasing allusions to infinite hotels and cliff-path walks, fast-cutting from the ancient Greeks to the Jewish cabbala (hence the "Aleph" of the title) while penning an affecting life-and-work portrait of the great 19th-century mathematician Georg Cantor. Cantor developed a theory of different sizes of infinities, or "transfinite numbers". His subsequent desperate attempts to prove his "continuum hypothesis" gradually eroded his sanity: he turned to literature, trying to prove that Bacon wrote Shakespeare's plays, and eventually died in an asylum. Concise and mind-stretching: almost a true-life version of the film Pi , although sadly lacking the industrial-metal soundtrack.

Letters from Prison

the Marquis de Sade, trans & ed Richard Seaver

(Harvill, £20)
Buy it at BOL

These were written during de Sade's 13-year incarceration in Vincennes, the Bastille and lastly Charenton. Nearly half the letters are addressed to his wife, Renée-Pelagie: demanding pots of jam, smothering her with endearments or trying to deduce his release date from numerological "signs" in her own letters. He delightedly reports a dream about his mother-in-law (who had got him imprisoned): "I saw her skinned alive, dragged over thistles, and then tossed into a vat of vinegar." Despite the torture of solitary confinement, de Sade remained a lucid and passionate correspondent, arguing always for the inviolate freedom of the imagination: "I have certainly not practised everything I have conceived and never shall."

The Road Since Structure

Thomas S Kuhn, eds James Conant & John Haugeland

(Chicago, £16)

Buy it at BOL

In 1962, Kuhn wrote The Structure of Scientific Revolutions , arguing that science proceeds in two ways. "Normal" science does experiments and expands our knowledge under agreed theories; "revolutionary" science introduces a new conceptual framework and demands that we abandon some of what was previously believed. The book has been much celebrated and vilified. Social constructionists think that Kuhn's socio-historical methodology implies that science uncovers no truth about the real world and is merely a thin veil of fiction over an ideology of power. In one of the "philosophical essays" here, however, Kuhn calmly disowns such errant readers. This collection of work since 1970 includes replies to his critics (including Popper and Feyerabend) and a long autobiographical interview conducted a year before his death in 1996.

webTitle: Pick of the week: Pleasures and Regrets by Marcel Proust

fields.headline: Before time's loss
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Lezard on shorter Proust
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard on Pleasures and Regrets, a shorter Proust.
fields.body:
Pleasures and Regrets
Marcel Proust, trans Louise Varese, intro D J Enright
(Peter Owen, £9.95)
Buy it at BOL

So, you've got the edition of Remembrance of Things Past all lined up on the shelf, you've read Alain de Botton's How Proust Can Change Your Life, but your life is still unchanged. That is, you're not particularly feckless or bogus - but you still haven't read the damn thing. It's not that you're stupid or incapable of concentration (although it has to be said that reading Proust tends to tax not only the short- but the mid- and long-term memories as well); you're just busy, damn it. So how do you get a flavour, first-hand, of the only writer who could compete, in the 20th century, with the intimidating geniuses of Joyce and Beckett?

I would suggest this little volume, first published in 1896 when Proust was 25 and containing in miniature, and in essence, most of the themes he was to worry over throughout his magnum opus. Here we have crises in high society, the anxieties of snobs, reveries and feverish arguments over music and composers, longings and loves perversely conjured up out of boredom. This last theme, splendidly played out in the "Melancholy Summer of Madame de Breyves", also contains an early example of the page-long Proustian sentence; a rarity in this volume, if not elsewhere.

Part of the fun lies in picking out early trademarks, indications of the writer's future. This is quite easy, and will make you feel clever (you need only rudimentary knowledge of A La Recherche). You may also feel that you have stolen a march on Proust's contemporaries, who at the time failed to notice these little sprouts as evidence of a future mighty forest of narrative. It is written by someone still very much part of the world he excoriates; the reference to Hesiod in the original title (Les Plaisirs et les Jours) is, I suspect, an implicit nod to the note of exhortation and lament in the ancient Greek mythographer: "Both Gods and men are angry with a man who lives idle, for in nature he is like the stingless drones who waste the labour of the bees, eating without working ... Work is no disgrace: it is idleness which is a disgrace."

Proust's characters are idle, and driven by habit; indeed, the habit has driven out the good in them. This is a lesson he was to expand on later; but he had known it for some time. It is interesting that he would approach the subject both in fragments, as here, and in an intimidatingly vast whole, as in the more celebrated work; but unless you count the abortive Jean Sauteuil , not in anything in between.

I would suggest, though, that you give the preface by D J Enright a miss until you have read a few of the pieces first: not only does he give away a couple of endings (and given the scant plotting, this amounts to giving away the whole point), but he is definitely sniffy about the whole book, intimately involved as he is with the best English-language version of A la Recherche and, presumably, keen to prove his independence of mind and respect for standards.

I have also given the first piece, "The Death of Baldassare Silvande", a temporary yet ongoing miss after looking at its opening line of dialogue, which seems rather beyond self-parody ("Master Alexis, don't cry like that. Perhaps your uncle, the Viscount, will give you a horse"). But in these portraits of the Parisian fin-de-siècle beau monde , sketchy and yet at the same time hothoused though they may be, you can read lessons about honesty, self-betrayal and love that transcend their air of period, of preciousness, of charm.

webTitle: Review: The Seduction of Place: The City in the 21st Century by Joseph Rykwert

fields.headline: Tales of the city
fields.standfirst: Jonathan Glancey  on the urban experience of Joseph Rykwert's  The Seduction of Place
fields.trailText: Jonathan Glancey on the urban experience of Joseph Rykwert's The Seduction of Place
fields.body:
The Seduction of Place: The City in the 21st Century

Joseph Rykwert

294pp, Weidenfeld & Nicholson, £20
Buy it at BOL

This is a necessary book. At a time when the future of cities is being discussed worldwide, Joseph Rykwert offers us an overview of the subject from its tentative beginnings in the Middle East some 10,000 years ago to the extraordinary experience of Mexico City today, with its population of 20m and rising. Has the city been a force for good or bad? When do measures of creative chaos in the life and form of cities tip over into conditions of alienation and dystopia? And what can we do to make our cities happy and healthy places to live in when they are shaped in part by economic forces largely beyond our control?

These are important questions. But before any answers, it must be said that the title of Rykwert's beautifully written book is a bit of a lie. This celebrated architectural historian is really telling us the intriguing story of how our cities - including London, Paris, Berlin, Mexico, Canberra, Brasilia and the author's beloved New York - got to be the way they are today. Rykwert is at his best when guiding us effortlessly through the past 10,000 years of city-making and at his happiest revisiting the individual buildings he cares most about.

As to how we can best influence positive change in our cities, instead of looking for strictly 21st-century solutions he takes us back to ancient Greece where the city was perfected - or so those of us at the tail end of long generations of classically educated Romantics still like to believe. The Greeks, says Rykwert, used the word "polis" to describe both the city and a favourite dice and board game rather like backgammon that depended on the interplay of chance and rule. Chance and rule: this is how they played games and designed cities. It remains, he says, perhaps the ideal way of making humane cities 2,500 years on from the completion of the Parthenon.

The city has not been shaped, Rykwert believes, by the kind of relentless impersonal forces of which Marx wrote; instead it is a "willed artefact . . . a human construct in which many conscious and unconscious factors played their part. It appeared to have some of the interplay of the conscious and unconscious that we find in dreams". Like dreams, the form of cities is malleable, and as a happy consequence we can do something to change them for our own ends.

Cities, says Rykwert in a revealing history-is-about-chaps moment, "are the aggregate products of the choices that were made by individuals". They do not develop organically - "they are too consciously manipulated" for that - but "develop quite unnaturally by jumps, by fits and starts". This "abrupt and uneven jigsaw of conscious and unconscious workings is exactly what I have always found both fascinating and perplexing". You and me both, professor.

So when did the city go off the rails in so many people's minds and experience? What happened to the golden age of fifth-century Athens? Rykwert, an unashamed city-lover, reminds us that the city has always been under attack by critics who have seen it as a symbol of humankind's fall from grace. Here is Andrew Marvell, quoting from Genesis: "And Cain . . . builded a city; & called the name of the city, after the name of his son, Enoch" (Gen 4:17). What the poet wishes to say is that the first city was built by a murderer as a shelter for sinful humanity driven out of the garden of Eden.

Not a promising start, then. As for the Greeks, not all of them were in love with the "polis"; it was mocked by Aristophanes, while Horace, Martial and Juvenal all laid into Rome. Rykwert might have quoted Julius Caesar here, too: the great soldier and controversial republican dictator com plained loudly in letters about the noise that continued throughout the Roman night and kept him awake. As for the early Christians, their ideal city was, of course, the heavenly or New Jerusalem described in gridded detail by St John in the Apocalypse. Intriguingly, Rykwert goes on to show how idealistic Christian sects - the Shakers, for example - were to build earthly settlements and buildings along St John's divine lines. The heavenly city could, in an unsatisfactory temporal way, be recreated in outline on earth.

Earthly cities, full of people making things and money, dancing, eating, singing and making love, can never be as squeaky clean as the New Jerusalem. A healthy, happy city will always be a bit messy, abounding with energy, passion and creativity and the disorder these qualities bring in their Dionysian wake. Rykwert is not against disordered cities, but against those that have lost their soul. No ideal resolution is possible, he argues, in big cities, partly because we all have different visions of what a city might be - the Shoreditch artist's idea will be as different from the Mayfair property developer's as the child sewing dresses in a Calcutta sweatshop will be from a Hollywood starlet shopping for the latest six-figure frocks on Fifth Avenue.

There may be no solution, says Rykwert, but by learning from history we can begin to understand the rules of the city-making game. We can see what to do and what not to do; what will make us happy and what will make us sad. What seems to have made so many of us sad at one time or another is the industrial city on overdrive and the subsequent dumb attempts - postmodern architecture with all its trite, whimsical conceits, for example - to tidy it up as it moves into a post-industrial phase. Rykwert spins through the creation of the industrial city and the ills spawned in its wake. But he is never so bald as to suggest, like some latter-day Aristophanes, Martial or Marvell, that all was wrong with the industrial city. It gave Rykwert himself his favourite "polis", New York. Without Bessemer and his invention of steel smelting or Otis and the first safe passenger lift, the charismatic Manhattan skyline would never have lifted off.

What Rykwert shows to devastating effect is the degree to which architects paid little heed to the plight of the inexorably expanding 19th-century city. They toyed with the design of public buildings, compounded grand urban planning theories (some quite mad), but only rarely considered the dystopian plight of the masses somehow surviving among rows of shabby buildings not fit to be called architecture, awash with sewage and ravaged by disease. "From this filthy sewer flows gold," wrote the social observer Alexis de Tocqueville in 1835; he was describing Manchester, workshop of the world.

A linear city that would have stretched from Madrid to St Petersburg, a gallery of railways set on arches around central London, garden cities, cities of towers: all these get their turn under Rykwert's microscope. When the professor gets to the 21st-century city, however, you can see him beginning to throw up his hands. We now live in a world of theme parks, of ersatz urban experiences, cyberspace and SimCity (city making reduced to a digitised game in which money rules). We have the city as all-but-redundant tourist attraction (Venice) and the instant new cities of southern China (Shenzhen, for example) as parodies of their old western counterparts. In a "the world is too much with us/getting and spending we lay waste our powers" moment, Rykwert turns to Wordsworth for solace. Faced with such inanities, he finds comfort in these lines:

The eye - it cannot choose but see;

We cannot bid the ear be still;

Our bodies feel, wher'er they be,

Against or with our will.

In other words, as sensual, sentient beings, we react viscerally against these dystopian visions, from SimCity to Shenzhen. And, in Rykwert's case, retreat to the glorious bustle of Manhattan. Here the city, for all the attempts to denigrate or undermine it by crude planning, mean building or escapist criticism, "remains unbeaten . . . though under constant siege [New York] has maintained its astonishing and contrary vitality". The greatest game of "polis" ever played, he might have said. You may well take issue with Rykwert and question whether New York is indeed the Athens of our day; but few authors can take you on such a convincing, rigorous and enjoyable journey from the fall of Adam and Eve to an electric-aided sunset over Manhattan. Rykwert's city game is well worth playing.

fields.headline: A bibliography of treason
fields.standfirst:
Anti-royal sentiment is nothing new, says John Mullan - English writers have been airing republican views with varying degrees of subtlety ever since Thomas More's Utopia
Special report: the future of the monarchy
Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: Anti-royal sentiment is nothing new, says John Mullan - English writers have been airing republican views with varying degrees of subtlety ever since Thomas More's Utopia
fields.body:
Like atheism, republicanism can seem conventional enough as a quiet, rational assumption, but distinctly odd as soon as it becomes an enthusiasm. Surely, some have argued, there are more important things to get worked up about. Yet there have been times when republicanism has made English pulses race. In the past, it has even seemed the best way of expressing ideals of social justice. There have been great writers for whom republicanism has seemed a channel for the essential powers of the human imagination. To see a world without monarchs has been the prerogative of visionaries and poets.

So republicanism has been a part of English literature as much as of English politics. Once, indeed, it was only through fiction that one could describe a society outside monarchy. Thomas More imagined a kind of communist republic in his Utopia, published while he was a courtier of Henry VIII. More would eventually lose his life for contradicting his monarch, yet his famous political fantasy was not considered a dangerous work. Intellectuals could always muse of perfect worlds, as Plato had originally done in his Republic. In the late 19th century, William Morris was still doing so, dreaming of a republican paradise of the future in his News from Nowhere (1890). (His title echoes More's coinage, Utopia, the Greek for "no place".)

For centuries, the educated classes drew their models of civic virtue from the literature of Greece and Rome, which provided rich republican precedents. Read Shakespeare's Roman plays and, without any gesture at subversion, you are admitted to a world which does not need kings, but in which nobility can still be nurtured. Elizabethans belonged to a society which cohered around a veritable cult of monarchy, yet they were free to admire Brutus in his principled opposition to the tyranny of rule by one individual. There is a long history of thinking of monarchy as the rule of fact, while entertaining a republic as an idealising fiction.

Some historians argue that it was only after, not before, executing Charles I in 1649 that English republicanism entered the realm of the possible. The English had killed their king and had to find impressive reasons for having done so. The need inspired the greatest of anti-monarchical writers, John Milton - "an acrimonious and surly republican", as Dr Johnson called him. His greatest work, Paradise Lost (1667), was composed after the commonwealth had perished and Charles II had returned to power. It is shadowed by this defeat of republican hopes, the poet's voice "unchanged/To hoarse or mute, though fallen on evil days,/On evil days though fallen, and evil tongues".

Before this fall, however, Milton had dedicated himself to "the Good old Cause" in a stream of pamphlet and polemic. He energetically defended the right of a people "to call to account a Tyrant, or wicked KING, and after due conviction, to depose, and put him to death". He ransacked biblical and classical texts for anti-monarchical passages in a 10-year rhetorical war on royalist sentiment. One of his surliest anti-monarchical works, Eikonoklastes, was written in response to a supposed memoir by Charles I, published at the time of his execution. Eikon Basilike, the Portraicture of His Sacred Majestie in His Solitudes and Sufferings - almost certainly a literary forgery - became one of the bestsellers of the age, convincing Milton of the gullibility of the populace: "fools and silly gazers". Republicans have ever regretted the sentimentality of the masses.

Milton was fortunate to escape with his life when the monarchy was restored in 1660 and he found himself "in darkness, and with dangers compast round". He was probably helped out of peril by fellow poet Andrew Marvell, a republican who managed to couch his views so indirectly that academics still find them difficult to tease out. Marvell's Horatian Ode upon Cromwell's Return from Ireland, one of the greatest of political poems, was claimed by both royalist and republican readers. Writers bend their imaginations to the times, and we cannot always tell where the heart is. The young John Dryden wrote poetry celebrating the providence of Cromwell's rule, but immediately upon Charles II's restoration he was celebrating royal justice and magnificence with the best of them.

The convictions of Milton and his friends did not perish. The sophisticated arguments of classical republicanism, which were to be put into practice in America, remained current among enlightened intellectuals in the 18th century. For these few there was still (as there scarcely is any longer) a republican intellectual tradition. They read Machiavelli (the godfather of republicanism) and works such as James Harrington's The Commonwealth of Oceana (1656), a vision of an ideal state built on the precedent of More's Utopia. Harrington wrote against Hobbes, who argued that humans, being selfish and violent, needed monarchies to keep them by fear from mutual destruction. Republicanism as Harrington bequeathed it was the consequence of believing in the goodness of human nature.

With the French revolution at the end of the 18th century, it was possible again to believe that men and women showed their capacity to make the world better when they got rid of kings and queens. This belief could be passionate if respect for monarchy seemed to stand for deeper human weaknesses. For the pioneering feminist Mary Wollstonecraft, in her Vindication of the Rights of Woman, the reverence of British subjects for their king was a model of voluntary enslavement, exactly analogous to the enslavement of women to men. Her future husband, William Godwin, denounced "the hyperbolical pretensions of monarchy" for sapping a society's moral energies. The very existence of a king, he said, was evidence of the intellectual cowardice of his subjects.

For some, the argument was a literary as well as political battle - a war of styles. The two great antagonists were Edmund Burke and Thomas Paine. Burke lamented the overthrowing of order and tradition in France in a high-aspiring rhetoric whose sonorousness embodied the very trust in customary sentiment for which it argued.

Paine's radicalism, in direct response, was a matter of form as much as content. "Lay the axe to the roots!" he exclaimed, writing in a style (designed to be read aloud) whose plainness and sarcasm put false refinement to the sword.

Paine was prosecuted for sedition not just because of his arguments, but also because of their accessibility. Yet his animus against George III was not always shared by other British radicals, even if the king's son, the Prince Regent, was generally reviled. "An old, mad, blind, despised and dying King" was how George III was characterised in Shelley's republican sonnet England in 1819, but four of those adjectives are not reasons for contempt, while "despised" was not strictly true. But Shelley, who was writing about the British monarchy from exile in Italy, took the person of the king as the mirror of man's moral failings. Like his father-in-law, Godwin, he made the monarch's existence a sign of all that was worst and weakest in human nature.

It is no accident that all the major English Romantic poets at least dabbled in republicanism. Literary and political revolutions seemed twinned, both born from a new faith in the imagination. Wordsworth's The Prelude, completed in 1805 when the poet had retreated from the radical politics of his youth, remains the most eloquent testament of this enthusiasm. In its first flush, Wordsworth and others produced versions of republicanism that would later embarrass them. Wordsworth wrote his passionate Letter to the Bishop of Llandaff, an unflinching vindication of the execution of Louis XVI and Marie Antoinette. It dismisses any expression of horror at the execution as "the idle cry of modish lamentation" and envisages a kingless state with universal (male) suffrage.

Luckily for the future poet laureate, it remained unpublished and the evidence of his youthful radicalism remained buried in his poems of the period, preoccupied with the plight of vagrants and the rural poor. Wordsworth's friend Southey did, however, publish his drama Wat Tyler, a celebration of revolutionary republicanism as personified by the legendary leader of the Peasants' Revolt. He was mortified years later when Chartist radicals began reprinting it. By then a steadfast Tory and Anglican, he went to court to have the publication of his own work banned.

For some Chartists in the 19th century, an end to monarchical power was symbolically associated with an extension of the suffrage. Their movement kept alive a resourceful, coarse literature of republican mockery and polemic, below the horizon of polite literary taste. Republicanism was one strain in the political satire of William Hone, whose lampoons and parodies were sometimes savagely illustrated by Cruikshank. In Victorian England, anti-monarchism closely followed the populist instincts of Chartism. Republicanism was kept alive by writers and publishers such as GMW Reynolds, who smuggled it into his cheap and highly popular mystery thrillers for lower-class readers.

Yet the greatest assistant to republicanism in all of the last two centuries was probably George IV. His sybaritism, his mistreatment of his wife (famously locked out of Westminster Abbey during his coronation) and his sheer grossness made vivid mock of monarchy. He inspired some of republicanism's most energetic flights of satirical fancy, from Byron's devilish Vision of Judgement to Shelley's raucously contemptuous Swellfoot the Tyrant.

In recent times, equally, the private lives of members of the royal family have seemed to threaten their status far more than any political antagonist. Coleridge in the 1790s, when republicanism was truly afoot, reflected on a lesson for monarchists and anti-monarchists alike: "If Monarchs would behave like republicans, all their subjects would act as royalists." Perhaps the legacy of our rich literature of republicanism is the sense that its greatest resource is not the force of intellectual argument, but the mere misconduct of royalty.

For centuries, the educated classes drew their models of civic virtue from the literature of Greece and Rome, which provided rich republican precedents. Read Shakespeare's Roman plays and, without any gesture at subversion, you are admitted to a world which does not need kings, but in which nobility can still be nurtured. Elizabethans belonged to a society which cohered around a veritable cult of monarchy, yet they were free to admire Brutus in his principled opposition to the tyranny of rule by one individual. There is a long history of thinking of monarchy as the rule of fact, while entertaining a republic as an idealising fiction. Some historians argue that it was only after, not before, executing Charles I in 1649 that English republicanism entered the realm of the possible. The English had killed their king and had to find impressive reasons for having done so. The need inspired the greatest of anti-monarchical writers, John Milton - "an acrimonious and surly republican", as Dr Johnson called him. His greatest work, Paradise Lost (1667), was composed after the commonwealth had perished and Charles II had returned to power. It is shadowed by this defeat of republican hopes, the poet's voice "unchanged/To hoarse or mute, though fallen on evil days,/On evil days though fallen, and evil tongues". Before this fall, however, Milton had dedicated himself to "the Good old Cause" in a stream of pamphlet and polemic. He energetically defended the right of a people "to call to account a Tyrant, or wicked KING, and after due conviction, to depose, and put him to death". He ransacked biblical and classical texts for anti-monarchical passages in a 10-year rhetorical war on royalist sentiment. One of his surliest anti-monarchical works, Eikonoklastes, was written in response to a supposed memoir by Charles I, published at the time of his execution. Eikon Basilike, the Portraicture of His Sacred Majestie in His Solitudes and Sufferings - almost certainly a literary forgery - became one of the bestsellers of the age, convincing Milton of the gullibility of the populace: "fools and silly gazers". Republicans have ever regretted the sentimentality of the masses. Milton was fortunate to escape with his life when the monarchy was restored in 1660 and he found himself "in darkness, and with dangers compast round". He was probably helped out of peril by fellow poet Andrew Marvell, a republican who managed to couch his views so indirectly that academics still find them difficult to tease out. Marvell's Horatian Ode upon Cromwell's Return from Ireland, one of the greatest of political poems, was claimed by both royalist and republican readers. Writers bend their imaginations to the times, and we cannot always tell where the heart is. The young John Dryden wrote poetry celebrating the providence of Cromwell's rule, but immediately upon Charles II's restoration he was celebrating royal justice and magnificence with the best of them. The convictions of Milton and his friends did not perish. The sophisticated arguments of classical republicanism, which were to be put into practice in America, remained current among enlightened intellectuals in the 18th century. For these few there was still (as there scarcely is any longer) a republican intellectual tradition. They read Machiavelli (the godfather of republicanism) and works such as James Harrington's The Commonwealth of Oceana (1656), a vision of an ideal state built on the precedent of More's Utopia. Harrington wrote against Hobbes, who argued that humans, being selfish and violent, needed monarchies to keep them by fear from mutual destruction. Republicanism as Harrington bequeathed it was the consequence of believing in the goodness of human nature. With the French revolution at the end of the 18th century, it was possible again to believe that men and women showed their capacity to make the world better when they got rid of kings and queens. This belief could be passionate if respect for monarchy seemed to stand for deeper human weaknesses. For the pioneering feminist Mary Wollstonecraft, in her Vindication of the Rights of Woman, the reverence of British subjects for their king was a model of voluntary enslavement, exactly analogous to the enslavement of women to men. Her future husband, William Godwin, denounced "the hyperbolical pretensions of monarchy" for sapping a society's moral energies. The very existence of a king, he said, was evidence of the intellectual cowardice of his subjects. For some, the argument was a literary as well as political battle - a war of styles. The two great antagonists were Edmund Burke and Thomas Paine. Burke lamented the overthrowing of order and tradition in France in a high-aspiring rhetoric whose sonorousness embodied the very trust in customary sentiment for which it argued. Paine's radicalism, in direct response, was a matter of form as much as content. "Lay the axe to the roots!" he exclaimed, writing in a style (designed to be read aloud) whose plainness and sarcasm put false refinement to the sword. Paine was prosecuted for sedition not just because of his arguments, but also because of their accessibility. Yet his animus against George III was not always shared by other British radicals, even if the king's son, the Prince Regent, was generally reviled. "An old, mad, blind, despised and dying King" was how George III was characterised in Shelley's republican sonnet England in 1819, but four of those adjectives are not reasons for contempt, while "despised" was not strictly true. But Shelley, who was writing about the British monarchy from exile in Italy, took the person of the king as the mirror of man's moral failings. Like his father-in-law, Godwin, he made the monarch's existence a sign of all that was worst and weakest in human nature. It is no accident that all the major English Romantic poets at least dabbled in republicanism. Literary and political revolutions seemed twinned, both born from a new faith in the imagination. Wordsworth's The Prelude, completed in 1805 when the poet had retreated from the radical politics of his youth, remains the most eloquent testament of this enthusiasm. In its first flush, Wordsworth and others produced versions of republicanism that would later embarrass them. Wordsworth wrote his passionate Letter to the Bishop of Llandaff, an unflinching vindication of the execution of Louis XVI and Marie Antoinette. It dismisses any expression of horror at the execution as "the idle cry of modish lamentation" and envisages a kingless state with universal (male) suffrage. Luckily for the future poet laureate, it remained unpublished and the evidence of his youthful radicalism remained buried in his poems of the period, preoccupied with the plight of vagrants and the rural poor. Wordsworth's friend Southey did, however, publish his drama Wat Tyler, a celebration of revolutionary republicanism as personified by the legendary leader of the Peasants' Revolt. He was mortified years later when Chartist radicals began reprinting it. By then a steadfast Tory and Anglican, he went to court to have the publication of his own work banned. For some Chartists in the 19th century, an end to monarchical power was symbolically associated with an extension of the suffrage. Their movement kept alive a resourceful, coarse literature of republican mockery and polemic, below the horizon of polite literary taste. Republicanism was one strain in the political satire of William Hone, whose lampoons and parodies were sometimes savagely illustrated by Cruikshank. In Victorian England, anti-monarchism closely followed the populist instincts of Chartism. Republicanism was kept alive by writers and publishers such as GMW Reynolds, who smuggled it into his cheap and highly popular mystery thrillers for lower-class readers. Yet the greatest assistant to republicanism in all of the last two centuries was probably George IV. His sybaritism, his mistreatment of his wife (famously locked out of Westminster Abbey during his coronation) and his sheer grossness made vivid mock of monarchy. He inspired some of republicanism's most energetic flights of satirical fancy, from Byron's devilish Vision of Judgement to Shelley's raucously contemptuous Swellfoot the Tyrant. In recent times, equally, the private lives of members of the royal family have seemed to threaten their status far more than any political antagonist. Coleridge in the 1790s, when republicanism was truly afoot, reflected on a lesson for monarchists and anti-monarchists alike: "If Monarchs would behave like republicans, all their subjects would act as royalists." Perhaps the legacy of our rich literature of republicanism is the sense that its greatest resource is not the force of intellectual argument, but the mere misconduct of royalty.

webTitle: Review:  Letter from an Unknown Woman by  Stefan Zweig

fields.headline: Letter from an Unknown Woman
fields.trailText:
Letter from an Unknown Woman Stefan Zweig

(Pushkin Press, £7)
Buy it at BOL
fields.body:
Letter from an Unknown Woman Stefan Zweig

(Pushkin Press, £7)
Buy it at BOL

"Can you understand, now, what a miracle, what an alluring enigma you seemed to me, the child? Here was a man of whom everyone spoke with respect because he wrote books, and because he was famous in the great world? Of a sudden he had revealed himself to me as a boyish, cheerful young man of five-and-twenty! I need hardly tell you henceforward, in my restricted world, you were the only thing that interested me ..."

So writes the apparently unknown woman of the title in Stefan Zweig's moving short tale of an unrequited love that is brought to a tragic conclusion. The story was filmed by Max Ophuls in 1948, starring Louis Jourdan and Joan Fontaine. It is all the more moving because Zweig's life itself had its own dark ending. Born into a wealthy Austrian-Jewish family in 1881 in Vienna, he became known as a poet and translator and later as a prose writer. With the rise of Nazism he moved briefly to London in 1934, then New York and finally Brazil - where together with his wife he was found dead in bed in 1942 in what appeared to be a double suicide.

The volume also includes "The Fowler Snared": more or less the same scenario, except this time it is the man whose love is unrequited.

webTitle: John O'Farrell on the SAS novelists

fields.headline: Kill-and-tell
fields.standfirst: The SAS novelists' success is a challenge for the army, and might win new readers too
fields.trailText: The SAS novelists' success is a challenge for the army, and might win new readers too
fields.body:
It was just another literary luncheon in Hampstead. Martin Amis and Melvyn Bragg were sipping Pouilly Fumé and discussing the Booker shortlist when suddenly there was a loud explosion and the french windows were smashed in.

Smoke bombs and stun grenades rolled across the floor as three figures in black balaclavas abseiled in through the window. And John Mortimer looked up from his canapés and said: "I think it's rather spoiled the atmosphere since all these SAS writers started coming along."

The SAS kill-and-tell book is now established as one of the most successful literary genres of the last decade. Magical realism is all very well, but frankly the airport bookshops are hoping that Zadie Smith's next novel will feature a few more gory gun battles with Iraqi commandos. Earlier this year I found myself at a booksellers dinner alongside Chris Ryan.

"You'd never guess he'd been in the SAS," I thought, as he tucked into his slap-up meal of two earwigs and a bit of moss, and then sent back his glass of water because it wasn't dirty enough. He shook my hand at the end of the evening and I still have the bruises on my fingers to prove it. There were plenty of other authors at the event but they never stood a chance; all the literary middle-class liberals who work in the bookshops were queuing up to ask Ryan what sort of gun he used when he killed all those Iraqis.

But at the SAS training camp they've stopped bothering with rifles and grenades. The new recruits stand to attention and give their name, rank and ISBN number. Then they demonstrate how to strip down a fountain pen and load a new ink cartridge in 30 seconds flat. Squaddies leap out of the armoured troop carrier at the top of Charing Cross Road, and have to sign at every bookshop in time to make their author talk at Waterstone's Piccadilly.

In fact, the market for SAS books actually peaked a couple of years ago, so now is the time that the Ministry of Defence have chosen to take some legal action and give the genre the shot in the arm that it needs. With all the foresight that the MoD showed when it dropped the Bravo Two Zero team behind Iraqi lines equipped with only a cheese grater and a 1960s street map of Kettering, they have tried to prevent the publication of the latest account of that mission, giving the book far more publicity than the publishers could have dreamed of. Now the British public will be denied the chance to buy it on Amazon.co.uk and will have to suffer the huge inconvenience of going all the way to Amazon.com instead.

The upper reaches of the British military disapprove of these books because they claim that they create a security risk. In fact what is really at the root of their irritation is something far more deeply rooted than their concern for national security, and that is good old-fashioned class prejudice.

It's always been all right for the officer class to write worthy hardbacks to give to each other at Christmas. Ever since the second world war officers have been writing books about the SAS; there is even a biography of the regiment's founder by General Sir Peter de la Billière. He decided to write a 100,000 words, put his name at the top of the page and then found he was half way there already.

What rankles with the army high command is that these new chaps who are selling millions of copies - why, they're just ordinary soldiers. "So leaving the armed services and ending up sleeping on the streets like all the others isn't good enough for them I suppose?" If the new breed of SAS writers were not so successful, their superiors wouldn't bother doing anything about them.

Andy McNab's Bravo Two Zero is the bestselling war book of all time, and apart from anything else he has saved the army recruiting office a small fortune in advertising. Though these books may not be to the taste of most Guardian readers they are reaching an audience which includes many people who might otherwise never think of going into a bookshop.

Admittedly an 18-year-old squaddie is not going to put down Immediate Action and think, "Blimey I quite enjoyed reading a book, I think I'll try that Vikram Seth bloke next." But he might read the next Andy McNab and then he'll find he has moved effortlessly from non-fiction to fiction and then the idea of regularly reading novels is not such an impossibility.

This, of course, is to be welcomed. Not just because we want a more literate society, not just because it will help make him a fuller person. But because this squaddie is going to need all the literary skills he can get in the future. The moment he's out of the army, a dozen publishers will be waiting for him.

"Right!" they'll say. "All set to write us a book about it?"

fields.headline: Knowing all the right people
fields.standfirst: Biographer Artemis Cooper explains her network to John Cunningham
fields.trailText: Biographer Artemis Cooper explains her network to John Cunningham.
fields.body:
A biographer could hardly get luckier: it's almost habitual for Artemis Cooper to get a phone call asking if she'd like to do a book about X or Y; uncanny the way filing cabinets stuffed with personal letters and papers of the subject fall across her path when she begins a project.

Ten years after Cooper did a phone interview with Elizabeth David (the subject of her new book), about Brits in Cairo during the second world war, a call came out of the blue from an editor at Penguin. Would she be interested in portraying the life of Mrs David - who brought the first glint of the Mediterranean to middle-class kitchens in the dreary 1950s?

She would. Cooper's career had started with another chunk of good fortune. Philip Ziegler, biographer of her grandmother, Lady Diana Cooper, wondered if Artemis could edit a collection of her letters? Indeed she could.

In difficult circumstances even, good luck comes to her rescue: Cooper was contracted to do a book about Paris after the Liberation. It had to be in the shops for the 50th anniversary - September 1994 - but she was way behind with her research. Happily, she was able to persuade a first class historian to pitch in as co-author: Antony Beevor, her husband.

The good fortune continues. Her next biography will be of the fabled travel writer Patrick Leigh Fermor. Beevor interviewed him for a book about Crete years ago, and raised the matter of a biography. Fermor said no, but they kept in touch, and he eventually relented, and agreed that Artemis should do the biog. She's just spent 10 days on Crete talking with Fermor and his wife, both in their mid-80s.

And as if that weren't enough, she confesses: "Paddy is an old friend of my family. I've known him since childhood." For not only does she have legendary grand-parents, the Duff Coopers, but her father is Mr Venice, John Julius Norwich, diplomat and historian of Byzantium.

Cooper is used to jokes about her well-connected world. She even makes them herself: "I hope it doesn't sound too awful, but some people inherit Unilever; I've inherited a magnificent network." There is a serious point, though: "Networks are only as good as what you do with them. Give me credit for that."

Connections help a biographer, but they are far from the whole story. Cooper had misgivings about the Elizabeth David project. As authorised biographer, she'd have access to diaries and documents, but what if David's literary trustee - Jill Norman, her friend and editor for 25 years - acted as censor?. Nothing to fear, there: "Jill was very open with me. I'm sure she's got her secrets, but she certainly told me a great deal."

Another misgiving was that someone was already burrowing into David's life: food historian Lisa Chaney. "Having a rival in the field was quite scary. Her book was out a year before mine, and did attract a good deal of attention. I had hoped it might not be quite so good."

Cooper was also anxious because she was no great expert on culinary matters. "I told them [publishers Michael Joseph]: 'While I am extremely greedy and interested in food, and not a bad cook, I don't know much about cooking.' They said: 'Oh, we don't want a foodie.'"

What she did know about was Egypt, where Elizabeth had fetched up in 1941, after having sailed away in a little boat on a romantic adventure to escape from gloomy England. Working in the ministry of information library in Cairo during the war, she met her husband, Tony David, an army officer.

Researching this period should have been relatively easy: "I certainly knew about the circles she was moving in. But there were times when it felt like the curse of Tutankhamun. No sooner would I get hold of someone than they would pop their clogs."

But there were compensations. David's papers had been fully indexed; and, even though "she never talks about her personal life in her letters", Cooper came across an extraordinary one to the great love of her life, Peter Higgins. David never recovered from their intermittent affair. In a long draught of anguish she laments his betrayal, and says that Higgins was the inspiration behind her books.

Cooper believes this was a wild exaggeration by a distraught David; but it illustrates the picture she paints of the magazine and paperback food writer who, in the course of 10 books, gradually turned out more scholarly tomes. There was a massive contrast between the cool prose and the elegant persona that David cultivated for 40 years, and the private rows and rages she had with lovers, relatives, editors and business partners

Ultimately, "Elizabeth David is an enigma", Cooper admits. There were rumours that the childless David was a lesbian: she may have had a fling, but Cooper has come up with no testimony of gay relationships. Sitting at her own kitchen table in Fulham, she says she admires Cooper's heroism. She had lots of reverses: a failed marriage, and her acrimonious withdrawal from the eponymous kitchen shop, opened in Pimlico in the swinging 1960s, which could have secured her financially.

There are still some loose ends, but Cooper is glad that biography isn't always a tidy business. "Who knows what may turn up in the future?" she says. All grist for a future edition.

 Buy Writing at the Kitchen Table at BOL

fields.headline: First novels
fields.trailText: Lisa Darnell looks at the best recent first novels
fields.body:
At a time when popular historians such as Simon Schama are writing books with all the punch of contemporary fiction, it is only to be expected that novelists should plunder history in return. American writer Betsy Tobin takes us back to a 17th-century England brimming with warm ale, witch hunts, evil humours and bleeding cures. Bone House (Review, £10), a euphemism for the complicated system of stays and corsets designed to rein in unnatural female passion, is the story of larger-than-life Dora, a zesty prostitute in a small god-fearing village. Known as the "great bellied woman", she provides physical and emotional solace to both men and women. But Dora dies horribly on the first page, and it is up to Tobin's young female narrator to find out why. All the bleak horrors of the period are conjured, but Tobin's workmanlike plot becomes stifling after a while. Less than satisfying as a mystery, the novel is nonetheless strong on atmosphere, and will appeal to devotees of the gothic romance.
Buy it at BOL

Another American, Darin Strauss, has imagined the stranger-than-fiction lives of Chang & Eng (Allison & Busby, £9.99). Born in early 19th-century China, these original Siamese twins were attached by a single wide band at their chest. Snatched from their parents by the King of Siam, they were kept as a show-piece before being sold to a travelling circus as a freakshow. Yet they soon became wealthy enough to dictate the pattern of their own lives, settled in America, married, and between them fathered 21 children. In this deft fabrication, though the brothers share a stomach they have little else in common. Chang, a charmer, becomes dependent on adulation and alcohol alike, whereas the more saturnine Eng reads Shakespeare and joins the Temperance movement. It is no surprise, given Strauss's winning lightness of touch and scrupulously realised descriptions of the Orient and of pre-Union society, that this novel received so much attention in America.
Buy it at BOL

The young and beautiful Lieutenant Adrian F is injured on his first day in action. His body is miraculously unmarked, but he is cruelly deprived of the lower half of his face. Confined to a Paris hospital for five years, he undergoes lengthy and painful reconstructive surgery which, although enabling him to eat again, still makes him appear a freak in the eyes of the woman he most desires. Bone House (Review, £10), a euphemism for the complicated system of stays and corsets designed to rein in unnatural female passion, is the story of larger-than-life Dora, a zesty prostitute in a small god-fearing village. Known as the "great bellied woman", she provides physical and emotional solace to both men and women. webTitle: Review:  High Albania by Edith Durham and Kosova Kosovo by Mary Motes

fields.headline: Non-fiction - 8 December
fields.trailText: Vera Rule looks at High Albania, by Edith Durham and Kosova Kosovo, by Mary Motes
fields.body:
High Albania

Edith Durham

(Phoenix, £12.99)
Buy it at BOL

Durham hacked through Albania/ Kosova in 1908, whenTurks still overlorded the Balkans, and her perceptions remain so pertinent that we know a correspondent who operated there last year with an old edition of this book in lieu of a Nato briefing. Durham defined that essential divide between the angular patterning of the Slavic Serbs and the Illyrian bronze age/arabesque coils and curves of the Albanian - the fault line of the human soul. She (being curviform herself) made it the basis of her understanding as she wandered the wilds in her waterproof Burberry skirt, sketching the local modes of headshaves.

Kosova Kosovo

Mary Motes

(Merlin Press, £10.95)
Buy it at BOL

Motes arrived to teach in Pristina in the 1960s, past gypsy carts towing large brown dancing bears down Marshal Tito Street, and returned repeatedly, with precious rolls of toilet paper for her friends on both sides of that "a/o" division in the land's identity until her last entry, June 1999, when her closest pals called to say they had just had Nescafé with Brit soldiers. These are memoirs without pretensions, but they are so observant - the red apples of Pec, the bottles of Kosovski Kabernet - and vivid that they make up the best description of the region since Edith Durham.

webTitle: Review: Raymond Roussel and the Republic of Dreams  by Mark Ford

fields.headline: Glorious freaks
fields.standfirst: Stephen Romer  hails the enigma of Raymond Roussel in Mark Ford's biography
fields.trailText: Stephen Romer hails the enigma of Raymond Roussel in Mark Ford's biography
fields.body:
Raymond Roussel and the Republic of Dreams

Mark Ford

312pp, Faber, £25
Buy it at BOL

The glory of Raymond Roussel (1877-1933) is to have carried through, to a degree of excess, all that he did. The way he dressed, for example. The cover of this book shows him resplendent in white hat, high collar, silk shirt and tie, tie pin, tweed jacket, white flannels and shoes, sporting a cane: the ultimate dandy. Accentuated by the curling handlebar moustache, he looks out at the viewer with an air of mild amusement as though from somewhere far away. Posing in front of the artificial backdrop of the studio, he seems to have alighted, like a character in one of his works, flawlessly dressed, into a perfectly arbitrary universe in which he will perform some astonishing, unprefaced act of ventriloquism or physical acrobatics.

This mesmerising blend of extreme descriptive (or sartorial) precision and total lack of apparent raison d'étre has fascinated his followers and exasperated his detractors ever since Roussel first felt called upon to grace the public with his works. Casting around for the right adjective, "Pythonesque" comes to mind, in its association of the stuffily conventional with the berserk. Ardent rousseltre John Ashbery, in many ways godfather to this critical biography by Mark Ford, describes the Frenchman's works as "the perfectly preserved temple of a cult which has disappeared without trace, or a complicated set of tools whose use cannot be discovered".

In his excellent book, Ford prefaces his plunge into the labyrinth with a statement of aims: "I determined to try to make him appear as a writer who is worth reading, rather than as an engaging exotic or an intriguing case history." Winding up his account of this unique life and works, however, Ford wittily concedes that, after all, "no age could be ready for a wind-powered road-mender's tool capable of making a mosaic out of human teeth, or hairs dancing the jig 'Sir Roger de Coverly' from pore to pore across a man's bald pate, or tarot cards containing tiny insects that perform 'The Bluebells of Scotland', or a furless cat who transforms himself into a living battery and stimulates the remnants of Danton's head to fresh flights of oratory".

This litany of wonders comes from the 1914 novel Loctis Solus and could be extended almost indefinitely, such is the fecundity of Roussel's imagination. But he has claims on our attention, Ford argues, for reasons beyond those of inventing weird contraptions. These reside chiefly in his procédé, a technique based on the pun which, in true Roussellian cloak-and-dagger fashion, he revealed posthumously, in a book entitled Comment j'ai écrit certains de mes livres. One example of the procédé transforms the phrase " Napoleon premier empereur " into " nappe ollé ombre miettes hampe air heure" (tablecloth olé shadow crumbs pole wind time). As Ford explains: "For the first of four elements he devised a scene in which castanet-clicking dancers perform a lively flamenco on a fully laden table." He continues: "While on one level the procédé reveals all words - or fragments of words - to have potential double meanings, on another it imposes on them the strictest possible laws of connection."

It should be clear even from this brief exposé why Roussel has been championed by more recent writers who foreground the opacity, autonomy and self-proliferating nature of language. The Oulipo group were natural followers (one thinks of Queneau's sonnet "machine"), but Alain Robbe-Grillet and Michel Butor have also cast him as one of the founders of the nouveau roman. Confronting Roussel's poem "La Vue", a 73-page description of a tiny beach scene enclosed behind glass in a pen-holder, written in hypnotic alexandrines, Robbe-Grillet remarked on its "demented acuity" and the "total transparency, which leaves neither shadow nor reflection behind it". And he captures the most disturbing effect to be found in all of Roussel's writing: "Roussel describes, and beyond what he describes, there is nothing." There is no moral contour - in Impressions d'Afrique circus acts alternate with ingeniously horrible executions, in a kind of karaoke-cum-freakshow, all described with the same implacable neutrality. There is no hint of transcendence, no psychology, barely any subjectivity. Which is why, tempting though it is to liken Roussel to Proust, as his "dark, disturbed double" - they were both handsome, rich (Roussel fantastically so), bourgeois, homosexual, neurasthenic, reclusive - their work is radically different.

With what Ford beautifully calls his "inviolable naivety", Roussel lays out his procédé with all the seriousness of the professor-heroes of Poe or his beloved Jules Verne, up there with Dante and Shakespeare (probably a little higher) in Roussel's eccentric pantheon. And it is this inviolable naivety that, throughout the extraordinary episodes and vicissitudes of his life, gives Roussel his charm and makes him so irresistible. Born into a vast fortune, the son of an adoring, eccentric mother - she had a set of bathtubs installed for her chihuahas in her Biarritz villa - Roussel never really had to leave what he called "the perfect bliss" of his pampered childhood.

At the age of 19, while writing his first interminable poem, "La Doublure", he underwent an experience that he called " la gloire". The conviction that he was to be one of the greatest writers of all time never really left him. As he explained to his psychiatrist Pierre Janet - who, not surprisingly, later wrote up the poet as a case history - he could compose his poems only in carefully screened rooms because "to leave these papers lying about would have sent out rays of light as far as China". Roussel would not be Roussel, as Ford admits, if one did not have to ask the question his critics always asked: "Is Roussel mad? Or is he possessed of such luminous powers that we cannot bear the glare?" "Is it nothing? Or is it everything?"

Even the Surrealists, who were almost alone in championing Roussel during his lifetime, could not fathom him. And Roussel, with supreme irony, never cared much for this audience of Young Turks, venturing that he found their works "un peu obscur". The story of his dealings with them, sometimes carried on through his business manager or a detective agency, is a long, exquisitely polite and baffled malentendu. It is also richly comic - as are the accounts of Roussel's ruinous theatrical ventures in his attempt to buy the public acclaim which always eluded him. As Cocteau suggested, Roussel's genius "extends to the furthest type of extreme of the practical". In his lifetime, he invented a type of house insulation, devised the first custom-built camper van - his famous roulotte - and calculated a fiendish endgame in chess. He also went on two world tours, spending most of the time sealed off behind closed curtains. Quite apart from these singular achievements, we have his works. No words can describe them adequately, though Mark Ford, in his delicate, patient and tactful way, sets forth their procedures with admirable clarity. His book should swell the numbers of those now dedicated to furthering la gloire of Raymond Roussel.

fields.headline: Fiction - 9 December
fields.trailText: Isobel Montgomery is lost at sea with Ship Fever, plus Going, Going, Gone, Brilliant Careers: The Virago Book of 20th Century Fiction and A Mother's Kisses
fields.body:
Ship Fever, by Andrea Barrett (Flamingo, £6.99)

Each of these stories could serve as a preparatory sketch for an epic. Writers whose trade is plundering the past and fictionalising the biographies of great men or great times must be cursing Barrett for making use of Gregor Mendel, Carl Linnaeus, 19th-century scientific voyagers and Grosse Isle off the Canada coast, where Irish emigrants were quarantined before being allowed into the New World. Barrett, though, lends emotion to history. Linnaeus is an old man who cannot remember his daughter's name; and we see from a woman's point of view the egoism of scientific discovery. Barrett has subtlety, elegance and a fine understanding of human nature.

Going, Going, Gone, by Jack Womack (Voyager, £6.99)

The point of Womack is linguistic fireworks: every sentence is a small display with a show-off image. He makes sure every paragraph will win a few rounds of applause and then some, but essentially he rewrites Chandler substituting 1960s east coast, LSD and politics for 1930s west coast, bourbon and divorce cases. Walter Bullitt does things on the quiet for men in Washington but prefers "hep" New York. He isn't too happy with a new assignment involving Robert Kennedy, nor with the two ghostly figures who have moved into his brain. Weird piles on weird, but after a few near-death experiences Bullitt gets the girl and straightens things out.

Brilliant Careers: The Virago Book of 20th Century Fiction, eds Ali Smith, Kasia Boddy & Sarah Wood (Virago, £9.99) ; The Secret Woman: The Virago Book of Classic Short Stories, ed Lynn Knight (Virago, £8.99)

Either of these repackagings of the 20th century's best female writing is a good idea; both is too much. Brilliant Careers picks a writer a year to illustrate the past century - Elaine Dundy, Miles Franklin (of course), E M Nesbit, Gillian Slovo, Eudora Welty and so on - and tells a literary history in fragments. Secret Lives gives you complete "classic" stories by authors who all appear in the first book. Of the two, Brilliant Careers works better as a taster of Virago's back catalogue.

A Mother's Kisses, by Bruce Jay Friedman (Chicago, £9)

Friedman wrote a couple of multiplex teen movies - Splash and Stir Crazy - but back in the mid-1960s he was being held up as the "new JD Salinger" for Stern and this, his second novel. Joseph is a disgruntled Brooklyn teenager who, when he doesn't get into Columbia, fills up with teenage ennui. Everything should be tentative fumbles with local girls and all-purpose desperation, except for the presence of Joseph's mother Meg, the archetypal Brooklyn matriarch. The pairing of the Jewish mother-and-son gag with the tortured adolescent makes for a brilliantly funny picaresque in which neither archetype is allowed to upstage the other.
