fields.headline: The Red Badge of Courage, by Stephen Crane
fields.standfirst:
(Naxos, £11.99, 320 mn)
Buy the book at BOL
Hear an extract
You will need RealPlayer to listen to this clip. You can download it here free
fields.trailText: Fight or flight? How will a soldier coming under fire for the first time behave?
fields.body: Fight or flight? How will a soldier coming under fire for the first time behave? This disturbing fiction, published in 1895, explores the tortured emotions of Henry Fleming, a young bluecoat recruit in the American Civil War as he steels himself for, fights, then flees from his first battle. It is remarkable for its convincing exposition of the mental pressures on a soldier by a young author who had not experienced combat - Crane was born six years after the Civil War. Interest is sustained through the plodding pace by flashes of insight, high-grade descriptions of confusion, and an aura of authenticity. I was initially anxious that the voice of the reader, Walter Lewis, would not bear me through the first five minutes. It's light, high and with a timbre that can sound whiney to British ears. But it settles into the perfect nervy tone for the gawky adolescent rookie scared witless.

webTitle: Review: Crying by Tom Lutz and Laughter by Robert Provine

fields.headline: Laugh? I nearly cried
fields.standfirst: Giles Foden  on links between weeping and whooping in Crying: The Natural and Cultural History of Tears and Laughter: A Scientific Investigation
fields.trailText: Giles Foden on links between weeping and whooping in Crying: The Natural and Cultural History of Tears and Laughter: A Scientific Investigation
fields.body:
Crying: The Natural and Cultural History of Tears

Tom Lutz

352pp, Norton, £11.95
Buy it at BOL

Laughter: A Scientific Investigation

Robert R. Provine

258pp, Faber, £12.99
Buy it at BOL

In his excellent book Laughter at the Foot of the Cross (1999), M A Screech considered the uses of laughter at certain moments in the Bible. Sometimes these are belly laughs, sometimes chuckles, sometimes the dark laughter of the grotesque - as when Christ is laughed at by spectators as he hangs in agony at Golgotha.

The crucifixion is, perhaps, the classically dangerous cultural rendezvous for laughter and tears, and not just in Monty Python's Life of Brian. The uneasy conjoining of the two has been a feature of Western civilisation right from Euripides (maniacal women kicking a severed head round like a football) to Northern Irish poet Paul Muldoon (the ambivalent trembling of a trifle that may, or may not, be a terrorist bomb).

Maybe the Greek and the Irishman have it right. In an absurd world, perhaps a bit of nervous laughter is more honest than floods of tears. As Tom Lutz points out in Crying: The Natural and Cultural History of Tears - one of two new books in the burgeoning literature of emotion - there is a tradition of moral weeping that has more to do with a show of piety than with genuine sadness. This piety isn't always heavenly. Saint Augustine, who unlike other divines found himself unable to sob his troubles into God's ear, would no doubt have disapproved of teenagers crying themselves a river through Titanic.

Although some argue that elephants shed the odd tear in sadness and we know that crocodiles express fluid from their lachrymal ducts when opening their mouths very wide (thus crocodile tears), it is generally agreed that humans are the only animals who cry because of their feelings. We do so at our most important thresholds - birth, love, sex, death - and we do so in different ways but most often when "least able to fully verbalise" overwhelming emotions.

Yet, as Lutz elaborates, some crying is a turning away from emotion rather than a purging of it: he adduces the evidence of deposition scenes (the lowering of the dead Christ from the cross) in hundreds of classical paintings, in which there is invariably a weeping figure not looking at the body. Often it is the Virgin Mother, and it could be argued that her tears, like those of many mourners since, "signal a desire, a wish, or a plea".

Tears taken to signify the bereaved's desire to "wind the clock back" may seem inappropriate for Mary, but it makes more sense when you think of Freud's 1909 lectures at Clark University in the US, where he argued, in Lutz's paraphrase, that "patients need to come to terms with their desires rather than their loss". In some paintings, such as Giovanni Bellini's Pietà in the Accademia in Venice, Mary has clearly done this, lying with the body in her lap, her face full of the profound sorrow of acceptance. She is contemplating events rather than demanding their reversal. There is no apostrophe (literally, in Greek, a "turning away"), no address or appeal to the apparently absent Father, and not a single teardrop curls down her cheek.

Contemplative acceptance is the challenge of the bereaved, even if they do not have a Christ to redeem their loss. For crying infants, meanwhile, redemption comes in the shape of food or attention. A child's tears demand a reaction, although if neglected it will, like a severely depressed person, stop crying altogether. "It is the infant who believes it will be picked up that wails," says Lutz, "energised by its fear that it will be left alone."

For Darwin, crying was simply standard mammalian behaviour; later followers have built sophisticated theories of the "separation cry" as the oldest evolutionary vocalisation, a tracking device well suited to nocturnal forest-dwellers, though still with us through the plasterboard of many a bedroom wall.

Grown-up tears can sometimes mask calculated demands, as Mr Bumble knows when his wife starts to blub in Oliver Twist : "Tears were not the things to find their way to Mr Bumble's soul; his heart was waterproof. Like washable beaver hats that improve with rain, his nerves were rendered stouter, and more vigorous, by showers of tears, which being tokens of weakness, and so far tacit admissions of his own power, pleased and exalted him." He goes so far as to encourage her to continue: "'It opens the lungs, washes the countenance, exercises the eyes, and soften downs the temper,' said Mr Bumble. 'So cry away.'"

Did Dickens know about goblet cells and the glands of Manz and Zeiz? Did he know that there are three types of crying: basal (continuous lubrication, at the rate of five to 10 ounces a day), reflex (onions, flies, pokes in the eye) and psychic (partners, parents, kids)? This useful book could have told him all the science; although, as Lutz freely concedes, it is at its best on the cultural rather than the natural history of tears.

The strongest passages are those concerned with potentially laughable weeping: the endless sobbing of Goethe's Young Werther, or the hero of Henry Mackenzie's 18th-century novel The Man of Feeling, who cries at just about everything, including the death of the house dog, Trusty. Of that book Fanny Burney, reading it aloud with friends, reported how they roared with laughter where 10 years earlier they had wept copiously. Oscar Wilde reacted against a later, Victorian wave of sentimentalism."One would have to have a heart of stone to read the death of Little Nell without laughing," he wrote, and accordingly gave a steely glint to his own fairy tales.

Perhaps the most interesting chapter in Robert Provine's Laughter: A Scientific Investigation deals with exactly such abnormal or inappropriate amusement, citing Titus Andronicus ("Why dost thou laugh? It fits not with this hour") on the return of the eponymous Roman general's own severed hand and the heads of the two sons it was supposed to ransom. The grotesquerie of Shakespeare's tragedy would take a literary mind back to Euripides, but Provine's investigation is, as it says on the tin, a scientific one. He moves swiftly on to kuru, that degenerative neighbour of BSE in the early stages of which victims display "paroxysmal hilarity", often "laughing at their own stumbling gait and fall" with relatives sometimes joining in.

Kuru is just one of a number of fascinating conditions listed by Provine. They include the masque manganique , a fixed but jovial facial expression described in Moroccan miners suffering magnesium poisoning, and the toxic effects of crowfoot or wild parsley; profuse in Sardinia, it gave us and Homer the term "sardonic laughter". Provine's enjoyable fairground tour of the science of the laugh also takes us to sound labs and opera houses (can there be a true musical notation of laughter?) and raises the ticklish question of why we can't tickle ourselves. Elsewhere he considers everything from laughter's part in boosting the immune system to the role of laughter in speech evolution. As with grooming (the tit for tat of monkeys removing fleas from each other), it is clear that laughter was important in the development of social cohesion. Who knows, perhaps the first human sound uttered in those primeval forests was a "laugh of togetherness" rather than a "separation cry"?

This isn't as far-fetched as it first seems. Our relatives the chimpanzees produce a laugh-like sound, often when gambolling. It's an ah-ah-ah rather than the human ha-ha-ha, Provine tells us, before employing some nifty respiratory science in an attempt to propose a causal link between bipedalism, laughter and vocalisation.

It is a nice thought if true (better to begin with a laugh than a whimper), but the way laughter even among friends can so easily tip over into the aggressive or macabre shines a darker light on the thesis. The French philosopher Bergson thought that we laugh mainly when others are humiliated, particularly when they become mechanical or marionette-like or maimed. It is the sheer arbitrariness of this kind of laughter that makes it so terrifying: as like the closing shots of Harry Enfield's comedies as those stumbling kuru victims. As like a man nailed to a cross in a place called Golgotha.

webTitle: Review: Lady Caroline Lamb: This Infernal Woman by Susan Normington

fields.headline: A volcanic fairy
fields.standfirst: Frances Wilson  meets Byron's scandalous stalker in Susan Normington's biography of Lady Caroline Lamb
fields.trailText: Frances Wilson meets Byron's scandalous stalker in Susan Normington's biography of Lady Caroline Lamb
fields.body:
Lady Caroline Lamb: This Infernal Woman

Susan Normington

352pp, House of Stratus, £18.99
Buy it at BOL

Caroline Lamb, the notorious niece of Georgiana, Duchess of Devonshire and granddaughter of the first Earl Spencer, was described well by Byron, with whom she had a brief affair during the height of his celebrity, as "an exaggerated woman". She was born into the 18th-century aristocratic elite, an insular and inbred world which worshipped superficiality. The values of high society can be illustrated by its near idolisation of the dandy "Beau" Brummell, whose only notable characteristic, other than cynicism, was his perfectly knotted necktie.

While Brummell conformed to the fashionable world's fantasy of itself, Caroline Lamb did not. The adjective most commonly used of her was "volcanic": she was neither cool nor discreet at a time when these were the vital qualities needed in an unfaithful wife, and nor would she, as her collateral relation Princess Diana said, "go quietly" when both Byron and her husband's relations decided that they had had enough of her.

Caroline married into a powerful and newly rich family bent on establishing themselves at the heart of Whig society, but despite her impeccable pedigree and status she was loathed by the socially conscious Lambs for what they regarded as her self-publicising eccentricities. This included writing novels, the first of which, Glenarvon, was a bestselling scandalous satire of her circle and exposé of her relationship with Byron. Her in-laws unsuccessfully tried to ban any further literary output - Lamb produced two more novels and became something of a bluestocking - and when they proved unable to control her unpredictable behaviour took steps to have her certified insane. They failed in this too, but did succeed in separating her from her husband, William - after which she drank a bottle of sherry every day and died at the age of 41 while he became prime minister to Queen Victoria.

Susan Normington's reappraisal of Caroline Lamb is long overdue, and it is not claiming much to say that this enjoyable but slight book is the best biography to date. It has been Lamb's legacy to inspire dreadful prose, and Normington's is no exception. "With her sharp little chin, perfect complexion, golden-red curls, wide, hazel eyes and darting ways she sometimes seemed more like a fairy than a human being," she writes of her heroine, and the early days of Caroline's marriage to William Lamb are described as "a delicious mist of passion, fighting and making up".

Lamb's story has always spawned from her defenders and critics alike an army of hackneyed phrases and mawkish stereotypes. Henry Blyth, Lamb's previous biographer, describes his subject as having "small kittenish ways of showing her affection, with kisses that touched the cheek and tiny, intimate caresses". At the same time, "her small mouth could spit venom as well as list endearments. The tiny feet could stamp in fury". Lamb's whole personality is reduced to her height.

Apart from a few excruciating moments, Normington's representation of Caroline Lamb avoids the traditional resort to sentimentality, fantasy and misogyny, a spectacular example of which is Henry Blyth's suggestion that "One of the tragedies of their married life is that William had never beaten her at all, and scarcely even slapped her." This, Blyth will be happy to know, seems not to have been the case. Normington documents William's fetish for flogging women and little girls; a topic on which he felt so strongly that he hoped one day to write a treatise describing its virtues.

Susan Normington tells the story of Caroline Lamb's troubled marriage, thwarted literary talent and hectic affair with Byron in a clear, straightforward way - and that is the problem. There was little in Lamb's life that was clear and nothing that was straightforward; she was a product of a highly artificial world in which she was surrounded by hypocrites, perverts and duplicitous power seekers. By trying to rationalise her, Normington precisely avoids dealing with Lamb's intensely frustrated, and frustrating, self-sabotaging personality.

Normington's defence of Lamb is achieved at the cost of any analysis of her behaviour, as if admitting to psychological complexity might render her heroine culpable. This is most apparent in her account of Lamb's bizarre pursuit of Byron, which today would be seen as stalking. We read of her dressing up as a boy to gain access to Byron's rooms, forging his writing, ceremonially burning copies of his letters, sending him cuttings of her pubic hair, imitating his poetic style, poisoning his wife against him with dark hints of his incestuous and homosexual adventures - and all this is narrated without so much as an aside from the author on the nature of the frustrated desires that inspired such actions.

It is too simple to suggest that we are dealing here with a victim, and Normington makes her subject dull by presenting her as innocence confronting evil: how much more interesting it would be to consider instead why Lamb was so exaggerated in the first place.

webTitle: Review: The Diagnosis  by Alan Lightman

fields.headline: The anatomy of despair
fields.standfirst: Robert Edric  is unmoved by Alan Lightman's  modern parable of loss, The Diagnosis
fields.trailText: Robert Edric is unmoved by Alan Lightman's modern parable of loss, The Diagnosis
fields.body:
The Diagnosis

Alan Lightman

369pp, Bloomsbury, £16.99
Buy it at BOL

Neither of Alan Lightman's previous two novels will prepare the reader for the dull, familiar unfolding of The Diagnosis. Einstein's Dreams and Good Benito were exhilarating experiments in storytelling and dismantling; incisive, provocative and daring in what they attempted and, largely, achieved. The Diagnosis, though garlanded with all these same epithets (and shortlisted for the prestigious National Book Award), is a different thing entirely.

Simply put, the story is this: Bill Chalmers, successful financial analyst, living a good, modern, American, techno-fetishistic, consumer-obsessed life, suffers a blackout, followed by creeping numbness and gradual paralysis. A stroke, or perhaps something psychosomatic. Who can say? Certainly none of the doctors, specialists and analysts to whom he takes himself in his desperate quest for answers. This quest is watched and cruelly commented upon by his wife and son, neither any true support to him as he slowly loses his faith, hope and belief in the world which has created and sustained him so handsomely for so long.

The notions of loss and reevaluation in a society that, for all its innovations and medical miracles, cannot define or understand - let alone begin to cure - this devastating ailment remain the core of this book throughout. It is called The Diagnosis where none exists, and wants to be considered tragic where tragedy is measured all too often only in material loss and the refusal of others to understand. Lightman writes with force and felicity, and yet for all the instances of loss and degradation, of flickering hope and crushing despair, there is little genuine connection with the man at the centre of the maelstrom. Everything imaginable in this slow collapse of the soul is chronicled in the greatest detail, but these details neither clothe the man nor take us inside him.

Too many false notes sound. Bill's wife is having an email affair with a stranger at the start of the book, "talking" to him on the day of her husband's first collapse, but a few pages later the man has simply disappeared. Great swathes of this book are leavened (that, I imagine, was the hope) by endlessly mistyped emails, which soon become a distracting indulgence.

Considerably more indulgent are the sections chronicling the death of Sokrates (sic). These are intended to provide a powerful and stabilising counterpoint to the unimaginable and unstoppable collapse of Bill Chalmers, but they sit awkwardly beside the impressionistic, endlessly fracturing and reforming language of the modern story. Worse, they leave the main narrative sagging because the philosophical underpinning they are intended to provide (spurious at best) is simply not delivered.

Here, as elsewhere, Lightman writes with grace, clarity and imagination, but here, and here alone, without conviction. He may capture, as Norman Mailer has suggested, the pervasive spiritual poverty of an otherwise prosperous land, but he does this without the impact and the humour his readers have come to expect from him. And he does it in such a way that every tiny detail of Bill Chalmer's loss and disaffection is like a line drawn in gentle erasure across the flesh and blood of the man at the centre of this otherwise terrible and potentially moving story.

fields.headline: Book lovers
fields.trailText:
Let's meet tonight between the covers
to thumb each other's spines
fields.body:
Let's meet tonight between the covers

to thumb each other's spines

like true book lovers.

Steamy passion or sweet romance,

with titles picked at random,

our mood will depend on chance.

I'll stroke your hard back and thighs,

trail my fingers over your fly-

leaf - admire your point size.

You'll enjoy ogling my index,

fondling my frontispiece, thinking

I'm just the type you like for sex.

I'll let you flip my pages, skim

my contents, skip my appendix

or linger over my fine lines at whim.

And if I get pregnant (which I won't)

let's meet again - in nine months' time.

You choose the font.

You'll enjoy ogling my index, fondling my frontispiece, thinking I'm just the type you like for sex. I'll let you flip my pages, skim my contents, skip my appendix or linger over my fine lines at whim. And if I get pregnant (which I won't) let's meet again - in nine months' time. You choose the font.

webTitle: Lift the flap and stiffen the structure

fields.headline: Lift the flap and stiffen the structure
fields.trailText: Hipper-than-thou publishers Canongate threw a party this week at - where else? - the ICA to launch their new internet radio station, a 24/7/365 (that means it's on all the time) affair
fields.body:
 Hipper-than-thou publishers Canongate threw a party this week at - where else? - the ICA to launch their new internet radio station, a 24/7/365 (that means it's on all the time) affair that goes by the name of Dublab. You can access it through their website at canongate.net, but less adventurous readers might find themselves distracted by the cocky publishers' annual survey of the most hyped, least sold books of the year. Currently leading the field are Anthea Turner and Ronan Keating with their autobiographies (although the Boyzone frontman gets a unanimous five-star rating on Amazon), with a strong challenge from those ubiquitous New Puritans.

 In an effort to take hapless Christmas shoppers unawares, Penguin have chartered a big red bus to take their brightest stars - including Paddy Ashdown, Zadie Smith, Alain de Botton and Nick Hornby - on a mass bookshop crawl. Roll on congestion charging, the Loafer says.

 If rumours from the States are true, Amazon.com isn't having the best of festive seasons. According to one source, Borders has supplanted Amazon as top online bookseller; elsewhere, we hear that Amazon.com's website has crashed three times since Thanksgiving. Not the moment, then, for chief execs to read reports of staff problems in the New York Times, which has news of a company website containing guidelines to help managers root out furtive union activity. One helpful hint, apparently, is to beware of "small group huddles breaking up in silence on the approach of the supervisor". With anti-espionage tactics like that, we have no doubt they'll manage to identify the troublemakers.

 Just time to mention one of the literary calendar's most enjoyable awards, the Bookseller's Diagram Prize, presented to the book with the year's oddest title. This year's winner is High-Performance Stiffened Structures, published by Professional Engineering Publishing, with the intriguing-sounding Did Lewis Carroll Visit Llandudno? and Whose Bottom? A Lift-the-Flap Book as close runners-up. The Loafer's personal favourite, however, missed out on the gongs, but might provide a handy Christmas gift for the enthusiastic and fearless hobbyist: Woodcarving with a Chainsaw.

You can access it through their website at canongate.net, but less adventurous readers might find themselves distracted by the cocky publishers' annual survey of the most hyped, least sold books of the year. Currently leading the field are Anthea Turner and Ronan Keating with their autobiographies (although the Boyzone frontman gets a unanimous five-star rating on Amazon), with a strong challenge from those ubiquitous New Puritans.  In an effort to take hapless Christmas shoppers unawares, Penguin have chartered a big red bus to take their brightest stars - including Paddy Ashdown, Zadie Smith, Alain de Botton and Nick Hornby - on a mass bookshop crawl. fields.headline: Carol stingers
fields.standfirst: Adrian Mole, aged 33
fields.trailText: My boy asked, "What's a lump of coal?" I said, "It was a piece of black, shiny rock that we used to set fire to and burn in fireplaces." He laughed long and hard.
fields.body:
Tuesday, November 28, Ashby-de-la-Zouch

My mother has signed up to be an Earth Watch volunteer. She is hoping to count birds migrating over a lake in Kenya. Frankly, I am disgusted. My mother is abusing a worthy conservation project. To my sure knowledge, she has never shown the slightest interest in birds, Kenya or counting. She is obviously hoping to get a free holiday. Earth Watch should be informed: she can't even count. The figures for migrating Kenyan birds could be hopelessly confused for years to come. This could lead to stress and trauma amongst ornithologists and their possible premature deaths.

I confided in Glenn my worries about the orphans of the Kenyan ornithologists. He furrowed his brow: "Why are you worrying about somethin' that 'asn't 'appened yet, Dad." I had no satisfactory answer. Later, my therapist, Angela House, asked me precisely the same question. Perhaps I should give her £25 fee to Glenn. At least it would keep the money in the family, and save me the trouble of driving to Mrs House's house, thus avoiding the attendant parking problems and the embarrassment of overhearing Mr House urinating in the downstairs cloakroom.

Wednesday, November 29

I rang my mother's house this morning, and was astonished and outraged to learn that she was in Paris! Ivan Braithwaite told me she had gone to the hotel where Oscar Wilde died 100 years ago this week. How dare she swan about on the Eurostar when people are starving? It is disgusting. Especially when it is me who is the Wildean expert.

Few who saw it will ever forget my depiction of Lady Bracknell in the sex-swap performance of The Importance Of Being Earnest at Neil Armstrong Comprehensive School in 1982.

Friday, December 1

Brick Eagleburger has asked his solicitor, Peter Elf, to take a civil action against the American government. Brick is now convinced that his postal vote has been violated. Apparently, Mr Elf was reluctant at first to take on the US, being more used to doing a little light conveyancing in the Hampton Wick area.

Saturday, December 2

I have resigned from my position at Eddie's Layby Cafi. The work was very unfulfilling and I never properly came to terms with the constant smell of rancid fat on my clothes. Eddie took my resignation with equanimity. He said, "I knew you weren't cut out for the caterin' industry the first time I clapped eyes on yer. You ain't got the wrists for it." I asked him in what way my wrists were deficient. He answered, "They gotta be flexible for the butterin' and the fryin', an' your wrists are about as flexible as a lump of bleedin' coal."

I related this conversation to Glenn as we prepared lobster nuggets for our dinner. He asked, "What's a lump of coal?" I said, "It was a piece of black, shiny rock that we used to set fire to and burn in fireplaces." He laughed long and hard. The lad thinks that central heating has always been around. He probably thinks that Jesus had a double radiator in the manger.

Sunday, December 3

The rabble on the estate have formed themselves into a choir and are going from door to door demanding money for singing a few discordant notes of Slade's Merry Christmas Everybody. Those of us refusing to hand over a few silver coins are threatened that our wheelie bins will be pushed down the road and possibly overturned. I phoned Greg Dyke, our community policeman, but could only get his voicemail.

Monday, December 4

William has been chosen to play third shepherd in the school Nativity play. I went to Habitat tonight and bought him a new tea towel for his headdress. Only the best is good enough for my son.

fields.headline: Arabian nights
fields.standfirst: Vera Rule  explores western fantasies of the harem
fields.trailText: Vera Rule explores western fantasies of the harem
fields.body:
Harems of the Mind

Ruth Bernard Yeazell

314pp, Yale, £22.50

Buy it at BOL

Subjects of the Sultan

Suraiya Faroqhi 358pp, I B Tauris, £35

Buy it at BOL

Inside the Seraglio

John Freely

360pp, Penguin, £8.99
Buy it at BOL

Among the luscious plates in Yeazell's book are two Thomas Rowlandson cartoons: a turbanned pasha among a tumble of women, who stimulate him worshipfully; another potentate surveying nudes in tiered rows, exactly like shelves of porno mags in the newsagent's. In both drawings, the grand turk has a grander erection. But just the one, and such a choice to spend it on ... It's the definitive, subversive image of male-imagined omnipotence in this wicked study of western fantasies, literary and pictorial, about the private life of Islam.

The west got it all wrong, of course, even the name: the Turkish word haremlik means the place of sanctuary, the family side of the house. But the salacities started soon after the Ottomans swept in as the power challenging Europe from the east. True, the sultan kept the unlimited concubines allowed him by the Koran, and they did abide in discretion, if not total seclusion, in the saray (palace); but the west confused saray with the Italian serrare, to lock up, and conjured the seraglio as a whorehouse with Holloway-high security. Yeazell points out that the French and the English had the "richest tradition of oriental fantasising", perhaps because of their safe distance from janissary armies massing at the gates; and around 1700, they also had bric-a-brac from translations of the 1001 Nights, that compendium of dreams from medieval Baghdad and Cairo.

As Yeazell enjoys noting, the protestant English - and even the French, post-Rousseau - had a monogamous official culture that made the pluralities of the Ottoman sultancy, sauced piquantly with cruelty, alluring to men. Travellers, playwrights, artists, the Marquis de Sade, Mozart and makers of cheesy films alike have all drawn on and contributed to the west's collective myth of the harem as a brothel in which hundreds - or, for greedy Byron, thousands - of enslaved beauties are implausibly expert at giving (seldom taking) sexual pleasure, despite the fact that their enforced dedication to a single master must have meant a chance to practise about once a year (those hints of lesbianism were introduced just to titillate males the more).

The harem fantasy was as adaptable as its direct descendent, the Hollywood movie, to all manner of masculine bragging: the English sailor who multiply cuckolds the sultan and is paid in diamonds by the women for his services; Sade's cannibal Moor whose erotic despotism extends to punishing females who feel physical pleasure. It might even be presented as gallery art - consider the critics getting hard-ons in a Paris salon of 1862 while admiring the many tits in Ingres's The Turkish Bath.

Yeazell notes that women also exploited the concept's gynocentricity. Mrs Delarivier Manley, in her 1706 play, Almyna, reworked the standard male plot of harem rivals jealous for the attentions of their lord into a drama of heroic sisterly devotion. Her contemporary Lady Mary Wortley Montagu, wife to an ambassador in Istanbul and with access to real haremlik, wrote sharply that whatever bullocking about there might be among Circassian palace slaves, no woman of quality would suffer a husband to take a second wife - slippers would be thrown with violent intent. Faroqhi's book, which is dense with detail from the same period, substantiates Lady M by citing a female merchant with her own warehouse, a woman dervish respected as a mystic, and Fitnat, a poet of wit and sexy innuendos.

Yeazell writes that Charlotte Brontë's Jane Eyre knew well the love story of Roxelana, who persuaded Sultan Suleyman to marry her as sole consort at the height of Ottoman glory. After Jane discovered that Mr Rochester was a polygamist and keeper of serial continental concubines, she rejected his silks and jewels: "If you have a fancy for anything in that line, away with you, sir, to the bazaars of Stamboul." We might speculate on whether Jane's serail would have been based on the voluptuous oils of Eugène Delacroix or the unerotic watercolours of John Frederick Lewis, whose frightfully English wife posed in fancy dress among de luxe soft furnishings - more Liberty's than liberties.

The real Roxelana, as fondly described by Freely, learned to write in order to communicate with her adored Suleyman while he was on campaign laying waste to Hungary: he put aside all other women for the rest of his days. After he had laid her in her exquisite tomb, two of their sons attempted to eliminate each other to become sole heir; Suleyman ordered the loser, and the loser's five sons -Suleyman's own grandchildren - executed.

Freely narrates private lives beyond the Gate of Felicity in Topkapi Saray, Istanbul, in all their fearfulness, murderousness and dullness, although he is perhaps too close to the style of the Ottoman chronicles, enumerating how many offspring each sultan produced and how many years each princeling mouldered bored in the Cage, the semi-prison in which heirs awaited accession or death - 78 strangled with the silken bowstring in 450 years.

He is at his most sympathetic when sneaking away from the gloomy pomp of the lords upon the Golden Horn and the realpolitik of the viziers to wander Topkapi palace, that permanent encampment blown through by damp salt winds. He quotes from a male English visitor who entered the temporarily deserted harem in the 1790s, only to find it "in the state of an old lumber room ... large dusty pier glasses, neglected and broken, stood leaning against the wall ... scattered fragments of chandeliers and empty confectionery boxes were the only objects". Ah, reality: it always leads to detumescence.

fields.headline: Blobs, babble and blackness
fields.standfirst: Adrian Searle is overwhelmed by Comedie - a forgotten Beckett film starring one man, two women and three urns
fields.trailText: Adrian Searle is overwhelmed by Comedie - a forgotten Beckett film starring one man, two women and three urns
fields.body:
Blackness. Three bright dots reveal themselves as heads; two women and a man, their bodies lost inside grey urns. They are a long way away. A harsh spotlight illuminates them, interrogates them as they speak, turn by turn and all at once. When silence falls, darkness falls with it. The light goes on and off. That is all there is, in essence, to Samuel Beckett's Play, first performed in Britain at the Old Vic in 1964.

Anthony Minghella has recently filmed Play, with Kristin Scott Thomas, Juliet Stephenson and Alan Rickman, as part of a project to film all 19 Beckett plays. It is being touted as the first filmed production of Play. It is not. Comedie (Play in French) was filmed by Beckett himself, in 1966, working with a young French film-maker, Marin Karmitz. Then only 24, Karmitz had worked as an assistant to Roberto Rossellini and Jean-Luc Godard, and had made a film with Marguerite Duras before meeting, and being befriended by, Beckett.

Comedie was shown, without success, at the 1966 Venice Film Biennale. Unseen since, it resurfaced this year, in Paris, in an exhibition called Voilà. Now it is at the Anthony Reynolds Gallery in London. According to Karmitz, in London this week, Beckett was wholly engaged in this magnificent, disturbing film production. This is not a stage play revisited - although Comedie is filmed with the cast of the original 1964 Paris stage production - but made as though film were its natural medium.

A dark space. The screen fills the wall. The spotlit heads flash and burn. Michael Lonsdale, and Eléonore Hirt and Delphine Seyrig, who flank him, are bright blobs, little more than flecks in the film's emulsion, the reflection on their urns faint after-images, grey against the irredeemable black. As the 18€-minute film progresses, they come closer, or perhaps we step into the dark towards them. Beckett, apparently, wanted the blackness to be as much a protagonist as a background, a consuming presence in a work which, transposed to cinema, also comes close to painting. He does in film what cannot be done on the page, or on the stage, or on the painted plane.

The voices, too, are almost an abstraction; they speak, but we can unravel very little from the compressed babble. The odd, singu lar word erupts: a shriek, a stifled laugh, a scripted hiccup. Karmitz and Beckett worked on the sound first, eliminating the gaps between words electronically, condensing the delivery to a near indecipherable, riven music. The actors mime the playback, the pressurised condensation of their bile, as they seethe in their urns, along with their stew of memories, jealousy, bitchery and bitterness.

Comedie becomes much more than the farcical depiction of a triangular relationship. It is a dynamic of spaces and distances, unbridgeable gulfs of time, space and intimacy. Sometimes the camera brings us too close. The man's face is a leonine sun, then the disappearing, decaying dot on a TV screen. Heads loom, out of scale, against their fellows, who appear like diminutive, mummified pupae. As Comedie progresses, there is a greying of the light, as though the heads were fuzzed with mould, like rotting peaches. The soundtrack becomes scratchy. Comedie is an endless cycle of rejections and recriminations. And like any bitter relationship, it goes over its ground again and again. Towards the end of the work, Beckett offers a direction to repeat the entire text, to do it again - and, the implication is, again and again.

Comedie is filled with excruciating things. It is also bizarre and funny. Pared back to the irreducible, the symmetry of the relationship is reflected in the space of the film, the clustering of the line of heads, the grey bulk of their urns in the field of blackness. Under the shifting, inquisitorial spotlight, the grim melody of speech reduced to squirts and barks and babble is almost baby talk, the clay urns like swaddling clothes. The trio are like three writhing maggots. It is a primal scene.

Of course, Comedie has dated, but only in inessentials. There are moments when you see those disembodied heads, the kohl-rimmed eyes, the raggedy Weetabix mop-top wigs and hairdos, in stark chiaroscuro, and you think of the cover of With the Beatles, from 1963. The film's technique may have been superseded, yet, shown in a gallery, Comedie could almost be a film installation by any number of contemporary artists. Except of course it is better, more radical, more extreme than most. Artists have, for a long time, been interested in Beckett's forays into film, his pieces for television (filmed brilliantly in Germany in the late 1970s and early 1980s). Not I, with Billie Whitelaw's mollusc-like wet mouth filling the screen, remains one of the most radical works ever produced for television.

Beckett's friendship with artists and interest in art is well-known. Many artists now would claim him for their own. A recent exhibition in Vienna concentrated on the relationship between Beckett's work and American artist Bruce Nauman, and in London there is currently a two-part show of younger European artists, influenced by, and paying their dues to, Beckett. Karmitz believes Beckett would be happy to see his works in this context, and that this is the right way to show Comedie. In the dark space of the gallery, film, set, stage and installation coincide. Our relationship to the screen is physical. We are not so much watching something, as inside it, in some transitional darkness of our own. The DVD projection can't quite emulate the precise yet infinitely nuanced gradations of texture and tonality of 35mm film, but Comedie still makes your hair stand on end.

Comedie is a rejoinder to the current project to film all Beckett's plays. Coming across a publicity still from Minghella's forthcoming film version of Play, I am horrified. It shows a field of urns in a dismal swamp, a gnarled, blasted oak in the background, a lowering, Chernobyl sky. Any minute, expect a dragon. This is adolescent, and worse, cliched and illustrational. Damien Hirst might be filming Beckett's painfully terse Breath (approximately: a stage littered with rubbish, a cry, another cry, curtain), and I can see a certain inevitability about this, but the current Beckett project fills me with dread. Not because Beckett is untouchable, but that he was so good, so rigorous, so exact in what he wanted and what he didn't want (these are not the same at all, yet taken together, they amount to his intention). Karmitz receives but one passing footnote in all the Beckett biographies. Comedie, itself passed over, largely unseen and unremarked by Beckett's commentators, has escaped its own urn at just the right moment.

 Comedie, Anthony Reynolds Gallery (020-7491 0621), London W1, until December 23, and from January 3-13.

The film's technique may have been superseded, yet, shown in a gallery, Comedie could almost be a film installation by any number of contemporary artists. Except of course it is better, more radical, more extreme than most. Artists have, for a long time, been interested in Beckett's forays into film, his pieces for television (filmed brilliantly in Germany in the late 1970s and early 1980s). Not I, with Billie Whitelaw's mollusc-like wet mouth filling the screen, remains one of the most radical works ever produced for television. Beckett's friendship with artists and interest in art is well-known. Many artists now would claim him for their own. A recent exhibition in Vienna concentrated on the relationship between Beckett's work and American artist Bruce Nauman, and in London there is currently a two-part show of younger European artists, influenced by, and paying their dues to, Beckett. Karmitz believes Beckett would be happy to see his works in this context, and that this is the right way to show Comedie. In the dark space of the gallery, film, set, stage and installation coincide. Our relationship to the screen is physical. We are not so much watching something, as inside it, in some transitional darkness of our own. The DVD projection can't quite emulate the precise yet infinitely nuanced gradations of texture and tonality of 35mm film, but Comedie still makes your hair stand on end. Comedie is a rejoinder to the current project to film all Beckett's plays. Coming across a publicity still from Minghella's forthcoming film version of Play, I am horrified. It shows a field of urns in a dismal swamp, a gnarled, blasted oak in the background, a lowering, Chernobyl sky. Any minute, expect a dragon. This is adolescent, and worse, cliched and illustrational. Damien Hirst might be filming Beckett's painfully terse Breath (approximately: a stage littered with rubbish, a cry, another cry, curtain), and I can see a certain inevitability about this, but the current Beckett project fills me with dread. Not because Beckett is untouchable, but that he was so good, so rigorous, so exact in what he wanted and what he didn't want (these are not the same at all, yet taken together, they amount to his intention). Karmitz receives but one passing footnote in all the Beckett biographies. Comedie, itself passed over, largely unseen and unremarked by Beckett's commentators, has escaped its own urn at just the right moment.  Comedie, Anthony Reynolds Gallery (020-7491 0621), London W1, until December 23, and from January 3-13.

webTitle: Review: Promises, Promises by Adam Phillips

fields.headline: The poetry of mind
fields.standfirst: Adam Phillips gets Andrew Rissik  wondering whether we should read Freud as science or as literature with his collection Promises, Promises
fields.trailText: Adam Phillips gets Andrew Rissik wondering whether we should read Freud as science or as literature with his collection Promises, Promises
fields.body:
Promises, Promises

Adam Phillips

376pp, Faber, £10
Buy it at BOL

Psychoanalysis and the disciplines of psychology in general began as a new, revelatory development of medical science. There is a distinct possibility that they will end as a discredited but historically significant branch of mysticism. That, at least, is the spectre of scepticism, the nagging emotional qualification that haunts Adam Phillips's continually absorbing and intellectually wide-ranging collection of lectures, essays and journalism, Promises, Promises.

Phillips was a student of literature before he trained as a child psychotherapist, and his writing has always been torn by the decencies of doubt and by a sense of the independence of language: the way it can take over from, as well as accurately depict, empirical truth. He knows what Freud felt and sometimes openly admitted, that the world's age-old gathering of insight into human nature is stored in its literature, that poets are and always have been what Shelley once called them, "the unacknowledged legislators of the world" - priest-like expounders of sacred mysteries, "unapprehended inspiration". Accordingly, he writes and speaks with wary, foot-in-both-camps precision and care, acutely aware of the paradox of language: that it lies, falsifies and invents in order to reveal.

All our lives contain an innate tension between what we want to be and what events, contingency and the world seem to wish us to become. We are "translated" - to use the term of Phillips's astute Gwyn Jones Memorial lecture "On Translating A Person" - from our original selves by external circumstances, inner trauma. This sense that the lives we live are often damagingly and diminishingly different from the ones we are capable of living lies at the heart of psychoanalysis, which promises what (in different and often zealously competing ways) both Christianity and Marxism also promise: redemption through self-education, wholeness through self-knowledge. To psychoanalysis, the inner life is always, also, a potential life - an ample but unlived-out existence which the analyst can help the patient first to uncover and then, if circumstances are propitious, to recover and make real.

The difficulty with this, as Phillips sees in a long, coolly penetrating essay on "Poetry and Psychoanalysis", is its fundamental generic resemblance to the processes of fiction, and fiction's dependence on the security and concreteness of language. What we know, in any field, is largely what we are able formally to express, and the telling of stories is history's most articulately evolved medium for the expression of human psychology and behaviour. Freud, imaginatively abasing himself before the works of Sophocles, Shakespeare and Goethe, understood this humiliatingly well and perhaps always yearned for some of literature's flawless linguistic and philosophical coherence. On the page, the best of his work astonishes us by the miraculous lucidity of its understanding. We read it as Shelley thought we should read poetry, apprehending beneath the literal, apparent meaning a profound, universalising genius, able to mirror, in some uncanny and shamanistic way, "the gigantic shadows which futurity casts upon the present". Perhaps what Freud really did was to write the explicit and single-minded parables of hunger and erotomania that literature had not yet written, or had balked at writing during long centuries of Pauline Christian conditioning. Although he ranked himself with Copernicus and Darwin, perhaps we should put him alongside Ibsen, Strindberg, Joyce and Lawrence.

Behind Phillips's fine, discursive book lies a fundamental, informing uneasiness that psychoanalysis may be pretending to an authority that it cannot ultimately possess. When Phillips describes Freud as writing "science which sounded like literature", it is possible to go further and argue that psychoanalytic theory is actually literature dressed up as scientific investigation. Art's strength is metaphorical: it works by analogy, by reorganisation and rearrangement, and has the freedom and irresponsibility of thought itself. Psychoanalysis claims to be essentially a science: to proceed, like physics, by broadly verifiable laws and to embody some sort of literal truth. The drawbacks of this for clinical medicine seem obvious. Freud's doctrine of the powerful unconscious has taught us increasingly to interpret illness in metaphorical terms, yet to resist the idea that diagnostic emotional suppositions may not be hard fact. As Lewis Wolpert, in his recent superb study of depression, Malignant Sadness, observes: "It is curious that conversion disorders, made so famous by Freud, in which emotional conflict was converted into, for example, blindness, deafness or paralysis, seem nowadays to be very rare. One possibility is that many of the cases were indeed due to a physical disorder."

Conversion is the essence of psychoanalysis, as well as of language itself. Both try to resolve the contradictions of being alive through alchemical transformations, wresting new securities from the chaos of old and rooted griefs, calming the mind's ever-threatening anarchy through narratives that channel our experience and hold it in a kind of tense but apparent orderliness. Sophocles's Heracles, in Ezra Pound's far-sighted translation, cries out, at the supreme moment of his life, in a half-mad ecstasy of emotional recognition: "It all coheres."

Freud believed this too. It's not surprising that he saw dreams as a kind of art, a "royal road to the unconscious" that could be read, picked apart and diligently expounded as though the analyst were a supremely authoritative literary critic. It was his most seductive experiment, and easily the most fallacious. Art can be experienced by anyone able to receive it; dreams can be experienced by no one but the dreamer. Even our memory of them is a reorganisation of the material by a meaning-obsessed waking consciousness. Freud knew this, of course - he calls the process "secondary elaboration" - but, in his driven, Messianic, Sherlock Holmes-ish way, couldn't bring himself to abandon the formal beauty of the system he had created. In truth, the magico-religious cultures of the ancient world probably got closer to decoding the mysterious dialect of dreams than he did.

The continually impressive thing about Phillips's work is its refusal to disregard the human costs of systems, theories and dogmatic verbal structures. He always earths argument in lived experience. Occasionally this caution lends to his precisely articulated prose a distant or monochromatic note, but it proceeds from an admirable distaste for the vibrato of fake wisdom to which linguistic stylishness is notoriously prone. In a review of Martin Amis's novel, Night Train, he writes: "The effect of his often brilliant verbal delirium is to make things wordy and unreal, language warding off the experience it describes, whisking it away." It's a mistake Phillips takes pains not to make himself.

For him, the work of Freud and the other great psychological thinkers is more imaginatively enabling than it is empirically accurate or "true". Consequently he argues for a version of analysis "more committed to happiness and inspiration (and the miscellaneous) than to self-knowledge, rigorous thinking, or the Depths of Being". To Phillips, the real promise of psychoanalysis is to widen our language rather than to extend our science. Freud's ground-breaking gift - despite its denial of the historical or collective in favour of the internal - was to make it possible for us to say things about our minds, our consciousness, that had never been said before, or never said in such specific, unhysterical, anatomising detail. He gave us secular classifications for areas of our being that had been assumed to lie beyond the scope of secular classification. Or, in Phillips's liberating terms, he freed us to translate ourselves and be translated. "On Translating A Person" might have been a better and more accurate title for this richly thought-provoking book.

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Is the euro good for home loans?

fields.headline: Exploding the euro myth
fields.standfirst: Tony Blair says the British support monetary union in principle because, among other benefits, it is important for their home loans. But a report by the Halifax reveals that, despite lower bank rates on the continent, property buyers there are little better off than their counterparts here. Patrick Collinson investigates
fields.trailText: Tony Blair says the British support monetary union in principle because, among other benefits, it is important for their home loans. But a report by the Halifax reveals that, despite lower bank rates on the continent, property buyers there are little better off than their counterparts here. Patrick Collinson investigates
fields.body:
Halifax this week exploded one of the central myths about the benefits of joining the euro.

In a research report that will be seized upon by euro-sceptics it concluded that even though the European Central Bank's rate is 4.75% compared with the Bank of England's base rate of 6%, homebuyers in the euro-zone are little better off than the British.

The average mortgage rate in the UK is 6.9%, taking into account the fact that large numbers of people are on fixed and discount rates. This compares with 6.64% in Germany, 6.3% in the Netherlands and 6.2% in Italy. Only in Spain and France are home loans significantly cheaper, at 4.9% and 5.5% respectively.

The figures contradict widely held assumptions in Britain that entry into the euro will automatically mean cheaper mortgages. It's also an assumption held by prime minister Tony Blair, currently debating the EU's future shape at the Nice summit in France.

At a dinner in July with German Chancellor Gerhard Schröder, he said of the euro: "It is precisely because I believe it's important for British jobs, British industry, the British people's mortgages, that we are in principle in favour."

But this week Halifax general manager Shane O'Riordain said: "Even though the UK is not in the euro-zone, UK mortgage interest rates are broadly comparable with those in most countries that are in the single currency area . . . the UK appears to have one of the most competitive mortgage markets, be it the rate on offer or the range of products available."

Halifax looked not just at mortgage rates but at the wider range of issues around home ownership, including house prices, owner occupancy levels and repayment periods across Europe.

Owner occupancy : Under Margaret Thatcher's council house right-to-buy scheme, more than 1m households switched from renting to home ownership, fostering the idea that in Britain you are more likely to own your own home than almost anywhere else. But the Halifax research found that this, too, is a myth.

In recent years, the level of home ownership has levelled out in the UK at around 67%. However, in both Spain and Italy, which do not have the same northern European tradition of public housing, the level is 78%. One of the lowest levels of home ownership is in the Netherlands, at 50%, even though the mortgage market is similar to the UK. In Germany, where rent controls are widespread, the financial equation behind house buying stacks up poorly. Only four in 10 Germans own the home they live in, but tend to have greater security on both tenure and rent increases on their properties. In France 54% own the homes they live in.

Prices : Anyone who thinks Britain is alone in suffering a boom and bust house price cycle is wrong. Halifax compared price rises during the period 1990-98 across seven countries, and found that prices had risen slower in Britain than anywhere else.

In the UK, prices rose by an average of 6.4%, compared to a staggering 81% increase in the Netherlands. However, the British figure was deflated by the period chosen, as it covered much of the post-1980s property slump and before the recent price boom came into play.

Price rises in France and Sweden were equally sluggish, but Spanish homeowners enjoyed an increase of 27%, while in Germany the gain was 37%.

Repayment periods: In Britain, most people take out mortgages which will be paid off over a 25-year repayment period, but it is by no means the standard for Europe. In the Netherlands, it is usual to repay over a 30-year period, while in Spain the typical length of a mortgage is only 15 years - making loans much more costly.

How much you have to stump up as a deposit also varies across Europe. Whereas in Britain most first-time buyers need to put down a 5% deposit, in Spain they have to find 20%. In Holland, 125% mortgages are common, so homebuyers do not have to put up a deposit at all.

Tax : European tax harmonisation on mortgages is a long, long way off. Whereas Britain has simplified its tax regime by abolishing mortgage interest relief, it still has one of the most favourable capital gains tax regimes in Europe for homeowners. When you sell your home in Britain, there is no tax to pay on the gain over the price you originally paid. However, both France and Holland charge tax on the gains made.

Types of mortgage: Fixes, discounts, caps, variable, flexible or tracker; the British homebuyer has a daunting array of products to choose from. However, in a number of northern EU countries, long-term fixed rate mortgages are the only products on offer. In Spain and Italy, countries with a poor inflation record in the past, variable rate mortgages are the norm.

Gains in Spain stay mainly on the plane
Tony Levene

Home loan rates in Spain average a bargain basement 4.9%, according to Halifax statistics. So it is less than plain why Norwich & Peterborough is asking Brits to pay 6.99% on fixed rate for five years on loans to buy homes on the Spanish Costa del Sol.

And it is seemingly even more unfair why it goes up to 8% after that. A five-year UK fixed mortgage costs 6.39%.

But N&P, which lends in Gibraltar and along the Costa del Sol, is not alone. Lenders such as Abbey National, Halifax, NatWest, Royal Bank of Scotland and Woolwich all charge around 7.75%. The interest rate premium is in exchange for simplicity and risk reduction. Many Spanish banks will not lend to non-residents who, typically, fail local credit tests.

And according to N&P, the risks and potential hassles of a euro-based mortgage could make Spanish loans more expensive in the long run.

"If the euro strengthens against the pound, sterling- based borrowers will need to find more both for monthly interest and capital repayment," says N&P's Alison Rolls. A terraced property with a shared swimming pool costs £70,000, while villas with private pools average £108,000. Buyers tend to put down large deposits say 40% and pay off loans over 17 years.

fields.headline: Can you be  a www-inner?
fields.standfirst: As the high-tech shakeout enters its second phase, Patrick Collinson finds that the older and bigger funds are now being hit heavily
fields.trailText: As the high-tech shakeout enters its second phase, Patrick Collinson finds that the older and bigger funds are now being hit heavily.
fields.body:
Were you one of the investors swept up in the technology euphoria at the beginning of the year? It was difficult not to be, considering the gung-ho advertising by nearly all the investment managers and the huge paper fortunes made by the dot.com millionaires.

"Get plugged in" screamed Framlington in February as it hailed the amazing performance figures on its NetNet fund: "Plus 106% in nine months."

Not to be outdone, Societe Generale jumped in with its SG ISA. "Up 246% in 20 months" it proclaimed, as it told potential investors that "technology is probably the fastest growing market sector, with enormous potential for investors."

Jupiter rushed out a new unit trust as hundreds of millions of pounds began pouring into technology funds. "WWWin with Jupiter's new Global Technology fund," it gushed.

But there have been almost no wwwinners, just lllosers. The best a technology fund has been able to achieve since the beginning of the year is -12.46% and the worst -47.91%. Put another way, if you invested £7,000 in a tech ISA on January 1 you could now be sitting on as little as £3,650, with more lopped off for charges.

The collapse in price of the dot.com funds, such as Framlington NetNet and Close FTSE techMARK has been well documented since the end of the tech boom in March. But in a second leg of the technology shakeout, it is the older and bigger funds, such as Henderson Global Technology, SocGen Technology and Aberdeen Technology which are now being hit hard.

Until last month they had ridden out the dot.com sell-off by avoiding the "lastminute" style consumer net companies in favour of firms that build the infrastructure of the internet and (in some cases) actually make money. But during November share prices in such stocks plunged amid fears that earnings are on the slide, typified by the 44% collapse in the price of Anglo-French computer services group Sema in just one day after it issued a profits warning.

The £1.3bn Henderson fund fell 22% during the month, Aberdeen's £1.3bn fund dropped 20% and the £280m SocGen fund was down 17%.

So what should you do now? Cut your losses and sell out, or soldier on in the hope that the current despair will soon lift?

One thing is clear. After the avalanche of money into tech funds in March - more than £700m - new money coming in has slowed to a barely discernible trickle, according to fund analysts Lipper. "With tech funds we have gone from excessive optimism to pervasive pessimism," says Lipper.

Surprisingly Framlington says almost no one has cut and run from its £200m NetNet fund, despite it being the worst performer this year. Marketing director Craig Walton says: "We have 44,000 investors and only an absolutely tiny amount are selling out. Our view is that there are some very good net companies that have been oversold during the current violent downswing and which didn't deserve to be."

This week Framlington issued a note to financial advisers saying it is "repositioning" the fund away from pure dot.coms and into software companies. It also disputes the idea gaining ground that the internet is just a fad and that people are now logging off. According to recent figures, 28m Americans and as much as 2m Britons now fall into the category of "former internet users".

But Framlington NetNet manager Chris Bell says: "The underlying growth of the internet is still dramatic, with global users predicted to grow at over 20% per annum until 2005."

One indicator that e-commerce is still alive and well comes this week from Intelligent Finance, which launched its website last week. It says that it is picking up 1,200 full-scale accounts every day, helped by its current advertising blitz featuring FatBoy Slim, and that "hits" on the site match those of the big banks already.

Most financial advisers were happy to rake in commission on tech fund sales during the dot.com hysteria and are now having to face angry clients. But one adviser who actively warned the investing public off technology funds was Brian Dennehy of Dennehy Waller. "We put out specific warnings at the time telling people to expect 50% losses on these funds," he says.

Does he think you should still steer clear? "A number of funds were recklessly launched and lavishly marketed just as the bubble was about to burst ... but perhaps there is now selective good value. For example, the broader US stock market is on a price earnings (PE) ratio of 24, with earnings growth of 8% expected next year.

"In contrast a number of US technology companies now have PE ratios in the range of 30-40, but with earnings growth of 30-40% conservatively expected next year. There is a danger that the earlier excess of euphoria will now swing to an excess of despair."

Mr Dennehy does not believe that technology funds are about to bounce, because the risks of a "hard landing" in the US economy are still high. But when pressed for a technology fund recommendation, he picks Henderson Global Technology, which has rapidly replaced the management team that recently left. "Our view is clear, stick to proven performers and experienced teams," he says.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Robyn
fields.trailText: My favourite club in Vancouver is The Commodore. If you get a chance, check out a show there ...
fields.body:
Hey Milly,

I just read the first week of your trip. I live in Steveston and I work downtown
in Vancouver (the building with the revolving lookout on top). You are so
lucky with the weather. This has been the best winter weather I've seen in a
long time. Usually it's rainy, but so far it seems like all you've had is sun,
which is great. :) I'm glad you liked Steveston, and it's true, they film a lot
of movies around here. Arnold Schwarzenegger's movie The Sixth Day was
filmed in Steveston and downtown Vancouver. If you see it, you might recognize
part of the city.

Someone advised you to go to the Cecil. My advice? Don't go there unless you
want to see men drooling over dancing naked women! (It's a strip club!)

My favourite club? The Commodore. If you get a chance, by all means check out a
show there. It's located a few blocks up from the Global Backpackers hostel
(nextdoor to Cheap Thrills on Granville Street).

Hope you have fun in Banff! You've got great weather! And hopefully the
cold didn't get you too much in Vancouver. It's the warmest spot in Canada and
rarely drops below what it is right now. It's the other parts of Canada that get
much colder, so bundle up - but by all means, have a blast, and have fun!! :)

Robyn

PS I'm 20, and I'm planning my second trip to London for the springtime. Any advice? :)

fields.headline: The best party restaurants
fields.standfirst: It can be a real bind choosing the right restaurant for a rousing get-together. Matthew Fort should know: he has to do it every year. Here's his pick of the best
fields.trailText: It can be a real bind choosing the right restaurant for a rousing get-together. Matthew Fort should know: he has to do it every year. Here's his pick of the best.
fields.body:
God, there's nothing in this world that causes my heart to plummet faster than the call to arms of a party. In particular, I dread the festive season, party time in excelsis. It drains good cheer from my soul. It casts a shadow over life. It blights each day. This may seem extreme, but I have good reasons - the very reasons that any amateur party organiser must experience.

We, at Weekend Guardian, are a tightly-knit team. I wouldn't go quite as far as to say that we are a family, unless you think of a family like the Sopranos. Anyway, we toil away during the year, uncomplaining, unheralded and unfussed and then, come December, suddenly it's party time. "Matthew," the cry goes up, "where shall we have the Christmas party this year?" Where indeed? How should I know?

You see, our kind of party is a particular kind of party. It's not a dance party, or a drugs and sex party, or even a pyjama party. It's a kind of lunch party, although that suggests something altogether too orderly and polite. But there has to be eating and drinking, and of a certain quality. You wouldn't expect me to agree to anything less, would you? Hangovers are all very well in their way, but experience has taught me that the degree and pain of a hangover are in direct relation to the quality of the vittels, solid and liquid, consumed. Basically, Fort's theory of the hangover is that the lower the quality of the food and booze, the worse the hangover. Anyway, my confrères et soeurs on the magazine have come to expect a high standard, and I am loath to disappoint.

There are a few free spirits who float in and out of the quorum, depending on pressure of work, but generally speaking our numbers vary between 18 and 24. But within this tight pod of Weekenders, we have a rainbow coalition of gastronomic tastes. There are fish lovers, unreconstructed vegetarians, offal aficionados and meat epicureans. We have people who worship Italian food, and those who have a yen for something plain and British. There are the pickiest of pickies and the most gourmandising of trencherfolk. There are oenophiles and beeromaniacs. And they all expect me to come up with somewhere that will meet their particular dietary requirements.

Fair enough, you may say, but let me tell you that the responsibility is crippling. They all want to have a good time, too, a noisy time, a tombola-and-lucky-dip time, a leisurely, pleasurely time. They want good food and fun. And they'll rend me limb from limb if I don't come up with the goods. Oh, and we can't spend more than half a euro per head on it. That's the official budget line. Are you beginning to appreciate the scale of my problem? They will be familiar to anyone also caught in the Christmas party organising trap.

In the past, we have put L'Odéon through its paces, and Kensington Place. For two years, we have given the Blue Print Cafe a going over. And there was one memorable year when we went to Maison Novelli, although the reasons for that occasion's noteworthiness I shall leave to your imaginations. This year, it's the turn of Mash in Great Portland Street, because it fulfils the profile that I have been developing year by year for the perfect Weekend Christmas Party. The rules are quite simple:

1 Don't go anywhere near your own doorstep. You don't want to have to run the gauntlet of accusing faces for weeks to come for incidents of which you have no memory;

2 Make sure it's sufficiently roomy to handle a large number of people sitting down to eat at once;

3 If possible, get a private room. Then, no one (except the waiting staff, that is) will notice how abominably you behave;

4 Check in advance that there's sufficient variety on the menu to satisfy even the most arcane of diets;

5 Order wine, beer and water to be on the table when you arrive. And no rubbish, please. The relaxation that drink induces will make your party revellers tolerate an extraordinary amount;

6 Keep an eye on the level of alcohol consumption before the first courses arrive. You don't want things getting out of hand too quickly. So make sure those starters make an early appearance;

7 Be prepared to go over budget. In the end, it's not your money;

8 Make detailed notes of serious misbehaviour. Knowledge is power.

Anyway, here are a few places around the country that I know - either from personal experience or good report - meet the various criteria outlined above. I would be happy to land the motley Weekend crowd on any of them, and be sure of having good food and a good time. What more do you want?

webTitle: Charities need to account for our money

fields.headline: Charities need to account for our money
fields.trailText: The charter of the National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children requires it to "carry out publicity and educational work of all descriptions". And so, the charity said shirtily yesterday, there is absolutely no basis for criticising it for spending very large sums on its Full Stop campaign, which aimed to raise awareness of child abuse on the way to eliminating it.
fields.body:
The charter of the National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children requires it to "carry out publicity and educational work of all descriptions". And so, the charity said shirtily yesterday, there is absolutely no basis for criticising it for spending very large sums on its Full Stop campaign, which aimed to raise awareness of child abuse on the way to eliminating it.

The NSPCC rejected the charge that it had diverted money from the provision of services: educating the public is a way of preventing adults harming children in future. When rent-a-quote Tory MPs pile in as they did yesterday, citing the NSPCC's support for reducing the homosexual age of consent, it is hard to be anything but sympathetic to an institution which the public cherishes and does much good. And yet the figures in its annual accounts do provoke questions, not just about the NSPCC but also the accountability of the voluntary sector. The NSPCC problem results in part from the anachronistic definitions of charitable purpose that the cowardice of successive governments in refusing to bite the bullet of reform have left us with.

Last year the NSPCC spent just under £30m of its total of £75m spending on "local services". But of the rest, the charity says hotly, the £1.6m spent on a helpline, the money spent on training and, critically, the £20m spent on "public education" and campaigning are just as important as frontline work. But the public is unaware of those ratios. It tends vaguely to believe that its money buys a specific service.

When confronted by one of the in-your-face street canvassers increasingly employed by the big organisations, members of the public are generally not told about admin costs and the like. Perhaps the NSPCC should have clearly said: we want your money to pay for expensive television adverts and endorsements by stars because we believe that is the only way to arrest people's attention. The risk was that donors might not have been as generous.

Campaigning got Shelter into trouble under the Tories and the issue of how far charities can stray into the realms of controversy still gives the Charity Commission sleepless nights. To care about children or housing or the third world and work to assist them is of course to hold "political" beliefs. But charity law forbids partisanship. In order to campaign on such controversial issues as debt forgiveness or the role of the multinationals in the third world, Oxfam set up a not for profit company, without the tax benefits of charitable status. So far the NSPCC has felt able to lobby for changes in law without compromising its status, but it is treading a fine line.

The NSPCC's Full Stop campaign has been a blunderbuss. Some wondered whether an expensive national campaign would be less effective than work in particular places - on the model of the campaign certain local authorities have waged against physical violence against women. Social services directors accused the NSPCC of exaggeration for the sake of generating gifts.

The NSPCC is not disinterested in the results of public policy, in the sense that it has inspectors and social workers to employ and the large expansion in investigation of children in care would be to their advantage. While auditors crawl all over public authorities, the inspection of charities is limited - the Charity Commission is not the Audit Commission, with a battery of tests of efficiency and effectiveness. Charities enjoy legal privilege in order to help the underprivileged. They owe the public transparency in what they do with donations. On this occasion a major one might have explained itself better.

fields.headline: Tube boss to get £2m house
fields.trailText: After a hard day dealing with the decay and grime that is London's crumbling underground system, Bob Kiley, the capital's incoming transport supremo, will be able to unwind in a £2.1m Georgian house in Belgravia paid for by Ken Livingstone.
fields.body:
After a hard day dealing with the decay and grime that is London's crumbling underground system, Bob Kiley, the capital's incoming transport supremo, will be able to unwind in a £2.1m Georgian house in Belgravia paid for by Ken Livingstone.

The London mayor personally authorised the purchase of the property for Mr Kiley, who starts his post as commissioner of transport for London on January 1.

He is moving from New York where he is credited with turning round that city's transport system. Mr Kiley was tempted by a lucrative package linked to performance that could earn him £2m over four years.

The three-bedroom house near Sloane Square, and just a few minutes from the underground, will remain the property of Transport for London.

Mr Kiley will pay for his own furniture for the house, built in 1740, and described as hav ing "great character and charm". The property has a stone-tiled hall, marble fireplaces, oak floors and lots of wood panelling.

In a statement, Mr Livingstone said: "Mr Kiley is one of the world's greatest experts on transport. He will have the opportunity to earn £2m over four years. Half that salary is linked to his ability to achieve real improvements in bus and tube services.

"TfL will be purchasing a house, valued at £2.1m, to provide accommodation for him in central London. The house will remain the property of TfL."

John Biggs, Labour's transport spokesman on the Greater London Authority, said: "It is two-faced of the mayor to one day attack the private sector and the next outbid them."

Bob Neill, leader of the Conservative group on the GLA, said: "I shall want to see where the money is coming from, whether its from the TfL budget or the precept. We want to make sure it is not coming from the 30% council tax increase Ken Livingstone is planning in the GLA portion of the tax."

 Ken Livingstone pulled out of a meeting with London Underground managers and staff after he was refused permission to take a television crew along, writes Kevin Maguire. Mr Livingstone's decision left underground managing director Derek Smith "livid", one executive claimed.
fields.bodyText: After a hard day dealing with the decay and grime that is London's crumbling underground system, Bob Kiley, the capital's incoming transport supremo, will be able to unwind in a £2.1m Georgian house in Belgravia paid for by Ken Livingstone. The London mayor personally authorised the purchase of the property for Mr Kiley, who starts his post as commissioner of transport for London on January 1. He is moving from New York where he is credited with turning round that city's transport system. Mr Kiley was tempted by a lucrative package linked to performance that could earn him £2m over four years. The three-bedroom house near Sloane Square, and just a few minutes from the underground, will remain the property of Transport for London. Mr Kiley will pay for his own furniture for the house, built in 1740, and described as hav ing "great character and charm". He will have the opportunity to earn £2m over four years. Half that salary is linked to his ability to achieve real improvements in bus and tube services. "TfL will be purchasing a house, valued at £2.1m, to provide accommodation for him in central London. The house will remain the property of TfL." John Biggs, Labour's transport spokesman on the Greater London Authority, said: "It is two-faced of the mayor to one day attack the private sector and the next outbid them." Bob Neill, leader of the Conservative group on the GLA, said: "I shall want to see where the money is coming from, whether its from the TfL budget or the precept.
