Mr Livingstone's decision left underground managing director Derek Smith "livid", one executive claimed.

fields.headline: £275m lifeline for post office bank
fields.trailText: Ministers last night moved to rescue their plans for a post office based bank by offering up to £275m of taxpayers' money towards its running costs.
fields.body:
Ministers last night moved to rescue their plans for a post office based bank by offering up to £275m of taxpayers' money towards its running costs.

The move is a desperate attempt to win the backing of the high street banks which have complained they are being asked to bear too high a risk in supporting the so-called universal bank. But if they refuse to participate, they fear a draconian government windfall tax.

With the Christmas deadline imposed by the government, the banks have yet to agree to stump up a share of the running costs of the new bank which is at the heart of the government's plan to throw a lifeline to the post office. But ministers are convinced that they have now done enough to clinch a deal with the banks.

Yesterday, the major banks missed their self-imposed deadline to agree a united response to the government. But, it is understood that the government remains optimistic that an announcement could be made next week.

The universal bank is to offer accounts, branded "clear", to some 5m people who do not have access to a bank account but will need one when social security payments are automated in 2004.

The banks have warned it could carry the stigma of a "poor people's" bank and feel they should not be expected to bear its running costs. The costs are staggered, with the big banks paying up to £12m a year and the smaller ones, including internet banks, around £5m.

The banks fear they would be saddled with unlimited costs should the so-called universal bank prove to be more expensive than the original business plan.

As a result, the government has agreed that their annual cost will not exceed £125m, and that any additional finance will be at taxpayers' expense. Some senior bankers believe that the business plan underestimates the running cost of the bank which they believe could reach £400m a year. The government is promising to share half the annual running costs of the universal bank.

Even with extra government money, it was far from clear last night that the banks would all back the plan. But, during a series of high level meetings with ministers, the banks' concerns have grown.

Their fears range from dubbing their annual share of the running costs as "windfall tax" to an escalation of an investigation into competition among the major banks. High-level meetings between the banks are expected to try to gauge support for the scheme.

fields.headline: Mandelson defends Bush remarks
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the US elections
Special report: Northern Ireland
Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: Downing Street rallied to the defence of Peter Mandelson last night after he was quoted as claiming that George W Bush was sympathetic to Sinn Fein.
fields.body:
Downing Street rallied to the defence of Peter Mandelson last night after he was quoted as claiming that George W Bush was sympathetic to Sinn Fein.

A spokesman insisted that the Northern Ireland secretary had not spoken out of line after it was reported that Mr Mandelson had questioned the impartiality of Mr Bush, who has won the support of two pro-Sinn Fein congressmen in his battle for the White House.

"It is a fuss about nothing," the Downing Street spokesman said. "Peter Mandelson said, in terms, that were George Bush to become president we are totally confident he would continue to be even-handed."

Downing Street intervened after it was reported in last night's London Evening Standard that Mr Mandelson had suggested at a Westminster reception on Thursday night that Mr Bush sympathised with Sinn Fein.

Mr Mandelson reportedly pointed out that Mr Bush had adopted a nationalist stance on Northern Ireland earlier this year to win the support of two congressmen in his battle against John McCain to win the Republican nomination.

Peter King and Ben Gilman threw their weight behind Mr Bush after he backed nationalist demands for the full implementation of the Patten report on policing.

Mr Mandelson emphatically denied that he had raised questions about Mr Bush. "This story is complete and utter rubbish," he said. "As anyone who was there knows I said the opposite, which is that George W Bush's approach would be entirely even-handed towards the two traditions in Northern Ireland."

Aides confirmed that Mr Mandelson had been asked at the reception to sketch out the views of Mr Bush and his Democrat rival, Al Gore, on the Northern Ireland peace process. He replied that neither candidate could afford to ignore the Irish-American lobby and that Mr Bush had courted the two congressmen.

However, Mr Mandelson made clear that this would not affect Mr Bush's conduct as president.

"The idea that Peter Mandelson regards George W Bush as a Sinn Fein supporter is nonsense and shows no grasp of American politics," the aide said.

Downing Street, which is privately hoping for a Gore victory, has gone out of its way not to get involved in the US election. Memories still run deep of the catastrophic blunder by the Tories who rummaged through official documents on behalf of George Bush Snr in 1992 to try and prove that Bill Clinton was a draft dodger.

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, said last night at the EU summit in Nice that he hoped both Al Gore and George W Bush would continue the Clinton contribution to the peace process.

webTitle: Policyholders say they know exactly whom to blame

fields.headline: Policyholders say they know exactly whom to blame
fields.trailText: Policyholders who battled with Equitable Life through the courts yesterday blamed management incompetence and failures in the regulatory system for the demise of the oldest mutual life company in Britain.
fields.body:
Policyholders who battled with Equitable Life through the courts yesterday blamed management incompetence and failures in the regulatory system for the demise of the oldest mutual life company in Britain.

The court action, which led to a House of Lords ruling costing Equitable £1.5bn, was brought by retired investment manager David Hyman on behalf of a coalition of policyholders including doctors, lawyers and professors.

Yesterday Mr Hyman said: "I am immensely sad. When the case was over I wrote to the managing director and said I was distressed that because of the action one of the oldest life companies should be brought down by incompetence."

Others placed the blame squarely on the management, led by chief executive Alan Nash, who resigned yesterday.

Stuart Bayliss, managing director of Annuity Direct, who organised the 1,500-strong Equitable policyholders' action group, said: "It's tragic, but I blame the management. They bet the future of the company on a court case when they were in a no-win situation, and when we were saying we were willing to do a deal. The management played ostrich the whole time."

Regulators were also criticised for failing to act earlier, amid calls for the industry and government to arrange a bail-out of Equitable. Dr David Abrams, an eye surgeon and leading member of the action group, said: "Regulation of Equitable was bounced from the Department of Trade and Industry to the Treasury and then to the financial services authority. Somebody should have said something about a decision taken in 1993 not to reserve for guaranteed annuities. It is not good enough to say they cannot organise a lifeboat. If Equitable becomes insolvent, it is the Treasury who should bail them out."

MPs - many of whom have an Equitable policy through the Commons superannuation scheme - stepped back from demanding government intervention, calling instead for an industry-wide rescue. Barry Sheerman, MP for Huddersfield, and an Equitable policyholder, said: "There is a role for the government in ensuring that people do not lose out. The industry should get together so policyholders are not disadvantaged."

fields.headline: Equitable's life is over
fields.standfirst: Dilemma for 650,000 customers  Prudential pulls out of bid talks
fields.trailText: The country's oldest mutual insurance company, Equitable Life, is to close to new business after failing to attract a buyer. As the 238-year organisation suffered a humiliating consignment to the history books, recriminations began to fly about why regulators had not spotted the problems earlier.
fields.body:
The country's oldest mutual insurance company, Equitable Life, is to close to new business after failing to attract a buyer. As the 238-year organisation suffered a humiliating consignment to the history books, recriminations began to fly about why regulators had not spotted the problems earlier.

The move left Equitable's 650,000 policyholders with the decision of what to do with their policies, some of which were sold as recently as Thursday.

In a desperate attempt to avoid a catastrophic run on its £33bn pool of assets, Equitable immediately imposed a 10% penalty on any policyholder wanting to switch their money from the company.

Equitable said it was left with little choice but to decide to turn away new customers after discovering late on Thursday night that Prudential had decided not to make a bid for the company. Alan Nash, Equitable's chief executive, resigned as a result.

The Pru was the last of 15 bidders, which included CGNU and the European alliance Eureko, to terminate its negotiations. It was a shock end to a sale process which began in July when the law lords ruled that holders of guaranteed annuities had been unfairly treated by the insurer. While that decision left Equitable with a £1.5bn shortfall, industry sources had regarded the group as an attractive takeover target with a possible price tag of £4bn.

But during the sale process of Equitable, the scale of the potential bill faced by the insurer to top up guarantees began to emerge. Even conservative estimates suggested that the hole could be as large as £5bn with the potential to grow further, enough to deter even the most determined bidder. Yesterday, the "black hole" in the accounts was estimated by some industry experts to be £7.5bn.

Equitable is to keep its business open for existing customers, some of whom may even have signed up in the past few days as the company was permitted to continue to advertise for new business until yesterday.

Questions were raised by senior City sources about whether the new regulator, the Financial Services Authority, had performed effectively.

"This an embarrassment for Howard Davies [the FSA chairman]. He allowed them to carry on selling new business. Should they have been allowed to?" one source said.

Last night an FSA spokesman said: "Stopping it from selling new business would have effectively killed the prospects of a sale. After the House of Lords judgment we wanted a sale that would achieve maximum value for policyholders. Until that prospect was gone it was right to give such a deal a chance."

Equitable's new chief executive Chris Headdon, the former finance director, defended the on-going sales. He said the company had wanted offer potential bidders a "vibrant, thriving organisation".

But the failure to find a buyer is painful for existing policyholders who for seven months had been forced to accept lower policy values of as much as 5%. Equitable had pledged to restore the lost money once a buyer was found, but policyholders will now have to bear the loss permanently.

Their returns on the policies will also be lower as Equitable will move out of higher returning equities into less risky bonds to cover its liabilities.

Is there any way out?

What does this mean for my policy?
The 450,000 people who have with-profits policies will lose 10% of the value of their money if they switch out. The penalty is designed to stop a catastrophic run on the £33bn under management.

What will happen to the future growth of my policy?
Equitable is switching investments away from shares towards deposit-style investments to shore-up its funds, which will mean lower future returns, falling from, say, 7% a year to 6% a year.

What happens to the lost growth earlier this year?
Growth on policies was suspended from January 1 to July 31, and was supposed to be restored on the sale of the company. With no buyer, the growth, worth around 5% on policies, will now never be restored.

Should I continue making payments?
If you are close to retirement, continue paying say advisers. But for the bulk of policyholders, advisers recommend suspending payments and starting an alternative plan with another provider instead.

What should I do with the money I already have invested?
This is the thorniest problem. Transfer the money, and you lose 10%. But stay, and you lose future growth on your policy. With policies far from retirement, advisers say a transfer, even suffering the 10% penalty, may make sense.

I have a "top-up" company AVC scheme. Will I be hit?
Yes, with a 10% penalty if you transfer, plus the loss of growth earlier this year and lower returns in future. The general advice is to make future payments into an alternative AVC provider and take advice on the existing money saved.

Are all policies affected?
No. "Unit-linked" (such as unit trusts) and "term" policies are unaffected.

I have a with-profits retirement annuity. Am I protected?
The contracts lock you in and you cannot transfer.

Where can I get help?
Equitable agents can be contacted on 0870 900 8020, or for general information ring 0870 600 2272. Try the equitable website, or the members' action group website.

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Working from home

fields.headline: A post-modern business
fields.standfirst: Dreaming of working from home? That need not mean the spare room, says Elizabeth Langton
fields.trailText: Dreaming of working from home? That need not mean the spare room, says Elizabeth Langton.
fields.body:
Working from home can be lonely and sometimes as stressful as sticking with the nine-to-five office job.

Homeworkers can find themselves cut off from the daily social interaction that comes with going out to work and there is no escape from the phone and computer as the desk in the spare room becomes the centre of the house.

Industry minister Patricia Hewitt told a conference in September that the UK should be able to get a third of its workforce teleworking for at least part of the time. Other studies by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation found one in four UK workers now do some of their job from home.

Many full-time homeworkers move their computers, files and desks out of the house and into shared offices. But the monthly rental payments mean this can be expensive. Conservatories and cabins in the garden can't bring back the office banter, but they do take the work out of the house and cabin makers report that business is booming.

Norwegian Log and Homelodge Buildings claim demand for their wooden cabins has never been higher. The companies' brochures say the buildings make successful offices for everyone, from artists and music teachers to physiotherapists.

Norwegian Log's solid log buildings, that typically measure 15 feet by 12 feet, cost about £12,000 plus VAT and come ready wired for teleworking. Nick Forrester, Norwegian Log director, says planning permission is not usually required.

Homelodge make double-glazed, pre-fabricated buildings with lights, power points, a heater and even kitchen units and water heater where requested. The building, which sits on concrete padstones, is assembled on site.

For many small business men and women, however, living above their place of work, rather than building it in the back garden, is the norm.

Before the internet found its way into the nation's spare bedrooms, working from home usually meant living above the shop. Bakers and grocers, for instance, donned an apron and walked downstairs to begin the daily grind.

There are still thousands of opportunities to live and work in the same place. And the canny small businessperson can snap up a bargain flat and business in desirable areas for less than the cost of a standalone apartment.

Buyers on the look out for a complete change - a guaranteed salary and an inexpensive home in a prime location - might want to consider running a post office. The idea is not as outlandish as it seems for the commercially minded. Sub-postmasters and mistresses receive a salary, plus, where there is a retail business attached, additional in come from the newsagency or corner shop.

There are almost 19,000 post offices around the UK, many of them in high-priced areas. In London's Notting Hill, a post office with a one-bedroom flat is on the market for just £100,000. The new owner would receive an income of £48,000 for running the business.

Even the most committed bargain hunters would probably balk at becoming a sub-postmaster or mistress in order to get their hands on a nice flat. Although the benefits are significant, the responsibilities are substantial. Sub-post masters and mistresses are responsible for the cost of kitting out and maintaining the office, including the cost of signs and security.

But for those interested, the website, Businessesforsale, has the Notting Hill property and hundreds of other post offices on offer. In Beetham, in south Cumbria, a community post office and general store is on the market for £17,500. The deal includes a leasehold three bedroom home with a garden, garage and studio/workshop. The salary is £4,000, plus profits from shop sales.

In Scotland, a post office, off licence and convenience store in Thrumster, is on sale for £95,000, with a £3,500 salary. The property has six bedrooms and extensive gardens, says Businessesforsale.

Another agent, Bradley Countrywide, also has a range of offices for sale. A post office in an "affluent north Essex village" is on the market for £219,000. The freehold property comes complete with a cards and stationery business, a four-bedroom detached house and an income of £34,500 and £17,000 shop sales.

Yet the picture postcard good looks of many of the country's rural post offices hide a service in crisis. The number of offices has declined by 10% over the past 10 years. In June, a report by the cabinet office-based Performance and Innovation Unit, said offices had been slow to adapt to the changing economic environment and needed to be dragged into the 21st century through diversification.

Rural post offices were singled out as in greatest need of protection, said the report Counter Revolution. In isolated communities, offices are the lynchpin of community life. When the sub-post master or mistress dies or resigns, the post office often struggles to find a replacement. If it fails, the business closes and a key public service disappears along with it.

The report found that people's reasons for buying a post office varied, but for the majority it was a way of life rather than a straightforward investment.

Buyers interested in taking on a post office have to be vetted by Post Office Counters. According to a spokeswoman, the person selling the business finds a buyer who submits an application form. The buyer is expected to provide references, submit a business plan and is then interviewed.

If they pass the test, a conditional contract is drawn up and a transfer date agreed. Training is available for new sub-postmasters and mistresses.

The Bradleys Countrywide website has a handy guide to buying a business to help novices assess the level of commitment which the venture entails.

Conservatories and cabins in the garden can't bring back the office banter, but they do take the work out of the house and cabin makers report that business is booming. Norwegian Log and Homelodge Buildings claim demand for their wooden cabins has never been higher. The companies' brochures say the buildings make successful offices for everyone, from artists and music teachers to physiotherapists. Norwegian Log's solid log buildings, that typically measure 15 feet by 12 feet, cost about £12,000 plus VAT and come ready wired for teleworking. Nick Forrester, Norwegian Log director, says planning permission is not usually required. Homelodge make double-glazed, pre-fabricated buildings with lights, power points, a heater and even kitchen units and water heater where requested. The building, which sits on concrete padstones, is assembled on site. For many small business men and women, however, living above their place of work, rather than building it in the back garden, is the norm. Before the internet found its way into the nation's spare bedrooms, working from home usually meant living above the shop. Bakers and grocers, for instance, donned an apron and walked downstairs to begin the daily grind. There are still thousands of opportunities to live and work in the same place. And the canny small businessperson can snap up a bargain flat and business in desirable areas for less than the cost of a standalone apartment. Buyers on the look out for a complete change - a guaranteed salary and an inexpensive home in a prime location - might want to consider running a post office. The idea is not as outlandish as it seems for the commercially minded. Sub-postmasters and mistresses receive a salary, plus, where there is a retail business attached, additional in come from the newsagency or corner shop. There are almost 19,000 post offices around the UK, many of them in high-priced areas. In London's Notting Hill, a post office with a one-bedroom flat is on the market for just £100,000. The new owner would receive an income of £48,000 for running the business. Even the most committed bargain hunters would probably balk at becoming a sub-postmaster or mistress in order to get their hands on a nice flat. Although the benefits are significant, the responsibilities are substantial. Sub-post masters and mistresses are responsible for the cost of kitting out and maintaining the office, including the cost of signs and security. But for those interested, the website, Businessesforsale, has the Notting Hill property and hundreds of other post offices on offer. In Beetham, in south Cumbria, a community post office and general store is on the market for £17,500. The deal includes a leasehold three bedroom home with a garden, garage and studio/workshop. The salary is £4,000, plus profits from shop sales. In Scotland, a post office, off licence and convenience store in Thrumster, is on sale for £95,000, with a £3,500 salary. The property has six bedrooms and extensive gardens, says Businessesforsale. Another agent, Bradley Countrywide, also has a range of offices for sale. A post office in an "affluent north Essex village" is on the market for £219,000. The freehold property comes complete with a cards and stationery business, a four-bedroom detached house and an income of £34,500 and £17,000 shop sales. Yet the picture postcard good looks of many of the country's rural post offices hide a service in crisis. The number of offices has declined by 10% over the past 10 years. In June, a report by the cabinet office-based Performance and Innovation Unit, said offices had been slow to adapt to the changing economic environment and needed to be dragged into the 21st century through diversification. Rural post offices were singled out as in greatest need of protection, said the report Counter Revolution. In isolated communities, offices are the lynchpin of community life. When the sub-post master or mistress dies or resigns, the post office often struggles to find a replacement. If it fails, the business closes and a key public service disappears along with it. The report found that people's reasons for buying a post office varied, but for the majority it was a way of life rather than a straightforward investment. Buyers interested in taking on a post office have to be vetted by Post Office Counters. According to a spokeswoman, the person selling the business finds a buyer who submits an application form. The buyer is expected to provide references, submit a business plan and is then interviewed. If they pass the test, a conditional contract is drawn up and a transfer date agreed. Training is available for new sub-postmasters and mistresses. The Bradleys Countrywide website has a handy guide to buying a business to help novices assess the level of commitment which the venture entails. webTitle: Big drop in library book borrowing

fields.headline: Big drop in library book borrowing
fields.trailText: A sharp and apparently steady collapse in book borrowings from public libraries was disclosed yesterday.
fields.body:
A sharp and apparently steady collapse in book borrowings from public libraries was disclosed yesterday.

Last year we took out nearly 104m fewer library books than we did a decade ago. The total of books issued in the UK has plunged by 21.2% since 1989.

The worst drop, of 25%, is in Scotland, which prides itself on reading. In Wales the fall is 19%, in Northern Ireland 15.9%, in England 21%.

"It does seem to be the beginning of an apparent collapse in borrowings," Claire Creaser, statistician at the library and information statistics unit at Loughborough University in Leicestershire, said yesterday.

The trend is underlined in Annual Library Statistics 2000, compiled by the Loughborough unit. In 1989 the public borrowed 492m library books, a figure which has fallen year by year to 388m last year.

Earlier figures for the 1980s - when there was a drop of about 12% in borrowings - indicate the fall is part of a long-term trend that grew steeper in the 1990s. If the trend continues the public will soon be borrowing fewer than half the 660m library books it took out in 1981.

The more recent decline is blamed partly on cheese-paring cuts in library opening hours and staff throughout the 1990s, one of the worst decades for the service since it was set up in the 19th century.

Britain now has only one professional librarian per 9,300, compared with one for every 7,100 in 1989.

Spending on books fell steadily until last year, when it rose slightly. But the detailed figures also strongly indicate a shift in public leisure habits.

The biggest pointer to this is the decline in borrowing of adult fiction - down 31% in the UK. Non-fiction is 14% down. The only habit immune to this trend is borrowing by children. This has increased slightly during the decade.

In Scotland, however, even borrowing by children has dropped, by 10%. Adult fiction loans are down 29% and non-fiction loans are down 24%.

The forces drawing people away from public libraries and the habit of reading are seen as including television, shopping, increased part-time working, increased drinking, weekend football-watching, videos, gym, and possibly the internet.

The statistics show library spending on books went up in real terms from £91.2m in 1998 to £91.9m last year, as part of a government effort to stop the rot.

webTitle: Extra misery on railways as storms take their toll

fields.headline: Extra misery on railways as storms take their toll
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the weather

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Train passengers suffered further misery yesterday as storms took their toll on the battered rail network. Floods saw services cut in the west of England and Wales, while east coast services were disrupted by fallen trees. Heavy rain in Scotland severely affected ScotRail services.
fields.body:
Train passengers suffered further misery yesterday as storms took their toll on the battered rail network. Floods saw services cut in the west of England and Wales, while east coast services were disrupted by fallen trees. Heavy rain in Scotland severely affected ScotRail services.

Another day of troubles on the railways followed an admission by the new Railtrack chief executive, Steve Marshall, that "to get things pretty much back to normal, as far as everyone is concerned, that's going to be towards Easter."

The Department of Transport later made it clear that Railtrack officials had told Thursday's rail action group meeting that passengers would see a "substantial improvement" in services by the end of January.

"Passengers will have robust and reliable timetables for the majority of services by the end of next month," a spokesman said, "dependent on an aggressive engineering programme being carried out between Christmas and the new year."

Railtrack announced last night that it planned to re-rail 20 miles of track this weekend - inevitably leading to more delays. The biggest job will be between Bow and Bethnal Green in east London, where 3,784 yards will be re-railed.

Services in Wales, Devon and around Bristol were particularly badly hit by floods yesterday. South West Trains, Wales & West and First Great Western bore the brunt of delays and cancellations.

The companies laid on buses to bypass the flooded areas, but many roads were under water as well.

Railtrack said the track between Exeter and Taunton might not be back in service for up to a week.

Wales & West said sections of the line between Abergavenny and Hereford had been washed away and that reopening "may take some time".

webTitle: Where the street is a playground for bored youngsters

fields.headline: Where the street is a playground for bored youngsters
fields.standfirst:
Teenage curfews: children shove crime-fighting plan out in the cold

Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Haslingden is like any other small mill town in Lancashire. At 7pm on a week night rain streamed down cobbled streets and six 13-year-old girls with their wet fringes plastered to their foreheads stood opposite the 24-hour garage talking about hairstyles. Raindrops poured off their noses on to tracksuit tops zipped up over their chins. They pulled down the zips to suck on a cigarette. They probably didn't notice the words "shitty" and "mortar" carved into the sides of gritstone houses overlooking the valley. They were bored.
fields.body:
Haslingden is like any other small mill town in Lancashire. At 7pm on a week night rain streamed down cobbled streets and six 13-year-old girls with their wet fringes plastered to their foreheads stood opposite the 24-hour garage talking about hairstyles. Raindrops poured off their noses on to tracksuit tops zipped up over their chins. They pulled down the zips to suck on a cigarette. They probably didn't notice the words "shitty" and "mortar" carved into the sides of gritstone houses overlooking the valley. They were bored.

Haslingden is a beautiful town, but there's nothing to do there if you're 12.

The town is half a mile wide and three miles long. It is mostly white working class, with middle-class pockets and an Asian population of 5%. The nearest McDonald's, which opened three years ago, is a 10-minute bus ride, but the bus service isn't great and buses are expensive. The nearest cinema is eight miles up the motorway. You can't get a bus there and back at night, and even if you could, you couldn't afford it.

So teenagers go out into the street at night and talk. They start aged 11 and keep doing it until 18, mostly congregating in groups of 20 or 30 in the market place, the park, the cemetery, the patch behind the swimming baths, the car park behind the garage or outside the chip shop. Some smoke, some drink beer. A few sniff solvents, some smoke joints - but for this they disappear into smaller groups.

Boys and girls congregate together although the girls sometimes break off in clusters to talk about the boys, and the boys sometimes break off to talk about DVDs. They send text messages. They usually bring some form of wheels: rollerblades, bikes. This year, it's scooters, although the cobbles aren't good for it. Skateboarders hope they get a lift to Accrington where there's a specially designed skate park.

The routine is have tea with your parents, leave the house at 6pm, and hang out until 9pm or sometimes later.

Anne Bullock, a senior youth worker at the Haslingden youth club, has worked with local teenagers for 15 years, mainly out on in the street at night. She said there was no profile of a single type of teenager outside. Some were wealthy, others weren't, but few carried much cash with them. Some as young as 11 were heavy drinkers, but often their parents would stop by to ask if they were having a good time, before going off to their own entertainment. Other parents knew their children were out and imposed their own curfews, usually 9 or 10pm.

Last Saturday, Kerry, 14, left her house at 6:30pm to stand on a pavement for three hours in the biting cold with three friends. They chatted. Her friend made a list of the good and bad points of boys she liked. They put them in rank order. They got bored and went home.

When the girls go out at night, up winding streets, past the antique clock shop and bakery with fairy lights in the window, they find a spot to stand in and just gossip "because there's nowhere else, except outside in the street". Kerry wants to be an air hostess. Her favourite subject is maths. Her friend, Zoe, 15, has just finished three English courseworks. She wants to be a hairdresser or a vet. They like pop, garage and Eminem.

"We hang out, we doss around and we chat. We have fun. It's a laugh, except it's freezing outside," she said. When it rains, they still go out - "otherwise we'd get bored" - but they stand in covered alleyways, which they don't tell anyone about in case they steal their spot. They don't go to the park with the others because it's dark and it spooks them. But they have chatted in the cemetery. They would never walk around alone at night, so Kerry brings her 13-year-old brother if she's worried. They usually go home at 9:30pm. Some of their friends stay out til 11 or 12.

Kerry works part-time in a hairdresser's. "That's good because it keeps me off the streets," she said. Zoe can't find a job. "I did go to the sandwich shop to ask, but it was shut," she said.

Kerry, like most Haslingden residents between 11 and 17 lives for Monday, Tuesday and Thursday nights, when the youth club, H20, is open from 7:15pm to 9:30pm in a converted pub with designer decor, new snooker table and internet link up. They go there at 5:30pm and "hang out" outside until it opens. "The only good thing about this town is the youth club," said Zoe. "We can hang out with the Asian boys, which we can't do anywhere else because it's against their religion. Apart from the club, there is nothing here. And it's not open on Saturday. We like to go out. We don't want to die of boredom."

Any mass of teenagers on the streets is seen as a nuisance to residents. There was recently an exchange of letters in the local newspaper, the Rossendale Free Press, following reports that a handful of teenagers in one part of Haslingden had been running riot on an estate full of pensioners. Some believed that teenagers had set fire to cars. Letters poured in. Steve Roman, district manager of the Lancashire Youth and Community Service, responded by assuring the paper that the majority of young teens who just chat outside at night would respond well to any calls to keep the noise down and move on. His letter was published under the heading, "Respect the yobbos".

"Being young is not a crime," said Mr Roman. "Most teenagers resent being stereotyped as hooligans, especially when they are keen for any activities the council can provide."

This week, the Queen's speech included plans to impose after-dark curfews on teenagers up to 16. Powers to ban under 10s from public places between 9pm and 6am came into force under the Crime and Disorder Act in 1998, but have never been used in England. In Scotland, the age limit is already 16 and police have powers to question any teenager found on the streets after dark. If no good explanation is given, the teenager is taken home. If there is no one at home, they are kept at the police station until their parents return. The curfew scheme tested in Hamilton, in Lanarkshire, is currently being evaluated, but councillors claim youth crime is down.

Generation gap

There is debate as to the precise form and time limit of the curfews that will appear in the crime bill early next year. A Home Office spokesman said curfews will relate to areas, not individuals. Police can apply for a curfew order then remove all under 16s from a specific area, regardless of whether they are persistent offenders. This could be after 9pm, or it could be dusk until dawn.

Defending the idea, Jack Straw, home secretary, asked: "Why are there youngsters out on the streets at 10pm or 11pm? Where are their parents?" In Haslingden, some teenagers' parents let them meet their friends outside until that time, then drive round and pick them up.

Inspector Ewan Cameron, of Lancashire police, says crime does happen amongst young teens on the streets in Haslingden. He prefers to call it "juvenile nuisance", which includes kicking footballs against shop windows, graffiti, skateboarding where they shouldn't, abuse to people who tell them off, bad language in the street. Sometimes the elderly are scared of large groups of teenagers and won't leave the house if they are outside. They are prisoners to the generation gap.

But Insp Cameron does not believe in punishing teenagers for being bored: "We can move teenagers on if they cause a nuisance. But I am more interested in working with the council to get facilities in the area to stop boredom. A curfew is short term. The police are good at short term, we just move the problem on, but we don't solve it. We have to think of the future. Quick-solve measures like curfews may just be like sticky plasters." He is currently working on the idea of an under-12s disco.

To the Haslingden police, the idea of dusk-dawn curfews seem restrictive. "Measures have to be proportionate to the problem. I would have to be sure we are not interfering with human rights by imposing a curfew. We would have to have good reasons or evidence to send someone home. Curfews might be policeable if they related to small, specific areas. But as a whole borough, it would be inappropriate."

The Haslingden teenagers turn ashen at the thought of staying in from dusk at 4:30pm in the winter. "They can stick that idea up their backsides," said one. "I couldn't live like that. I couldn't be stuck inside with my little sister all night. It would be like being locked up."

One 16-year-old, who tells stories of smoking joints in the cemetery, said: "When we saw the police, we ran off. Sometimes they moved us on, then we waited five minutes and went back. We have to have a place to hang out. We can't just be stopped from walking down the road. We live round there."

Another boy, aged 15, said: "We have needs." Asked what they were, he said: "Astroturf and the internet. I just want somewhere to kick a ball."

"I would build a huge building like the youth club and have a weight training room and the internet, then I wouldn't need to stand outside," said Zoe.

Further north, in smaller villages in the Ribble Valley, like Gregson Lane, the nearest youth club is eight miles away, with no bus service. Paul Smith, of the local tenants' group, deals with residents' complaints about teenagers being out in the street. "I don't see how curfews can be enforced. A lot of the teenage graffiti around here is actually directed at the police. But I would much rather the effort was put into organising facilities for these teenagers. It's not their fault they are bored. But sometimes trying to organise facilities is so complicated it's like banging your head against a brick wall."

 The names of teenagers have been changed

fields.body:
Yet another flood warning was issued for the river Dee yesterday as rain cascaded over the Welsh border near Wrexham.

Four weeks ago, the Dee, the Alun and the Pulford brook swelled, combined and flowed across the 200 acres of Almere farm and through the Goodwin family's 17th century home, which stands only 13ft above sea level.

The water receded and the clean-up began. But now the water is back: the Alun has burst its banks and the road to the farm is impassable.

"When will it ever stop?" asked Pamela Goodwin yesterday. Mrs Goodwin, who has lived at Almere since she married her husband, George, 37 years ago, is due to meet the Prince of Wales in Rhyl next week to tell her floods story. But if the waters keep rising, she may not be able to keep the date.

"We've been told to get the animals up on to high ground," she said.

When last month's deluge loomed, the Goodwins retreated with a microwave to a first floor bedroom, where they could do little more than gaze across a lake stretching for two miles in any direction.

The only way in and out of the farm was by motorboat, across waters up to 10ft deep. It docked at the summit of a 7ft silage heap.

"Under normal circumstances, the floods would be just one of those things," said Mr Goodwin. "Now, with BSE with us for so long, we have no working capital to go on. But my family moved here in 1904, and I'm damned if I am going to be the one to lose it.

"Times have been rough for all farmers, but now we cannot work out how to make a bit of money to get over our problems."

As the first floods seeped away, the farm's buildings were cleaned up and new straw was laid. About 180 store cattle, evacuated to a neighbour's farm, returned a week ago. One calf drowned in the flood; four severely stressed calves were put down, as was an ageing cow with arthritis. All the animals are now susceptible to illness.

A £1,500 generator was written off, 18 tonnes of hay were ruined, and a question mark hangs over the spare milk tank. But most silage remains usable, and three tractors that sank have been rescued.

Mrs Goodwin grieves over flood-damaged furniture and ruined carpets. "We've cleared out a couple of inches of mud. We had frogs in the cupboards, snails up the walls and fish jumping on the lawn."

The family manages to keep laughing. "That's how we cope, that's our safety valve," she said.

webTitle: MPs lose battle for prior scrutiny of weapons sales abroad

fields.headline: MPs lose battle for prior scrutiny of weapons sales abroad
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour's ethical foreign policy
fields.trailText: The government yesterday rejected MPs' demands for prior parliamentary scrutiny of arms exports licences, but offered them confidential briefings on "general policy considerations", including the supply of small arms.
fields.body:
The government yesterday rejected MPs' demands for prior parliamentary scrutiny of arms exports licences, but offered them confidential briefings on "general policy considerations", including the supply of small arms.

Parliamentary scrutiny of proposed arms deals would undermine the competitiveness of British weapons manufacturers, delay valuable exports and damage relations with the countries concerned, the government said.

Commons committees on foreign affairs, defence, international development, and trade and industry said in a report this year: "There can be few decisions of greater potential impact on the conduct of foreign relations, and on the lives of people overseas, than decisions as to whether to permit weapons made in this country to be put into the hands of overseas governments and their forces.

"The nation as a whole feels an exceptional degree of engagement. There is understandable anger when it is found that British-made weapons have been used to oppress people, or to endanger the lives of our servicemen and women or civilians."

Responding to the report, the government said yesterday that its view remained "that there is no role for advance scrutiny of individual casework decisions which are quintessentially matters for ministerial decision in accordance with delegated powers conferred by parliament".

It offered the committees "confidential briefings on general policy considerations, for example on small arms policy".

webTitle: Airlines urged to clean up their act

fields.headline: Airlines urged to clean up their act
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Airlines are to be told to take tougher measures against air rage offenders, and improve air quality on long flights.
fields.body:
Airlines are to be told to take tougher measures against air rage offenders, and improve air quality on long flights.

Lord Macdonald, the transport minister, is expected to tell British airlines next week to brush up their act and improve customer relations. This will coincide with a consultation with the airlines on the future of the industry in front of senior figures from British Airways and Virgin Atlantic.

Lord Macdonald's populist approach is unlikely to please the airlines, who will be more concerned to hear how airport capacity is to be improved. But the government is still waiting for a report on the new terminal 5 at Heathrow.

Lord Macdonald is likely to concentrate on short term measures. Air rage continues to be an issue, although the number of incidents collated by the Civil Aviation Authority has changed little over the past few years.

The government wants to see airlines dealing more sympathetically with poor air and restricted movement for passengers on aircraft. It wants better information on availability of low fares, and queues for check-in and waiting for luggage eliminated.

fields.headline: Football hooligan 'generals' jailed
fields.trailText: Two football hooligans exposed by an undercover television programme were jailed for seven and six years yesterday for planning violence at a game and trying to disrupt a march through London to commemorate Bloody Sunday.
fields.body:
Two football hooligans exposed by an undercover television programme were jailed for seven and six years yesterday for planning violence at a game and trying to disrupt a march through London to commemorate Bloody Sunday.

Described as "generals" among the Chelsea Headhunters football hooligans, Andrew Frain, 36, of Reading, and Jason Marriner, 33, of Feltham, Greater London, were also banned from attending football games for 10 years.

Passing sentence at Blackfriars crown court in London, Judge Charles Byers branded both as "dangerous men" who "relish violence".

Frain, known to his followers as "Nightmare", has links to the racist group Combat 18 and was a member of the Ku Klux Klan, holding the title of grand knight hawk. He has 33 previous convictions, which include burglary, possession of an offensive weapon, importing drugs, assaulting a police officer and possession of racist material.

Together with Marriner, he was exposed by the BBC programme MacIntyre Undercover as co-ordinating attacks on rival fans. Hidden camera footage of a Chelsea match in Copenhagen showed Marriner shouting: "We've come here to have a war."

Donal MacIntyre filmed the two men planning a fight against rival fans while travelling in the back of a car to Leicester. At one point Frain was heard relishing the fear opponents would feel when they learnt he "was on the loose in Leicester".

At another point on the footage, Marriner was heard boasting: "We have got about three coaches going and a minibus. It's sorted. It's naughty. Leicester will be naughty."

It was the Chelsea Headhunters who organised an ambush of Scottish supporters in Trafalgar Square during the Euro 96 championship. Forty people were injured and an ambulance was damaged in clashes.

The court heard that the men regarded such violence as "fun" and the best way to get their "kicks".

Judge Byers said that while there was no evidence that either men had indulged in any fighting "the fact remains that football violence is one of the most horrifying and frightening spectacles of recent times. It affects not only innocent people who get caught up in it, but it discourages people who genuinely watch football from attending matches.

"It terrifies young people and it terrifies the elderly, who would like still to attend football matches. It brings disgrace upon the clubs and it brings disgrace upon this country."

The programme exposed their links to rightwing groups and their blatant racism. In one piece of footage, Marriner explained how he and Frain had visited Auschwitz and mocked visitors with Nazi salutes: "I quickly took the photo [of Frain giving a Nazi salute], and a Polish geezer starts crying. I think I put the final nail in the coffin when I tried to get into the oven."

The jury was told that Frain and Marriner took part in an attempt to disrupt a "perfectly lawful" march through London to commemorate the Bloody Sunday shootings in Northern Ireland.

Both were secretly filmed by journalists gathering at Waterloo station before heading for a pub along the route. The idea was that somebody from Combat 18 would be watching for the head of the march, and at the right moment he would give the order for attack. But police penned them in before serious violence could erupt.

The jury of nine men and three women found the two men guilty by majority verdicts of conspiracy to commit violent disorder and affray.

webTitle: Cook to seek India's release of arms dealer

fields.headline: Cook to seek India's release of arms dealer
fields.trailText: The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, has formally asked the Indian government to release a British arms dealer jailed for life earlier this year for his part in a plot worthy of a John Le Carré novel to smuggle guns to a rebel group.
fields.body:
The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, has formally asked the Indian government to release a British arms dealer jailed for life earlier this year for his part in a plot worthy of a John Le Carré novel to smuggle guns to a rebel group.

Mr Cook wrote on Monday to India's foreign secretary, Jaswant Singh, urging India to free Peter Bleach, who has spent the last five years in jail in Calcutta. The Foreign Office had previously said Bleach's case was a matter for the Indian legal system.

But in July the Russian president, Vladimir Putin, secured the release of five Russian pilots who were convicted with Bleach in February.

Sir Rob Young, Britain's high commissioner in New Delhi, yesterday said that officials had finally studied all the documents from Bleach's two-year trial and concluded that there was "no distinction in law" between Bleach's conviction and that of the Russians. India has said it will review the case but last night gave no hint as to how quickly Bleach might be released.

Bleach, 48, a former Conservative party activist, was found guilty of parachuting crates of Bulgarian weapons over the village of Purulia in December 1995. They were allegedly destined for the rebel group Ananda Maraga, a Hindu cult fighting West Bengal's communist government.

Bleach carried out the drop using a plane crewed by the five Russians. They were all arrested when the plane was forced to land at Bombay. Another man, known as Kim Davy, escaped.

At his trial Bleach, from Howdale, north Yorkshire, claimed he had tipped off MI5 and MI6 before the mission. The drop was merely a sting operation to lead Indian police to the real culprit, he argued.

After meeting Mr Davy - a Danish national whose real name is Neils Christian - Bleach sent a fax to the MoD's defence export sales organisation warning of the plot. He also alerted Special Branch officers from North Yorkshire police, he said.

webTitle: Hunters to get year's grace in new bill

fields.headline: Hunters to get year's grace in new bill
fields.standfirst: Special report: the hunting debate
fields.trailText: Fox hunters will be given a year's grace to carry on with their sport if a bill outlawing the pastime is passed, the government said yesterday.
fields.body:
Fox hunters will be given a year's grace to carry on with their sport if a bill outlawing the pastime is passed, the government said yesterday.

Anti-hunting groups immediately condemned the proposal, saying it would lead to the deaths of 100,000 animals whose lives should be saved from the moment parliament decides to ban fox-hunting.

Mike O'Brien, the home office minister who will pilot the fox hunting bill through the Commons, defended the gesture to huntsmen. "It is a reasonable straightforward period of time to ensure that people will have time to put their house in order," he said.

The year's grace was a surprise feature of the hunting bill which was unveiled by Mr O'Brien yesterday. The bill, which the government agreed to introduce in the face of overwhelming support for a ban in the parliamentary Labour party, will give MPs the chance to vote on three options:

 An outright ban on all hunting with dogs, except in limited circumstances, such as to locate an injured animal;

 Setting up a licensing system. All huntsmen would have to apply to a hunting authority for a licence;

 Voluntary self-regulation.

Tony Blair opted for a "multiple choice" bill in which MPs will have a free vote, to avoid accusations of a government imposed ban.

Mr O'Brien, who also supports a ban, insisted yesterday that he would present the bill in a "neutral and straightforward" way. "The government is neutral on the issue and individual MPs will be able to vote as they feel appropriate."

MPs, who voted overwhelmingly in favour of Mike Foster's unsuccessful anti-fox hunting bill soon after the last election, will debate the new bill on December 18.

webTitle: £7m study to reveal mobile phone risks

fields.headline: £7m study to reveal mobile phone risks
fields.standfirst: Special report: mobile phone fears
fields.trailText: The Department of Health yesterday announced a £7m research programme on mobile phones and a health problem that no one has yet been able to identify.
fields.body:
The Department of Health yesterday announced a £7m research programme on mobile phones and a health problem that no one has yet been able to identify.

It is also to distribute more than 1m leaflets - on both the handsets and the base stations that feed them - with each new mobile handset, or through doctor's surgeries, libraries, post offices and on the internet.

"There is uncertainty. We don't know whether a risk might be discovered," said Liam Donaldson, the government's chief medical officer.

The research programme follows a report by a government-appointed independent committee this year that it could find no evidence of a health risk in the use of mobile phones which conformed to international guidelines. But nor could it confirm that they were absolutely safe.

A taskforce, funded jointly by government and industry, will look more closely at evidence of subtle but apparently harmless biological effects linked with low level microwave radiation.

The leaflets will advise buyers to look at the SAR or "specific absorption rate" values of each make of phone, because these are a measure of exposure to radio waves.

And they will advise parents to discourage the use of mobile phones by children under 16, because they have smaller heads, thinner skulls and still-developing brains and could therefore be more at risk. Any calls by children should be for essential purposes only - and kept short.

They will also point out that drivers are at extra risk from road accidents if they use mobile phones while driving, and that the instruments can also be dangerous because they interfere with vital equipment in aircraft and hospitals.

There are around 30m mobile phones in Britain - and the number is rising - and there has been growing concern about possible health risks. There has also been alarm about transmitter masts. The leaflets will point out that exposure to radio waves from masts is thousands of times lower than the maximum levels stipulated by guidelines.

Behind the government's concern is the lesson of BSE, the so-called mad cow disease. There is no evidence that the phones can cause harm - but until 1996, there was no evidence that BSE could reach the human population.

Mobile phone research has been bedevilled by inconclusive experiments and conflicting results. There have been claims that hands-free sets could lead to lower radiation exposure, and counter-claims that they could lead to higher exposure. And although manufacturers of radiation "protection systems" have talked of hazards, most scientists are not convinced by the evidence.

"We find ourselves in a position where we don't have a clear answer on whether particular headsets reduce exposure and we probably don't have good enough science so far to be able to say one way or the other definitely, so further research is being conducted," Prof Donaldson said. "We can't tell the public something that isn't true and the position is that we just don't know."

The taskforce that oversees future research will be led by Sir William Stewart, a former government chief scientific adviser, who chaired the independent inquiry which left the safety question open.

The Federation of the Electronics Industry, which represents the phone network operators, said it hoped the public would not be puzzled by the advice on the use of phones by youngsters. There were clear security benefits in being able to stay in touch with children by mobile phone.

webTitle: People's court indicts Japan's late emperor for war sex slaves

fields.headline: People's court indicts Japan's late emperor for war sex slaves
fields.trailText: Japan's deceased emperor Hirohito was charged yesterday with a crime against humanity for allowing the sexual enslavement of hundreds of thousands of women in Asia during the second world war
fields.body:
Japan's deceased emperor Hirohito was charged yesterday with a crime against humanity for allowing the sexual enslavement of hundreds of thousands of women in Asia during the second world war

The indictment was not made in a court of law, but in a "people's tribunal" established to apportion responsibility for the suffering of the 200,000 euphemistically named "comfort women" who were forced to provide sex to Japanese troops in brothels run by the imperial army.

During three days, 78 elderly survivors - the largest ever gathering of comfort women - will testify in a Tokyo assembly hall about the rapes and beatings they suffered while serving as "the emperor's gift to his troops".

A panel of eight prominent judges will also hear accounts by historians and veterans who used the army's brothels, the existence of which was denied by the Japanese government until 1993.

Organisers said they invited Japanese government officials to put together their own team, but got no response.

The Women's International War Crimes Tribunal is modelled on a hearing organised by Bertrand Russell and Jean-Paul Sartre to protest at the actions of the US during the Vietnam war.

It has no legal authority, but the organisers say the mock trial will fill a gap left by the Tokyo war crimes tribunal which ended in 1948 without touching on the emperor's guilt, or sexual slavery. At the time, the US, which wanted to make Japan an ally in the cold war, considered these subjects too politically and culturally sensitive to explore.

"This is a moral court," said judge Gabrielle Kirk McDonald, former president of the Yugoslavia war crimes tribunal. "We have stepped into a void created by the Tokyo tribunal's unconscionable failure to cover the 'comfort women'."

One of those women is Suhana, a elderly Indonesian who said she was 16 in 1942 when Japanese soldiers dragged her from her home and took her to the Gudangodapan army brothel in Cimahi Bandung, west of Java, where she and 80 other young girls were kept in a single room.

"They locked me up for two days and then on the third day it started," she recalled. "The first man to rape me was called Sergeant Ikeda. He was followed by five other soldiers that day and about the same number almost every day for three years. On Fridays, the doctor would examine me, and when he was finished he would rape me too."

Her story is far from unique. The army set up hundreds of "comfort stations" in Asia as a means of satisfying the sexual frustrations of its troops and controlling the spread of venereal disease. The women - from Korea, the Philippines, China, Taiwan, Indonesia, East Timor and the Netherlands - were forcibly recruited or duped into believing they would be given well-paid factory jobs in Japan.

On reaching the brothels, some say they had to serve up to 50 men per day. Many died from disease or beatings. Those who survived often found that they were shunned when they returned home.

"Even after the war ended, the pain continued," said Ms Suhana, who has never married or had children. "After three years of continuous rape, my uterus was so badly torn that I needed surgery to stop the bleeding. No man in the village would look at me."

Pictures of the long, ugly scar across her belly will be among the evidence submitted today. Prosecutors say that the ultimate blame for such suffering lies with the emperor.

"We will prove that Hirohito was involved. As head of the army, he must take responsibility for the behaviour of his troops," said an Indonesian prosecutor, Antarini Pratiwi.

webTitle: Lifeline for the women victims of violence

fields.headline: Lifeline for the women victims of violence
fields.standfirst:
This month we are highlighting the work of the four charities chosen for our Christmas appeal. Today a mother of four tells how Refuge changed her life

Special report: Christmas appeal 2000
fields.trailText:
This month we are
highlighting the work of the
four charities chosen for
our Christmas appeal. Today
a mother of four tells how
Refuge changed her life
fields.body:
The slightest rattle in the night is enough to throw her into terror. She sits bolt upright in a cold sweat and listens for the clues that spell danger.

The beatings stopped four years ago when she finally threw her husband out of the home after a decade of abuse, but the knowledge that he is still alive and capable of unthinkable cruelty keeps her feeling constantly under threat.

Catherine, an architect with four teenage daughters, paints a picture of the life that went so wrong as she sits in the bright, airy kitchen of the Hampshire home she designed.

"I never knew this man was going to harm me," she said."The first time, it happened as an isolated incident, then not for years," she said. "The birth of the children was what made it even worse.

"He used to come into the bedroom at night. Once, after my third daughter was born, he dragged me out of bed by my hair and started to have violent sex with me on the floor by the baby's cot."

Henry, a media executive whom she had met as a student at Cambridge, became more abusive and violent until Catherine was suffering daily beatings and humiliation.

According to the charity Refuge, one in four women will experience violence from a partner in her lifetime, and she will be physically abused on average 35 times before seeking police support.

The scale of the problem was highlighted when UK police forces detailed domestic violence calls received on a day in September: acts are committed on average every six seconds, and 999 calls reporting attacks are made every minute.

Police took 1,300 crisis calls in that 24 hours, reporting incidents of rape, stabbings, razor blade attacks and beatings. More than 80% of the victims were women attacked by men.

Despite changing attitudes and raised awareness of the issue, a significant number of cases are never reported. Many women such as Catherine suffer in silence, terrified they will not be believed, that they will provoke worse abuse, and ashamed of what is happening.

"When you have been hit you think, my God, this is cold-blooded, controlling, calculating stuff," she said. "You think, 'How can I be in this situation?' But you want to make it work. You love this person and you think it must be your fault, and he tells you it is. He is attractive and successful, people think he is wonderful, he is earning lots of money. You think, 'How come I do this to him?'."

Henry would swing from being the model of charm and attentiveness in the outside world to a jealous and possessive bully behind closed doors.

It was only after seeking help from Refuge that this bright, articulate woman began to realise she was not a failure, she was not to blame and she was certainly not alone.

"It was the systematic undermining of everything I did that was in some ways even worse than the physical abuse," she said. "You have nobody to talk to about what's happening, your reality is distorted, and you think you are going crazy. You are sitting there quaking with the baby and fearing for your life."

She found Refuge through The Charm Syndrome, a book by the charity's chief executive, Sandra Horley, which relates the experiences of many abused women and explores domestic violence. "I got hold of Sandra through the Refuge national domestic violence helpline."

This 24-hour helpline provides a gateway to refuges nationwide, emotional support and practical information on housing, legal and welfare rights. It enables thousands of women to leave violent partners and build a new life for themselves and their children.

About 38% of the women who try to reach the charity through the helpline, which costs £550,000 a year to run, are homeless and in urgent need of a safe house.

But lack of resources means that only a fifth of the 5,000 calls every week can get through. Refuge depends on donations to keep this and other services running.

With two women being killed every week by a partner or former partner in England and Wales, the need for a lifeline for those at risk is clear.

For Catherine that single phone call was a turning point: "I admitted to someone for the first time that I was in trouble. It was that admission that was enormously helpful."

When she finally found the strength to tell Henry to leave, blows rained down on her as she cowered on the sofa before she was dragged upstairs by her hair and threatened with a knife. Neighbours called the police and Henry stormed out.

In the months that followed, he came back to the house and raped her twice, made death threats and stalked her. Refuge helped her to gather evidence to gain an injunction against him and build enough confidence to fight back.

But she said: "I won't feel safe until he is dead, or until I have managed to disappear."

Catherine gazed at the smiling faces of her children in a photograph on the fridge and added: "Refuge gave me the strength to carry on the battle. Without Refuge I might not have made it at all."

 Catherine and Henry are not their real names

 The Charm Syndrome is available only at Waterstones

 Refuge offers a national lifeline for women suffering domestic violence, providing accommodation and emotional support. Its aim is to help women and their children enjoy a future free from physical and emotional abuse.
Refuge national domestic violence helpline: 0870 5995443

fields.trailText:
Prison van escape
A remand prisoner escaped yesterday when a prison van burst into flames on the M40 near Beaconsfield, Bucks. Darryl Swan, 20, fled when he and three other prisoners were released for their own safety from the vehicle, which was taking them to Bullingdon prison, Oxfordshire.
fields.body:
Prison van escape
A remand prisoner escaped yesterday when a prison van burst into flames on the M40 near Beaconsfield, Bucks. Darryl Swan, 20, fled when he and three other prisoners were released for their own safety from the vehicle, which was taking them to Bullingdon prison, Oxfordshire.

Aids boy loses battle
John Phiri, the 18-month-old Malawian boy featured in the Guardian's special report on Aids in Africa last Saturday, has died.

Film editor wins award
Film editor Anne Coates, 70, who won an Oscar for Lawrence of Arabia, and is tipped for another for Erin Brockovich, was yesterday presented with Carlton's lifetime achievement award for women in film and TV. Ruth Wrigley, executive producer of TV's Big Brother, won the project management award.

Parents back right to smack
Most parents believe they should decide if a childminder may smack their children (84%) or smoke in front of them (75%), according to a survey commissioned by the government among 1,031 parents with children under 10.

Guardian sales
The Guardian sold 398,332 copies a day in November, up 0.09% on November 1999. The six-month figure (June-Nov) is 395,880, a rise of 0.99% on the comparable period last year.

fields.headline: At this price?  Shire
fields.trailText: Doctors prescribed just the news that Shire Pharmaceuticals wanted to hear yesterday - confirmation that its Alzheimer's treatment Reminyl really is effective.
fields.body:
Doctors prescribed just the news that Shire Pharmaceuticals wanted to hear yesterday - confirmation that its Alzheimer's treatment Reminyl really is effective.

The announcement lifted the shares 74p, a rise of almost 6%, to £12.22 and the feeling is that there is still a long way for it to climb.

The company, which elbowed its way into the FTSE 100 in October, is well regarded in the City where it is seen as a high-growth stock.

But this has not always been reflected in its share price which has fluctuated between £5.80 and £15.08 over the past 12 months.

Much has been made of its dependence on Adderall, the drug for attention deficit disorder, and it is true that this has held the share price back. But there are signs that the company is tackling the issue.

Analysts believe real recognition will come as Reminyl is rolled out across the world and the market looks at other drugs on the company's books.

"This is a company with a high growth potential and the management is doing all the right things," said one analyst. "They are looking at acquisitions and addressing concerns about over-dependence. It's difficult to say what else they could be doing."

On the downside, Shire is facing increasing competition and this is expected to impact on Adderall.

It is also very strong in the US but relatively weaker in Europe and it is here the company needs to concentrate its efforts.

There has been talk of further acquisitions but nothing definite appears to be in the sights of senior management. In the longer term, Shire is also expected to face questions over whether it can continue its current pace of growth without having a dedicated research department.

Pharmaceuticals is a fast moving and exciting area for investors. Rounds of consolidation have increased the opportunities for smaller, specialist companies to prosper.

Buy.

webTitle: Interview: Pascal Lamy, European commissioner for trade

fields.headline: The French cricketer
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Another year, another riot. Twelve months on from the street fighting in Seattle that put paid to attempts to launch a new round of trade liberalisation, it was the turn of Nice to witness the thump of exploding petrol bombs and taste the tear gas.
fields.body:
Another year, another riot. Twelve months on from the street fighting in Seattle that put paid to attempts to launch a new round of trade liberalisation, it was the turn of Nice to witness the thump of exploding petrol bombs and taste the tear gas.

For Pascal Lamy, it's all starting to be a bit familiar. As Europe's trade czar, he was there when the Molotov cocktails were flying in Seattle and has watched as the backlash against globalisation has gained in strength. He is realistic about the challenge involved in putting trade liberalisation back on the agenda."The voice of the anti-globalisation forces are louder than they were", he said. "The politics of trade have not been moving in the right direction."

A 53-year-old Frenchman, Lamy seems an unusual choice to fly the flag for free trade. After all, France is the most protectionist country in a continent that has a reputation for feather-bedding its producers. As someone who hails from heartland agricultural France - the cream and Calvados region of Normandy - he ought to be the protectionist's protectionist. But things are a bit more complex than that.

While it's certainly true that Lamy is a socialist intellectual and a Brussels insider, he is also a confirmed anglophile. Stories abound about how he understands the American way of life and counts as his friends various members of the Anglo-Saxon great and good.

One fact alone should suffice: Lamy is a Frenchman who understands the laws of cricket.

He had the classic training of a French bureaucrat, graduating from the Ecole Nationale d'Administration and being spotted by Jacques Delors as a high-flyer in the early 80s. When Delors became EC president, Lamy was his chief of staff in Brussels between 1985 and 1994, before moving into the private sector to mastermind the restructuring of the ailing French bank, Crédit Lyonnais.

Those who ran across Lamy describe him either as a consummate political operator or a thug. Either way, they are ideal qualities for the modern trade negotiator, as is his hobby - running marathons.

Lamy is certainly aware that restarting the trade talks will be a real feat of endurance. Developed nations no longer go to war with guns; they fight trade wars with sanctions and counter-sanctions instead. And just as the first industrial revolution two centures ago caused democratic convulsions, so Lamy believes that globalisation is giving rise to justifiable calls for economic and political structures that can shape the modern age.

"Globalisation has its dark side and its bright side. The aim is to get more of the bright side, and that is a question of governance.Governance is running far behind globalisation."

He says he agrees with many of the questions posed by those who took to the streets in Seattle and Prague. "I have some sympathy with those who ask whether trade opening is good for sustainability in the broad sense of the word - be it economic, social or environmental. What I don't agree with is the sort of radical solution a number of the protesters are proposing."

He says that making progress on trade is not just about getting the technical details right, but getting the politics right. While there has been plenty of backroom activity since Seattle, the political difficulties have yet to be addressed. The well founded fear that any future trade talks will result in violent clashes on the streets means that no city in the world is willing to host next year's routine ministerial meeting of the World Trade Organisation.

Even before Lamy gets to grips with the Americans and the Japanese, he has to persuade the member states of the European Union that they should remove the national veto from key areas of trade - services, patents and investment.

While Lamy has been prepared to mix it with the Americans, threatening to impose $4bn of sanctions over the assistance - deemed illegal by the WTO - the US provides to exports from American multinationals, he has tried to lower the temperature between Brussels and Washington.

But although the EU and the US are the world's two biggest markets, securing agreement on trade now involves much more than simply striking a deal between Washington and Brussels. Lamy's solution is twofold. First, the rich countries need to build trust among the least developed countries, something the commission is trying to do by offering duty free access to goods from the world's 48 poorest countries. This initiative has been attacked both from vested interests in Europe - particularly the multinational sugar corporations - and from some of the less-poor developing nations, who feel that they will lose out.

Lamy's second idea is that the regional nature of the EU should be used as the template for future trade talks. The commission negotiates on behalf of all 15 EU countries, and there is no reason why the same model should not be adopted by countries in North America, Latin Amer ica, Africa and Asia.

However, even inside the EU such a move has problems, because only trade in goods is currently subject to majority voting. France, fearful of US cultural imperialism, is resisting giving up the veto, a move backed by campaigning groups who believe that handing more power to Brussels will hasten the globalisation process.

Predictably, Lamy does not see it that way. He believes that Europe can only punch its weight if it speaks with one voice, the same message he sends out to eurosceptics in Britain.

"The UK's road to any visible and forceful integration process is always longer than other member states. This is for historic reasons: the convergence is there but it always takes longer for the UK." Why is that? "Because of the politics of Europe and the UK. Because of British culture, history and public attitudes."

Britain, he says, is a similar country to France. The difference is that France has a border with Germany. "This has had a number of positive and negative consequences, and has made a difference to the way France has projected herself. The rewards have outbalanced the problems."

In the end, he believes, Britain will come round. He says that it will make a difference once euro notes and coins start circulating, but that staying outside monetary union will eventually lead to a loss of jobs. "The British are serious people who know what numbers are about."

Whether this happens before or after the launch of a new trade round remains to be seen. Both look a long way off, even for a marathon man.
