This is for historic reasons: the convergence is there but it always takes longer for the UK." Why is that? "Because of the politics of Europe and the UK. Because of British culture, history and public attitudes." Britain, he says, is a similar country to France. The difference is that France has a border with Germany. "This has had a number of positive and negative consequences, and has made a difference to the way France has projected herself. The rewards have outbalanced the problems." In the end, he believes, Britain will come round. He says that it will make a difference once euro notes and coins start circulating, but that staying outside monetary union will eventually lead to a loss of jobs. "The British are serious people who know what numbers are about." Whether this happens before or after the launch of a new trade round remains to be seen. Both look a long way off, even for a marathon man.

webTitle: Norway apologises for abuse of Gypsies

fields.headline: Norway apologises for abuse of Gypsies
fields.trailText: The Norwegian government apologised to the country's Gypsies yesterday for decades of oppression under a former policy that was called Norwegianisation, but it refused any general compensation.
fields.body:
The Norwegian government apologised to the country's Gypsies yesterday for decades of oppression under a former policy that was called Norwegianisation, but it refused any general compensation.

The Gypsies suffered from abuses that ranged from forced sterilisation to their children being taken away and placed in ethnic Norwegian homes or institutions.

They say they faced discrimination in many areas until about 20 years ago. Under a "racial purity" programme that began in the 30s and lasted into the 50s, about 500 Gypsy women were sterilised.

The minister of municipalities, Sylvia Brustad, apologised on national radio on behalf of the government for hundreds of years of discrimination against Gypsies.

But, she said, compensation to Gypsies as a whole would not be appropriate, since the law already allows compensation for individuals who have suffered injustices.

Instead, the government will fund a national centre for the documentation, study and history of Gypsies.

"Such a centre is more appropriate than compensation," Ms Brustad said, without providing specifics about how much money would be budgeted for the centre.

It is not clear how many people in Norway, which has a population of 4.5m, consider themselves Gypsies, but estimates put the number at about 5,000.

The president of the National Association of Roma, Leif Bodin Larsen, said that he was very disappointed by the government's decision not to offer collective compensation.

"I think it is terrible," he said, during an interview with the Norwegian state radio network NRK. "The government has had plenty of time to consider what it could offer our people."

The government's apology came three weeks after the state Lutheran church of Norway apologised for its role in the persecution of Gypsies.

webTitle: The Blurs:  Mo  Mowlam's husband paints Tony and Cherie

fields.headline: The Blurs:  Mo  Mowlam's husband paints Tony and Cherie
fields.trailText: Mo Mowlam's artist husband Jon Norton has captured the prime minister and his wife in an abstract painting. Tony and Cherie Blair are pictured in blobs of gold together with figures of red and black in the oil painting, titled The Golden Couple.
fields.body:
Mo Mowlam's artist husband Jon Norton has captured the prime minister and his wife in an abstract painting. Tony and Cherie Blair are pictured in blobs of gold together with figures of red and black in the oil painting, titled The Golden Couple.

The work by the husband of the former Northern Ireland secretary is one of 10 paintings to be displayed in a Birmingham gallery.

Mr Norton, 45, took up painting after losing his job as a merchant banker. He said: "The Golden Couple is Tony and Cherie with a slightly satirical slant... It features the couple as golden figures pulled together by a red socialist figure with a black silhouette completing the line-up."

Mr Norton's strange interpretation of William Hague's wife Ffion is also being shown at Number Nine, the Gallery. Mrs Hague's pink lips are depicted on a background of yellow and blue.

fields.headline: News of talks lifts Merant
fields.trailText: Merant, the software firm, saw its shares jump by more than 34% yesterday on news that it is in talks which could lead to it being taken over.
fields.body:
Merant, the software firm, saw its shares jump by more than 34% yesterday on news that it is in talks which could lead to it being taken over.

The City had been anticipating an announcement since August when the company admitted it was considering alternatives to boost its market value.

Merant has been shifting focus from traditional software products to its new Egility software, which allows users to mix computer applications programmed in different languages.

But it has been unable to replace services fast enough which has resulted in a softening of demand for the older products.

Merant said: "Discussions are at a very preliminary stage". But as the London markets closed last night it appeared investors liked what they heard and shares climbed 29p to 113p -off the 504p year high but comfortably ahead of the 72p low.

webTitle: Lung cancer falls as California's tobacco laws bite

fields.headline: Lung cancer falls as California's tobacco laws bite
fields.standfirst: Special report: smoking
fields.trailText: California, the state with perhaps the toughest anti-smoking laws in the world, is celebrating a huge drop in the number of lung cancer deaths and planning fresh measures to curb the use of tobacco.
fields.body:
California, the state with perhaps the toughest anti-smoking laws in the world, is celebrating a huge drop in the number of lung cancer deaths and planning fresh measures to curb the use of tobacco.

A new study shows that California's lung cancer rate fell by over 16% between 1988 and 1997, compared with a drop of 2.7% in the rest of the US. California recorded 72 cases per 100,000 in 1988 and 60 per 100,000 by 1997.

The drop coincides with the state passing Proposition 99 in 1988, when it raised tobacco taxes by 25 cents (17 pence) a pack and spent 20% of the revenue on an aggressive educational programme, and steadily banning smoking in public places such as the workplace, bars and restaurants.

Anti-smoking groups have leapt on the figures as proof of the effect of the state's controversial policies and want them repeated elsewhere. "It is big news", said Carolyn Martin for the American Lung Association of Sacramento. "It shows [an aggressive educational policy] makes the difference between life and death."

The number of smokers in California has fallen by 40% in the past decade, with those still smoking cutting their consumption by almost half. While 25% of adults smoke nationally, only 18% of Californians smoke. Only in Utah, with a large Mormon population for whom smoking is against their religion, is the rate of smoking lower.

Few places in the world make smoking less acceptable. It is banned in bars, the workplace, on public transport and in some areas near a playground. Posters warning of the dangers of tobacco adorn the highways; one shows a "Marlboro man" with a drooping cigarette and the warning that smoking causes impotence.

Now there are moves to make curbs on smoking even tougher. The Beverly Hills city council has just passed a measure banning smoking in its public parks. Violators will be given two warnings before the police take action.

The West Hollywood city council has even drafted plans to stop people smoking in their flats if the neighbours complain about secondary smoking. Tenants who refuse to give up smoking could ultimately face eviction.

Further north in Sacramento, fresh efforts are being made to stamp out the habit in bars, with compliance officers touring premises with sheriff's officers to enforce the law. A San Diego bar was briefly shut down for breaching the ban.

California banned smoking in the workplace in 1994, and, more controversially, in bars in 1998. Some bars get round this by using makeshift tinfoil ashtrays which are hidden when enforcement officers arrive. Smoking is allowed outside bar areas such as patios, but this is under threat.

The tobacco manufacturers have changed their tactics in the light of the laws. They now spend money on "community projects" which they then advertise on television. They also operate "bar nights" in which they hire bands and advertise the event in the local press, handing out promotional material such as lighters at the events.

"They spend $30m (£21m) on community programmes and $100m on television advertising telling you about what they are doing," said Ms Martin. "They have not disappeared and have tried to polish up their pitiful image."

There are a few places where the smoker still finds a welcome. The John Wayne room in the Dow Villas motel in Lone Pine is kept as a smoking room in honour of "the Duke", who was a heavy smoker before he succumbed to cancer.

Lone Pine is situated on the edge of Death Valley.

fields.headline: Menzies out of the game
fields.trailText: It has been a turbulent few weeks for newspaper wholesaler John Menzies .
fields.body:
It has been a turbulent few weeks for newspaper wholesaler John Menzies .

No sooner does it initiate legal action against WH Smith, claiming it bullies publishers into exclusive distribution deals, than another round of bad news arrives.

In an announcement to the stock market late yesterday afternoon, the company said it had lost the UK distribution contract with electronic games company Nintendo.

The Japanese manufacturer has decided not to renew the contract, which ends next March, choosing to take on the distribution itself.

For the first time it was disclosed that Menzies, through its The Games division, had been making around £5.5m operating profit through the contract.

The shares immediately slumped and, as the London markets closed last night, they had fallen 36p to 363p - a drop of 9%.

Industry observers were insisting that the company was still strong and claimed the loss of the games contract would eliminate a volatile and uncertain area of business.

Menzies is also not alone in its spat with WH Smith which last month announced plans to set up a nationwide distribution system.

Daily Mail & General Trust, publisher of the Daily Mail, has already said it will withdraw two thirds of a wholesale deal in protest.

Elsewhere, it was telecoms which ruled the roost on an otherwise fairly uninspiring day on the markets, supplying 25 points to help the FTSE 100 close up 56.9 points at 6288.3.

Colt Telecom rose almost 10%, or 141p, to £16.40, while British Telecom was up 34p to end the day at £6.61

But the session could have been a lot worse had Wall Street not shrugged off earnings warnings in the volatile technology sector.

Intel, the US chipmaker, admitted it expected fourth quarter sales to come in below forecasts but this failed to make a serious impact.

Bookham Technology, a good barometer of market sentiment, still managed a climb of 14% to £13.50, while Baltimore gained 22p at 415p and ARM Holdings, the chip designer, was up 30p at £6.35.

The relative buoyancy resulted in the Techmark index of technology shares rising 56.32 points to 2,794.23.

Among the day's main casualties was Actinic, the e-commerce software firm. It could only watch in horror as its stock value more than halved on news that product demand was down and revenues were disappointing. Shares sunk 59%, or 63p, to a year low of 44.5p. Also suffering was Granada Compass, the food services group, which closed down 42p at £6.30, ahead of next week's annual results.

The banking sector provided some comfort, adding 12 points. Alliance & Leicester rose 27p to £6.75, Barclays put on 23p at £19.83, while HSBC was up 21p at £10.35.

Rio Tinto, the mining group, also had reason to celebrate as it hit an 11-month high on the back of rising metals prices. The stock was up 68p to £12.23 by the close of play.

Media companies were boosted by the dawn raid by SMG on the shares of Scottish Radio.

Capital Radio rose 16.8% to £12.85 while GWR gained 57.5p at 637.5p, although this is still a long way off the year high of £11.25.

Other gainers included Kidde, the producer of fire safety products, which rose almost 8% to 64.75p after Merrill Lynch issued a "buy" notice.

Gainers outnumbered losers by five to three and volume was an acceptable 1.8bn shares in the blue chip index of leading shares.

As London closed, the Dow Jones Industrial Average was up 60 points and the Nasdaq Composite was up 100 points. Some of this improvement was being credited to US jobs data which showed an easing of the employment market. The FTSE 250 index of mid-cap stocks ended the session up 45.5 points at 6,514.9.

webTitle: First one to hit the panic button's a Euro-sissy

fields.headline: First one to hit the panic button's a Euro-sissy
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: When the last of the riot squad's tear gas had dispersed over the still glamorous resort of Nice yesterday, the European Union's 15 heads of government got down to taking unavoidable decisions they have postponed for too long.
fields.body:
When the last of the riot squad's tear gas had dispersed over the still glamorous resort of Nice yesterday, the European Union's 15 heads of government got down to taking unavoidable decisions they have postponed for too long.

In the terrifying circumstances in which they find themselves twice a year such hesitation is understandable.

It is a little known fact that at EU summits elected prime ministers and presidents have to make important decisions all on their own - without the assistance of the army of unelected officials, bagmen and spin doctors who normally keep them afloat.

Euro-ritual provides that the 15 (currently all blokes) convene after breakfast at a designated conference centre. In this instance that means the Palais de Congrès, a slab of 1970s brutalism known as the Acropolis in downtown Nice - which assorted Euro-militants had almost stormed before being repelled by force on Thursday morning.

The dignity of the Fifth Republic thus restored, the leaders met round an oval table with a hole in the middle, an apt Euro-symbol. They were sustained only by coffee and mineral water (French in this case), supported only by a motley crew of foreign ministers and a buzzer.

The deal is that notetakers take one official set of notes. Every 20 minutes or so they emerge from the summit room and brief characters called Antici - one per country - named after the Italian official who invented the system, Paulo Massimo Antici, pron. "Antichi" to be precise.

The Antici then brief their national delegates who panic. They are 30 minutes behind the curve and the boss may be poised to give away the store. The rules forbid them rushing in to stop him. It is a one-way buzzer.

The buzzer can be used in emergencies - like the phone in Who Wants To Be a Millionaire - when a leader wants advice or a draft in writing.

But pressing it involves loss of face. EU leaders are big on face. Officials, who like to feel indispensable, say the politicians use it rarely. The politicians say they use it without shame. "I rang my buzzer three times this morning," said one participant.

The system is fine if you are as clever as the late President François Mitterrand of France, as tall as Germany's Helmut Kohl, or as wily as Wim Kok, who is usually prime minister of Holland.

A smart lawyer like Tony Blair can also cope, especially if he is accompanied by a smart Robin Cook, whose law degree was awarded by Barrack Room College. John Major (LlB from the Polytechnic of Life) was also surprisingly good at the close-quarters small print. Legend has it that he once put one over on Mr Mitterrand at a summit.

Admittedly, the old boy was asleep at the time and Sir John Kerr, a notoriously cunning British diplomat, was said to be hiding under the table at the time, in breach of the Antici rules. But British sovereignty went ever-so-slightly uneroded as a result.

It is trickier for Mr Mitterrand's successor. British diplomats are polite about Jacques Chirac's abilities and describe him as "good at keeping speakers on time" and "very good at summing up".

Yesterday Robin Cook praised his "great determination, courtesy and skill". But he is a fellow-politician. Even Alastair Campbell, Mr Blair's press spokesman, focussed his daily wrath on the Euro-sceptic press and the need to protect Burnley football club from the EU's new transfer plans.

Other witnesses, EU commission president Romano Prodi of Italy, for instance, are less flattering. The Italian equivalent of "complete plonker" and "arrogant bully" have been heard.

Mr Prodi will clearly not be called as a character witness if Mr Chirac's domestic financial problems ever come to court, though yesterday - in public - they beamed at each other like an engaged couple.

Mr Chirac may have something of Ronald Reagan about him, and as a Frenchman in the age of American hegemony he always has something to prove. There again, all politicians remember the time Ron nearly promised Mikhail Gorbachev total nuclear disarmament during an informal chat at a summit at Reykjavik in 1987.

After that, his summit buzzer was glued permanently into "help urgently needed" mode. Mr Chirac could have done with one of these when he irritated Chancellor Gerhard Schröder of Germany at dinner on Thursday over the need for 82m Germans not to have more EU votes than 58m French because that is the way God intended it to be.

Fortunately for the prestige of France, however, Mr Chirac rotates out of the EU presidency on December 31. As such he was allowed to take lots of extra staff with him to the oval table inside the Acropolis, not just his foreign minister, Hubert Védrine, but his Socialist prime minister, Lionel Jospin. No need for the buzzer at all!

Mr Jospin was reported to be smiling a good deal, but not saying much yesterday as Mr Chirac raised hackles around the table. If this summit goes wrong we know who the Socialist candidate for president of France in 2002 will blame. And we know who the candidate will be.

fields.headline: Blasts leave 4 Russians feared dead
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Four people were feared to have died yesterday in two car bomb attacks in a street market in the southern Russian resort town of Pyatigorsk.
fields.body:
Four people were feared to have died yesterday in two car bomb attacks in a street market in the southern Russian resort town of Pyatigorsk.

Russia's security council chief, Sergei Ivanov, swiftly announced a search for the "terrorists responsible". No group claimed responsibility for the blasts, which injured 24 people, but some locals linked them with the fighting in neighbouring Chechnya.

At least one more person was thought to have died in a suicide bomb attack in the Chechen town of Gudermes, the temporary seat of the pro-Russian Chechen government.

A man at the wheel of a water tanker died when he triggered an explosion while driving into the Chechen police headquarters in the town. A second man, thought to be a police officer, was missing. Another 12 officers were hurt.

According to reports, this explosion came a few hours after a grenade attack on a pro-Moscow police truck nearby, in which two officers died.

Although Russia claims to control almost all of Chechnya, apart from the mountainous south, Chechen fighters have for months been orchestrating frequent low-level lightning attacks on soldiers across the Russian-occupied heartland - with a success rate that has sapped troops' morale.

After 14 months of fighting, the Russian army is struggling to hold on to the areas it has seized and loses men daily. According to a Kremlin spokesman, some 13 Russian soldiers were killed in attacks throughout the war-torn region late on Thursday and early yesterday.

Although Russian officers insisted this time last year that the war would be swiftly over, the conflict shows little sign of being resolved. Some 150,000 refugees in short-term camps built last year in the neighbouring region of Ingushetia are facing another winter amid dismal conditions.

Human rights organisations continue to berate Russia for the way the battle has been fought. In its annual world report published yesterday, Human Rights Watch concluded: "Russia has conducted its war in Chechnya with gross disregard for the suffering of the civilian population."

"The closeness of Pyatigorsk to Chechnya makes it and other towns in the Stavropol region fairly vulnerable," the government spokesman on Chechnya, Sergei Yastrzhemsky, said. The government controls 51% of ORT and Mr Berezovsky has said he controls the rest.

webTitle: Wray to make £13m on Burford sale

fields.headline: Wray to make £13m on Burford sale
fields.trailText: Nigel Wray, the entrepreneur and chairman of property group Burford, will walk away with £13.5m after the £498m deal to take the company private.
fields.body:
Nigel Wray, the entrepreneur and chairman of property group Burford, will walk away with £13.5m after the £498m deal to take the company private.

Burford, whose portfolio includes London's Trocadero centre, has agreed a 121p-per-share offer with Thayer Properties, a vehicle owned by a management team and investment bank Lehman Brothers.

The company blamed the stock market's disillusionment with the sector and its reluctance to "appreciate" the value of the Trocadero for its decision to sell. Burford shares have failed to climb above the 120p mark - despite being backed by assets worth 149p.

Yesterday's deal is at a 15% premium to Burford's price when it announced on December 1 that it was in bid talks. As the London markets closed last night the shares were up 6p, or just over 5%, to a year high of 119.5p.

Chief executive John Anderson, who is staying on to run the company, has been credited with boosting visitor numbers at the centre with the introduction of new bars and ten-pin bowling.

He will receive just £20,000 but is expected to benefit from options worth £300,000.

Analysts believe the company's mixed portfolio of assets was the reason it suffered at the hands of the City. "They have some attractive things like Mayfair Place but the Trocadero was always seen as an overvalued asset," said one.

webTitle: Early riser SMG raids radio rival

fields.headline: Early riser SMG raids radio rival
fields.trailText: SMG, the Scottish media group, launched an audacious stock market "dawn raid" yesterday on neighbour and rival Scottish Radio Holdings.
fields.body:
SMG, the Scottish media group, launched an audacious stock market "dawn raid" yesterday on neighbour and rival Scottish Radio Holdings.

The move fuelled expectations that a fierce bout of consolidation amongst Britain's leading radio companies is likely to follow publication of the government's white paper on media ownership rules, slated for next Tuesday.

The Glasgow-based company, which owns Virgin Radio as well as the Scottish Television and Grampian ITV franchises, surprised the sector by declaring a 2.9% stake in Scottish Radio before the market opened yesterday morning. Its stockbroker, ABN Amro Hoare Govett, then proceeded to increase the holding by a further 12%, taking SMG's total stake to 14.9% at a cost of £70m.

SMG said it would not launch a full takeover for its rival, unless another competitor turned predator, and its action was immediately seen as a pre-emptive move to deter a bid from the likes of Carlton or GWR. There has also been speculation that any one of the numerous European radio groups might be interested in using Scottish Radio as a launch pad in Britain.

"We want to be a leading player in any consolidation," said Andrew Flanagan, SMG's chief executive, indicating that he would also like a seat on Scottish Radio's board.

Scottish Radio lost out to Capital Radio in the hard-fought battle for control of Border Television earlier this year, since when it has concentrated on developing a publishing business which includes the Ireland on Sunday newspaper.

On the stock market, SMG's move electrified the radio sector, sending shares in the likes of Capital Radio up almost 25% on speculation that next week's white paper will relax rules governing cross-media ownership, making it easier for owners of television channels and newspapers to diversify into areas such as radio. Shares in Scottish Radio jumped 297.5p to £15.05, against the £15.00 at which Hoare Govett was buying stock.

A source close to the companies described SMG's move as tactical: "This is seen as parking their tanks on the lawn."

Under the current rules, due to its ITV assets, SMG is barred from owning more than 20% of Scottish Radio. While any changes proposed in the white paper will require fresh legislation and are unlikely to become effective for at least 18 months, a string of takeovers and mergers is seen as inevitable, with radio following the pattern of consolidation already seen in the ITV network.

SMG has already played a part in consolidation by buying Chris Evans' Ginger Media, including Virgin Radio, for £225m earlier this year.

webTitle: Chirac gives way in row with Blair on Nato

fields.headline: Chirac gives way in row with Blair on Nato
fields.standfirst:
Differences on defence remain despite a show of unity
Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Jacques Chirac last night backed down over efforts to distance European defence from Nato as the EU summiteers pledged to work closely with the Atlantic alliance.
fields.body:
Jacques Chirac last night backed down over efforts to distance European defence from Nato as the EU summiteers pledged to work closely with the Atlantic alliance.

Britain sought to portray Thursday's row with France about defence as a semantic difference. But Tony Blair, rattled by Tory criticism and sensational headlines, insisted on cutting back the summit's defence text "to avoid misunderstandings" about the new rapid reaction force.

Diplomats acknowledged that difficulties lay ahead in agreeing detailed future EU-Nato arrangments on planning, which are crucial to keep the US and the alliance happy - and the Eurosceptics at bay.

Ironically, these must now be overseen by neutral Sweden, which takes over the EU's presidency next month. "The EU hopes for a favourable reaction from Nato so that these arrangements can be implemented on a mutually satisfactory basis," a summit statement said last night.

Mr Chirac jangled nerves on Thursday when he said that the EU's 60,000-strong rapid reaction force should be independent from Nato's military headquarters. But yesterday he said EU efforts were intended to "complement" Nato.

Irritated by what was seen as an unnecessary if predictable domestic-driven diversion by the rightwing French president, the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, insisted there were no real disagreements.

"There was no row," Mr Cook said. "The decision took about eight minutes. It was unanimous and taken in a spirit of unity. These documents give Britain all we ever wanted on European security."

There was support from Javier Solana, the EU's foreign policy supremo. "It's more a question of language, a question of semantics," Mr Solana said of Mr Chirac's statement. "Let's make it very clear. It's not a threat to Nato. We are not trying to create a European army."

But sensitivities were evident when the 15 leaders approved a report on defence policy but omitted several paragraphs from a statement summarising the EU's role in crisis management, including links with Nato.

Mr Blair said the draft contained slight deviations from agreed wording on the defence initiative. Mr Chirac said the differences were slight, but agreed to omit the passages rather than waste time on a detailed debate on wording.

The EU insists its initiative is compatible with Nato and is intended to carry out peacekeeping and humanitarian missions when the US and Nato choose not to get involved. But questions linger about the degree of coordination between the EU and Nato, and the role granted to six Nato members, especially Turkey, which are not in the EU.

William Cohen, the US defence secretary, warned this week that Nato could become a "relic of the past" if the EU set up a divisive European caucus within the alliance and established rival structures for defence planning.

And Britain's chief of the defence staff, Sir Charles Guthrie, fuelled the debate yesterday: "Judging from what President Chirac said, there is certainly a difference of opinion," he said.

Smelling an opportunity, the Tories returned to the attack. The shadow defence secretary, Iain Duncan Smith, said: "What Mr Chirac said, and what is on the table today, is nothing new. It is simply what Mr Blair has agreed to already. It's no good Mr Blair pretending that he has reservations now, when at no stage over the past two years has he insisted on any formal link to Nato, nor spoken of any problems. Mr Blair's attempt to use British defence forces to place himself at the heart of the EU now risks weakening and destroying Nato."

The French president later told a news conference that he was "100% happy" with the outcome, which was a good agreement in "perfect harmony" with Nato.

"Nato naturally remains the foundation of collective defence among the allies," Mr Chirac said. A European defence capability was a complement to Nato that "strengthens the Atlantic alliance and does not weaken it."

fields.headline: Tube boss to get £2m house
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: After a hard day dealing with the decay and grime that is London's crumbling underground system, Bob Kiley, the capital's incoming transport supremo, will be able to unwind in a £2.1m Georgian house in Belgravia paid for by Ken Livingstone.
fields.body:
After a hard day dealing with the decay and grime that is London's crumbling underground system, Bob Kiley, the capital's incoming transport supremo, will be able to unwind in a £2.1m Georgian house in Belgravia paid for by Ken Livingstone.

The London mayor personally authorised the purchase of the property for Mr Kiley, who starts his post as commissioner of transport for London on January 1.

He is moving from New York where he is credited with turning round that city's transport system. Mr Kiley was tempted by a lucrative package linked to performance that could earn him £2m over four years.

The three-bedroom house near Sloane Square, and just a few minutes from the underground, will remain the property of Transport for London.

Mr Kiley will pay for his own furniture for the house, built in 1740, and described as hav ing "great character and charm". The property has a stone-tiled hall, marble fireplaces, oak floors and lots of wood panelling.

In a statement, Mr Livingstone said: "Mr Kiley is one of the world's greatest experts on transport. He will have the opportunity to earn £2m over four years. Half that salary is linked to his ability to achieve real improvements in bus and tube services.

"TfL will be purchasing a house, valued at £2.1m, to provide accommodation for him in central London. The house will remain the property of TfL."

John Biggs, Labour's transport spokesman on the Greater London Authority, said: "It is two-faced of the mayor to one day attack the private sector and the next outbid them."

Bob Neill, leader of the Conservative group on the GLA, said: "I shall want to see where the money is coming from, whether its from the TfL budget or the precept. We want to make sure it is not coming from the 30% council tax increase Ken Livingstone is planning in the GLA portion of the tax."

 Ken Livingstone pulled out of a meeting with London Underground managers and staff after he was refused permission to take a television crew along, writes Kevin Maguire. Mr Livingstone's decision left underground managing director Derek Smith "livid", one executive claimed.

webTitle: Informant sues the Met over 'broken promises'

fields.headline: Informant sues the Met over 'broken promises'
fields.trailText: A supergrass is suing the Metropolitan police for £100,000 he claims he is owed in return for information about a string of drugs barons.
fields.body:
A supergrass is suing the Metropolitan police for £100,000 he claims he is owed in return for information about a string of drugs barons.

Cafe owner Mehmet Ali Deniz also accuses the Met of reneging on a deal to give him a new identity and home which, he says, put his life in danger.

Despite having a contract on his head, the informer has lodged a high court writ against the Met commissioner, Sir John Stevens.

In his writ, Mr Deniz alleges that detectives promised him a £3,000 reward for every kilo of heroin seized. One raid alone is said to have resulted in a haul of 60 kilos of the drug.

After a series of successful raids, police told Mr Deniz that they were concerned for his safety as a result of evidence he gave against members of the Turkish mafia. They advised him to leave his home and cafe business in Bethnal Green and placed him in a safe house in Richmond, Surrey.

Mr Deniz, who also closed his kebab shop in Darlington, Co Durham, claims he never received compensation for the loss of his businesses or the British passport he alleges he was promised.

The writ describes how Mr Deniz contacted the ITV programme Crimestoppers in April 1996 saying he had information about drugs dealers operating in London.

After a series of discussions with detectives, Mr Deniz supplied details of more than 25 criminals believed to be members of the Turkish mafia, and also provided details of a store of illegal weapons and ammunition he says were used in mafia-related murders.

Mr Deniz says he was only paid £5,000 of a promised £20,000 by the Met for information about the heroin dealings of a man named Akhtar, a known criminal included on the force's "most wanted" list. Despite being promised the balance by "a very senior police officer", he never received any further payments.

The writ, served by Mr Deniz's solicitors, Purcell Brown of Edmonton, alleges he assisted in setting up six drugs deals, one of which resulted in the murder of a heroin dealer after he failed to pay for three kilos of heroin he bought.

In another case, on the instructions of police, Mr Deniz acted as an accomplice for a heroin importer and set him up with a deal to supply five kilos of heroin to an undercover detective. The dealer was later jailed and Mr Deniz says he was offered £20,000 for his information.

Police became so concerned for Mr Deniz's safety that they asked him not to return to his home address and to close down his businesses. He alleges that when he complained this would mean losing his livelihood, the Met promised to compensate him.

When he was moved to a safe house in Richmond a criminal justice protection unit officer said he would be provided with a new name, a British passport, proper financial reward and permanent secure accommodation. He was told the process would take three to four months.

The writ adds: "The defendant was negligent in failing to give the claimant the proper care and support reasonably expected for a police informant giving information on the dealing and importation of heroin and the use, sale and importation of firearms."

Last night a Scotland Yard spokeswoman said: "We can confirm that Mehmet Ali Deniz has commenced civil proceedings against the commissioner.

"We are not prepared to discuss it further."

In April, a high court judge ruled that supergrasses who claim they have been short-changed in rewards paid for information have no legal right to sue. The judgment came in a case launched by the informant Keith Robinson, who claimed £33,574 plus interest against the commissioners of customs and excise for breach of an alleged contract under which he said he was promised reasonable remuneration and expenses.

Mr Justice Douglas Brown held that no contract existed and that, in any event, on grounds of public policy, "an informant cannot maintain a claim against the commissioners or indeed a chief officer of police in respect of any reward for information supplied".

fields.headline: The knowledge
fields.standfirst: Stress-free party catering
fields.trailText: Stress-free party catering
fields.body:
The subject
Food for an army of revellers - the Knowledge's grand strategy.

The basics
When you're throwing a party, the last thing you want is last-minute panic followed by slave-duty in the kitchen. That's why you need to remember three words: planning, planning and planning.

The details
Planning countdown, three days before party-time: count the guests and add 20% for insurance. Flip through cookbooks to get ideas. Do not consult with your partner, who will merely grumble.

Party-minus-two, afternoon: decide what you're serving. Change your mind a few hours later. One final tweak, then make a shopping list including accessories (napkins, paper plates, toothpicks, etc) and booze.

Party-minus-two, evening: plan your cooking strategy, what can you do a day ahead and what needs to occur on the Big Day. Make sure you have enough serving plates.

Party-minus-one, mid-morning: do the shopping (don't forget the list, knucklehead!) and unpack when you get home.

Party-minus-one, mid-afternoon: go out again to buy the stuff you forgot in the morning. Party-minus-one, evening: cook everything that can be cooked a day in advance. Most dips, stews and soups sail under this flag of maximum convenience. Do the washing-up, even if you're knackered. Get a good night's sleep.

Party-minus-six hours: finish off the cooking. Wash up again. Get grumbling partner to assemble hardware (plates, etc) and software (napkins, etc).

Party-minus-zero: bring out the food, cross your fingers, and start drinking.

Party-plus-four hours: wonder when everyone will get the hell out.

Party-plus-too many hours: say goodbye to the last guest.

Party-plus-exhaustion: collapse. Get partner to wash up.

The easy way out
No-sweat party faves: nuts, olives, breadsticks, carrots and celery sticks. Go for dips and home-baked cheese straws if you want to make an impression. Or the Kitchen Doctor's offerings, if you want people still to be talking about your prowess this time next year

Where to buy
When you're this busy, a supermarket. But keep your cotton-pickin' hands off the frozen vol-au-vents!

fields.headline: Party drinks
fields.standfirst: As if feeding your guests isn't trouble enough, how do you choose what drinks to serve, asks Fiona Beckett. Few know better than the men behind Match bar
fields.trailText: As if feeding your guests isn't trouble enough, how do you choose what drinks to serve, asks Fiona Beckett. Few know better than the men behind Match bar.
fields.body:
Funny, our attitude to parties. Why do we feel obliged to cater for every conceivable taste? Wine, beer, spirits, soft drinks - you name it, we lay it on. Apart from making sure your veggie guests are happy, you don't do that with food - people get what they're given - so why do we do this with drinks?

I put this to drinks masters Dick Bradsell (who created the cocktails for our fashion shoot on pages 86-94) and Jonathan Downey of Match, expecting them to endorse the idea of keeping drinks simple. Instead, they look shocked. "I've had Americans come to my flat," says Downey, "and tell me exactly how they want their drink served: 'Two shots, serve the ice separately,' that sort of thing. You can't tell people what to drink."

"Of course, you have to have water, too," says Bradsell, briskly. "In fact, you have to have two different types of water. Some people hate fizzy."

Bang goes my idea of a budget party, then. Still, if anyone knows what to give people to drink, this pair should. Bradsell, by common consent, is the most influential barman in London, the inventor of such legendary cocktails as the Vodka Espresso and the Wibble. Downey is the proprietor of the ultra-cool Match bars. Between them, they run a consultancy, Bar Solutions.

So what do they serve at parties? Bradsell starts rattling off ideas: "You need something with pow to get people going. Fizz is good to get them in a happy mood. Mix vodka, lemon juice and cassis, pour into glasses over ice and top with champagne or sparkling wine. Or add cheap fizz to a splash of sloe gin. That's seasonal. Or make bellinis with prosecco and peach purée. Then you can move on to something stronger."

Such as? "Almost any classic cocktail," says Bradsell. "Old-fashioneds, Manhattans, Cosmopolitans. Choose drinks that are popular. I'd never serve Campari at a drinks party because so many people don't like it."

"You could also theme your drinks," suggests Downey. "You could have a Polish evening, say, and give everyone a shot of vodka when they arrive. Or a New York-style party with Cosmopolitans and Manhattans. Or a Prohibition party with Long Island iced tea. Or a Cuban one with mojitos and daiquiris."

"I once filled a large display vase full of limes and mint, pummelled it all together, added vodka, ladled it into glasses and topped up with soda," reminisces Bradsell. "If you can make things in bulk, it's a real help. Almost any tropical fruit juice works with rum. Or any dark spirit with ginger ale and a bit of fruit."

The trick, though, is not to go overboard with the alcohol. "People tend to go for mad things like vodka and Red Bull, or tequila slammers, but you want to avoid aggressive drinks. People can be aggressive enough as it is. As the evening wears on, you want to concentrate on single-shot drinks like a Pontberry Martini [one shot vodka, two shots cranberry juice, three tablespoons crème de mre]. A nice, balanced drink - not too strong. Or try this one that I've just created for Agent Provocateur: one shot of vodka, two of apple juice and two tablespoons of passionfruit syrup."

But where do you get crème de mre and passionfruit syrup from? "Good off-licences such as Gerry's in Old Compton Street, London [020-7734 4215], or the Class magazine barshop [0808 100 2691], which also has a good selection of glasses and other cocktail kit," says Bradsell.

But doesn't all this get rather expensive? "If you're short of cash, get everyone to bring a bottle, sure, but make sure they bring the same thing," says Downey. "Ask them for a Stoli or Absolut vodka, a Tanqueray gin or a Havana Club rum."

So, pukka brands, then, not a quick dash to Asda? "God, yes," says Bradsell. "You've got to use good ingredients. Like freshly squeezed juice."

"And ice," chips in Downey. "You can never have enough ice. Twice as much as you think you'll need, and you still won't have enough."

"No ice, no party," adds Bradsell. "Imagine gin and tonic without ice." I say I can't imagine gin and tonic in winter, anyway. "Oh yeah? It's an all-season drink - there's always someone who's going to want that."

It sounds like a lot of messing about, especially if you're not a dab hand at cocktails. "Hire a barman," says Downey. "It'll cost about £10 an hour, but it's money well spent."

"The barman can't drink, either," adds Bradsell firmly. "You can't mix drinks if you're drunk. We've got barmen you could hire, haven't we?"

"Yeah," says Downey. "Just email Lucy at lucy@barsolutions.com."

"Even if you've got a mate who knows how to make drinks," says Bradsell, "you would not believe how much pressure it takes off you. What you don't want is to let people make their own drinks - that's a disaster."

As the evening wears on, they also advise you to reduce the alcohol in the drinks. "By the end, you want to be getting as much liquid into people as possible," says Bradsell. "And if they won't go home, make drinks without any alcohol in them at all."

"A Moscow Mule with water instead of vodka for anyone who can't say the word condescension," chips in Downey.

Finally, what if it all goes pear-shaped and you have people throwing up all over the place? "Here's an essential party tip on how to get the smell of sick out of your house," says Bradsell. "Deodorised cat litter - it works really well."

So now you know

fields.headline: The pity and the sorrow
fields.trailText: You suggest we ought to "pity the killers" of Damilola Taylor (Pity the killers, December 1). The perpetrators of this crime have not been identified, yet the Guardian claims that "their mental health needs have been bypassed". How do you know?
fields.body:
You suggest we ought to "pity the killers" of Damilola Taylor (Pity the killers, December 1). The perpetrators of this crime have not been identified, yet the Guardian claims that "their mental health needs have been bypassed". How do you know? All we seem to know about the perpetrators is that they are black. Are you claiming that all black youth in these areas are suffering from mental illness? Is it beyond possibility that ignorant, bigoted bullies killed Damilola and that the black communities in Britain need to address the anti-social behaviour of many young black people?

I am of African descent and have, like Damilola, endured racially-motivated bullying by people of West Indian descent. For the Guardian to try to find a scapegoat which avoids saying that black people need to take responsibility for this situation, and not degrade ourselves by claiming that we are all victims of "this system" and "that system" every time something like this happens, is cowardly and irresponsible. I don't remember you asking readers to "pity" the killers of Stephen Lawrence. How do you know that "their mental health needs" were not also "bypassed"?
David Smart
London

 My heart broke in two when I heard Tunde Taylor speak at his brother's memorial service (Thousand gather to mourn Dami, December 8). If ever there was evidence of a shared humanity it was this, but running parallel was a profound sense of the inequality in peoples lives.
Sue Berger
Bristol

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In a Face to Faith article in reply to AN Wilson, page 22, December 2, the author of the piece wrote: "To say that Christian leaders are cowards, who dare not 'rock the boat' in questioning concepts such as the Resurrection and the Virgin Birth is to miss the point of what the modern Church is about." This came out in the edited piece as: "To say that Christian leaders are cowards who dare to question concepts such as the Resurrection and the Virgin Birth ..." This completely changed the sense. AN Wilson was criticising church leaders for not questioning doctrines, not for questioning them.

It is for a first book, fiction or non-fiction, in any category except children's and reference, for instance. Naomi Klein, who was on the shortlist this year, is Canadian rather than American.

fields.headline: That's the spirit
fields.standfirst: Great parties are all about getting just the right mix of people - and the same applies to the snacks you put on offer, says Bob Granleese. Kitchen Doctor Rosie Sykes puts her reputation on the line.
fields.trailText: Great parties are all about getting just the right mix of people - and the same applies to the snacks you put on offer, says Bob Granleese.
fields.body:
'The thing about parties," says Rosie Sykes, Kitchen Doctor, "is that most of us get into a terrible tizzy when it comes to the food - everyone wants to lay on a fantabulous spread of nibbles, but that means work, so we tend to fall back on boring old sausage rolls, crisps and nuts. It's much better to make just one or two really special dishes, to complement more standard fare."

Rosie is unpacking her shopping bags in the kitchen of Christopher Woods and Michael Cormick, covering the work surface with the ingredients that she hopes will help make their party go with a real bang. Both work in the theatre - Christopher is a set designer (his most recent creation can be seen in The Mystery Of Charles Dickens at the Albery Theatre, London), while Michael is an actor with the Australian Musical Theatre - and rarely need an excuse to invite friends round to their home in Camden, north London.

Even so, this time they've got one: the couple are off to spend the next few months in Australia, and are having a farewell party and a Thanksgiving celebration on successive nights. The only problem is, they are letting the house to a bunch of actors while they're away - "We're theatrical landladies now," quips Christopher - and it's far from ready for its new tenants. They've already drafted in an American friend to cook the Thanksgiving meal, but the catering for the party has had to take second billing to DIY. Which is where the Kitchen Doctor comes in: they contacted Rosie with the simplest request (or, more accurately, bribe) she's ever received: "If you sort out the food, you can come to our party." How could she resist?

"Admittedly, I did spend quite a lot," says Rosie as she finishes unpacking, "but that's because I'm doing a whole range of finger food. If you didn't have me here, however, you'd probably only want to do two or three of them at most."

Unsurprisingly, Christopher, who is going to help her out while Michael carries on with the painting and decorating, doesn't seem to mind at all. "What do you want me to do?" he asks.

"Well, you could start by making the dough for the Spanish-style stuffed rolls," says Rosie.

Following Rosie's instructions while she gets to work on the other dishes, Christopher is soon up to his elbows in flour, while Basil, his lurcher, ignores the enormous cowbone in his basket and gets under everyone's feet in his eagerness to snaffle every last bit of debris that falls off the work surfaces. "He only eats human food," explains Christopher, "and hardly even looks at that bone. Michael gets more use out of it, because he threatens me with it in the mornings, to get me out of bed - he's the spit of Bamm-Bamm in the Flintstones." Rosie chuckles, but then, realising there is still much to do, tells Christopher quickly to add a big glug of white wine to the dough mix. "Does that speed up the process, or something?" he asks.

"Exactly," replied Rosie.

"I wonder, does it do the same for humans?" says Christopher, then promptly drains what's left in the glass and licks his lips. "What next?"

"Peel the quails' eggs for the filling," says Rosie, who has already got the chicken soaking in its yoghurty marinade, and the beef cut and pounded thin as you like for the carpaccio. Christopher begins his task keenly enough, but, after 10 minutes have passed with only three eggs peeled, soon gets frustrated: "You can buy these ready-peeled in jars, you know - I've seen them at Sainsbury's."

The look on Rosie's face soon puts paid to this putative kitchen-hand rebellion, however, and Christopher resumes his toils, before mumbling, "And I thought you said these were meant to be soft-boiled - they seem pretty well done to me."

"Bum," says Rosie. "Then again, when you make a Scotch egg, it's hard-boiled, isn't it?"

"So, these are like a Spanish Scotch egg, then?" says Christopher.

"Well, no, not at all like that, really," replies Rosie, looking deflated again. "Never mind, they'll have to do." And with that she returns to the chopping, pounding, stirring and all those other things a Kitchen Doctor does when she's doing her stuff. "And now, for the lentil patties to go with the chicken tikka. Oh, and the savoury Eccles-type cakes or, as I prefer to call them, the new vol-au-vents - they're a bit like a new black for the nibbles set."

"Sounds impressive," says Christopher. "What's in them?"

"Goats' cheese, olives, herbs and all sorts of yummy stuff - Eccles cakes are quite crunchy, and I wanted to recreate that, only in a savoury way, so pinenuts are in there, too. Have you got any scales?"

"Sorry."

"Oh dear - I am so bad at measuring things by eye," says Rosie. "I always wildly overestimate." As if to prove her point, she opens a 500g packet of lentils and pours three-quarters of it into a pan. "That's about 200g, isn't it?"

Christopher soon puts her right, and they set about finishing everything off. All of a sudden, a German pointer comes bounding into the room, swiftly followed by its owner, George, Christopher's best friend. "This is Billie," she tells the KD crew, before adding hurriedly, "as in Holiday, not Piper."

While Basil and Billie join forces on a scrap hunt, Rosie lays an enticing array of nibbles on to serving plates, and then announces, rather grandly, "Because you've done so well, I think it's time to test the cocktail I've devised for tonight - it's called the Amber Growler, because of its colour and bite."

Christopher, who has already displayed a certain keenness for a drop or three, and George watch Rosie even more slavishly than their dogs had done while she fills two glasses with champagne, vodka, bitters and a sugar cube. As the cubes fizz away, they pounce. "Bloody hell, that's strong," gasps Christopher. "Should go down a treat."

And so it did: the next day, when asked how the party had gone, Christopher couldn't really remember: "We overdid it a bit," he said. "Everyone had about six or seven of those cocktails, and we've just sent out for the Nurofen - Growlers should come with a health warning."

All recipes serve eight.

Carpaccio-wrapped rocket salad
A mixture of a couple of recipes that I learned from my main culinary influence, Juliet Peston

500g good quality beef fillet

1 generous splash good olive oil

Black pepper

150g rocket leaves

1 tbsp truffle oil (expensive, I know, but you use it only sparingly)

30g Parmesan

Slice the fillet into 1.5cm thick slices (to make cutting easier, refrigerate the meat for an hour or two, to firm it up). Toss the slices of beef in olive oil and black pepper, and leave to marinade until 10 minutes before serving.

When you're ready to plate up, place each piece of meat between two pieces of clingfilm and flatten with a rolling pin until very thin. To serve, season the rocket, shave over the Parmesan and mix in the truffle oil. Take a piece of beef, season with a little salt, lay some rocket salad on top, then roll up and arrange on a plate, perhaps with a little more Parmesan shaved over the top.

Pancetta-Wrapped Tiger Prawns
These can be prepared in advance, and take only a minute or two to cook, so are ideal if time is short. For an alternative, use green beans instead of prawns.

500g tiger prawns, peeled, heads and tails on

Black pepper

225g pancetta

8 sage leaves, cut into strips

Lemon juice

Season each prawn with pepper, lemon juice and a few strands of sage, then leave to marinade for about half an hour. Wrap a strip of pancetta around each prawn until it is completely covered. To cook, lay in a very hot griddle or frying pan for a minute or so, turning once.

Lentil rounds with chicken tikka, yoghurt and mint
The lentil cakes are based on a recipe by Lorna Wing. She uses split red lentils, but I prefer the earthiness of puy lentils. Served with spicy chicken, yoghurt and mint makes for a pretty hearty mini-snack.

For the lentil cakes

225g lentils

1 chilli, deseeded and finely chopped

2 cloves garlic, peeled and crushed

5cm piece fresh ginger, peeled and grated

2 heaped tbsp finely chopped fresh coriander

tsp turmeric

1 dssp passata

1 egg

tsp salt

Oil, for frying (I favour grapeseed)

Rinse the lentils in cold water, pick out any stones, pop them in a bowl, stir in the passata and pour in enough water to cover. Leave to soak for eight hours.

Drain the lentils, tip them into a food processor, along with the remaining ingredients, and blend to a smoothish paste. Divide the mixture into even-sized balls, then flatten into patties. Leave to rest for about half an hour. Shallow fry in hot oil over a moderate heat for about four minutes on either side until crisp and golden. Allow to cool slightly, then top with the following:

For the chicken

2 chicken breasts, skinless and boneless, cut into 3cm pieces

150ml pot natural yoghurt

1 tsp ground cumin

1 tsp ground coriander

tsp cinnamon

tsp paprika

2 tbsp chopped mint

Salt

8cm cucumber, peeled, seeded and finely chopped

Mix all the herbs and spices into 100ml of the yoghurt, reserving half a tablespoon of mint for later. Pour the mixture over the chicken, and leave to marinade for as long as the lentils, or as long as possible. The new Vol-Au-Vent This is a sort of savoury Eccles cake, which I thought could be this season's vol-au-vent on the party circuit. Another fantastic filling would be leek and mushroom - it's one of those things that has endless possibilities.

2 shallots, finely chopped

50g green olives, roughly chopped (I used ones that were stuffed with pimento and anchovy - it's all down to personal choice)

50g black olives, pitted and roughly chopped

200g crumbly goats' cheese, rind removed and cheese broken up

55g pinenuts, roughly chopped

1 tbsp parsley, finely chopped

1 dssp basil, chopped

Black pepper

1 egg yolk

For the topping

1 egg white

1 tbsp sesame seeds

1 tsp coarse sea salt

55g cherry tomatoes

30g Parmesan, coarsely grated

55g French beans (or asparagus tips - both optional, depending on the size of the chicory leaves)

1 dssp balsamic vinegar

For the dough

15g fresh yeast (or double the amount of dried)

10g salt

A good slug olive oil

300-350ml warm water

For the filling

Amber growler

20ml vodka, chilled

slice lemon and 10ml lemon juice

1 sugar lump

1 dash Angostura bitters

fields.bodyText: 'The thing about parties," says Rosie Sykes, Kitchen Doctor, "is that most of us get into a terrible tizzy when it comes to the food - everyone wants to lay on a fantabulous spread of nibbles, but that means work, so we tend to fall back on boring old sausage rolls, crisps and nuts. It's much better to make just one or two really special dishes, to complement more standard fare." Rosie is unpacking her shopping bags in the kitchen of Christopher Woods and Michael Cormick, covering the work surface with the ingredients that she hopes will help make their party go with a real bang. Both work in the theatre - Christopher is a set designer (his most recent creation can be seen in The Mystery Of Charles Dickens at the Albery Theatre, London), while Michael is an actor with the Australian Musical Theatre - and rarely need an excuse to invite friends round to their home in Camden, north London. Even so, this time they've got one: the couple are off to spend the next few months in Australia, and are having a farewell party and a Thanksgiving celebration on successive nights. The only problem is, they are letting the house to a bunch of actors while they're away - "We're theatrical landladies now," quips Christopher - and it's far from ready for its new tenants. They've already drafted in an American friend to cook the Thanksgiving meal, but the catering for the party has had to take second billing to DIY. Which is where the Kitchen Doctor comes in: they contacted Rosie with the simplest request (or, more accurately, bribe) she's ever received: "If you sort out the food, you can come to our party." How could she resist? "Admittedly, I did spend quite a lot," says Rosie as she finishes unpacking, "but that's because I'm doing a whole range of finger food. If you didn't have me here, however, you'd probably only want to do two or three of them at most." Unsurprisingly, Christopher, who is going to help her out while Michael carries on with the painting and decorating, doesn't seem to mind at all. "What do you want me to do?" he asks. "Well, you could start by making the dough for the Spanish-style stuffed rolls," says Rosie. Following Rosie's instructions while she gets to work on the other dishes, Christopher is soon up to his elbows in flour, while Basil, his lurcher, ignores the enormous cowbone in his basket and gets under everyone's feet in his eagerness to snaffle every last bit of debris that falls off the work surfaces. "He only eats human food," explains Christopher, "and hardly even looks at that bone. Michael gets more use out of it, because he threatens me with it in the mornings, to get me out of bed - he's the spit of Bamm-Bamm in the Flintstones." Rosie chuckles, but then, realising there is still much to do, tells Christopher quickly to add a big glug of white wine to the dough mix. "Does that speed up the process, or something?" he asks. "Exactly," replied Rosie. "I wonder, does it do the same for humans?" says Christopher, then promptly drains what's left in the glass and licks his lips. "What next?" "Peel the quails' eggs for the filling," says Rosie, who has already got the chicken soaking in its yoghurty marinade, and the beef cut and pounded thin as you like for the carpaccio. Christopher begins his task keenly enough, but, after 10 minutes have passed with only three eggs peeled, soon gets frustrated: "You can buy these ready-peeled in jars, you know - I've seen them at Sainsbury's." The look on Rosie's face soon puts paid to this putative kitchen-hand rebellion, however, and Christopher resumes his toils, before mumbling, "And I thought you said these were meant to be soft-boiled - they seem pretty well done to me." "Bum," says Rosie. "Then again, when you make a Scotch egg, it's hard-boiled, isn't it?" "So, these are like a Spanish Scotch egg, then?" says Christopher. "Well, no, not at all like that, really," replies Rosie, looking deflated again. "Never mind, they'll have to do." And with that she returns to the chopping, pounding, stirring and all those other things a Kitchen Doctor does when she's doing her stuff. "And now, for the lentil patties to go with the chicken tikka. Oh, and the savoury Eccles-type cakes or, as I prefer to call them, the new vol-au-vents - they're a bit like a new black for the nibbles set." "Sounds impressive," says Christopher. "What's in them?" "Goats' cheese, olives, herbs and all sorts of yummy stuff - Eccles cakes are quite crunchy, and I wanted to recreate that, only in a savoury way, so pinenuts are in there, too. Have you got any scales?" "Sorry." "Oh dear - I am so bad at measuring things by eye," says Rosie. "I always wildly overestimate." As if to prove her point, she opens a 500g packet of lentils and pours three-quarters of it into a pan. "That's about 200g, isn't it?" Christopher soon puts her right, and they set about finishing everything off. All of a sudden, a German pointer comes bounding into the room, swiftly followed by its owner, George, Christopher's best friend. "This is Billie," she tells the KD crew, before adding hurriedly, "as in Holiday, not Piper." While Basil and Billie join forces on a scrap hunt, Rosie lays an enticing array of nibbles on to serving plates, and then announces, rather grandly, "Because you've done so well, I think it's time to test the cocktail I've devised for tonight - it's called the Amber Growler, because of its colour and bite." Christopher, who has already displayed a certain keenness for a drop or three, and George watch Rosie even more slavishly than their dogs had done while she fills two glasses with champagne, vodka, bitters and a sugar cube. As the cubes fizz away, they pounce. "Bloody hell, that's strong," gasps Christopher. "Should go down a treat." And so it did: the next day, when asked how the party had gone, Christopher couldn't really remember: "We overdid it a bit," he said. webTitle: Weekend: The weeping Madonna of Civitavecchia

fields.headline: The crying game
fields.standfirst: When villagers at Civitavecchia witnessed tears of blood falling down the face of a souvenir Madonna, they proclaimed it a miracle. But soon, experts were branding it a cunning hoax and a row ensued. It's a familiar pattern in Italy, and beyond. What is the truth of such apparitions? Alix Kirsta investigates
fields.trailText: When villagers at Civitavecchia witnessed tears of blood falling down the face of a souvenir Madonna, they proclaimed it a miracle. But soon, experts were branding it a cunning hoax and a row ensued. It's a familiar pattern in Italy, and beyond. What is the truth of such apparitions? Alix Kirsta investigates.
fields.body:
What strikes people most when they first see the Weeping Madonna of Civitavecchia is her size. The white glazed plaster statue is only 16 inches high, her face, with its downcast eyes, no bigger than a man's thumb. Originally bought from a souvenir stall at the shrine of Our Lady at Medjugorje in Bosnia, she cost less than a fiver, but, as mass-produced religious statuettes go, is surprisingly untrashy.

For the past five years, La Madonnina, the little madonna, as she is known locally, has stood behind bulletproof glass in the little church of St Agostino in Pantano, a poor agricultural suburb of the port of Civitavecchia, near Rome. Every year, she attracts thousands of pilgrims. Of the scores of "miracles" reported in Italy during the lead-up to the millennium, only this "weeping Madonna", who even has her own website, continues to bring in the charabancs, transforming a once unknown chapel off a dirt-track into an international religious shrine.

However, anyone hoping to see her weep, or detect traces of blood on her cheeks, will be disappointed. Since allegedly weeping tears of blood in front of thousands of witnesses in February 1995, La Madonnina has remained dry-eyed and all traces of blood have long since faded. Which is more than can be said for the controversy that surrounds her.

La Madonnina's worldwide renown is due as much to her supposed mystical powers as to the fact that, for the past five years, she has been the subject of an unprecedented and bizarre criminal investigation in which the Italian authorities have become embroiled in a so-called "pious fraud", a charge normally ignored, or dealt with by the church. In this case, the Procura, or district attorney, is determined to expose La Madonnina's tears as a hoax and identify the culprits as the statue's owner, Fabio Gregori, and his family.

The enquiry appears set to run indefinitely and has all the makings of an absurdist melodrama, involving the diverging interests of anti-cult campaigners, judicial authorities, the Catholic church, and the mayor of Civitavecchia, Pietro Tidei, a communist nonbeliever who is determined that the shrine at Pantano should become as commercially viable as Lourdes, Fatima or Medjugorje. Meanwhile, like many thousands of believers, Gregori, a 37-year-old electrician from Pantano, believes that what he witnessed five years ago was a miracle. What he also knows is that it has changed his life, largely for the worse.

It began, like most mystical experiences, in the most humdrum circumstances. As a devout Catholic, Gregori was overjoyed when his local priest, Father Don Pablo Martin, returned from a visit to Medjugorje in September 1994 and gave him a plaster statuette of the Virgin to protect his home and family. With nothing to distinguish it from the serried ranks of Madonnas around the Bosnian pilgrimage site, Father Pablo nevertheless believed that this one had special powers, claiming he was guided by one of Italy's most celebrated religious figures, the late Capuchin friar Padre Pio, to bring the statue back to Civitavecchia, where "the most beautiful event of this life" would occur.

Five months on, an event did indeed occur that propelled the tiny hamlet into the spotlight. On the afternoon of Thursday, February 2, 1995, Gregori was hurrying to mass when his six-year-old daughter Jessica's shrieks pierced the air. "Papa, Papa, come and look. The Madonnina is crying. There's blood everywhere!" Rushing to join her at the little stone shrine he had built in the garden, he saw, he says, red liquid well up in the statuette's eyes and trickle down her cheeks and gown.

Deeply shaken, he drove to mass, where he recounted the incident to Father Pablo. Within hours, news of the "weeping" had spread throughout the district and crowds of acquaintances and strangers began gathering outside his gate. The circus had begun.

Throughout the weekend, as the story hit the headlines, the faithful and the merely curious, including reporters and TV crews, thronged in their thousands down the small country lane to Gregori's house, pushing into his small garden, praying, weeping, gawping, chattering and crossing themselves as they filed past the tiny statue before shuffling out again to gossip and speak to the press.

"It was a mass invasion, they were swinging from the trees," recalls Scottish-born Carmela Dinardo, who runs Civitavecchia's foreign language school. "You couldn't move for cars, buses and people blocking the way to his home. I wanted to see the Madonna, too, and drove down there, but was forced to park far away and walk. It took hours to reach the shrine. They were battering down his gate, hundreds of people at a time trampling around his garden. People had come from all over Italy. The Gregoris simply locked themselves inside the house." After several people had tried to handle the statue and touch the blood, police were called to maintain order at the site.

By late Sunday, February 5, the statuette had, according to many witnesses, wept blood 13 times. By the following day, Gregori could take the strain no longer and, pursued by paparazzi, delivered the statuette to Father Pablo at St Agostino for safekeeping. Then he locked the gates to his garden and put up a notice: "Please don't stop here. The Madonna is no longer here."

And there the drama should have ended. It was, after all, just the latest in a long line of incidents involving holy effigies, animated statues and sightings of the Virgin Mary during the 90s throughout the world. In India and England, reports that animal statues at various Hindu temples had begun "drinking" milk also drew crowds for several months.

Even in Italy, with nine separate lacrimazioni (weepings) reported in the first two months of 1995 alone, belief had begun to give way to scepticism as each incident was either dismissed due to unreliable eyewitness reports or found to be a practical joke or some natural phenomenon, such as dewdrops forming on a statue.

Why should La Madonnina of Civitavecchia be any different? And what makes locals, such as Dinardo, an ardent believer in miracles, and her friend, Christiana Vallarino, a local reporter from Il Messaggero, who saw the tears but insists it's a clever trick, still argue over the incident in the cafes on Civitavecchia's seafront? The answer lies in the web of intrigue that still surrounds the case, and speculation over one of the most colourful characters involved in it, Monsignor Girolamo Grillo, the bishop of Civitavecchia.

As he welcomes me to his house to tell me about the story, Monsignor Grillo, a jocular 70-year-old known locally as "il grillo parlante" (the talking cricket) because of his outspokenness, still chuckles over his initial reaction. After taking the statuette from Gregori, Father Pablo delivered a report to Grillo, describing what had occurred in the family's garden that weekend.

Phoning him several hours later to ask him what to do with the statue, Father Pablo was shocked at the bishop's response: "I tore up the report and threw it in the bin and told Don Pablo to destroy the statue immediately, so as to end all this trouble! I had no doubt it was a hoax. Naturally, I started hearing from angry parishioners condemning me for not believing in all this rubbish."

There were well-founded reasons for Monsignor Grillo's wish to distance himself from "this rubbish". According to rumour, the area around Civitavecchia is heaving with Jehovah's Witnesses, occult groups and Satanists, any of whom could have planned a hoax. More significantly, the Vatican, sensitive to charges of superstition, favours a cautious attitude towards reported "miracles", especially those involving inanimate objects, rather than mystic "seers" as in Fatima.

His next step, which was to phone the police and ask them to investigate the Gregori family, therefore, seems logical, as does his request to his own doctor to carry out tests on the "blood" now congealed on the statue. What he wasn't prepared for was the result: the substance was haemoglobin.

That report, says Monsignor Grillo, only strengthened his resolve to expose the trick. "The Gregoris, I found out, were simple, poor, hard-working, local people, honest and devoutly religious, with no criminal record. I even did an exorcism on them, believing it was a satanic set up."

But, being something of an amateur sleuth, Bishop Grillo wouldn't let the matter rest. Father Pablo, disobeying instructions, had given the statue to one of Gregori's brothers, so Monsignor Grillo persuaded the family to let him take it to Rome for analysis of the bloodstains and x-rays of the structure. The tests were repeated several times by separate teams, one headed by Professor Angelo Fiori at the Vatican's Gemelli hospital, the other by Rome's leading forensic medical examiner and DNA expert, Giancarlo Umani-Ronchi, director of the Institute for Forensic Medicine at the University of Rome.

"When I handed the statue in at the lab, they assured me it would turn out to be animal blood," laughs Monsignor Grillo, drawing out the story for effect. "Then they found it was human blood." But greater revelations were to come: repeated analysis and DNA tests established that it was male blood, while a series of x-rays and CAT scans of the statue itself confirmed that it was solid, with no sign of having been rigged. "That actually increased my doubts. Obviously it was a hoax. The blood of Our Lady ought to have been female, no?"

After reporting these developments to the Vatican, Monsignor Grillo was authorised to set up a theological commission to study the case. It was the start of many sleepless nights, he says. On March 1, soon after the statue had been returned to him, CODACONS, Italy's largest consumer protection group, alarmed at extensive media coverage of the case, issued a formal complaint against "unknown persons". This was followed by an allegation of fraud from a prominent Italian helpline, Telefono Antiplagio, run by Professor Giovanni Panunzio, a children's religion teacher in Sardinia and director of the Italian Committee to Help Victims of Charlatans and Gurus.

Again, Monsignor Grillo admits giving police the go-ahead to investigate. "I called in the law, hoping they would finally help me prove the weeping was a joke, because I was so sure it was." But when police raided the homes of all four Gregori brothers and their mother at dawn on March 8, turning everything up-side down in the search for evidence of trickery, they drew a blank.

Fabio Gregori's ordeal, however, was far from over. Under Italian law, once an accusation is made, the public prosecutor is obliged to open a full-scale criminal investigation, which can drag on for years, even if there is insufficient evidence to prosecute. What happened a week later added a whole new dimension to an already farcical situation. While saying mass at home with his sister, brother-in-law, nephew and two Romanian nuns, the bishop claims that La Madonnina cried tears of blood as he held her in his hands.

Although he announced what he had witnessed in a TV interview a week later, in effect endorsing the miracle, he refuses to use the word miracle: "It's a mystery - there is no rational explanation," he tells me, with the first sign of gravitas that afternoon.

The bishop's announcement - carried out against the advice of the Vatican - merely cranked up Antonio Abano, the public prosecutor, who enlisted Criminal-pol, the Italian equivalent of the FBI, to dig further into the case. Abano ordered the bishop to hand over La Madonnina and requested all male members of the Gregori family to submit blood samples for DNA testing against that on the statute. Neither request was met.

"Since I had witnessed the weeping myself, the Vatican gave me authority to tell the police to stay away from the case and not permit the statue to be confiscated," says Monsignor Grillo. "That didn't go down so well. Now the prosecutor was convinced that Gregori and I were in this together. They accused me of being in cahoots with the Vatican and both of us of fraud. At this stage, they would have liked to put me in jail for being the hoaxer, but a bishop is still a bishop, so they tried to seize the Madonnina. The upshot, Fabio Gregori's lawyer, Bruno Forestieri, says drily, was "a very Italian-style compromise". The courts agreed to let the bishop keep the statue in a sealed cupboard in his residence while the enquiry continued. Hundreds of irate local parishioners had been publicly protesting at the state's interference with their plans to carry the statue "home" to St Agostino church in the town's traditional Good Friday procession, which more than 10,000 worshippers were expected to attend. Two weeks later, an order was issued for its release. "Which makes me the only lawyer in history to set the Virgin Mary free," says Forestieri.

However, the order came too late for the Easter procession - which may have been a blessing of sorts. For instead, in a gesture that spoke volumes, the Pope's close friend and fellow countryman, Cardinal Andrej Maria Deskur, after giving an address at the cathedral of Civitavecchia on Easter Monday, presented a blessed copy of La Madonnina to the Gregori family. Implying that the Pope shared his views, Cardinal Deskur went on to compare the tribulations of Gregori's original statuette to that of the revered Madonna of Czestochowa in Poland, sequestered by the communist authorities in 1967 and now standing in the Pope's diocese of Krakow.

Although, thus far, the Vatican had remained silent, the subtext of Cardinal Deskur's speech hardly needed spelling out. La Madonnina was finally returned to the parish church in June, after undergoing further x-rays and scans together with DNA analysis of the new bloodstains, which were reportedly identical to the first.
