However, as the child of elderly parents - always assuming her desire to be exposed as a changeling continues to be thwarted - she feels entitled to trace her direct blood line back to the 19th century and the photographic image of her maternal grandfather, "the only gorgeous member of the family". Dark, dark brown eyes, black hair, excitingly foreign, she'd pore over the portrait and ask her mother, was he Italian? Spanish? And her mother would hush her up, no, no, no, don't be so silly, as though the mere thought of being anything other than entirely English, with perhaps a bit of Scottish on dad's side, was somehow shameful, something not quite right in the woodshed. Her mum was intent on bettering herself, not dwelling on dubieties of ancestry. She was knocking 40 when she met Eileen's dad, and, according to family lore, obliged him to marry her in exchange for taking care of his three-year-old daughter while he serviced the automobile of the Portuguese ambassador. He was called an under-chauffeur, which meant that, though he couldn't actually drive a car - he didn't know how - he got to vacuum them and polish their bonnets. When his first wife died, he took up lodging in Eileen's mum's mother's house in Stoke Newington, where they all lived together in quiet desperation and increasingly cramped conditions as the children of the union arrived at a rate of one a year. When she was pregnant for the third time, she opted for an abortion in the interests of health, space and respectability. Then, when her two-year-old died of diphtheria, she realised God had punished her for her wickedness. Life went on in the little house; dad read gas meters, mum sewed for a factory all day and went out at night to be a barmaid in the Elephant & Castle. And that was it until, at the age of 47, she discovered she was pregnant again. "It's funny," Eileen says, "but I always felt I've come out of a massive row." She sounds enigmatic, but it's probably literally true. Her father, it seems, had undergone testicular surgery, a painful and emotionally unmanning experience that prompted a somewhat taunting comment from his good lady. "I'll show you . . ." he is supposed to have retaliated and, wallop, Eileen was conceived. She was born in the Salvation Army Home in Clapton, north London, a geographic fact furiously denied by her mother, who insisted until the day she died that it was a hospital, not a home. They were allotted a council house in Tottenham as a prize for the birth of Eileen June. They'd never had it so good. The six of them piled into the two-down, three-up; gran, mum, dad, half-sister, brother and the tiny blonde princess, God's forgiving gift. "My very first memory of being alive," she says 66 years after the event and bright as yesterday, "is being tossed in the air by my father and laughing and knowing, really knowing, that his was absolute joy." She knew that, and she knew that she was unequivocally adored. There was never, ever any doubt about it. She could tell her siblings were miffed, and she knew, even then, she couldn't blame them for that. She was a born dotee and, in the Jesuitical sense, she reciprocated the dote till the age of seven, when she ceased to be pretty and realised she could read and didn't need her dad to tell her his wonderful stories any more. Not to mince words, her dad was a bit on the backward side. He left school, of necessity, at the age of 12 and was known by the children of his acquaintance as "Uncle Funny Man" for his amiable, childlike qualities. To Eileen, as she began to look about herself with the critical eye of a seven-year-old, he was just stupid. Irritatingly so. For instance, when they built the first motorway, the M1, he would always pronounce it the M Eye. It made her wince. So she said to him, listen dad, it's not the M Eye. It's the M One. Next time they build a motorway, it'll be the M Two, then the M Three. "That's right, luv," he said cheerfully, "M Eye." She remembers the day she read her first words as one of the greatest moments of her life. She knows exactly where she was in the high street, holding her father's hand, looking at an advertising hoarding with a poster of a man with yellow hair riding a bicycle on top of a jar of Bovril. And the words, "Bovril is good for you." She read them out loud. Oh Bliss. "Bovril is good for you." She didn't feel her father's deflation until they got home and she heard him say to her mother, "She can read", in the same tone he'd have used if he'd said, "I lost her", or, "Her leg came off". From then on books were her ecstasy. Even now, when that unaccountable flooding of euphoria, bliss, happiness, whatever you call it, wafts across her consciousness - you know how it does sometimes, for no particular reason - she gets a flash of the steps leading up to the library in Tottenham, just round the corner from the council house. Her father didn't tune himself easily to the separation caused by his daughter's literacy. Whatever sadness he felt he channelled into a threatening irascibility over the possibility of a ha'penny fine being imposed on her overdue library books. He'd pick them up, sigh, then glare at the date stamps. Stupid, stupid man. Only when she was nearing middle age did she appreciate she was just like him. Thick. She has the same kind of intransigent thickness as the one she despised as a child. She prepares for her roles slowly. S-L-O-W-L-Y and with difficulty. She finds herself at parties with erudite friends, suddenly unable to understand a word anyone's saying, as though something tripped in her brain and she's fallen down a black hole. Once she had a lover who asked her to nip out and move his car. When she told him she couldn't drive, he turned on her. You idiot. He bawled. You incompetent. "That's right," she said. "I act and I fuck and that's it." Her mum was the pushy one. Sometimes now, when she looks down at her own hands, she sees her mother's. She's like her, too. When Eileen was three, a Gypsy came to the door selling lucky heather and clothes pegs. Not getting much change out of Eileen's mum, she gazed at the little girl clinging to her skirts and announced she was to be a world famous dancer. Never one to pass an opportunity, Eileen's mum went straight out and enrolled her in the nearest dance class. She tended to make the best of things, did Eileen's mum. From the age of three, Eileen has been insomniac. Her mum dragged her around doctors' surgeries, distraught for two years, until an old Indian physician explained the problem. "She has," he said, "too much imagination." He prescribed, for reasons best known to himself, breakfast in bed and lots of books. Mother and daughter were well satisfied with the arrangement. Eileen's mum would say, airily, "Oh no, she never sleeps. She has too much imagination." As though vaunting another facet of her own and her daughter's innate superiority. Eileen didn't like dancing class. At the same time, she discovered in herself an aptitude for inventing, telling and maintaining monstrous lies. That and snivelling. While her mother persevered with the famous dancer fantasy, enrolling her in school after school, Eileen invented her own exit lines. "They're awful to me," she'd come home blubbing. "That Doreen, she put my head down the toilet and pulled the chain." She doesn't know to this day where she got it from, or how she held on to her story while the innocent Doreen was pilloried and exiled to outer darkness. "I was just . . ." she says, "a liar." In 1939, and for some time after, the exigencies of the war threw up a moral climate among Londoners in which it was considered the height of adult responsibility for parents to evacuate their children to rural locations, where strangers were prevailed upon to take them into their homes, while they remained in the prime bombing area to contribute to the war effort. In deference to this masterstroke of social engineering, Eileen, aged five, was given a bar of chocolate and put on a bus with her 12-year-old brother and innumerable other brats, and transported to a village called Little Baddow in Essex, or, if her brother's recollection is more accurate, Great Baddow. There, in company with some Civil Defence dignitary, the children were trailed from house to house, imploring the residents to take them in. "Aw, please take us, lady, we're ever so clean," she heard her brother beseech a woman at her garden gate, which was bad enough. Then a huge, unpleasant-looking woman arrived, demanded the pretty one with the ringlets and whisked Eileen home to her daughter, who kicked her, pinched her and scoffed her chocolate. Endlessly weeping was again the answer to her problem. She sobbed, she cried, she damned near died, for many months. Then her mother came and took her back to London, omitting to register her as a resident and therefore a schoolchild. She stayed at home with mum, who, to distract her traumatised daughter from the air raids and bomb devastation, redoubled her efforts to give the Gypsy's prediction a helping hand. Tirelessly she sewed the little nymphet costumes. Ruthlessly she hawked the child, now known as "Baby Eileen", around the working men's club circuit, where she tappy-toed and sang faintly iffy songs for 15 shillings a pop. Of course, she knew there was something deeply wrong with being Baby Eileen (see picture, page 41). The whole frilly-knickered-bum-chuck, finger-to-dimple awfulness of it all. She once heard a big bosomed chanteuse complain to the management, "Hey, Buster, how am I meant to compete with that ?" cocking a thumb in her direction. But 15 bob was a lot of money in those days, and besides, it's not everyone who can boast they were on the same bill as Anna Neagle, at age seven, singing I'm A Yankee Doodle Dandy and toe-tapping on a drum at the stage door canteen. In the golden autumn of her elegantly fulfilled life, Miss Atkins has no particular complaint about the bizarre nature of her childhood. "Bad things happen," she says imperiously. "Cope!" What really pisses her off is the current vogue for "counselling". The slightest thing happens, you witness an accident, you get burgled, some fool sends you a victim support round robin and the offer of "counselling". She sounds, she concedes, like some fat old blimp. "I was thrashed with the buckle end of a belt and it never did me any harm." Yes, that's her. A disgustingly reactionary old woman. "Wheels come off? Get on with it. Cope. Survive." She isn't joking. Pragmatic people don't jest about themselves; rather, they sometimes choose to elaborate on one half of a contradiction for reasons of economy or modesty. The fact that life hurts is a banality, and we're all free to choose to be anaesthetised or sensitised or, as Eileen puts it so succinctly, "You might as well stay indoors for ever, because if you go out the bus conductor might not like you." By the time she went to high school, she was bright enough not to give a stuff about being stupid. At the end of a lesson, teachers would say to the class, "Do you understand?" then, "And does Eileen understand?" and everybody would laugh. She didn't take offence and therefore no offence was intended. School offered "Drama", and a drama teacher who allowed her more enthusiastic pupils to improvise and perform their own playlets. Eileen found her niche and stuck to it. In the fourth form she took the title role in the school production of Alice In Wonderland, a triumph that put her occasional scholastic weakness into perspective and gave her an identity she could grow up with. More significantly, perhaps, she found a mentor in the shape of the divinity master, an energetic and singular fellow with a penchant for moulding receptive schoolgirls, who sailed fairly close to the wind by eventually marrying one of them. But his influence on Eileen was purely cerebral, and, in imparting to her the benefits of his mindset, broke down the remaining barriers of her upbringing. They travelled to and from school on the same bus, he took her to the theatre, he explained to her with meticulous care the societal improprieties of capitalism and the moral superiority of socialism. He made her a free thinker. This had the effect of making her perfectly foul to her mum and dad. My, how she knocked and mocked the poor darlings, their narrow-mindedness, the petty parameters of their ambitions for themselves and herself. When she was 14, going on 15, she took it upon herself to address a Mr Robert Atkins, a Royal Shakespeare Company director with an encouragingly familiar name and an on-going production she felt she had something to say about. "Dear Mr Atkins," she wrote. "The boy who plays the prince in your King John isn't good enough. I could do it better." Or words to that effect. He must have been temporarily amused, because he wrote back and suggested she drop in some time. He was less amused when she turned up, having dressed and cosmeticised herself to resemble her idea of a going concern. In fact, he was rather nasty. Good God, he said rudely, we don't want any shop girls here. Flattered, she replied that she wasn't a shop girl, she was a schoolgirl, and threw herself into her little prince speech with no trepidation. After that, he told her to come back when she was a grown-up and she went back to school thinking it had all been rather a good day's work. Eileen didn't get into Rada. Guildhall wasn't keen, either, but signed her up for its teaching course and nobody noticed when she slipped herself in with the drama students and took up their curriculum as well. She wanted to be an actress. She was an actress. At 18, going on 19, she was slogging up and down Charing Cross Road, knocking on doors, looking for jobs. That was how it worked in those days. You put yourself on as many agents' books as there were agents, then you went home and hoped. One Christmas she nearly got a job as a pantomime dog. An agent rang her up and said, quick, tell the truth, how tall are you? Five foot seven, she said. Damn, he said, the costume's for five foot two. Oh, she said, did I say five foot seven, I must have been thinking of my sister, she's the five foot seven one, honest - I'm five foot two. An hour later, she was backstage at some fleapit in Walthamstow with three other contenders. There was no audition, just the skin. So there she was, sweating and straining and yanking at the zip of this ratty costume, her entire life depending on cramming her five foot seven frame into a five foot two dog skin, and failing. No job. No money. No life. Next day brought another great opportunity. A Christmas show in Norwich. "You'll be met at the station, dearie," said the agent. "It's a three pounds a week, all in. Digs and everything." Nothing to lose, everything to gain, she packed her suitcase and boarded a train for Norwich, where she was met at the station by a sad creature with a baby in her arms and a toddler round her ankles who dolefully led her to a bus stop. The bus stopped outside a theatre showing Mother Goose with Cyril Fletcher, and what luck, a young man called Peter Johnson, who she'd been at drama school with. Only it wasn't her stop. The bus sailed on into the countryside and set her and her dismal companions down by a fairground. She was then led through the deepening darkness to a caravan in which a large man, another child and three huge dogs were already ensconced. These, apparently, were her digs. "Look, lovey," said the large man, relieving her of her suitcase and stowing it beyond her reach. "I know all you girls think you're serious actresses" - which Eileen thought was perspicacious of him - "but get a load of this . . ." and he produced a cardboard box of Turkish harem costumes and flourished it at her in the manner of one offering the answer to a maiden's prayer. "Go on," he said, "you can choose!" Her role, it seemed, was to adorn herself in the exotic scanties of her choice, then prance about outside a tent in the cold, exhorting people to buy tickets to watch her host throwing knives at his wife, after which she was welcome to bed down with them in the caravan, babies, dogs, the whole ensemble. And no, there was no telephone and no again, her suitcase was staying put. When in doubt, Eileen reckons, act it out. Certainly, bursting into tears was not going to work this time. So she fingered the horrible costumes in the vile box and said, ooh, yummy, how lovely, she could hardly wait - then, muttering something about finding other digs, ran panic-stricken into the night, leapt aboard a Norwich-bound bus and found herself at the stage door of Mother Goose. "Mr Johnson," she demanded, pulling herself together. "Mr Peter Johnson." Someone bawled along a corridor and Mr Johnson was roused from his kip between matinee and evening shows to emerge in green tights, horns, full Demon King fig, still holding his trident. Even his face was green. He threw his duffle coat over his kit, hailed a cab, bundled Eileen into it, took her back to the fair, thumped on the caravan door and addressed himself to the knife-thrower. "Evening," he barked. "Sorry. Not suitable. All right? Sorry. Give us the case. Jolly good. Sorry. Thank you. Goodnight." Then he drove Eileen to the station and put her on a train back to London. She got home at five in the morning. Her brother Ron let her in. "Right," said Ron, taking one look at her, "that's it. She's had it. The end." But it wasn't. She continued to live at home in Tottenham with her parents and Ron while they gamely supported her in whatever she did as best they could. Her mum and dad sat bored and bewildered through interminable Shakespeares and Ibsens and Chekhovs and, good grief, Strindbergs, while their beloved daughter spread her wings far, far beyond their wildest dreams of her betterment. They'd hoped for a successful chorus girl. They didn't complain. They were, she says, valiant. One day, she thinks she was doing a Strindberg play at the time, she was with her father when they passed a theatre somewhere in Croydon where the late Cicely Courtneidge was starring in an extravaganza called Steppin' High or Steppin' Out or some fine thing. "Now that's the sort of thing I'd like to see you in," her dad said to her. She could have killed him at the time, but now, well, bless. And she wonders if she ever thanked Peter Johnson properly. Six years ago, Eileen was in New York doing a play with Kathleen Turner. The two women didn't get on. Not to put too fine a point on it, they seemed to share a deep and visceral mutual aversion. And then Eileen got cancer. She took her little lump to the doctor and knew immediately what it was because he avoided her eye. She won't hear a word against oncologists. "Not only do they work impossible hours," she says, "but they're supposed to behave impeccably and be psychiatrists as well." Her best friend went with her for the big biopsy report and the best friend burst into tears and everybody looked the other way and, yes, she had cancer and they took her in and cut it out and that was it. Next morning some poor, benighted counsellor came into her room and confided to her that she must be very angry. Angry? asked Eileen. Oh yes, she'd kicked up a fuss because of the noise of the television set next door. Sorry, she said, but how are you supposed to get any sleep with that row going on? No, no, said the counsellor. You must be angry about the cancer. You know, he prompted, you must be thinking, why me? "Look mate," she told him. "I've been angry all my life. I'm not about to start blaming it on cancer at the age of 61. And I've never thought, 'Why me?' I don't understand 'Why me?' My attitude is: 'Why not me?'" She took some time off actually to have the cancer, of course. She didn't need to, but she did. They gave her the chemo and the radiation and she lay a bit low, because, to be honest, she didn't want people's eyes sliding off her all over the place. She did some writing, read a bit, ate well and felt perfectly wonderful all the way through. Her hair failed to fall out. She never felt sick. She doesn't know what all the fuss is about. She enjoyed it. She met such marvellous women having chemo. Marvellous. It's nothing to do with being brave, it's about getting on with it. You really have no choice. "I'll tell you what pisses me off," she says, not for the first and I trust not for the last time, "it's that soppy cow on the Archers, weeping and wailing about her bloody cancer." Then she thinks for a minute. Still, she concedes, she is a bit young and she'd better watch what she says about the Archers in case she ends up on it. Come to think of it again, she reckons, she'd rather like that  Eileen Atkins will appear in The Sleeper on BBC1 at Christmas.

fields.headline: Bon Voyage!
fields.standfirst: The actors must believe in the sincerity of their roles. If the cast is peopled with caricatures, never mind. They must be played straight
fields.trailText: The actors must believe in the sincerity of their roles. If the cast is peopled with caricatures, never mind. They must be played straight
fields.body:
Its success will be for the audience to decide, but a new "musical farce" running for five days from next Wednesday at the Tabernacle, in Notting Hill (box office, 020-7565 7800), is at any rate a timely antidote to pretentiousness in the musical theatre. Bon Voyage!, as it is called, has no purpose but to entertain, which was all that the best Broadway and Hollywood musicals of the 20s and 30s aimed to do. From the 40s onwards, the American musical became increasingly ponderous and overblown as it strove for deeper meaning and greater dramatic tension. Perhaps because of the second world war and all the horrors that flowed from it, the tide turned against irrelevance and escapism even on the stage. The world was considered too serious a place for unashamed frivolity.

But the time may be right for it again now. I hope so, because I am more than peripherally involved in Bon Voyage! The music and words were written by my son-in-law, Alexander Waugh, and his brother, Nathaniel, sons of my old friend Auberon Waugh and, of course, grandsons of the novelist Evelyn Waugh. They wrote it some years ago to amuse themselves, but then entered it for the Vivian Ellis Award for Best New Musical, which it won in 1996. This, however, did not lead to a staging, and the brothers are now putting it on themselves, hoping that some West End impresario will subsequently take it to the commercial stage.

This enterprise, like the play itself, is a bold piece of derring-do, which has already generated the kind of alarums, excursions, tensions, feuds and changes of plan that are associated with most risky theatrical ventures. The outline of the plot of Bon Voyage! is described in a foreword to the published libretto: "Set in 1735, a Plymouth Gypsy warns passengers not to travel on the world's first luxury cruise. Everyone ignores her except the ship's second officer, Lieutenant Gossima. Once on board, this scheming, incompetent, terrified, inadequate man inadvertently causes the prophecy to come true."

The show is described as "a vicious black comedy farce, set in the early 18th century - a play with a spinning plot, a panoply of vivid Hogarthian characters, and abundance of music and dance, a passionate love affair and an unexpected mixture of twists, jokes and minor tragedies". But the authors point out that, "for this play to succeed, all of the actors must believe in the sincerity of their roles. If the cast is peopled with archetypes and caricatures, never mind. They must be played straight. Any inclination towards Savoyard camp or any attempt to pitch for cheap laughs will meet with certain failure." Let us hope that this advice is followed.

Readers may be forgiven for concluding that this column is being used to plug a family enterprise, but is that bad? In my view, one should support any effort to inject some freshness and originality into the predictable entertainment fare at Christmas, especially since "certain failure" would also be guaranteed to Bon Voyage! if it were denied publicity and nobody knew it was coming on.

I don't know how people get publicity for anything unless they are already famous, or have lots of money to spend. If you are Catherine Zeta Jones and Michael Douglas, it is a doddle. All they had to do was to have a baby and a swanky wedding, and they actually got paid a couple of million pounds to allow themselves to be photographed and interviewed by OK! magazine. It is not even clear to me what they have been trying to promote apart from themselves. They have made a film together, but that has hardly featured in all the guff about marriage and motherhood to which they have subjected us.

Beautiful though the new Mrs Douglas may be, I now feel ready to scream if I see another magazine cover of her or of her tense and bewildered-looking husband. She is now on the January cover of Vanity Fair, telling us inside about their pre-nuptial agreement. "Prenups are brilliant, because it's all sorted out," she says. "Why should Michael be in a position where half of his fortune, which he's worked bloody hard for, lands in someone else's lap?" Personally, I do not see how a prenuptial agreement is compatible with marriage vows to stay together "till death do us part". It presumes from the start that the vows may not be kept. But that is by the way.

I know that it is pointless even to criticise the celebrity culture. The public's appetite for celebrity news, however phoney and cynical, is apparently insatiable. It is an appetite to which newspapers and magazines are bound to cater if they want to be competitive and profitable. But sometimes it seems only fair to grant a little drop of publicity to somebody else.

fields.headline: Dear Weekend
fields.trailText: Gideon Mendel's photographs of the impact of Aids in Malawi were both shocking and challenging (While The World Looks Away, December 2), but I could not help but be more appalled by their juxtaposition with the advertisements.
fields.body:
Gideon Mendel's photographs of the impact of Aids in Malawi were both shocking and challenging (While The World Looks Away, December 2), but I could not help but be more appalled by their juxtaposition with the advertisements.

On the right-hand page lies the dying Eliza, gaunt and naked, unable to afford the necessary drugs; on the left, a western woman, in almost identical repose, beside the latest 'wireless, stylish and advanced computing'. On the right, a mother gazes into space as her sixth child awaits death; on the left, a young man uses his mobile to book a 'cheap flight to the sun'. On the right, the 'most advanced cycle' in the world; on the left, the most basic of coffins. On the right, we imagine the stench of death at Nhkotakota District Hospital; on the left, 'the new fragrance' by Kenzo.

Whatever explanation we - as readers or editors - choose to give for these perverse contrasts, let us not forget that they are two sides of the same coin. To see one picture but only look at the other is a psychological disease as prolific in the west as Aids is in Africa. Perhaps we should be grateful to Weekend for staving off the blindness of indifference in this unjust world.
Ed Cox
Levenshulme, Manchester

Miriam Mbwana is pulling at my heartstrings. Is there any way of sponsoring some of her grandchildren directly?
Alison Patel
St Albans, Herts

Call ActionAid on 01460 238080.

The punctuation of your article with images of pouting models flogging such basic necessities as perfume and electrical goods could be seen as editorial juxtaposition bordering on genius or rank insensitivity. I wish I could be confident that it wasn't the latter.
Jeff Williams
Stockton-on-Tees

The juxtaposition between your feature and advertising is insensitive and nauseating. Such features should be ad-free, or at least in context (eg world charities).
Paul Sharville
Hove, East Sussex

We now know that it is technically, politically and financially feasible to stabilise and reduce the spread of HIV and Aids, but only if donors and governments share an urgency to support local communities in providing a commitment to prevention and care. Uganda has achieved a major decline in HIV infection, the result of appropriate government policies and the direct actions of local organisations. While they have a long way to go, the reduction of infection rates is significant cause for hope.
Wanjiku Kamau ActionAid, London N19

I've just returned from Rwanda, where people call Aids 'the new genocide'. I hope your article will provoke more thought, action and compassion, so that people can be assisted to prevent infection, and that those living with Aids can at least die with some dignity.

Concern Worldwide, Dublin

It refers to the third of the world's population who do not know if they will eat tomorrow. The fraction remains pretty constant, despite economic development.

webTitle: Mandelson moves to block release of 'Mad Dog' Adair

fields.headline: Mandelson moves to block release of 'Mad Dog' Adair
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The government is to fight moves to free the loyalist paramilitary leader Johnny "Mad Dog" Adair who was returned to jail in August after orchestrating a wave of violence in Belfast.
fields.body:
The government is to fight moves to free the loyalist paramilitary leader Johnny "Mad Dog" Adair who was returned to jail in August after orchestrating a wave of violence in Belfast.

Amid fears that Adair would spark new killings, the government will mount a strong appeal against a decision by the independent early release body to free the notorious loyalist.

The sentence review commission, set up under the Good Friday agreement, announced yesterday that Adair should be freed. It is understood that the commission has given the Northern Ireland Office seven days to "expand" on its reasons for the jailing of Adair in August.

Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, ordered the jailing of Adair after he was blamed for sparking a loyalist feud which claimed seven lives in Belfast.

Adair, a leader of the outlawed Ulster Defence Association, was released early from prison in August and was the first prisoner to be sent back to jail for breaching a licence.

The NIO last night made clear its anger with the decision by the review commission. A spokesman for the prison service said the commissioners' position was "surprising" and may not stand up to close legal scrutiny.

The move by the review commission could seriously destabilise the peace process if Adair returns to his stronghold in the loyalist Shankill area of Belfast. "This is highly irresponsible," a senior government source said. "But then this is the first case of its kind and so the commission is trying to test the law."

Tensions are high in Belfast. Two men, one a Protestant and the other Catholic, have been killed in recent days.

The IRA last night denied murdering Protestant taxi driver Trevor Kell who was shot dead at the wheel of his car in Belfast on Tuesday night. The Real IRA has also denied in volvement in the shooting which the RUC blamed on republicans. The murder provoked two shootings by Adair's UDA which left one Catholic dead and another critically wounded.

Adair was jailed for 16 years in 1996 for directing terrorism - a new charge specifically introduced to catch him.

Adair made his name in the early 1990s when he masterminded the UDA's ruthless campaign against Catholics under the cover name of the Ulster Freedom Fighters.

His close friend John White, chairman of the Ulster Democratic Party, the UDA's political wing, insisted last night that he should be freed immediately.

"I think the secretary of state should do the honourable thing and let him go. You cannot hold every prisoner accountable for what is happening on the streets."

webTitle: 10 die as violence flares on West Bank

fields.headline: 10 die as violence flares on West Bank
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israeli tanks fired on a Palestinian police post, and Jewish motorists were sprayed with gunfire as one of the bloodiest days in 10 weeks of Middle East violence left 10 people dead yesterday.
fields.body:
Israeli tanks fired on a Palestinian police post, and Jewish motorists were sprayed with gunfire as one of the bloodiest days in 10 weeks of Middle East violence left 10 people dead yesterday.

Thirteen years after Palestinian anger at Israel's occupation exploded in the first intifada, the first of two days of protests to mark the 1987 uprising brought a sharp escalation in violence yesterday.

The day began and ended with drive-by shootings by Palestinian gunmen, intensifying the battle for control of the roads in the West Bank. Three Israelis were killed in two separate attacks.

Yesterday also saw Palestinians returning to the stone-throwing protests which have been waning since the first weeks of this intifada.

Seven Palestinians were killed by Israeli forces across the West Bank and in Jerusalem, where protesters burned tyres and stoned riot police on the Via Dolorosa, in the fiercest clashes in the holy city for two months.

In the bloodiest single incident of the day, Israeli tanks launched three shells at a Palestinian police post in the West Bank city of Jenin, killing three uniformed officers and a civilian passerby. Zuheir Manasra, the governor of Jenin, said the Israelis had opened fire without provocation on an area under the control of Yasser Arafat's Palestinian Authority.

An Israeli military spokeswoman said the post was in an area under Israeli control, but admitted the soldiers had fired first. "It is a place where a lot of Palestinian people opened fire on our soldiers," she said. "It was very dangerous."

Outside the Jewish settle ment of Kiryat Arba yesterday morning, gunmen sprayed a white Israeli van with bullets, killing a school teacher, before fleeing to a village under Palestinian control. The van driver died later in the day.

A second Israeli car was targeted after dark outside a Jewish settlement near Jericho, killing a soldier.

During the last four weeks, Palestinian drive-by shootings have exacted an increasingly heavy toll on Israeli settlers and soldiers in the West Bank and Gaza, and driven some Israelis from their homes in the isolated Jewish outposts.

Israeli intelligence officials warned this week that the Palestinian gunmen were perfecting their methods, turning the roads built with the intention of protecting Jewish settlers into killing zones.

Yesterday's killings increased the pressure on Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, to strike back against Palestinian gunmen, and extinguished hopes that a relative lull in violence could take hold.

Nearly 310 people have been killed in the uprising, which exploded with far greater savagery than the original intifada.

Those protests, which lasted until 1993, pushed Israel to enter negotiations with Mr Arafat aimed at creating a Palestinian state. But after yesterday's violence, and the prospects of reprisal attacks today as Israelis and Palestinians bury their dead, hopes of re-opening negotiations seemed all but lost.

As news of the van shooting spread yesterday morning, angry settlers roamed the streets of nearby Hebron with assault rifles, calling for revenge. Mourners from the funeral procession of the slain teacher clashed with riot police and leftwing peace activists out side Mr Barak's residence in Jerusalem.

2Inside the ramparts of Jerusalem's old city, meanwhile, afternoon prayers at the al-Aqsa mosque on the second Friday of Ramadan saw hun dreds of protesters fan out along the Via Dolorosa, breaking up chunks of rubble before hurling them at police.

As young men with their heads covered with scarves prowled the ramparts of the mosque, raising the Palestinian flag, one group broke away to attack the gates of a police station at Lion's Gate with a steel battering ram. Once inside, they set it alight, for the second time in two months.

Among the 10 who died yesterday was a teenager killed when riot police fired rubber bullets; a boy, 16, shot by Israeli troops in Bethlehem; and another Palestinian, 15, declared clinically dead in Hebron.

fields.headline: Shock ruling rescues Gore
fields.standfirst: Judges vote 4-3 for Florida hand recounts and cut Bush lead to 154
fields.trailText: Judges vote 4-3 for Florida hand recounts and cut Bush lead to 154
fields.byline: Julian Borger  in Tallahassee and Martin Kettle in Washington
fields.body:
The United States was facing a potential constitutional crisis last night after the Florida supreme court decided by a single vote to order an immediate hand recount of more than 9,000 disputed Miami ballots which could hand the presidency to Al Gore.

In a dramatic turn of events, the court also ordered the acceptance of 383 votes arising from earlier recounts, reducing George W Bush's estimated lead in Florida to a margin of 154 votes.

That margin could easily be overturned with a recount of the disputed ballots which mainly came from Democratic precincts in Miami-Dade.

The court gave permission to other counties to start new manual tallies of "undervotes" - ballots on which counting machines failed to register a vote for the presidency. There are estimated to be about 175,000 such "undervotes"

Jubilant Democrats rallied around Mr Gore. Congressional party barons Dick Gephardt and Tom Daschle issued a joint statement calling for a "full fair and accurate vote count". They said there was "more than enough time to count ballots cast but never counted".

Republicans were stunned into near-silence. A party official said: "We feel today like we've had the wind knocked out of us."

Before the decision, George W Bush had told journalists: "We're prepared to, if needs be, take our case back to the [US] supreme court, but we hope that doesn't have to happen."

Yesterday's decision raised the prospect that Florida might send two rival groups of electors to the electoral college which formally votes for the president. In that case, the US Congress might be brought into the crisis as a final arbiter for the first time in more than a century.

Republicans gathered in Tallahassee loudly booed yesterday's decision and vowed they would not accept the decision of the Florida supreme court, which is made up of six Democrats and one independent. It had overturned a ruling in Mr Bush's favour by a lower court a few days earlier.

Supreme court spokesman Craig Waters stood on the steps of the Florida supreme court building and said: "By a vote of four to three, the majority of the court has reversed the decision of the trial court in part. It has further ordered that the circuit court of the second judicial circuit here in Tallahassee shall immediately begin a manual recount of the approximately 9,000 Miami-Dade ballots that registered undervotes.

"In addition, the circuit court shall enter orders ensuring the inclusion of the additional 215 legal votes for Vice-President Gore in Palm Beach county and the 168 additional legal votes from Miami-Dade county.

"In addition, the circuit court shall order a manual recount of all undervotes in any Florida county where such a recount has not yet occurred."

But the court's ruling was vague on the crucial question of what would constitute a vote among the disputed "undervote" ballots. Most are punchcard ballots on which the voter has not entirely punched through the card, but left a small flap, or chad.

The judges yesterday ruled: "In tabulating what constitutes a legal vote, the standard to be used is the one provided by the legislature, 'a vote shall be counted where there is a clear indication of the intent of the voter'."

Meanwhile, the Republican-dominated Florida legislature declared itself ready to appoint its own electors to the electoral college due to vote for the president on December 18, if the counting was still under way by next Tuesday.

If the Florida legislature certifies a separate list of Republican electors, its certification would have to be signed by the governor, Jeb Bush, George W's brother.

webTitle: Blair feels heat over EU veto

fields.headline: Blair feels heat over EU veto
fields.standfirst:
Britain accused of dirty tricks over EU veto
Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Tony Blair last night dug in his heels against 11th-hour concessions over Britain's veto powers, as leaders negotiated into the small hours to break the deadlock threatening the historic enlargement of the European union.
fields.byline: Michael White and  Ian Black in Nice
fields.body:
Tony Blair last night dug in his heels against 11th-hour concessions over Britain's veto powers, as leaders negotiated into the small hours to break the deadlock threatening the historic enlargement of the European union.

After President Jacques Chirac, the Nice summit's French host, cancelled a formal banquet to stage brief bilateral "confessional" meetings with all 14 of his colleagues, key players - including France - faced mounting pressure to blink and accept majority voting on treasured national policies.

Britain was under particular pressure after Denmark's decision to accept compromise wording on social security policy left Mr Blair and Robin Cook alone in refusing to abandon its veto on this issue.

London's position was made harder by a "dirty tricks" row in which Foreign Office offi cials were accused of trying to manipulate the Danish media into criticising their government for accepting an allegedly "meaningless" compromise.

One Danish diplomat called it "a desperate and inept attempt to destabilise Denmark's negotiating position". But a British official said: "Let's not over-dramatise this unnecessarily. It's a perfectly reasonable point which we are perfectly entitled to make. Talk of dirty tricks is surprising."

In contrast to Denmark, Luxembourg and Ireland remained staunch last night in resisting pressure to permit majority voting on certain tax issues - the thin end of an EU wedge, Whitehall fears.

Meanwhile, British ministers, delighted at pushing their preferred version of the new EU defence plan through the summit in just eight minutes, refused to be dismayed by slow progress to a new treaty of Nice.

"We are making good progress," the foreign secretary said.

With up to 50 existing vetoes listed for replacement by QMV to speed up sluggish decision-making when up to 28 new members join after 2004, the summit looked likely to drag on into tomorrow, as ministers struggled to resolve issues they ducked in 1997 at the last inter-governmental conference (IGC) in Amsterdam.

While proclaiming his passionate commitment to getting applicants such as Slovenia, the Czech Republic and Hungary in quickly, Mr Blair signalled more flexibility than either France or Germany on the issue of re-weighting votes and more votes for the four big members.

Diplomats said Chancellor Gerhard Schröder was likely in the end to accept that Germany would maintain parity with France, Britain and Italy, which is deeply important to Paris.

In return, he will get a pledge that another reforming conference, an IGC in all but name, will start around 2004 to demarcate the limits of the EU's central powers. That, Mr Blair also believes, would halt what the Tories call the endless march towards an EU "superstate".

"We would prefer an outcome of the kind in which the major four nations remain within the same band of votes," Mr Cook said, "but we will judge the package not by what it does for Germany, France or Spain [which is also pro-reweighting], but by what it does for Britain."

But the prime minister refused to budge on Labour's core agenda or sanction hints that he has a symbolic concession in his back pocket.

With an election looming and the Eurosceptic Conservatives breathing down his neck, Mr Blair insisted he would not abandon his six "red line" policy vetoes - notably on tax and social security.

"We are not bluffing," said Mr Cook.

France showed no signs of abandoning national protection of its cherished film and music industries. Introducing QMV would allow a wider remit for EU trade negotiators to cut future deals with the World Trade Organisation, where Hollywood seeks to open up protected markets.

With Mr Chirac allotting just 15 minutes to each leader to make their case, the Swedes went in first, Britain 10th and France last. EU officials admitted it was a high risk approach that could mean paralysis when French diplomats and the commission meet this morning to produce a "synthesis" of what was agreed overnight.

"There is a danger that people won't be prepared to give anything because they don't know what the others are ready to do," warned one. Romano Prodi, the president of the European commission, was holding separate consultations.

Enumerating his list of the toughest issues, Mr Chirac said: "They touch on questions that are sensitive either for public opinion or for those in power. Everyone will have to make a major effort to reach a compromise."

Nice was calm again yesterday 24 hours after France's riot police, the CRS, fought running battles with protesters in the city's streets.

webTitle: George W Bush: Following in Daddy's footsteps

fields.headline: Following in Daddy's footsteps
fields.standfirst:
Blood is more important than talent at the court of George II
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Blood is more important than talent at the court of George II, writes Mark Lawson.
fields.body:
In the week when this newspaper has been calling for a referendum on the monarchy, the proud republic which tore itself free of the British crown has been offering a lesson in the drawbacks of inherited power.

The biggest problem facing the likely president, George W Bush, is the perceived illegitimacy of his hold on the White House throne. Bush's shaky mandate is partly due to the closeness of the vote and the legal wrangling afterwards.

Yet his claim to run America was undermined long before the state of Florida was twinned with Chad by a central and very English illegitimacy. He is a monarchic president. At the exact moment when the British might be seriously questioning the rule of primogeniture, America is handing down power from father to son. Arise, King George.

Most of the reasons that this second Bush presidency appears either sinister or ridiculous result from its dynastic stucture. The essential problem with monarchy is that it puts power at the mercy of relatives and genetics. And this is precisely what hobbles the putative new Bush administration.

Let's begin with the question of Jeb. There's an honourable tradition of presidents being worried by their brothers. Jimmy Carter was often distracted from national security matters by concern over what the maverick Billy might say next. Roger Clinton's troubled and druggy past was one of the holes in which the Republicans tried to dig dirt on Bill. But these sibling difficulties are minor beside the difficulties opened up for George W Bush by his little bro.

Winning the presidency by a negligible and heavily doubted margin would be enough humiliation for any politician. But God reserved an even harsher joke for the governor of Texas. His victory-is-it? would be sealed by the results of a state run by his brother, who would be required to sign the legislation awarding the votes to him.

His public comments during the vote-tie crisis show no sign that Governor Jeb Bush of Florida understands the extent to which his brother is, in a reversal of the usual process, rendered illegitimate by family ties.

"I did everything I could to help my brother win," he admitted early on. More recently, to suggestions that he might recuse himself from the duty of signing Florida's election results into law, he insisted that he could not "recuse myself from my family".

Republicans spent eight years trying to prove that President Clinton had blood on his hands. The problem for President George W Bush is the blood in his veins. One of the major arguments for a republic - that you can't become head of state just because of being someone's relative - is being proved again in a nation founded on that doubt.

The defence of the Bush family, as it was for the Kennedys, is that their dynasties are elective. But government through bloodline is vulnerable to the same objections whether it occurs through voting or the passing down of a crown. This becomes even more apparent in the shape of King George II's main family problem - his dad, King George I. Already weakened by the perception that his brother got him the job, King George II seems determined to restore his father's court in Washington.

Putative cabinet appointments spun to the press as fresh and radical - General Colin Powell as the first black secretary of state, Condoleezza Rice as the first black national security advisor - are impaired by the fact that these candidates first served the king his father in other roles. His vice president, Dick Cheney, is another retread courtier. It's always said that Dubya is too dumb to read books but he seems to have studied English history with dangerous avidity.

Another case against the inheritance of power is the kick hidden in the DNA: whether haemophilia or stupidity. Again, a Bush administration would illustrate this risk. His father's reign was that of a borderline dimwit whose mental wiring left him unable to speak the English language with conviction or precision. Precisely these design faults occur in King George II, with the additional hindrances of alcoholism (under control) and, unlike his father, extreme laziness.

This presidency would perfectly prove Philip Larkin's lines about the influence of parents on children: "They give you all the faults they had /And add some extra, just for you." In fact, the decision of half of the electorate to vote for George W Bush is perhaps best understood as a genetic experiment. In an age obsessed with DNA and inheritance, the voters decided to see what would happen if they sent a son into a situation recently occupied by his father.

But the result of the experiment will almost certainly be disastrous and I urge Americans to consider the merits of Republicanism. By coincidence, a revival of Stephen Sondheim's musical Merrily We Roll Along opens in London on Monday. It includes a satirical song at the Washington court of the Kennedys, in which the paternal kingmaker sings: "One day, elections will be unknown/As each of our kids will ascend the throne."

Written as a joke about America's past, it now sounds like a gag about the nation's future. Prepare to watch The Madness Of King George II, a warning against monarchy from a nation which once took pride in not having one.

webTitle: Flooding fears as storms claim four lives

fields.headline: Flooding fears as storms claim four lives
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Torrential rain and gales sweeping across southern England and Wales claimed four lives yesterday in road accidents. Two teenagers were killed in a head-on collision in Hampshire, while in Devon a couple's car was swept off the road into a rain-swollen river.
fields.body:
Torrential rain and gales sweeping across southern England and Wales claimed four lives yesterday in road accidents. Two teenagers were killed in a head-on collision in Hampshire, while in Devon a couple's car was swept off the road into a rain-swollen river.

As heavy rains moved north yesterday, five severe flood warnings were issued across Wales, the Midlands and southern England. Areas saturated by earlier waves of bad weather were braced for renewed flooding. Several people had to be rescued from cars stuck in rising waters, while roads were blocked by falling trees.

The teenagers who died were Tara Dance, 19, and Alastair Tremlett, 17, students at a college near Winchester. They had been heading to a pub with three friends when they were in a crash with another car on a B road in Hampshire, which police said had been made treacherous by rain.

Sergeant Tim Ashman said: "There was a hell of a lot of surface water on the road and it would appear their car aquaplaned on a big puddle and slewed out of control."

Early yesterday an elderly couple's car was swept off a road bridge near the village of Cheriton Fitzpaine in Devon. The body of Jean Meadows was recovered from the car, which appeared to have ploughed through wooden railings to land upside down in the Hollywater river. Her husband Norman's body was recovered later downstream.

At the height of the storm west Wales was practically cut off when flooding closed two major roads into the region. More than 1,000 homes and businesses in south Wales suffered power cuts.

The AA warned that the situation was "quite treacherous for drivers", particularly in Devon and Cornwall, where broken down vehicles were littering the road.

More than 31 people - including a number of pensioners - had to be airlifted from a caravan park at Dawlish Warren, Devon, by a helicopter from RAF Chivenor.

Rail services were badly hit by the weather, mainly in the west of England, Wales and Scotland.

The highest rainfall over Thursday night was recorded in Milford Haven, Pembrokeshire, where 4cm fell in 12 hours.

The highest wind speeds were recorded along the Solent between Portsmouth and the Isle of Wight, with gusts up to 62mph.

fields.headline: £275m lifeline for post office bank
fields.standfirst: More about the Post Office
fields.trailText: Ministers last night moved to rescue their plans for a post office based bank by offering up to £275m of taxpayers' money towards its running costs.
fields.body:
Ministers last night moved to rescue their plans for a post office based bank by offering up to £275m of taxpayers' money towards its running costs.

The move is a desperate attempt to win the backing of the high street banks which have complained they are being asked to bear too high a risk in supporting the so-called universal bank. But if they refuse to participate, they fear a draconian government windfall tax.

With the Christmas deadline imposed by the government, the banks have yet to agree to stump up a share of the running costs of the new bank which is at the heart of the government's plan to throw a lifeline to the post office. But ministers are convinced that they have now done enough to clinch a deal with the banks.

Yesterday, the major banks missed their self-imposed deadline to agree a united response to the government. But, it is understood that the government remains optimistic that an announcement could be made next week.

The universal bank is to offer accounts, branded "clear", to some 5m people who do not have access to a bank account but will need one when social security payments are automated in 2004.

The banks have warned it could carry the stigma of a "poor people's" bank and feel they should not be expected to bear its running costs. The costs are staggered, with the big banks paying up to £12m a year and the smaller ones, including internet banks, around £5m.

The banks fear they would be saddled with unlimited costs should the so-called universal bank prove to be more expensive than the original business plan.

As a result, the government has agreed that their annual cost will not exceed £125m, and that any additional finance will be at taxpayers' expense. Some senior bankers believe that the business plan underestimates the running cost of the bank which they believe could reach £400m a year. The government is promising to share half the annual running costs of the universal bank.

Even with extra government money, it was far from clear last night that the banks would all back the plan. But, during a series of high level meetings with ministers, the banks' concerns have grown.

Their fears range from dubbing their annual share of the running costs as "windfall tax" to an escalation of an investigation into competition among the major banks. High-level meetings between the banks are expected to try to gauge support for the scheme.

webTitle: Bell agrees to fight Tory safe seat in Essex

fields.headline: Bell agrees to fight Tory safe seat in Essex
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: Martin Bell, the white-suited independent MP for Tatton, was hailed as the definitive "ethics man" yesterday as he announced his intention of fighting a Tory-held Essex seat allegedly infiltrated by a charismatic Christian church at the next election.
fields.body:
Martin Bell, the white-suited independent MP for Tatton, was hailed as the definitive "ethics man" yesterday as he announced his intention of fighting a Tory-held Essex seat allegedly infiltrated by a charismatic Christian church at the next election.

Amid Conservative allegations that he had been swayed by "arguments of religious bigotry", the former BBC correspondent said he would contest Brentwood and Ongar - the Tories' sixth safest seat - unless voters inexplicably withdrew their support before then.

His decision came after he received 200 letters from voters of all parties anxious that the local Conservative association - and its MP, Eric Pickles - could be in danger of being manipulated by a wealthy evangelical sect, 119 of whose members had joined the party after the local council turned down their planning application. The Peniel Pentecostal Church is run by a former insurance salesman turned evangelical bishop. He has reportedly said the unemployed should starve, and described Muslims as "vile people". The church has dismissed these allegations as "foul lies."

Mr Bell yesterday said he deeply regretted his promise at the time of the 1997 election not to stand for Tatton a second time and his return to Westminster at the next election looks set to be a struggle.

Labour and the Liberal Democrats said they would not give him a clear run. They insisted they would field candidates, in contrast to the last election when both parties stood down.

Mr Bell, who defeated disgraced former minister Neil Hamilton at the last election on an "anti-sleaze" ticket, took pains to stress he was not accusing Mr Pickles of "sleaze."

But he suggested that Conservative Central Office had been negligent when an investigation concluded the local party was not guilty of malpractice despite the church members joining one branch on one day. "I do believe there was a problem of democratic process in the links between the Peniel Pentecostal Church and the Conservative association. Alarm bells should have been ringing," he said.

He criticised the fact that Central Office had failed to interview lead witnesses, many of whom split away from the party and formed their own Independent Conservative Association. He said: "I think it's very hard to conclude this was a full investigation."

He added: "This is not a question of sleaze, it's a question of democracy. In Tatton, although it seemed like sleaze, it was a question of democracy. What I was doing then I am doing now."

Tory Central Office - which spent the past week trying to encourage Mr Bell to stand against the disgraced Labour MP Geoffrey Robinson - rallied around Mr Pickles, with the shadow Cabinet Office minister, Andrew Lansley, arriving in the consituency to insist a full investigation had been held and lending him the party's "unequivocal support".

Michael Parrish, the local association chairman, accused Mr Bell of succumbing to the arguments of breakaway Tories that "have just developed into religious bigotry and Nazism". Mr Pickles, who has a 9,600 majority, denied his association was unduly influenced by the religious group. He said the controversy was due to "a personality dispute".

But Tony Donnelly, chairman of the breakaway Independent Conservative Association which first begged Mr Bell to stand, said: "The bishop has got Eric Pickles in a checkmate position... but we have got a white knight. We're calling him our Ethics Man."

webTitle: Leader: Bell has to run on his own merits

fields.headline: Return of the white suit
fields.standfirst: This time Bell has to run on his own merits
fields.trailText: This time Bell has to run on his own merits
fields.body:
The man in the white suit has fast become a fixture in the House of Commons. Scan the chamber and you can always pick him out. People have got used to him being there and he admits he has come to like it. Now Martin Bell has let it be known that he would like to stay on in Westminster.

He cannot remain as the member for Tatton, the seat he wrested from the sleaze-ridden Neil Hamilton in 1997, because he promised voters there that he would only serve one term as their MP. So he has had to go seat-hunting, lighting yesterday upon the Essex constituency of Brentwood and Ongar. Apparently Tories there approached Mr Bell to be their knight in a shining white suit amid some unusual claims that the local Conservative association had been infiltrated by 200-odd evangelical Christians.

Should Mr Bell do it? Of course he should. If he likes the MP's life, he has every right to try to extend it. He has already made something of a contribution in Westminster, speaking wisely on the Balkans, acting as a useful conscience on questions of party funding and parliamentary propriety and breaking the monotony of Westminster by serving as the chamber's only true independent. If he went, it would be the Commons' loss.

For all that, there is no reason for the former BBC war correspondent to be treated differently from any other independent seeking a seat at the next election. Mr Bell won Tatton in special circumstances: sleaze had so discredited Mr Hamilton, that the Liberal Democrats and Labour withdrew from the contest to allow the white suit a clear run. Bizarre accusations of evangelical entryism in Brentwood hardly amount to the same desperate need for Mr Bell's services: Labour and the Lib Dems are under no obligation to withdraw, especially when the latter have a decent chance of winning. So Mr Bell cannot run as the consensus candidate of anti-sleaze this time; he will have to run on his own merits. And in that effort, we wish him luck.

webTitle: Leader: Children must use their phones sparingly

fields.headline: Mobile mores
fields.standfirst:
Children must use their phones sparingly

Special report: mobile phone fears
fields.trailText: Children must use their phones sparingly
fields.body:
The chief medical officer for England, Professor Liam Donaldson, is to be congratulated for the unambiguous way he answered a question of considerable interest to millions of people. Asked yesterday whether the government had changed its mind on the potential dangers attached to hands-free mobile phones, he simply said: "Yes, it has."

Would that politicians were so forthcoming. In August, Labour minister Patricia Hewitt offered "unambiguous advice" that hands-free kits cut radiation levels. Since then the argument has moved on because of the claim of the Consumers' Association that hands-free kits increased the brain's exposure to radiation by 3.5 times. The government now admits the effectiveness of hands-free phone kits in reducing the amount of radiation absorbed by the body is uncertain and more research is needed. Yesterday it launched a £7m research programme (half funded by the industry) to inquire into this and other matters.

We do not know yet whether mobiles themselves are dangerous, but there is growing evidence that employing a phone while driving - irrespective of whether it is a hand-held model or not - greatly increases the chance of an accident. On present evidence more people have been hurt by driving and phoning than from radiation. Sir William Stewart, who is heading the new research programme, would do everyone a service if he made positive recommendations about curbing driving and phoning, a subject from which most politicians shirk from pronouncing on - presumable because they are afraid of upsetting the motoring lobby.

About 30m people, over half the population, now use mobiles and among some younger groups market penetration is over 90%. It is one of the most successful consumer products ever invented but the speed with which it has been taken up has run ahead of the resources invested in exploring possible downsides. The government, having learned from the BSE fiasco, is right to let as much information as possible into the public domain so people can make their own minds up. At present the best advice is not to make very long calls regularly and, above all, to ensure that younger people, who are at special risk because of their thin skulls and developing immune systems, use them for essential purposes only. The trouble is, as every parent knows, that is easier said than done.

Yesterday it launched a £7m research programme (half funded by the industry) to inquire into this and other matters. We do not know yet whether mobiles themselves are dangerous, but there is growing evidence that employing a phone while driving - irrespective of whether it is a hand-held model or not - greatly increases the chance of an accident. The trouble is, as every parent knows, that is easier said than done.

webTitle: Death in a Cornish car park

fields.headline: She was young, vibrant and well paid. So why did Davina Rappai starve to death in a car park?
fields.trailText: Davina Rappai was 33 when she was found dead, yards from her J-registration Ford Escort, in a National Trust car park near the Cornish village of Gorran Haven
fields.body:
After five weeks, the Ford Escort was customised for human habitation. The passenger seat went back as a bed; clothes hung from hooks over the windows and there was a Bible on the dashboard. The only signs of dishevelment were a few carrier bags on the back seat and some empty water bottles. When police towed the car away, it left a knee-high patch of grass where the gardener had mown around it, a reminder of the young woman who over the course of the summer had lain there dying.

Davina Rappai was 33 when she was found dead, yards from her J-registration Ford Escort, in a National Trust car park near the Cornish village of Gorran Haven. She had lost 40% of her body weight. In her bag was a slip of paper with the name Michael and a phone number on it, but she was utterly alone, just as she had been when she parked in the spot on a hot day in July and, to the dismay of local residents, begun withering in front of them.

Last week, three police officers from the Devon and Cornwall constabulary faced disciplinary charges for their handling of events leading up to Davina Rappai's death, which an inquest found in February to have been caused by malnutrition brought on by mental illness. Impossibly, it seemed, she had starved to death under the eye of ramblers, holidaymakers and on more than one occasion, police officers called to the scene by concerned locals.

When Davina Rappai left her home in Rugby, Warwickshire, five months earlier, she had been a woman accustomed to making a success of her life. It was March 1998 and she was working as a freelance computer engineer using IT skills she had taught herself. She was, said her sister Sunita, vigorous and beautiful, and the sums of money she was capable of earning were "pretty phenomenal".

"Her passions were astrology and belly dancing; she took judo lessons and learned how to fly a plane. She was one of those people who tried everything and learned as much as she could. She was mathematical, but she also loved the arts. She was my older sister and I looked up to her."

Davina was educated privately at New Hall school, in Chelmsford, Essex, and at St Joseph's boarding school in Tamil Nadu, southern India. In 1989, she won a place to read accounting and finance at North London Polytechnic. "I taught her in seminars," said Angela Filmer, then head of the accountancy course. "She was just very pleasant and normal. There was nothing about her that struck me as unusual."

She graduated with a lower second class degree and took a job as a recruitment consultant, a stopgap until her skills in IT were good enough to allow her to go freelance and move back to Rugby, where her parents ran a newsagency.

Strong-minded
Her mid to late 20s are gently referred to by her family as the time when she was "well". "She was an organiser," said Sunita, "a leader, an initiator, because she was incredibly independent and strong-minded."

But when she set off from the family home in March 1998, she was thought to be depressed and would later hint that the trip to Cornwall was undertaken in search of some peace and quiet. At the inquest, forensic psychologist Henrietta Bullard said that she was possibly suffering from schizophrenia.

Her family reported her missing, but she was taken off the police register when, in May, she was found living in her car at Loe Bar, an isolated stretch of coastline in Cornwall. In June, Sunita visited her there and said she seemed happy, if a little manic, and by July she had moved on again, this time to Truro.

"I had three meetings with Davina," said the Very Reverend Michael Moxon, dean of Truro cathedral. One weekday, early in July, Davina had slipped into the 19th century cathedral by its west door and hovered through evensong until Rev Moxon came over and spoke to her. "She was a strikingly good-looking lady of Indian background, which stands out around here," he said. "I asked 'are you down here on holiday?' because she was well turned out, highly articulate and gave no appearance of sleeping rough. I guessed there was some inner turmoil, however. She was willing to talk about some things, but then would go quite quiet." Davina intimated to him that she was in Cornwall because she found it peaceful. In this setting, Rev Moxon gathered, she would try to "recover" before returning to her old life.

The following Sunday, she went back to see him. "She seemed a bit more upset this time. We sat there for an hour, long after everyone had left the refectory, and she found it very difficult to talk. She would start saying something and then would go quiet. For much of the hour, we sat in silence. I couldn't find out where she was staying because she was evasive."

The third time he saw her, Davina seemed very upset. The Rev Moxon wrote his name - Michael - on a piece of paper, and gave her his telephone number.

On July 25 the family reported her missing for the second time.

In the Gorran Haven car park, it took a few days for Davina's red car to be singled out from the high season bustle. The village, a picturesque fishing resort arranged around a sandy cove, is 11 miles from St Austell and part of what locals describe as the Cornish Riviera. As you enter it, there is a large National Trust car park on the left hand side.

When Davina pulled in and failed to get out of her car, villagers assumed she was sleeping off a long journey. When she had not moved after several days, they grew concerned. Donald Gray, then coastal warden for the National Trust, said: "Originally she told us she was just staying in the car park because she was travelling round on holiday, but it became noticeable that the car was just not moving - the grass was growing up all under it."

Edward Savage and his wife Trudi live in the house nearest the car park. "In the early days, she was seen down in the village," said Mr Savage. "She seemed reasonably normal. She wasn't in some drug haze, or injured or obviously ill. She used to walk down the road to use the public toilets. It was difficult to communicate with her, because she would have her head down, and if you said hello, she didn't look up."

"She used to go into the disabled loo and wash out her smalls," said Joan Gandy, a retired villager. "Her situation struck me as wrong, right away. Every time I saw her in the car, she was asleep. I thought, you don't sleep all day and all night. I tried to talk to her, but she didn't want to know."

Waiving National Trust regulations, Mr Gray did not attempt to remove Davina. But as her stay seeped from days into weeks, both Mr Gray and his wife called the police. Trudi Savage also reported Davina's presence to the police twice. It was heard at her inquest that an officer came out to the vehicle, but did not feel able to detain Davina under the Mental Health Act. Davina's family were not informed of her whereabouts, the inquest heard, because checks run on the police national computer looked only at her car details and not at her name.

About a month into her stay, after being rebuffed several times in the street, Mr Savage tentatively approached the car.

"She startled when I got to the window. She was dozing in the back seat, which she did quite a lot. She had the window shut, even though it was a very hot day, so I got myself down to her level and said, 'I'm sorry, I didn't mean to startle you. Are you ok?' Her eyes welled with tears. She said 'yes'. I said, 'are you sure?' and she said, 'yes, I'm all right'. And I said, we're concerned about you and she shook her head and looked away. I said, if there's anything we can do we're just down the road. She nodded and that was it."

Two days before she died, Mrs Gandy saw her walking up the hill. "She looked terribly tired and dejected," she said. "But she didn't look emaciated enough to cause real alarm."

It was Edward Savage who found Davina dead. "She was sprawled on her front, spread out. It didn't look like she'd collapsed in a heap. It was as if she had just laid down to die."

Tragic
"If we'd known what a tragic end it was going to have, we might have done something more," said Mr Savage. "We got used to seeing her there. The National Trust used to send a bloke round to cut the grass that summer, and he just cut around the car. When the car was towed away, the grass was so long ..."

Sunita Rappai and her family lodged a complaint against the Devon and Cornwall police. "There is an argument for neglect," Sunita said at the inquest. "They failed to recognise she was a vulnerable person and failed... to protect her."

"I didn't know her well," the Rev Moxon said, "but I often think of her. You wonder how this young, beautiful, vibrant woman, who had the church, the police and her family at her disposal, could none the less have been lost. Should I have followed her out of the cathedral? Should I have gone to where her car was? Knowing what I know now, I could have taken more steps to help. But to what extent do you leave people to their humanity? To what extent do you let them make their own choice?"
