fields.headline: America - let the healing begin
fields.standfirst: In the first of his monthly columns for the Guardian,  Salman Rushdie argues that republics can need constitutional reform too
fields.trailText: In the first of his monthly columns for the Guardian, Salman Rushdie argues that republics can need constitutional reform too
fields.body:
We've all been put through electoral college by this time, and now most of us would like to "recuse" ourselves from the case or perhaps "vacate" our earlier judgments; we yearn for those innocent days when a butterfly wasn't a ballot and Chad was a place in Africa. Whoever wins this loses it, we sometimes say. Bush and Cheney will never live down their 300,000-vote defeat in the nationwide count. Gore-Lieberman will always be Sore-Loserman to half the country. But in other moments we think that nobody has a memory any more. Two weeks after one of the combatants is sworn in, all this will fade. So maybe whoever loses it, loses it after all. We give up. We're confused.

We've stopped thinking all this is funny or even sad. This is still the election that Nader wrecked and the one that Elián slanted and the one that Katherine Harris's partisanship derailed and the one the media screwed up, but most of all it's just interminable and coated in foggy legalese and we almost don't care any more. But under the boredom we know there has been damage. It will be a long time before America can preach to the rest of the world about electoral transparency. This election has been about as transparent as a Floridian swamp.

America reveres its democracy, its constitution, its presidency, and the past weeks have done damage to American belief in all three. How then is the strength of the republic, the wholeness of America, to be restored? Bush doesn't seem too interested in reaching out to Gore, and Gore has been too committed to the fight to pay more than lip service to the notion of a reunited nation.

The truth is that these United States have rarely been so divided. America, which so often casts itself as the world's peacemaker, now needs to make peace with itself; and so, perhaps, might benefit from the experience of other divided peoples. I'm thinking, in particular, of Israel, and of the aftermath of the post-Begin election of 1984.

The Israeli National Unity government came into being after that election, once it was clear that neither Yitzhak Shamir's Likud nor Shimon Peres's Labour party could command a majority. The two major parties then came together in an uneasy, but nevertheless enduring, alliance. For two years Peres served as prime minister, Shamir as foreign minister; then they swapped portfolios. After the elections of November 1988 failed to shift the balance of power significantly, the coalition was renewed, with Shamir retaining the premiership, and Peres still serving as foreign minister. The arrangement finally broke down in 1990, because of the parties' incompatible views of the peace process. While it lasted, it wasn't the world's most effective gov ernment, but it did bring down the Israeli inflation rate, and, more importantly, permit Israel to present a united front to its adversaries for six long years: no mean achievement.

How could such a grand coalition be brought into existence in the USA? Hypothetically, president-elect Bush might persuade his running-mate Dick Cheney to stand down, citing Cheney's recent ill-health; the vice-presidency could then be offered to Al Gore. In the alternative imaginary scenario, vice-president-elect Joe Lieberman would opt to take up his Senate seat, whereupon president-elect Gore would offer the number two spot to Bush. After so radical a move, the creation of a genuine coalition cabinet would be relatively - and I mean relatively - simple. As to whether it would be constitutional for the president to step down after two years to allow his deputy a turn, that's an issue for the swarm of litigators presently buzzing around this election to consider.

I mpossible? Out of the question? Maybe so. But everything about this election so far has strained credulity. What was once unthinkable might, in these odd circumstances, actually begin to make sense. It might even have become necessary. There's a satirical text from Zimbabwe, that great democracy, doing the rounds of the internet at present. Asking us what we would think of the US electoral fiasco if it had happened in a third-world country, this satire, supposedly written by "a Zimbabwean politician", pokes much predictable fun at the alleged corruption of the United States. If America can now be laughed at by Zimbabwean pols, then it is surely time for drastic remedies to be considered.

A Bush-Gore alliance might just renew American (and international) faith in the honour of their leaders and restore some much-needed lustre to their tarnished institutions. It would certainly be an administration capable of speaking legitimately for the whole of America. There's no doubt that it would be a government of strange bedfellows, but better that, perhaps, than four more years of bitter partisan squabbling, which would inevitably drag America's democratic institutions - congress as well as the presidency, and even, perhaps, the supreme court - further down into the Zimbabwean dirt.

"If only they could both lose." Why not stand the joke on its head? Let them both win. "The people have spoken," Bill Clinton said not so long ago. "It's just that we don't yet know what they meant." Maybe this sort of power-sharing formula comes closer to expressing the people's will than anything else.

webTitle: When only the devil will do

fields.headline: When only the devil will do
fields.standfirst: John Fordham  enjoys the rugged bluesiness of Sarah Jane Morris
fields.trailText: John Fordham enjoys the rugged bluesiness of Sarah Jane Morris
fields.body:
The gap between the raw-nerve nuances, earthy inflections and rugged bluesiness of Sarah Jane Morris's singing voice and the disarmingly simple Englishness of her announcements ought to throw a spanner in the works. But so completely does she become her singing self that it's like witnessing two women inhabiting the same body. Whatever a jazz singer is, it's hard to put Morris in that category, but her shows at Ronnie Scott's are always models of powerful songwriting, atmospheric ensemble-playing and passionate delivery.

She is preceded by a sharp quartet led by British bassist Geoff Gascoyne, featuring vigorous young saxophonist Ben Castle. Gascoyne's choice of Winter Wonderland was questionable, but he almost rescued it with his strong, muscular bassline and Gareth Williams's consistently fine piano improvising. The standout, though, was a postbop slalom on a devious structure of Dave Holland's, and Castle made a swerving, whooping sax soliloquy out of it.

Morris brought along a former Ronnie Scott sax partner in tenorist Mornington Lockett, who displayed his customary smooth fire. Much of the material is familiar, but Morris unwrapped some new material from a forthcoming album with Marc Ribot. With lines like "It's Jesus I love... but it's the devil I need tonight", she shows no signs of pulling back from the edge.

 Sarah Jane Morris and Geoff Gascoyne's quartet are at Ronnie Scott's, London (020-7439 0747), tonight.

fields.headline: Freddie in extremis
fields.trailText: Last night's TV
fields.body:
Freddie Mercury: The Untold Story (BBC1) started like a particularly rockin' Stars In Their Eyes special. Roger Daltry, Robert Plant, Brian May, Slash from Guns'n'Roses and someone from Mott the Hoople all turned up, along with Liza Minnelli, of all people. This sparked fear-tinged anticipation. Would Suzi Quatro surface from down on Devil Gate Drive, wearing her battered leather jacket, laughing her croaky laugh? Would Bonnie Tyler rise like a spectre of big-hair rock music, found in France after holding out for a hero? The possibilities were quite mind-boggling.

Quatro and Tyler never appeared but, even without them, this documentary was dangerously close to resembling Night of the Living Dead. Which, in a way, it was, since the dearly beloved were gathered together to celebrate the life of Freddie Mercury. Variously described as "rock's greatest showman", "a man of extremes" and "a shy extrovert", this was a reverential, almost sycophantic look at Mercury's life from the early days in Zanzibar to his Aids-related death in London nine years ago. No one, for example, described him as "a frightful old queen with dreadful dress sense". Not even Elton John, and he knows about these things.

Boasting contributions from "the people who really knew him", including family, school friends, teachers and loved ones, this was a fairly bog standard sympathetic biography. The man he replaced in the band Smile, which developed into Queen, ruminated: "If I hadn't got out of the way, the world wouldn't have had Queen." Thank you so much.

The most interesting contributions - and there wasn't much competition - came from Mary Austin, Mercury's longtime girlfriend, and Jim Hutton, his lover. Yet even these provided only bland, airbrushed portraits of the man who, according to Tim Rice, had everything in extremis. There was much talk of this extremis but, for a documentary purporting to reveal the undiscovered, it was remarkably shy, to the point of prurient, in addressing this side of Mercury's life.

There were big parties, we were told, which looked like Fellini sets, with dwarves covered in liver and men dressed as French maids. The decadence and excess at some, it was said, were of dionysian proportions. Presumably this meant Mercury took loads of drugs and shagged lots of people but we can't be too sure since the programme was far too obsequious to honestly discuss such lowly pastimes. Even in a discussion about when the Queen frontman may have contracted HIV, a friend referred to it only as "the illness that killed him" like some maiden aunt in denial.

Geniuses, one contributor said, were allowed certain liberties. If Mercury was a genius, and let's just argue he was, his liberties didn't come free. Despite the best attempts of the documentary to separate his death - from a disease transmittable through sexual activity and drug use - from his extreme, Bacchanalian life, there is a causal link there. The tone was one of eulogy and, as such, did everyone - audience and Mercury - a disservice. A distorted picture indeed.

Still no luck with Clarissa and the Countryman (BBC2) suffering tragic accidents, even though they ventured near the sea and went on a fox hunt. After their exploits in this, the last of the series, both are alive and well, which would suggest accidents don't just wait to happen.

In Charlie's Wildlife Gardens (BBC2), Charlie the Evil Robot was helping to create an organic vegetable patch on a Bristol housing estate. Along with Chris, her little helper, she was evidently following that charitable adage: "Give a man an organic marrow and he'll make a bong out of it. Teach him to grow organic vegetables and he'll uproot them and have a hash plantation in no time."

fields.headline: South Yorkshire
fields.trailText: An eerie stillness struck us as we entered Wharncliffe Woods. Above us, the treetops creaked and groaned, but at ground level all was peace and tranquillity. Except for the scolding of wrens, that is.
fields.body:
An eerie stillness struck us as we entered Wharncliffe Woods. Above us, the treetops creaked and groaned, but at ground level all was peace and tranquillity. Except for the scolding of wrens, that is.

Every bramble patch or tree stump seemed to have a wren sat upon it - tall, cocked upright, chattering loud and long, objecting to our presence. Further in, the wind in the tree tops died away, so that now the contact calls of coal tits and goldcrests could be heard as they skipped around the tops of pine trees in their never ending search for food. A female sparrowhawk glided noiselessly through the trees, on the hunt for unwary prey.

Stepping out on to the heath, a meadow pipit flew up from the heather, more wrens protested and yellow hammers took off, the sun catching the males' bright yellow heads and breasts. A work party was cutting silver birch scrub, part of the never ending effort to keep the heathland open.

Managed as a nature reserve by the Yorkshire Wildlife Trust, Wharncliffe Heath, like the woods, is a site of great antiquity. There is visible evidence of early man's occupation and industry, not surprising on a site that sits high above the upper River Don valley, offering views for miles in all directions.

It has more recent historical links. A herd of feral red deer, once confined to Wharncliffe Chase, can occasionally be seen. More often you find their tracks or droppings. Re-entering the woods, we saw their tunnelled pathways through a dense, young conifer plantation.

Down the track, several bullfinches were sampling the leaf buds of ash and sycamore, white rumps flashing as they flew off, the bright winter sun highlighting the male's bright pink breasts and blue-grey backs. Beneath a group of beech trees, a flock of chaffinches fed on the fallen mast. Another flash of bright colour, this time green, as two woodpeckers left the ground for the safety and cover of silver birch nearby.

All morning it seemed that the sun-lit plumage of our native birds were to be bright beacons in an otherwise drab winter landscape of greys and browns.

fields.headline: Never mind the forelocks
fields.standfirst:
Despite social reforms, Britain still has not shaken off its feudal ways. It is high time, says A C Grayling, that the concept of deference was consigned to history
Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: Despite social reforms, Britain still has not shaken off its feudal ways. It is high time, says A C Grayling, that the concept of deference was consigned to history
fields.body:
Lord Macaulay's famous poem The Lays of Ancient Rome was a best-seller in its Victorian heyday and for long afterwards. It tells how Horatius defended the bridge into Rome against its recently deposed king, Tarquin the Proud, and his ally Lars Porsena of Clusium. Tarquin had been a cruel and arrogant monarch, and the new republic was determined to be free of kings for ever. Horatius held the would-be invaders at bay while his comrades demolished the bridge behind him; and then, shouting an invocation to the god of the Tiber, he threw himself into its foaming waters, armour and all, and struggled back to the new Republic's cheering city shore.

A great irony surrounds this poem's success. Generations of public schoolboys - sons of the aristocracy, gentry and wealthy bourgeoisie - were encouraged to read it so that they could admire and emulate Horatius's selfless patriotism when, in their own turn, they went to serve their country. Yet the poem celebrates the birth of republicanism in Rome, and with it the ejection of its royal family, whose relation to Rome is forever symbolised by a rape: the rape of Lucretia by a Tarquin prince, an act which serves to encapsulate the expropriation of the wealth, liberties and rights of many by a hereditary few. So much did republicanism matter to the Romans that they passed a law banning monarchy for ever. Julius Caesar was murdered because his contemporaries thought he wished to be king; Augustus and all the emperors who followed never called themselves kings, though they were kings in fact.

So the members of royal Britain's establishment, including its soldiers, servants of Empire, and statesmen, were all educated in the austere virtues of Roman republicanism, yet they defended the crown to the last drops of their blood, and gratefully accepted from it honours and privileges in return. This in effect is still how things work in contemporary Britain; for although there are no great absolute monarchies left, the hierarchical social systems bequeathed by them persist in many places, and nowhere more obviously than in the United Kingdom, where titles, rank and station, the divisions between higher and lower classes, and priority and deference in social relations, all still exist.

To see what this means in practice one needs to note certain general points about social organisation. Societies employ a variety of ways to organise themselves, seeking to direct and control the behaviour of their members by means ranging from written laws to unwritten conventions. At one extreme they use imprisonment and execution as final sanctions against individuals who refuse to conform to requirements, while at the other they use education, persuasion, and the inducement of rewards and honours.

Closer to the former than the latter in society's armoury lie disapproval and social exclusion. These are potent weapons. Half a century ago unhappily married couples were encouraged to endure by the threat of opprobrium surrounding divorce. Today many things still carry enough stigma, despite being legal, to prevent people doing or at least acknowledging them - homosexuality is a case in point. The idea of an honour code, of disgrace, of what constitutes gentlemanly behaviour, implies internalised ideas of what society approves, and they are a powerful influence on the way many people act.

As societies have aged, their organisational structures have ossified. Rewards for good service to society (or its ruling elite) became hereditary and, because they once frequently took the form of land and titles, generations or even centuries later the descendants of the good servant still enjoy his dignity - for no better reason than that they are the latest issue in a series of pregnancies begun by him.

An essential component of a system where reward takes the form of rank and title is that the resulting hierarchy has to confer practical advantages on those who get them. For if the system is to work, people lower in the order have to show deference to those above them, and accept their condescension in return. Religion has always been a help to ruling elites here, by preaching the divine ordination of the arrangement by which rich men sit in their castles and poor men sit at their gates. As various uprisings throughout history show, not everyone was persuaded by this theology.

The functioning of social hierarchy is not just a matter of rustics pulling off their caps and standing aside as milord's carriage swishes by, splattering them with mud; it is as deeply rooted in the ambiguous and overfine strata occupying the space between peasants and peers. Thus the reason for the class divisions, deference, social climbing, false accents, forelock-tugging and snobbery that scar the face of British society. Telling examples are provided by Mr Collins in Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice, exuding oil at every mention of Lady Catherine de Bourgh, or Uriah Heep rubbing his hands together and bowing 'umbly throughout Dickens's David Copperfield. At least Heep did not really mean it; but for many real-life cases not much different from his, deference was a matter of livelihood, even of life.

Some thinkers believe that deference is an important ingredient in the proper functioning of society. "Without feelings of respect," asked Confucius, "what is there to distinguish men from beasts?" And Thomas Carlyle (typically for him) asked, "Does not every true man feel that he is himself made higher by doing reverence to what is really above him?" This was not a religious remark; it occurs in Carlyle's Heroes and Hero-Worship, as part of the reason why we should respect our betters. Neither of these writers would much appreciate the satire of Joseph Addison's Court of Honour, in which those annoyed by their inferiors' failure to doff their hats, or to "give them the wall" when crossing paths in the street, were arraigned for their crimes and condignly punished.

It seems trivial now that members of the aristocracy and gentry once expended much energy on deciding who could precede whom in and out of dining rooms. Do younger sons of barons take precedence over elder sons of knights? On whose arm should the eldest daughter of an earl go in to dinner? Everyone in the procession, hungry or not, had to defer to at least one other person, except for the most senior lady present, who could lead the way with equanimity. When Lady Macbeth wished to clear her dining room in a hurry because her husband was having a mad fit - he had seen Banquo's ghost, and she thought he might reveal their murder of Duncan - she shouted at her guests, "Do not stand on the order of thy going, but go!" The business of queuing up according to social rank is a very old one, and we can well imagine the gaggle of alarmed lords trying to get behind one another in a hurry.

Supporters of hierarchy, and its associated practices of social deference, deliberately or otherwise ignore much. They ignore the assumptions that lie behind such practices as kowtowing in imperial China, where a person of lower rank had to kneel and touch his head to the ground as obeisance to a person of higher rank, or the "droit de seigneur" in medieval France, according to which the local lord had rights over the maidenhead of any new bride in his domain. Both kowtowing and seigniorial sexual rights recapitulate the behaviour of non-human social animals. A dog defers to a higher-ranking dog in the pack - prostrating itself, exposing its vulnerable neck or belly to the superior, as if to say, "Kill me if you wish." Likewise among deer: bucks who acknowledge the dominance of one of their number leave the does in their herd to him.

Such behaviour is an instinctual way of defusing the aggression of higher-ranking animals, and it therefore keeps the peace where doing so might be a matter of life and death. Among humans, deference performs a similar function; but, given that intelligence has helped us master many of our instincts and to overcome many forms of behaviour only suited to a state of unreflective struggle for existence in the wild, the requirement of automatic deference is not only no longer necessary, it has become institutionalised insult, and it does great harm.

The reason is twofold. First, although there are of course cases where a certain kind of deference is appropriate - as when, in the matter of a burst pipe, one defers to a plumber's expertise - they are only cases where an appropriate and particular knowledge or ability is at issue. Nor in any circumstances would one defer to him because, in addition to being a plumber, he happened to be a duke.

Secondly, the system of social deference has been one of the main causes of human waste in history. Think of Gray's Elegy, in which the mute inglorious Miltons, the village Hampdens, the Cromwells sleeping under the rustic turf, never strayed from their sequestered vale because their position in life - worse, their fear of aspiring "above their station" or of "not knowing their place" - left their gifts unformed, their potential stifled and lost. In a social system which, for all that it permits a degree of upward and downward mobility, fixes divisions between people, there is bound to be massive wastage of human ability. Apart from the loss to science and art, to politics and invention, there is deep injustice in a dispensation where lives are blighted because of the inanities of social hierarchy.

That is why Mark Twain's remark that "irreverence is the champion of liberty, and its only sure defence" is so strikingly true. It makes one see clearly the insidious harm of snobbery, which, whether or not its votaries get the deference they expect from those perceived as lower than themselves, tells us that they have the monstrous effrontery to place themselves higher. In Nancy Mitford's famous essay - the one that put into public currency the "U and non-U" distinction ("lavatory" and "napkin" are "upper class" usages, as opposed to their "non-upper class" cognates "toilet" and "serviette") - we read that the English aristocracy "has real political power through the House of Lords, and real social position through the Queen". The first part of this sentence is, mercifully and by a whisker, no longer true - we only just managed to abandon feu dalism before the 20th century ended - but the second half, for all its fogginess of meaning, touches a nerve.

While we have a monarchy, and with it a system of titles and honours, the insidious consequences of social hierarchy remain. In places like the Netherlands and Denmark, where royals bicycle to the local cinema and aristocracy is a dead letter, there is much less occasion for snobbery and division. Acts of deference, if they occur, are more likely to be prompted by a sense of individual merit than institutional reflex. But it is alive and kicking in the United Kingdom because of its firm grasp on too much of the popular imagination. Readers of magazines about royals and aristocrats revel in the panoply of titles and (what they suppose to be) high life; a different part of the population aspires to be Sir This or Lady That, and to carry their noses in the air. Something diseased in the national soul allows all this to continue, forgetting - if ever it knew - what class and its attendant culture of deference really means: obsequiousness, servility, fawning, affected or ingratiating regard for another's wishes, an eager and exaggerated paying of court.

In practice this very often means subordinating worth and talent to fictions of rank and title, and perpetuating deep divisions in society either on the accidental basis of birth, or on fabricated notions of social rank, allowing them to outweigh real distinctions of merit and genuine entitlements to reward. It is no achievement to have a rich or titled father, who can send one to the best schools and supply useful social connections and business opportunities. Only think of the wise and thoughtful people whose advice was never taken, and whose experience was never consulted, because they happened not to inherit a title that gave them a seat in the House of Lords - where, instead, any inbred, pampered, sheltered scion of privilege could be allowed to influence the laws of the land, even if it meant doing so in the interests of nothing other than his own acres and perquisites.

On its best construction, deference can of course mean respect or esteem of the kind that might be owed another who deserves it. It implies making way, yielding to the authority or seniority of another when merited. But in a class society it is the less positive construction that dominates. Because of its importance to the social structure, and especially of those whose chief interest lies in maintaining it, the attitudes inimical to deference are given bad names: insolence, irreverence, disesteem, disfavour, discourtesy, incivility and rudeness. The three latter are unpleasant things in anyone's book, because they undermine the proper regard which people should automatically have for one another. But as implying a lack of deference, the rest have a healthy ring.

For deference begins in dependency. When the peasant on the land had only the option of starving, he was quick to pull off his cap or tug his forelock when the man who had his fate in his hands rode by. In this way an inspection of the origins and meanings of the concept of deference shows that the pieties of Confucius and Carlyle mask much that is fundamentally unacceptable. And when one asks what keeps this queer and harmful arrangement in being, and sees that it is the heavy weight of history, the corpse of a social order whose dead limbs still sprawl over us, one sees what needs to be done to escape it. And that is: to clear away the false old names and ways, and to put in their place a system that recognises merit, and gives it the applause of equals.

Tarquin had been a cruel and arrogant monarch, and the new republic was determined to be free of kings for ever. Horatius held the would-be invaders at bay while his comrades demolished the bridge behind him; and then, shouting an invocation to the god of the Tiber, he threw himself into its foaming waters, armour and all, and struggled back to the new Republic's cheering city shore. A great irony surrounds this poem's success. Generations of public schoolboys - sons of the aristocracy, gentry and wealthy bourgeoisie - were encouraged to read it so that they could admire and emulate Horatius's selfless patriotism when, in their own turn, they went to serve their country. Yet the poem celebrates the birth of republicanism in Rome, and with it the ejection of its royal family, whose relation to Rome is forever symbolised by a rape: the rape of Lucretia by a Tarquin prince, an act which serves to encapsulate the expropriation of the wealth, liberties and rights of many by a hereditary few. So much did republicanism matter to the Romans that they passed a law banning monarchy for ever. Julius Caesar was murdered because his contemporaries thought he wished to be king; Augustus and all the emperors who followed never called themselves kings, though they were kings in fact. So the members of royal Britain's establishment, including its soldiers, servants of Empire, and statesmen, were all educated in the austere virtues of Roman republicanism, yet they defended the crown to the last drops of their blood, and gratefully accepted from it honours and privileges in return. Societies employ a variety of ways to organise themselves, seeking to direct and control the behaviour of their members by means ranging from written laws to unwritten conventions. At one extreme they use imprisonment and execution as final sanctions against individuals who refuse to conform to requirements, while at the other they use education, persuasion, and the inducement of rewards and honours. Closer to the former than the latter in society's armoury lie disapproval and social exclusion. These are potent weapons. Half a century ago unhappily married couples were encouraged to endure by the threat of opprobrium surrounding divorce. An essential component of a system where reward takes the form of rank and title is that the resulting hierarchy has to confer practical advantages on those who get them. For if the system is to work, people lower in the order have to show deference to those above them, and accept their condescension in return. Religion has always been a help to ruling elites here, by preaching the divine ordination of the arrangement by which rich men sit in their castles and poor men sit at their gates. As various uprisings throughout history show, not everyone was persuaded by this theology. The functioning of social hierarchy is not just a matter of rustics pulling off their caps and standing aside as milord's carriage swishes by, splattering them with mud; it is as deeply rooted in the ambiguous and overfine strata occupying the space between peasants and peers. Thus the reason for the class divisions, deference, social climbing, false accents, forelock-tugging and snobbery that scar the face of British society. Telling examples are provided by Mr Collins in Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice, exuding oil at every mention of Lady Catherine de Bourgh, or Uriah Heep rubbing his hands together and bowing 'umbly throughout Dickens's David Copperfield. At least Heep did not really mean it; but for many real-life cases not much different from his, deference was a matter of livelihood, even of life. Some thinkers believe that deference is an important ingredient in the proper functioning of society. "Without feelings of respect," asked Confucius, "what is there to distinguish men from beasts?" And Thomas Carlyle (typically for him) asked, "Does not every true man feel that he is himself made higher by doing reverence to what is really above him?" This was not a religious remark; it occurs in Carlyle's Heroes and Hero-Worship, as part of the reason why we should respect our betters. Neither of these writers would much appreciate the satire of Joseph Addison's Court of Honour, in which those annoyed by their inferiors' failure to doff their hats, or to "give them the wall" when crossing paths in the street, were arraigned for their crimes and condignly punished. It seems trivial now that members of the aristocracy and gentry once expended much energy on deciding who could precede whom in and out of dining rooms. Do younger sons of barons take precedence over elder sons of knights? On whose arm should the eldest daughter of an earl go in to dinner? Everyone in the procession, hungry or not, had to defer to at least one other person, except for the most senior lady present, who could lead the way with equanimity. When Lady Macbeth wished to clear her dining room in a hurry because her husband was having a mad fit - he had seen Banquo's ghost, and she thought he might reveal their murder of Duncan - she shouted at her guests, "Do not stand on the order of thy going, but go!" webTitle: Weekend: Peter Stringfellow answers the questionnaire

fields.headline: The questionnaire
fields.standfirst: Peter Stringfellow
fields.trailText: Peter Stringfellow
fields.body:
Peter Stringfellow was born in Sheffield in 1940 and is the son of a steelworker. He worked as a merchant seaman, door-to-door salesman and pop promoter before opening his first nightclubs in the north of England. In 1980, he founded Stringfellow's in London, and has gone on to become one of the world's best known nightclub owners. He is twice divorced, and has two children. His autobiography is entitled King Of Clubs.

What is your idea of perfect happiness?

Anchoring my yacht off Ibiza for a video shoot with four of my beautiful girls, including my girlfriend.

What is your greatest fear?

I've already had a taste of it - that is, losing my business.

What is the trait you most deplore in yourself?

The way I will let something go just to make others comfortable and happy.

What is the trait you most deplore in others?

Disloyalty and dishonesty.

What do you most dislike about your appearance?

I'm getting older.

What is your most unappealing habit?

To keep my image perfect with the girls, I refuse to answer that question!

What is your favourite book?

Invariably the one I've just read.

What is your favourite fantasy?

I've had my fantasies. One I'd like to revisit is being on a deserted white beach about to make love to somebody who wants you to make love to them. You can't get any better, trust me.

Do you believe in monogamy?

Yes, but I've always found it difficult.

Have you ever said 'I love you' and not meant it?

All the time, but I don't use the words 'in love' unless I mean it.

Which words or phrases do you most overuse?

I promise.

What single thing would improve the quality of your life?

To get my eyesight back to perfect, to get rid of the tinnitus in my left ear, and to lose a stone in weight.

What keeps you awake at night?

Trying to make love when I'm drunk, and the Discovery Channel.

How would you like to die?

I'd like to know I was going, and then spend whatever time I had left on my boat in the sun with a vodka and tonic.

Do you believe in life after death?

I think there is something beyond the comprehension of human beings.

How would you like to be remembered?

Very few people are remembered - and I'm not one of them.

What is the most important lesson life has taught you?

That it is truly - cliche of cliches - a wonderful life.

fields.headline: How to...
fields.standfirst: keep warm
fields.trailText: keep warm
fields.body:
Ninety per cent of your body heat is lost through your head (unless you're a politician), so the easiest way to keep warm is to keep your head somewhere warm - in Trinidad and Tobago, say. Incidentally, the warmest part of your body is your groin: that's evolution's way of telling us what's really important in life.

There are telltale signs that the temperature in your house may be too low. Crevasses in the living room carpet are a giveaway, as is the fact that your kids are huddling in the fridge for warmth. Wearing enough clothing is vital: seven to eight layers are good, though teenagers should keep them well clear of their belly buttons, as it's better to be cool and dead than warm and uncool.

Exercise keeps the blood moving, so chopping wood is an excellent way to keep warm. Not only do you get the exercise of swinging the axe, but you can also burn the wood. Plus, there's the fact that accident and emergency departments in hospitals are usually very well heated.

Alcohol gives you the feeling of warmth, but can actually reduce your body temperature. The best thing to do is take a brisk walk to the local, and then have a few stiff ones. Don't overdo it, or you might have trouble finding your way home and die of exposure before you get within sight of your front door.

Vigorous sex is a great way of raising body temperature, provided you avoid getting undressed before you start. Polar explorers have solved this by having an ingenious arrangement of flaps that allows them to have casual, warming sex whenever the opportunity presents itself in the Antarctic wastes.

Huge mugs of steaming hot tea are similarly excellent for maintaining body temperature - unless you have an outside lavatory, in which case the more you drink, the more likely you are to get frostbite in a private part.

Since time immemorial, fire has been the best way of heating. Even today, there's nothing better than sitting around a roaring fire warming your cockles. Ideally, your house will also have a fireplace and chimney; otherwise, technically, your house is on fire, which is warming in the short term, but can have quite the opposite effect in the long run.

When you're at school, you're told not to sit on the radiators, because you'll get piles. But when you're older and you've actually got piles, they never ask you whether you sat on the radiators at school. Mind you, they never ask you how the Romans lived on Hadrian's Wall, either, and they tell you that at school as well

webTitle: Dulcie Domum: Time to face the music

fields.headline: Dulcie Domum: Time to face the music
fields.standfirst: 'I've come across Elspeth's bank statements,' growls ex-Spouse. Oh, heck!
fields.trailText: 'I've come across Elspeth's bank statements,' growls ex-Spouse. Oh, heck!
fields.body:
Wallowing in my only privacy these days: the bath. Ex-Spouse, aged Aunt and turbul ent teenager kept at bay by lovely bolt. Sink deep into hot swamp of coconut 'n' lime Tropical Bath Gel and prepare to shave armpits - which I can't attempt, these days, without seeing stars. I blame the ageing neck.

"Mum!" Harriet hammers on the door. "Fred's on the phone. He's invited us to go to Bali with him for the New Year!" Jolted upright by delight and horror - body does not bother to discriminate, just ladles out the adrenalin by the bucketful.

"Tell him I'll ring back in a minute!" Mind reels. Bali! Tropical Bath Gel writ large! Shall I swing in a hammock woven from mermaid's hair while the sound of a gamelan ensemble drifts across from the spice groves? Shall I hear the crash of surf and the jabber of monkeys? Or shall I stay here in the fog and murk, and look after Auntie? She has, after all, recently slipped me £50,000 to do just that. And only last half-term I was, as ex-Spouse puts it, "gadding about" in St Ives, also at the invitation of Fred. Could I have the barefaced cheek, so soon afterwards, to gad off with him to the South Pacific? Would aunt still be sporting? " Gorrrdon and I can indulge in our Hogmanay in prrrivate , dearrr ," she'd probably beam. But how many drams would it take before she was blabbing of her largesse?

And am I really entitled to Bali? We Virgos are so self-denying. I was beginning to feel guilty about adding extra hot water to the bath; now this. And why does Fred persist with his invitations, despite my ageing neck? Though he is roughly my age, he rejoices in boyish slimness and youthful curls, whereas I increasingly resemble Elton John. In fact, if I were male, we'd look a lot more convincing as a couple. Ex-Spouse has delivered acid asides about Fred being in search of a mother-substitute. But why not? Gay men famously adore their mothers. You could do a lot worse.

Another knock on the door. This time it's Gordon. "We need to talk," he mutters ominously.

"What about?" Has he found out about Bali already? I have so many guilty secrets nowadays, it's 10 times more complex and hair-raising than in the good old adulterous days.

"I've come across one of Elspeth's bank statements," he growls. Oh, heck! Second shot of adrenalin shoots up the aged neck.

"Snooping, eh?" I sneer, adopting a rather feeble counter-attack.

"As a matter of fact, it was in the freezer." It seems my short reign as a secret heiress is coming to an end. I'll say I was investing it for her. I probably would have, anyway. Trapped in my self-denying Virgohood. Get out of bath. Air freezing. In Bali, I bet even the rain steams. And I could afford it! For once in my life! On the other hand, wouldn't it be just like life to receive a message while the plane was refuelling somewhere - Dubai, Dallas - "AUNT COLLAPSED. COME HOME". I'd never forgive myself.

And on the third hand, as the Indian god might point out, should I be blowing aunt's money on trips to Bali? Surely I should invest it for her, in case she ever needs specialist nursing? When she put her bank statement in the icebox, wasn't it a sign that freezing assets, rather than freebies, were in order?

On the fourth hand, dress and venture out in search of phone - life's too short! Desperately, rebelliously determined to behave badly for once in my life and go to Bali.

"Fred? Sorry! I was in the bath. You had an idea for the New Year?"

"Yes. How does Bala grab you?"

"Bala?"

"Well, Lake Vyrnwy, really. Lovely spot. Lonesome pines. Rocks. Log fires."

"I'd love to, Fred, but, well," drop voice to a whisper, "we're a bit worried about Auntie. I'm so sorry."

Sink deep into hot swamp of coconut 'n' lime Tropical Bath Gel and prepare to shave armpits - which I can't attempt, these days, without seeing stars. I blame the ageing neck. "Mum!" Harriet hammers on the door. "Fred's on the phone. He's invited us to go to Bali with him for the New Year!" Jolted upright by delight and horror - body does not bother to discriminate, just ladles out the adrenalin by the bucketful. "Tell him I'll ring back in a minute!" Mind reels. Bali! Tropical Bath Gel writ large! Shall I swing in a hammock woven from mermaid's hair while the sound of a gamelan ensemble drifts across from the spice groves? Shall I hear the crash of surf and the jabber of monkeys? Or shall I stay here in the fog and murk, and look after Auntie? She has, after all, recently slipped me £50,000 to do just that. And only last half-term I was, as ex-Spouse puts it, "gadding about" in St Ives, also at the invitation of Fred. Could I have the barefaced cheek, so soon afterwards, to gad off with him to the South Pacific? Would aunt still be sporting? " Gorrrdon and I can indulge in our Hogmanay in prrrivate , dearrr ," she'd probably beam. But how many drams would it take before she was blabbing of her largesse? And am I really entitled to Bali? We Virgos are so self-denying. I was beginning to feel guilty about adding extra hot water to the bath; now this. And why does Fred persist with his invitations, despite my ageing neck? Though he is roughly my age, he rejoices in boyish slimness and youthful curls, whereas I increasingly resemble Elton John. In fact, if I were male, we'd look a lot more convincing as a couple. fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: The phrase 'party wine' is merely a synonym for something cheap and rarely cheerful that doesn't aim to be too thrilling, because a thrilling wine would only entice guests to wear out their welcome as they worked their way through the dregs of every last bottle. So, of the wines that follow, all are suited to parties, from a PTA get-together to an extravagant orgy.
fields.body:
The phrase 'party wine' is merely a synonym for something cheap and rarely cheerful that doesn't aim to be too thrilling, because a thrilling wine would only entice guests to wear out their welcome as they worked their way through the dregs of every last bottle. So, of the wines that follow, all are suited to parties, from a PTA get-together to an extravagant orgy.

Let us open with Somerfield, which has some terrific wines on special offer until January 2. Lindemans Bin 65 Chardonnay 1999 (16.5 points out of 20, on offer at £3.99), from Australia, is, for the money, one of the more striking examples of this often fatuously vinified grape. Hardys Nottage Hill Cabernet Sauvignon/Shiraz 1999 (16.5 points, £4.79) has engaging tannins and a subtle spiciness to its rich, ripe fruit, and represents one of the Aussie's smoothest red wine bargains. Domaine de Courtilles Cte 125 Corbières 1998 (16 points, £4.49) offers unusually stealthy and thickly knitted fruit that moves like lava across the tastebuds, revealing soft and warm nuances of plum and blackberry. Argento Malbec 1999 (at selected branches, call 0117 935 6669 for details) has beautifully textured, soft, red fruit with a savoury undertone - eagle-eyed readers will note that it has featured here before, but not as low as £3.99 and not quite as high as 16.5 points. A solidly fruity French red and white pair is Winter Hill Rouge and Winter Hill Blanc, both 1999s from l'Aude and available at £2.99 apiece. The red rates 14 points, being civilised and fruitily accomplished; the white rates 15 points, and is fine with smoked fish. Both are dry, respectable rather than exciting, but with food they represent excellent value. A white with a more luxurious finish and perfume is Domaine du Bois Viognier Vin de Pays d'Oc 1998, which fits the bill perfectly, not least because said bill is a faintly risible £3.49. This 16-pointer has lovely texture and a smoky edge to its apricot fruitiness, which make it so palate-teasingly breezy.

Asda has a wealth of inexpensive bottles, but this week's offerings from this retailer feature three luxury reds and a sparkling wine to entertain any lunch party at which game features. Temple Bruer Shiraz/Malbec 1998 (16.5 points, £6.96), from Australia, is a wonderfully adult blend of rich, jammy shiraz and dry, tannic malbec - the marriage is harmonious and energetic, food-friendly and deliciously deep. Ruvello Cabernet Sauvignon Passito 1998 (17 points, £7.99), from Italy, is a most individual cabernet of urgency yet with complex, lingering, slow-moving fruit that finishes strongly. Dry yet rich and delicate, earthy yet not inelegant, it has gentle tannins and great class. Crozes Hermitage Les Haut de Pavières 1999 (16 points, £6.88) is a classic Crozes mouthful, where the immediate plummy richness turns marvellously dry, smoky and chewy, and goes on developing layers of tarry fruit as it quits the throat. Bleasdale Sparkling Shiraz 1999 (16 points, £8.97) overflows with hedgerow fruit and is the quintessential Australian happy-juice.

For elite parties of red wine sybarites, Sainsbury has Domaine Michel Bernard Chateauneuf-du-Pape 1998 (17 points, £10.99, selected branches, 0800 632262 for details), which is a wine of enticing aroma, great depth yet finesse, complexity, power and delicacy. Unwins also caters for such groups with Henriques & Henriques 10-Year-Old Malmsey Madeira (16 points, £15.09), which is like sipping vinified fruitcake - it is one of those compelling fortified wines for occasions when a certain excess is permitted, and is utterly delicious and heart-rousing. It may also, with certain intimate groupings of two like-minded citizens, arouse a good deal more.

As would Apostoles Palo Cortado Muy Viejo, in the half bottle at Waitrose for £10.25. Even for parties of one, this is the ultimate treat: a sherry of huge, treacly texture (but not crude sweetness), baked apple and cobnut-crumble-edged fruit with touches of liquorice. It has a gripping finish and lingering richness and rates 18.5 points. A true companion for the bookworm and similar hedonistic solipsists.

 Superplonk 2001 is published by Hodder Headline at £10.99. To order a copy for the special price of £8.99, plus 99p UK p&p, freephone Guardian CultureShop on 0800 3166102.

fields.headline: On the rack
fields.standfirst: Malcolm Gluck offers vintage advice - what is value for money?
fields.trailText: Malcolm Gluck offers vintage advice - what is value for money?
fields.body:
My weekly recommendations in this magazine as to the best wine buys are, on the whole, well received - not least at this time of year by all those poor souls who have been given the responsibility of procuring a few dozen bottles that are cheap enough to serve by the gallon at the annual Christmas get-together or New Year's bash, yet that at the same time exhibit certain characteristics to set them apart from more run-of-the-mill or plain undrinkable fare.

As a result, I am often rebuked by readers if I include in my column a bottle of wine that costs more than £5 or £6; and if I go for one that retails at more than a tenner, I am positively hammered. Two emails recently received sum up the position of such readers.

"In the last two issues of Weekend, Malcolm Gluck has reviewed 41 wines, average price £7.96. Superplonk? Not to my pocket!" scolded Mr Draper, of Sheffield. Mr Gollan, of London N16, was a little more whimsical: "So, Malcolm Gluck's plonk now costs £8.30 a bottle. Never used to, did it? Or are policemen getting younger?"

I replied as follows: "Instead of averaging out the price of a superplonk over merely the past two columns, why not average it out over a year? Or the 11 years I have been writing it? You will find the average more like £3.50. A superplonk, may I add, is not dependent upon its price but its value for money, and this concept exists as readily at £10 as it does at £2.99."

I also confirmed to Mr Gollan his suspicion: yes, policemen are indeed getting younger. Where once brawny adults pounded the beat, or contained the enthusiasts at demos and the away supporters at football stadiums, all I see now is nappy-rashed, wrinkle-free youth. However, older though I may have become, I have not wavered in my conception of what a superplonk represents - it is a wine that, by virtue of its fruit, is superior to its price, and by means of comparing it with others of a similar price offers a good deal more than they.

True, I tread a fine line here, but a broad church reads this paper - and drinks accordingly - so if I were to restrict myself to less-than-a-fiver bottles, the Superplonk column would be impoverished. Its author would also not be regularly exposing himself to more expensive wines, and thus not have higher-price exemplars (or execrations) for comparison. Equally important, I would be failing to represent the true breadth and depth of retailers' wine ranges, which now include wines at all price levels.

To change the subject, Miss Z Vengerov, of Moscow, wrote asking: what is an organic wine? I replied that there is no such thing, but added that there is such a thing as wine made from organic grapes - that is, grapes that have been raised without the intrusion of artificial fertilisers, pesticides, fungicides and herbicides.

Will the absence of such repulsive adornments mean she can drink and suffer no hangovers? No. Hangovers are caused by alcohol, not the infinitesimal residues of any of the chemicals mentioned above. As a result, organic wine specialists who claim that people who drink their wines will avoid hangovers are liars

webTitle: Throwing a party in your own home

fields.headline: Back to mine
fields.standfirst: So you're mad enough to throw a party in your own home - how do you make sure it's a spectacular success? Fran Cutler should know: she and Meg Mathews are the most celebrated party organisers in London. Here, Fran shares the secrets of a special night in
fields.trailText: So you're mad enough to throw a party in your own home - how do you make sure it's a spectacular success? Fran Cutler should know: she and Meg Mathews are the most celebrated party organisers in London. Here, Fran shares the secrets of a special night in
fields.body:
Everyone enjoys a party - unless they're a hermit or strictly religious - but don't think it's going to happen by itself. If you plan to entertain friends, there are a few tricks that will help you get it right. The golden rule ought to be, never do it in your home. We all know what happens: it gets trashed. When people have more than two drinks inside them, ashtrays tend to disappear, cigarettes are stubbed out on the carpet and drinks get spilt. It doesn't matter how much respect people would normally have for your house - after several bottles of champagne, they lose it. Worst of all is the toilet situation: most people only have one loo in their home and if you're inviting, say, 50 guests, that means trouble.

There are alternatives: head down the road to the local pub, hire a marquee or go to the park if it's summer; or persuade a friend to lend you their nice loft-style apartment and cover the floor in plastic.

But the fact is, the best parties are very often at the host's own home - like the one I went to last New Year at Ronnie and Jo Wood's. About 20 of us sat down for dinner, then there was a full party afterwards, when loads of guests arrived. They had arranged a DJ booth and a proper dancefloor; everything was perfectly organised.

Organisation, you see, is the key. If you're going to have a house party - and don't say I didn't warn you - first settle your guest list. Here, you have to be quite heartless: you've got to set yourself a number and stick to it . Obviously, some of your friends don't mix well, so you have to be wary of this. You don't want couples that have split up bringing their new partners and then making a big scene. So always be upfront and honest - tell one of the couples that you don't think it's a good idea because so-and-so is coming, or let them decide for themselves who is going to be there.

Ask your guests to arrive at around 10pm. That way, they will have eaten first and you won't have to provide food. Start any earlier, and you're talking about a cocktail party, which means you have to serve food, get caterers in and do flash little canapés - you really don't want the added trouble of doing your own cooking. Also, this kind of gathering is often quite boring: it'll end about 10pm, and your guests will then go on to the really good party, which will finish about 4am.

Never let people know about your party too far in advance, because if you tell them, say, three weeks before, everyone will forget about it and throw away the invite. About a week before is a safe bet, because your guests will know by then what they've got on that week, and can rejig their arrangements. Also, don't worry about someone else having a party at the same time and friends not coming to yours, because anyone can go to two parties in a night. Anyway, because yours is going to be better, they are always going to come to you.

Be similarly confident about how many guests you want. Invite only the number you expect to turn up - perhaps a few more (this is determined by how many you can fit into your space). If it's a personal party, most people will make the effort.

Also, to keep out those you don't want turning up, it's a good idea to have someone on the door. They don't have to be professional bouncers; it could be a big friend or neighbour. This will stop gate-crashers - they are always the ones who cause the most damage, after all. However, you must also be prepared for guests getting out of control - the moment they do, ask them to leave and get them out before they scare off other friends.

As for yourself, try to relax - although this is always going to be difficult when you've got loads of people running around your house. If anything goes missing, for instance, it will probably turn up in the morning, so don't, when you've had a few drinks, go around accusing everyone of taking it.

But whoever is being the security person, make sure they know what they are doing. When we opened Sugar Reef, for example, Rod Stewart, Ronnie Wood and their entourages walked in and the security, who were under-experienced, would not clear a table for them, so they left. And I still haven't heard the last about the opening of Rock that I organised last March, when the bouncers wouldn't let George Clooney in. His driver came over and said to the doormen, "I've got George Clooney in the car" and they said, "Let's see him, then", and he wouldn't get out of the car, so they didn't let him in. Now, do you honestly think that someone as famous as George Clooney is going to hang around in the street - where hundreds of people will recognise him - while a doorman checks the guest list?

The idea of some people being more special than others is always going to cause problems, so never have a VIP, red-rope area (ie, the room upstairs that's out of bounds to all except your best friends). Everyone thinks they're a VIP anyway, and it will only create a bad atmosphere.

At the beginning of the party, stay near the door to greet people, making sure that everyone is all right and that they've got a drink. Once you have got them inside, you don't want them blocking the hall looking for somewhere to put their coats, so point them to the bedroom for the coats, then to the drinks and get them out of the corridor. Stay sober for the first couple of hours at least, but don't stay on guard all night - otherwise, you won't have much fun.

What type of drink you provide depends on how much you want to spend. Personally, I think it's always good to have white and red wine, beer, and sea breeze, because then you have more or less covered every option - most people will like one (or all) of those. That's quite a low-budget bar, but it is also a good one: you have got grapefruit and cranberry juice for the sea breeze, so there are some soft drinks available, though always provide bottles of water, too. People are not going to complain that you do not have a wide selection: all they want is a drink - any drink. Also, ask guests to bring a bottle if they want, though do not raise your eyebrows if they don't. And if they bring a bottle of squash, you have got to say, "That's great."

I would have a nice little bar in the corner of one room - not in the kitchen, though, because it's too small and is always banged out with people; everyone always goes there to get a drink, and it ends up like a blitzed area. Instead, put a cloth over a table and place the drinks on it.

Don't let guests help themselves, either: get a friend or young cousin who wants to earn a few bob, and ask them to act as bartender. And use plastic cups, not glasses, even if it's a special occasion - people really don't mind that sort of thing.

As for the amount of drink to buy, always, always have extra. Never let it run out. If the drink goes, so do the guests - and that'll be it, the end of the party. Get the barman to keep an eye on things, and if he thinks you're going to run out, ask someone to go to the off-licence. A rule of thumb is to double the amount you think you'll need.

After the alcohol, music is the most important thing. The drink should be in one corner - or even in another room - the music in the other. I've been to parties where all they have got is a basic stereo, which just doesn't work: you are only going to get two or three people fighting over which CD to put on. Everyone knows someone, even if it's only a friend of a friend, who's got decks, so set them up in the corner and get some guy to do their thing - there are hundreds of thousands of aspiring DJs out there who'll be only to willing to play in return for free beer.

Good music, dancing, everyone getting drunk and having a laugh - that's my idea of a good time

 Fran Cutler is a director of events organiser 2 ACTIVE, 020-7631 4244

As for yourself, try to relax - although this is always going to be difficult when you've got loads of people running around your house. If anything goes missing, for instance, it will probably turn up in the morning, so don't, when you've had a few drinks, go around accusing everyone of taking it. But whoever is being the security person, make sure they know what they are doing. When we opened Sugar Reef, for example, Rod Stewart, Ronnie Wood and their entourages walked in and the security, who were under-experienced, would not clear a table for them, so they left. And I still haven't heard the last about the opening of Rock that I organised last March, when the bouncers wouldn't let George Clooney in. His driver came over and said to the doormen, "I've got George Clooney in the car" and they said, "Let's see him, then", and he wouldn't get out of the car, so they didn't let him in. Now, do you honestly think that someone as famous as George Clooney is going to hang around in the street - where hundreds of people will recognise him - while a doorman checks the guest list? The idea of some people being more special than others is always going to cause problems, so never have a VIP, red-rope area (ie, the room upstairs that's out of bounds to all except your best friends). Everyone thinks they're a VIP anyway, and it will only create a bad atmosphere. At the beginning of the party, stay near the door to greet people, making sure that everyone is all right and that they've got a drink. Once you have got them inside, you don't want them blocking the hall looking for somewhere to put their coats, so point them to the bedroom for the coats, then to the drinks and get them out of the corridor. Stay sober for the first couple of hours at least, but don't stay on guard all night - otherwise, you won't have much fun. What type of drink you provide depends on how much you want to spend. Personally, I think it's always good to have white and red wine, beer, and sea breeze, because then you have more or less covered every option - most people will like one (or all) of those. That's quite a low-budget bar, but it is also a good one: you have got grapefruit and cranberry juice for the sea breeze, so there are some soft drinks available, though always provide bottles of water, too. People are not going to complain that you do not have a wide selection: all they want is a drink - any drink. Also, ask guests to bring a bottle if they want, though do not raise your eyebrows if they don't. And if they bring a bottle of squash, you have got to say, "That's great." I would have a nice little bar in the corner of one room - not in the kitchen, though, because it's too small and is always banged out with people; everyone always goes there to get a drink, and it ends up like a blitzed area. Instead, put a cloth over a table and place the drinks on it. Don't let guests help themselves, either: get a friend or young cousin who wants to earn a few bob, and ask them to act as bartender. And use plastic cups, not glasses, even if it's a special occasion - people really don't mind that sort of thing. As for the amount of drink to buy, always, always have extra. Never let it run out. If the drink goes, so do the guests - and that'll be it, the end of the party. Get the barman to keep an eye on things, and if he thinks you're going to run out, ask someone to go to the off-licence. A rule of thumb is to double the amount you think you'll need. After the alcohol, music is the most important thing. The drink should be in one corner - or even in another room - the music in the other. I've been to parties where all they have got is a basic stereo, which just doesn't work: you are only going to get two or three people fighting over which CD to put on. Everyone knows someone, even if it's only a friend of a friend, who's got decks, so set them up in the corner and get some guy to do their thing - there are hundreds of thousands of aspiring DJs out there who'll be only to willing to play in return for free beer. Good music, dancing, everyone getting drunk and having a laugh - that's my idea of a good time  Fran Cutler is a director of events organiser 2 ACTIVE, 020-7631 4244

fields.headline: The net addict
fields.trailText: In the end, Mum chose an idyllic rural chapel as the setting for her latest wedding, and I was really looking forward to the occasion, even if I had a feeling of déjà-vu. Part of my excitement was that I bought a fabulous, ludicrously expensive hat.
fields.body:
In the end, Mum chose an idyllic rural chapel as the setting for her latest wedding, and I was really looking forward to the occasion, even if I had a feeling of déjà-vu. Part of my excitement was that I bought a fabulous, ludicrously expensive hat.

Migraine Alan has been rather frosty since our Thanksgiving disaster, so I was on my own in the evenings; I tried my luck at blackjack at www.belaircasino.com, and I won! Easy money, and the hat is great.

The day before the wedding, I checked www.ananova.com (I find her more lively than many human newsreaders); there was a flood warning for the area.

'Nonsense, you're always the voice of gloom,' Mum snapped. Next morning, she phoned back in a panic. 'Tanya, the water in the chapel is 3ft deep! Oh, what am I going to do? I must go ahead regardless.'

I knew she'd say that; ever since her wedding to the Turkish wrestler, she s convinced that a postponed ceremony dooms a marriage.

'How can I save the occasion?'

'Don t worry, I ve arranged something,' I said mysteriously.

The ceremony was a soggy affair. We stood in waders, shivering, but then, after the blessing, magic: a semi-circle of synchronised swimmers in white rubber suits burst out of the water (I found them through the synchronised swimmers club at www.portsmouth-victoria.co.uk) and began singing Over The Rainbow; Mum was really moved (it's her favourite song).

We retired to a cosy - and dry - local pub to celebrate: no grand speeches, just an informal gathering and all the champagne we could take. As I sat there, slightly tearful after several glasses of bubbly, I watched the men laughing and drinking local ale in the other bar. It had been a long time since I was so happy, but would I swap one of their country lives for mine? I felt the fabric of my expensive new hat. Perhaps city life isn't so bad, after all.
Tanya Millbank
(www.gorgeoustanya.com; tanya@gorgeoustanya.co.uk)

fields.headline: Food party
fields.standfirst: You'll need to cater to the children's needs at the festive gathering, too, says Joanna Blythman
fields.trailText: You'll need to cater to the children's needs at the festive gathering, too, says Joanna Blythman.
fields.body:
It is difficult enough during the festive season to please everyone who arrives with the aim of eating and drinking you out of house and home. But throw into the pot the reluctant offspring of all those various constituencies - and things can go downhill quickly.

People positively sprout children at this time of year, as childminders and nannies head home to be coddled by their own parents, and securing the services of a babysitter becomes almost impossible.

Even if you are one of those fantastically organised people who can cope with a dedicated party menu, rather than pass off dusted-down and refreshed leftovers to the adults, there's only so long that you can barricade querulous toddlers and sullen teenagers in a room with a Friends video and a tube of Pringles before the problems begin.

Granted, people who arrive with babies usually come prepared - they won't be expecting you to whip up a salt-free butternut squash purée - but older progeny are a different matter entirely.

The solution? You can, of course, simply stock up on frozen pizzas and the like. But even the most dedicated young margherita-eater has had one too many by this time of year. The more satisfying alternative is to give in gracefully and accept that you are going to have to make something especially for the children.

And the odds-on favourite here just has to be a proper lasagne, with a good meaty ragu and lots of oozing bechamel sauce (with minimal effort, you can also whip up a separate ricotta and tomato sauce version for veggie kids). Let them get stuck into that, and they'll behave like angels for the rest of the evening - though, remember to guard against the unwanted attentions of the adults, who will need little excuse to demolish the pasta themselves.

Also, never underestimate just how receptive kids are to fresh fruit at this time of year. All those rich Christmas pies, cakes and pudding may be sweet, but they hold precious little appeal for children. A bunch of grapes or clementines, on the other hand, or even an Ogen or galia melon, makes for a refreshing change.

And what about the drinks? The effects on young kids of unlimited cola over a long period are too terrible to contemplate: there's no way they are going to want to go to bed - ever. For the easy life, look no further than fruit again - and if long-life fruit juices are too pedestrian for your tastes or, more important, your children's, try them on single-variety apple juice, say; given half the chance, they'll also quite happily guzzle their way through gallons of upmarket fruity, herbal fizzes, although the financial consequences of heading down that route are a little frightening.

A party is an occasion, perhaps, when it is actually worth making a pitcher of homemade lemonade, then leaving the kids to get on with it. You've done your bit.

webTitle: Kohl tries to keep Stasi files under wraps

fields.headline: Kohl tries to keep Stasi files under wraps
fields.trailText: Germany's disgraced former chancellor, Helmut Kohl, applied for an injunction yesterday to block the release of transcripts of his tapped telephone conversations.
fields.body:
Germany's disgraced former chancellor, Helmut Kohl, applied for an injunction yesterday to block the release of transcripts of his tapped telephone conversations.

A parliamentary commission is investigating whether Mr Kohl's governments swapped favours for party donations. There had been speculation that publication of the documents would decisively alter the course of the drawn-out inquiry.

The Stasi, the intelligence and security agency in the former East Germany, systematically intercepted conversations by Mr Kohl and other West German politicians during the cold war.

After the fall of the Berlin wall in 1989, most of the agency's records were entrusted to an official body known as the Gauck authority.

Ironically, Mr Kohl was the man who set up the authority and gave it responsibility for deciding who should see the highly sensitive material.

For more than a year now, the former chancellor has been locked in a battle to rescue his battered reputation for posterity.

He admitted last year that he had accepted donations for his Christian Democrat Union (CDU) in the 1990s, hiding their origin by having them channelled through interlocking secret bank accounts.

Mr Kohl said the money was handed over to help the Christian Democratic movement establish a presence in formerly communist East Germany after reunification.

Since then it has been established that during Mr Kohl's 16-year chancellorship, the CDU took millions of pounds without telling the relevant authorities, as required by a law which Mr Kohl had himself introduced.

One of the Gauck authority's guiding principles is that the subject of a surveillance file or telephone interception should be the first outsider to see it. A spokeswoman said last night that, after the existence of transcripts of his conversations became known, Mr Kohl was given until the end of August to study them.

It was expected that once he had completed his perusal, the documents would be thrown open for inspection by journalists and researchers.

The parliamentary commission investigating the former chancellor has said it will not use the files as evidence.

But it is clear that if the contents of the documents were to be made public through the media, the commission could scarcely ignore them, and the MPs running it have said they could use the information to question witnesses.

The Gauck authority's spokeswoman said that Mr Kohl had failed to finish his inspection of the documents by the initial deadline. Since he had also failed to give any indication of when he intended to do so, a new deadline was recently imposed of December 31.

Yesterday's petition for an injunction restraining the authority appeared to have been lodged in response to the new deadline.

A spokesman for the law firm handling Mr Kohl's affairs said he had already seen the files "two or three times" and intended to go back and look at them again before the end of the year.

Mr Kohl has repeatedly argued that the transcripts could contain distortions and inaccuracies.

Stephan Holthoff-Pförtner, his senior lawyer, said the documents in question had come into existence "through a gross violation of civil liberties".

webTitle: Dane named as new head of UN mission in Kosovo

fields.headline: Dane named as new head of UN mission in Kosovo
fields.standfirst: Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: The Danish defence minister, Hans Haekkerup, is to succeed Bernard Kouchner of France as the chief UN administrator in Kosovo, the United Nations announced yesterday.
fields.body:
The Danish defence minister, Hans Haekkerup, is to succeed Bernard Kouchner of France as the chief UN administrator in Kosovo, the United Nations announced yesterday.

Mr Haekkerup, 55, who has held the defence portfolio in Denmark since 1993, will take up the job in January.

"The secretary-general [Kofi Annan] has informed the security council of his intention to name Hans Haekkerup as his new special representative in Kosovo," UN spokesman Fred Eckhard said.

The UN mission in Kosovo is in charge of the civilian operation to rebuild the war-shattered Yugoslav province. It runs parallel to the Nato-led military operation.

Dr Kouchner told Mr Annan earlier this year he wanted to leave his job following local elections in Kosovo, held in October, after 18 gruelling months struggling to bridge the wide divide between the ethnic Albanians and Serbs.

Mr Eckhard said Mr Annan had spoken to Dr Kouchner, a former French health minister and co-founder of the Médecins Sans Frontières aid organisation, about a possible future assignment.

Mr Annan wanted to pay tribute to Dr Kouchner "for the inspirational leadership and dynamism with which he led this extremely difficult and challenging mission and for the remarkable success he has achieved there in its first year and a half", Mr Eckhard said.

Mr Haekkerup has had a lengthy political career, beginning with the Social Democratic Youth Organisation in 1960, and was a member of the executive committee of the Social Democratic party in the 1970s. He was elected as MP in 1979 and has served on various foreign affairs committees.

Mr Eckhard said Mr Annan was "pleased to have recruited a man of Hans Haekkerup's stature and ability to take over from Dr Kouchner ".

 Serbian police and ethnic Albanian rebels exchanged fire yesterday in a buffer zone along the boundary with Kosovo.

The shootout occurred near the village of Bukovac, inside the three-mile zone between Kosovo and the rest of Serbia, said Yugoslavia's police chief, Zoran Zivkovic. There were no casualties.

Yugoslavia has said that its security forces will take action if Nato-led troops in Kosovo do not expel ethnic Albanian rebels from the zone.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Belgrade claim of $4bn stolen | Clinton avoids death ruling | Putin advisers want 'spy' freed
fields.body:
Belgrade claim of $4bn stolen

Yugoslavia's central bank governor has accused the regime of former president Slobodan Milosevic of stealing more than $4bn (£2.7bn) - four times what was reported a week ago.

"We will launch a major money hunt right away," Mladjan Dinkic said in yesterday's edition of Politika. It was unclear why the sum had gone up so much in a few days.
AP, Belgrade

Clinton avoids death ruling

President Bill Clinton left it to his successor to decide on what would have been the first execution of a federal inmate in 37 years.

Juan Raul Garza of Texas stands convicted of three murders in 1990 and 1991.
AP, Washington

Gypsies get apology

The Norwegian government apologised to the country's Gypsies yesterday for a policy of "Norwegianisation" from the 1930s to the 1950s, involving abuses such as forced sterilisation and the placing of Gypsy children in institutions.

But it said the state would not be paying compensation.
AP, Oslo

Putin advisers want 'spy' freed

A Russian presidential commission advised Vladimir Putin yesterday to pardon a US businessman, Edmond Pope, sentenced to 20 years this week as a spy.

Commission members condemned the conviction - and what they called "spy mania" in the security services - as a cold war relic. Pope argued the torpedo specifications in question had already been published abroad by Russian arms salesmen.
Reuters, Moscow

webTitle: Jail doctor 'backed away' over cell death

fields.headline: Jail doctor 'backed away' over cell death
fields.trailText: The prison service apologised yesterday for procedural failures which left an ill-trained doctor in charge of 1,200 inmates at a tough Leeds jail.
fields.body:
The prison service apologised yesterday for procedural failures which left an ill-trained doctor in charge of 1,200 inmates at a tough Leeds jail.

The service acknowledged that the GP, who concealed his disciplinary record to get the post at Armley prison, had failed a remand prisoner who hanged himself.

The doctor, Kumar Sitaram Singh, was criticised at an inquest on Steven Wilkinson, 39, whose resuscitation treatment was stopped on the GP's orders. A jury at Wakefield coroner's court yesterday returned a verdict of misadventure contributed to by neglect.

The inquest heard that Dr Singh had "backed away" when called to Mr Wilkinson's cell as the doctor on sole duty in the jail. The jury was told he had not used his stethoscope or played any part in resuscitation procedures before telling police and prison staff Mr Wilkinson was dead.

The inquest heard that after the tragedy it emerged that Dr Singh had not told Armley's authorities that he was under severe restrictions from the General Medical Council following complaints over the deaths of two patients at his former practice in Derbyshire.

Ruth Bundey, solicitor for Mr Wilkinson's family, said that the prison had discovered that Dr Singh was undergoing extra training, but had failed to check his full GMC record.

"They would have learned much earlier than they finally did that he was barred from working single-handed and forbidden to act as a locum," she said.

The prison service said Armley had seen a host of improvements since Mr Wilkinson's death on February 28, 1998, including the appointment of a new governor and a suicide awareness co-ordinator.

Dr Singh, who did not appear at the inquest, successfully applied for voluntary removal from the register of medical practitioners a year ago.

The inquest was delayed for two years as police investigated possible charges against Dr Singh of deception, wilful neglect and manslaughter. He was suspended when his cover-up emerged after Mr Wilkinson's death and sacked from the jail shortly afterwards.
