fields.headline: £250,000 fine for 'black coffee' water
fields.trailText: A water company was landed with a £250,000 court bill yesterday for supplying water the colour of black coffee to outraged householders.
fields.body:
A water company was landed with a £250,000 court bill yesterday for supplying water the colour of black coffee to outraged householders.

Yorkshire Water pleaded guilty to 17 counts of piping water so foul that showers broke down, a leading hospital bought emergency bottled supplies and even the firm's own staff described it as having "a horrible appearance."

Fining the firm £119,000, Judge Norman Jones QC told Leeds crown court: "Water is the life blood of humanity and people have a particular emotional feeling towards the water they have to drink and when they see black gunge coming out of the tap it is very disturbing indeed."

The judge also imposed £125,000 costs on the company for a prolonged legal battle with the Drinking Water Inspectorate. Although the firm admitted the charges, it changed its plea from not guilty only after the trial judge ruled that "water which customers found aesthetically unappealing" was legally unfit for human consumption.

Yorkshire Water emphasised after last night's sentence that it still denied that what the court heard described as a "mud or sludgelike liquid sometimes accompanied by foul smells" was hazardous to health. An appeal against the judge's ruling has been lodged, which, if successful, could see the fine overturned.

The court heard that more than 15,000 customers in parts of Bradford and North Yorkshire were aghast to find a sort of non-fizzy cola coming out of their taps in 1997 and 1998. The water varied from brown to virtually black, said prosecutor David Perry, and frequently contained gritty residue or sediment.

Only a few months before, the Drinking Water Inspectorate had written to all water companies warning them to improve measures against supplying dirty water. But Yorkshire Water had failed to do enough about corroded and rotting pipework, and, in one incident at Boroughbridge near Harrogate, alarms went off at a treatment works because the state of the water was ignored.

webTitle: US elections: The story so far

fields.headline: Month of mayhem
fields.standfirst:
The story so far

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The story so far
fields.body:
November 7 America votes to choose a new president

November 8 In the early hours, television networks declare Bush has won. Gore concedes defeat in telephone call to Bush; then retracts, saying "circumstances have changed".

November 11 Bush sues to stop hand recounting of disputed votes in four heavily Democratic Florida counties

November 13 Florida secretary of state Katherine Harris prepares to certify statewide results. Gore launches lawsuit to prevent tally from being made final

November 16 Florida supreme court refuses to halt manual recounts in Democratic strongholds

November 18 With addition of overseas absentee ballots, Bush increases Florida lead over Gore to 930 votes

November 21 Florida supreme court orders recounts be added to final tally by November 26

November 22 Republican vice-presidential candidate Dick Cheney suffers slight heart attack. Miami-Dade county officials vote to call off their recount, saying they cannot meet November 26 deadline. Bush lawyers petition US supreme court to overturn Florida supreme court decision ordering manual recounts to be included in Florida tally

November 25 Gore challenges Palm Beach county results on grounds that "dimpled", or merely indented ballots were undercounted

November 26 Election officials declare Bush the winner in Florida. Canvassing commission certifies 2,912,790 votes for Bush, 2,912,253 votes for Gore, a margin of 537 votes for Bush

November 29 Bush team request the delivery of 11m ballots, trucked under police escort across Florida, to court in Tallahassee

December 2 US supreme court sends decision on extending the deadline for recounts back down to Florida supreme court

December 4 Leon county circuit judge rejects Gore's challenge to certified statewide victory and refuses to order further recounts

December 8 Florida supreme court orders recount of 9,000 Miami-Dade ballots,orders lower court to add 215 votes for Gore from Palm Beach County and 168 votes from Miami-Dade, and orders widespread manual recount of all undervotes

webTitle: Wembley plans go back to drawing board

fields.headline: Wembley plans go back to drawing board
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of Wembley
fields.trailText: The Football Association yesterday scrapped all existing plans for the new Wembley stadium, insisting that a new, cheaper project needed to be devised.
fields.body:
The Football Association yesterday scrapped all existing plans for the new Wembley stadium, insisting that a new, cheaper project needed to be devised.

The radical decision means the £660m project will return to the drawing board, with architects and project officials ordered to come up with a new blueprint for the stadium.

The decision followed a compromise deal between Chelsea chairman Ken Bates and FA chief executive Adam Crozier. In return for agreeing to abol ish the existing project, Mr Bates was allowed to continue as chairman of Wembley National Stadium Limited, the FA subsidiary company set up to oversee the project. It had been widely expected that Mr Bates would be removed from the project, following criticism of his leadership and problems in raising finance.

Around £18m has already been spent on the design of the new stadium, but the FA insisted it needed to start again to ensure it could construct a world class stadium aimed at football supporters.

Following a three-hour emergency FA board meeting officials also declared that the organisation would assume greater day-to-day control of the project and ordered WNSL to reformat its proposals on how funding for the new Wembley will be raised.

WNSL has had problems raising the £410m needed from city investors following concerns that it is too expensive and has too many unnecessary facilities not needed at a football stadium.

David Davies, director of communications at the FA, reading out a statement on the decisions taken by board members, said all non-core business activity would not be included in the new Wembley. This rules out ambitious plans by Mr Bates to include a hotel, office space and lavish banqueting facilities, leading to widespread criticism of the project.

The Guardian revealed last week that Chase Manhattan, the US Bank appointed by WNSL to raise finance, was having problems in trying to get city banks interested and that 30 had already turned them down.

Mr Davies said all costs for the project would be "attacked vigorously", suggesting that the redevised national stadium will cost considerably less than the £660m estimated by Mr Bates.

Mr Davies said the FA is being supported by Chase Manhattan, the government and Sport England, the organisation which distributes sport's National Lottery money.

Mr Davies added: "All parties believe passionately in the project. They share the desire to build a world class stadium that England can be proud of; also a stadium that has the ability to run as a profitable business which will provide long-term income to help fund grass roots football in England."

All 12 FA board members plus Mr Crozier and FA chair man Geoff Thompson attended yesterday's emergency meeting. Mr Bates met Mr Crozier privately for at least two hours beforehand.

One of Mr Bates's sternest critics, Arsenal deputy chairman David Dein, an FA board member, said after yesterday's meeting: "It was a very progressive meeting. I am very satisfied significant changes are being made to the project."

Mr Bates said: "The board has given me a unanimous vote of confidence."

fields.headline: America heads into the unknown
fields.standfirst:
Dispute could end with historic showdown in congress

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Dispute could end with historic showdown in congress.
fields.body:
When the newly elected Governor Jeb Bush appointed Peggy Quince to the Florida supreme court two years ago to the day yesterday, he little knew that his action might end in denying the presidency of the United States to his elder brother George.

Yesterday, however, Justice Quince, the first black American woman to serve on the supreme court of a state which once went to war with the US in defence of slavery, added her crucial vote to those of her three more experienced colleagues, Harry Anstead, Barbara Pariente and Fred Lewis. In so doing, the four judges propelled the US down the track towards its most dramatic constitutional showdown since the American civil war nearly a century and a half ago.

By overturning last week's circuit court ruling of Tallahassee Judge N Sanders Sauls, the 4-3 majority on the Florida Supreme Court not only revived Al Gore's presidential hopes, which almost all the American pundits had pronounced dead and buried, but also all but guaranteed that America's November 7 presidential election will not be resolved until early next year, just days before President Bill Clinton leaves office.

The principal direct effect of yesterday's Florida supreme court decision is to order a series of recounts of disputed "undervotes" which the Gore camp - and many in the Bush camp too - believe will swing the bitterly contested battle for Florida towards the vice-president.

At stake in the contest are Florida's precious 25 electoral college votes, votes which will decide whether Mr Bush or Mr Gore succeeds Mr Clinton. Mr Gore has 267 electoral college votes in his pocket. Mr Bush has 246. Whoever gets Florida's 25 votes will get past the 270 votes needed for victory.

At 4pm yesterday, when the Florida court made its ruling, the battle for those votes went into completely uncharted territory, putting the US constitution to its greatest test of the modern era. The outcome of that battle remains unknowable.

The court ordered that a net 383 new votes for Mr Gore that were already counted in Palm Beach and Miami Dade counties should be immediately certified as part of the Florida result. Those votes - 168 from the previously abandoned Miami-Dade recount and 215 from the recount in Palm Beach which finished too late to be certified by the Florida secretary of state Katherine Harris on November 26 - reduced Mr Bush's certified lead in Florida from the previous total of 537 to a new wafer-thin margin of 154.

The court also ordered that 9,000 still uncounted votes from Miami-Dade should now be recounted before Tuesday's deadline for nominating Florida's members of the electoral college, which is scheduled to meet to choose the next president on December 18. And it ruled that other counties may also conduct recounts of such "undervotes".

The net result of these orders is that Mr Gore stands on the verge of reversing the Bush victory in Florida and claiming the White House.

If he is to succeed in doing so, Mr Gore needs to do two things. First, he needs to defeat a likely appeal by Mr Bush to the US supreme court, which is already on a collision course with the Florida justices over their ruling of November 21, which allowed hand recounts in three counties. The Gore camp expressed confidence about that prospect last night, but the US supreme court now stands as Mr Bush's best hope of stopping the Gore revival.

Second, Mr Gore needs to win the recounts. That, it seemed last night, could be the easy bit. The challenge Mr Gore then faces is a political and constitutional one, as the Republican Party, which until last night believed itself on the threshold of the White House, fights with all the weapons at its disposal to prevent Mr Gore from winning what would now be the most extraordinary presidential victory in US history.

Yesterday, with the full blessing of both governors Bush, the newly elected houses of the Florida legislature - both of them Republican dominated - had already begun to debate a bill to certify the state's electoral college votes for Mr Bush. That debate goes into committee on Monday and is due to be signed into law by Jeb Bush on Wednesday.

Such a move puts the Florida legislature on a direct collision course with the counts ordered by the state's supreme court last night. If Mr Gore emerges as the winner of the recountsFlorida could find itself with two rival sets of electors meeting in Tallahassee on December 18 - with 25 Democrats supporting Mr Gore and 25 Republicans backing Mr Bush.

At that point the battle for the White House would move from Florida to Washington DC. The two newly elected houses of the United States Congress are due to be sworn in on January 3. In the 100-member Senate the parties are equally divided, with 50 Republicans and 50 Democrats, and the casting vote is in the hands of the sitting vice-president of the United States - Al Gore.

In the 435-member House of Representatives, the Republicans have a narrow majority of 221 to 212, with two independents. One Democratic congressman has died since the November 7 election.

On January 5 the two houses are scheduled to meet in joint session for what is normally a purely ritual event, at which they receive the results of the electoral college voting, count the votes and declare the winners of the presidential and and vice-presidential races.

This time, things could very easily be different. As each state announces the results of its electoral college voting any one member of the Senate or of the House can raise an objection. If that happens the joint session is brought to an end, and the two houses reconvene in separate session to settle the argument.

According to the constitution, the House then votes on the presidency, while the Senate chooses the vice-president. In the presidential vote in the House, each state casts a single vote, reflecting the balance of that state's representation. In the case of states such as Vermont and Wyoming, which have one congressman each, the solitary congressman would have the vote to himself. In California the one vote would be cast after the state's 54 congressmen and women had voted among themselves.

If each state voted according to its current political balance, Mr Bush would win, since more than 30 of the states have Republican majorities. Such an outcome is not a foregone conclusion, however, because the vote will also depend on the political pressures applied to congressmen as the decision day nears.

If Mr Gore emerges from the new counts with more votes than Mr Bush in Florida, congressional Republicans will face an agonising decision on January 5. Do they cast their presidential votes for their fellow Republican or for the man who won the election? Local considerations will sway many votes.

At least one moderate Republican, Congresswoman Connie Morella of Maryland, whose district voted heavily for Mr Gore on November 7, has already said she would find it difficult to vote for Mr Bush in those circumstances. Conversely, the conservative Mississippi "Blue Dog" Democrat Gene Taylor, whose district voted for Mr Bush, has said he would probably vote for Mr Bush if it came to it. The fluid loyalties of American congressional politics are likely to produce several surprises if the crisis gets that far.

Yet, if the Congress does make the final decisions in the November 2000 election, it is possible that the biggest and most ironic surprise could come in the final outcome. If Republicans in the House succeed in voting Mr Bush in as president, Mr Gore's casting vote in the Senate could simultaneously elect Joe Lieberman as vice-president rather than Mr Bush's running-mate Dick Cheney.

In that case, the presidential election of 2004 could be an unprecedented contest all of its own, with the sitting president Mr Bush facing a challenge from his own sitting vice-president Mr Lieberman.

fields.headline: Talking heads
fields.standfirst: Richard Thackray, managing director of internet bank first-e
fields.trailText: Richard Thackray, managing director of internet bank first-e
fields.body:
When did you first become a manager?

In the Royal Navy 15 years ago. After completing officer training I found myself responsible for 20 sailors.

What has been your best moment in management?

Unquestionably the launch of first-e. No start-up had launched a stand-alone internet bank before.

What was your greatest mistake?

Long ago I ordered 50,000 triangular Toblerones to go into an Easter egg promotion. To this day I can remember the Tesco confectionery buyer saying: "You can't drink from a triangular mug."

Which deal would you most like to have done?

Moses leading his people out of Egypt.

What do you find most annoying in your staff?

A lack of self belief saddens me. The biggest barrier to achievement is lack of self belief.

What management wisdom is most overrated?

I am disenchanted with the ideas-industry generated by the big consulting firms. I know them from the inside because I once worked for Boston Consulting Group, one of the best of the breed.

What will be the big business issue of the next decade?

For the UK I fear it has to be our apparent inability to produce either a cadre of competent managers or some outstanding business leaders.

What one lesson would you pass on to budding managers?

Never to be afraid of failure if you act with integrity.

Which management guru do you believe in?

General Electric's Jack Welch.

What is your view on British membership of EMU ?

It may well be expedient for some countries to stay outside for the time being. However, the reality is more a "when" than an "if" and we should prepare for this.

Who is your favourite politician ?

It would have to be Disraeli for his brilliance and wit.

What phrase or saying do you most overuse?

I'm sure I suffer from the abuse of one word, but you'd have to ask my friends and colleagues.

Apart from your family, what else makes you happiest in life?

A great book. I recommend Patrick O'Brian's novels.

What annoys you most?

Politicians, bad service and intelligent people being incompetent.

What was your last cultural experience?

I keep going back to the Tate Modern.

What is your favourite city?

Sydney holds many marvellous memories for me. And New York is also one amazing place.

Do you have a favourite website?

There is a deli in Milan called Peck reflects the physical experience. For Christmas I recommend a kilo of the finest parmigiano reggiano for only £16.

What would you really like to have been?

A submarine commander in the Royal Navy.

Long ago I ordered 50,000 triangular Toblerones to go into an Easter egg promotion. To this day I can remember the Tesco confectionery buyer saying: "You can't drink from a triangular mug." Which deal would you most like to have done? Moses leading his people out of Egypt. What do you find most annoying in your staff? A lack of self belief saddens me. The biggest barrier to achievement is lack of self belief. What management wisdom is most overrated? I am disenchanted with the ideas-industry generated by the big consulting firms. I know them from the inside because I once worked for Boston Consulting Group, one of the best of the breed. What will be the big business issue of the next decade? For the UK I fear it has to be our apparent inability to produce either a cadre of competent managers or some outstanding business leaders. What one lesson would you pass on to budding managers? Never to be afraid of failure if you act with integrity. Which management guru do you believe in? General Electric's Jack Welch. What is your view on British membership of EMU ? It may well be expedient for some countries to stay outside for the time being. However, the reality is more a "when" than an "if" and we should prepare for this. Who is your favourite politician ? It would have to be Disraeli for his brilliance and wit. What phrase or saying do you most overuse? I'm sure I suffer from the abuse of one word, but you'd have to ask my friends and colleagues. Apart from your family, what else makes you happiest in life? A great book. I recommend Patrick O'Brian's novels. What annoys you most? Politicians, bad service and intelligent people being incompetent. What was your last cultural experience? I keep going back to the Tate Modern. What is your favourite city? Sydney holds many marvellous memories for me. And New York is also one amazing place. Do you have a favourite website? There is a deli in Milan called Peck reflects the physical experience. For Christmas I recommend a kilo of the finest parmigiano reggiano for only £16. What would you really like to have been? A submarine commander in the Royal Navy.

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Cheers and jeers

fields.headline: Cheers and jeers
fields.trailText: This week's three cheers go to           Aston Martin for its plans to base the production site of its third model in  Gaydon, south Warwickshire. Proposals to install an operations site for the luxury car have been approved, creating up to 400 jobs.
fields.body:
This week's three cheers go to Aston Martin for its plans to base the production site of its third model in Gaydon, south Warwickshire. Proposals to install an operations site for the luxury car have been approved, creating up to 400 jobs.

Applause for mobile phone company Caudwell which is creating more than 1,000 jobs next year by opening over 200 of its Phones 4u shops. The privately-owned group, which currently has 99 shops will open new outlets across England and Wales.

Cheers, too, for Wireless Systems International which announced 264 skilled jobs at a new factory making power amplifiers for the mobile telecommunications industry. The electronics firm is embarking on a five-year £17.1m investment at Llantarnam Park in Cwmbran, south Wales.

Praises for GlaxoSmith-Kline, which was named as Britain's most admired company, by Management Today magazine. The company, which hasn't been cleared by regulators and technically doesn't yet exist, was chosen by its peers.

Finally, Sir John Browne, the chief executive of BP was singled out as Britain's most admired business leader, for the second year running.

Ear -splitting jeers for British Airways which is cutting 1,000 jobs over the next two years in a major restructuring of its operations out of Gatwick airport. The airline plans to reduce longhaul flights out of Gatwick from 43 to around 25.

Jeers for Corus the steel giant where two top executives, John Bryant and Fokko van Duyne dramatically resigned this week, fuelling fears of a fresh wave of job losses in the New Year.

The company, formerly British Steel, has written to workers in its Long Products division in the past few weeks saying it had not received enough volunteers to leave the firm. The joint chief executives will leave immediately and warned that further "major restructuring" was inevitable.

Time to boycott bananas for Christmas in a gesture of solidarity with workers at Fyffes which is to shed 200 jobs as part of an overhaul of its subsidiary Geest Bananas. It will close UK banana ripening centres, in Chippenham in Wiltshire, Blaby in Leicestershire and Clyde Valley, Scotland.

Lastly, the Scrooge of the week award goes to Britain's biggest cable TV company ntl, where the bosses have informed staff that the firm will not be paying for office parties this year.

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Tony Allan's big break

fields.headline: He's hooked for life
fields.standfirst: Tony Allan
fields.trailText: Tony Allan
fields.body:
You could probably count on the bars of a prison cell window the number of men who have gone from stealing lead off a school roof to entrepreneur of the year in less than two decades.

Yet, Tony Allan has achieved just that. Rather than spending time doing porridge, he often rises to check out the wares at Billingsgate fish market at an hour when John Humphrys and the rest of the Today team are still in bed.

Black Rod, or some such fellow, often calls him at an ungodly hour to see if something nice showed up for 150 or so MPs to have for lunch in the House. Fish are his life.

Back in his office, buried in the backstreets of London's Dickensian Borough district, the 36-year-old cuts a charismatic figure, in his cowboy boots and baseball cap worn Yogi Berra style. One can see, dimly, the boy ready for anything in his schooldays in Sidcup secondary modern.

"I was always bright," he says, "in the top stream but mischievous. I was a little sod but not bad enough to attract the law. When I was asked to leave, I thought I'd relieve the school of its lead flashing. Nowadays, you'd call me a fairly normal student. My builder father thought I was Einstein."

Next came South London Tec for a cookery course ("mum was a good cook") which he hated but brought a real break. A teacher told him to clear off "because I was a waste of space to myself and to the college. I was going to say not to worry I was off, when I did the other and said to myself, I'll show 'em.

"Then, next thing they knew, I came out top boy and won a chance to learn in Claridges' kitchen. I really thought I had arrived. I now realise what a great grounding I received. It gave me a wonderful start."

Then, as head chef at 20 at City restaurant, Salter's Court, he was fired for always complaining about the quality of the fish it was serving. "It was crap and we were only 50 miles from the sea, so they got fed up with my moaning and I was out on the street." His girlfriend of just three weeks (Denys, now his wife of 15 years), proved another break when he decided to take the fishmonger route. He asked her father, he'd only just met, for £400 to buy a van. Driving to Hastings in the early hours, he bought fish at auction.

Later in the day, he was cold-calling restaurants, as well as chefs he knew, to sell the fish for cash. The posh restaurants wanted credit and time to pay. The fish was so fresh, he is fond of saying, that the head chef of one fancy restaurant thought it was frozen.

"I couldn't believe how much money I was making. I paid back Denys' father the same week. In one week, I made £1,200 and got a mortgage on a house in Bexley.

"Now I live in the leafy suburbs of Chislehurst, thanks in part to the level of ignorance in the fish business. There was a real gap in the market for someone, who knew what he was about, to supply fresh fish to the customer's plate via a chef and owner who knew what they wanted."

By 1992, he was turning over £4m a year and the poacher turned gamekeeper was branching out into food preparation, with a salmon smokery. Four years later, he began to dream of a big, modern brasserie selling fish. He found a site, an old bank in London's Aldwych and, with a loan from Barclays, opened the restaurant, called Bank.

"It was a phenomenal success but the skill level of the employees was abysmal," he says. He thinks he has solved that problem with his latest venture, a restaurant simply called Fish!, which takes a small piece of beautifully fresh fish and cooks it simply.

"There was nothing for the public between a high street fish and chip shop and Wheelers," he says. His restaurant group, BGR, is to sell its three Bank and Zander sites and change its name to Fish. Mr Allan believes the growth prospects for the Banks in Birmingham, as well as London, are limited. "The return on capital is nowhere near Fish's," he says.

He sees Pizza Express as the chain to copy. "Ours will be a perfect restaurant, where you can eat three courses with wine for less than £25 a person. If you look at most fish restaurants, they lack atmosphere, the diners are from an older generation and they are expensive," he says.

With six Fish! already up and running, the first in the shadow of Southwark Cathedral, he is very optimistic. "I am now concentrating on Fish! and hoping it's going to be number one on the hit parade," he says.

Based on the story so far, that doesn't seem too fishy a boast.

webTitle: Jobs and Money: From the top

fields.headline: From the top
fields.trailText: The deluge of management books is unceasing. But are they teaching us the right lessons?
fields.body:
The deluge of management books is unceasing. But are they teaching us the right lessons?

They promise to reveal the secrets of being a great change agent. Their prescriptions are usually pretty similar and seem sensible. They tell us successful managers set ambitious goals, build a sense of purpose, trust their people, invest in the future, and so on. They are also alike in tone, favouring the missionary, you-can-do-it style, pioneered by Dale Carnegie's How to Win Friends and Influence People. For example, this month's tome from top guru Gary Hamel exhorts managers to chant: "I am no longer a captive to history. Whatever I can imagine I can accomplish"

But if there is one cause of scepticism, it is how bad these books have been in their choice of paragons. The most famous example of this was the Peters and Waterman book, In Search of Excellence, which triggered the current publishing boom. They carefully chose the 40 firms that had been the most outstanding performers in the past decade and from this sample identified 12 golden rules of management. Unfortunately, a decade later, two-thirds of these excellent companies had gone bankrupt or been taken over.

It is a trap that all these books have fallen into. For decades Peter Drucker held up Marks & Spencer as the world's best managed company. Past books have extolled the greatness of Saatchi & Saatchi, IBM, Hanson, GEC, or, until the recent crash in internet stocks, the virtues of Amazon, Priceline and Lastminute.com. Why is success so fleeting? Why do the gurus get it so wrong?

One problem is that they all ignore luck. Over time, virtually all gamblers lose. However, once in a while, someone will have an amazing streak of luck on the roulette table and win big seven sessions running. But studying how this gambler plans and thinks is completely purposeless - his run of luck is pure chance. So it is with many companies that have had a run of success. Often there is little to be learned, because as with M&S, their luck will run out tomorrow.

But there are also more fundamental reasons why success normally soon goes sour. Companies achieve outstanding growth and profits when their assets exactly match the requirements of the market. But as technology changes the environment, the firm's assets cease to match and earn a return. In fact these assets can easily become liabilities.

Even when change is less dramatic, competitors copy and eat away at a leader's advantage. Studies show that the normal maximum time a firm keeps an advantage that enables it to earn a return above its cost of capital is seven years. So even when companies survive long term, such as Pilkington or ICI, their returns generally deteriorate. Investors would have done better getting their money out.

What does all this mean? The cause of corporate failure is not always due to poor management. Firms fail when their luck runs out or when environmental change and competition erode the value of their assets. The guru guides that say managers can achieve radical change are creating a damaging myth. As BT has belatedly recognised, in times of great change, managers are better off squeezing cash out of their mature businesses and splitting off their growth businesses for others to develop.

A gung-ho belief that managers can take companies into leadership positions in different, mutually-conflicting markets is not one on which to bet.

 Peter Doyle is professor of marketing at Warwick University and the author of Value-Based Marketing, published by Wiley.
P.Doyle@warwick.ac.uk

webTitle: Jobs and Money: The Army as manager

fields.headline: Managers fall in to learn how to lead
fields.standfirst: The Army can teach industry a thing or two, Eileen Sheridan reports
fields.trailText: The Army can teach industry a thing or two, Eileen Sheridan reports.
fields.body:
Executives in Civvy Street might find it hard to believe, but the Army can teach them a thing or two about leadership.

And now a partnership between the Royal Military Academy at Sandhurst and civilian specialists MaST Inspirational Development is offering unique training courses to British managers.

The idea came when the Cabinet office expressed concern that lack of leadership was hindering the country's commercial success. So the government did what governments do in a crisis - call in the troops. The Army, with a 200-year history of training leaders and developing teamwork, was seen to have something to offer company bosses.

Since the launch of a pilot scheme in October the response has been so overwhelming that a longer term partnership is planned.

RMA spokesman Major Harry Emck, OBE, says: "The Army's training is focused on experience. What you learn has to be put into practice in short order. If people are out with a few logs and a bit of rope and they have to get across a 'mined area' it does amazing things to their thinking."

But the courses are not all about gung-ho machismo, and they're not boot camps either.

What the Army has developed over two centuries is an effective chain of command, so that information is passed seamlessly down the line, everybody has a role and everybody knows what their role is and what the ultimate goal is.

Rick Chattell MBE, project manager for MaST and a former Sandhurst cadet himself, says the Army is very good at what it calls processes.

"If a general issues an order it goes right down to the private who knows the circumstances and what to do with this piece of equipment. It's like a stick of rock with the same word all the way through. Companies are more efficient if they use such processes."

The trouble is, in most corporations the executive echelons feed their insecurities by not sharing their overall strategy with the foot soldiers. This leaves the workforce fumbling and provides the management team with ready made scapegoats should things go awry.

The MaST Inspirational Development courses start in the classroom where the styles, strengths and weaknesses of different leadership techniques are examined and the theories of inspirational leadership developed by MaST.

"It is about inspiring yourself and others to succeed," explains Mr Chattell.

The template for success is built on leadership which involves strategic thinking and having a vision; followership which is about delegation and empowering others to build a team; and partnership which creates co-operation and cross boundary team working.

Delegates also learn to think about what makes them and other people tick and analysing the different roles in a team.

Then it's out on command tasks with intriguing titles such as "bomb disposal", "ravine crossing" and "magic carpet". These create a level playing field, says Mr Chattell, unlike a corporate situation where managers are able to use their position to mask their inadequacies .

"At Sandhurst, they can't hide behind their rank and the skills of an individual are immediately apparent," he adds.

"Understanding leadership theory is important, but experience of putting it into practice in a safe environment is vital."

Delegates complete a personal action plan to use those lessons learned and can later attend a follow-up session to see how things have worked out and what new plans can be made.

The first managers on the course came from investment bank UBS Warburg. Shaun Collier, project director for the 40 strong IT team, wanted to boost morale before a multi-million dollar change programme was initiated .

"The mix of theory and practical exercises offered at Sandhurst seemed to be what was required," he says. "All activities were completed successfully and the sense of achievement and team constitution was remarkable by the end of the day. The team was on a high and so relished the opportunity to attempt Sandhurst's infamous assault course."

Since their Sandhurst experience, says Mr Collier, the team has a greater appreciation of its' own constitution and the need for complementary skills.

"The team wants to go back. They still talk about it today."

For details of MaST Inspirational Development Courses, tel RMA Sandhurst 01276 412240.

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Direct sales revamped

fields.headline: Extra polish on the doorstep
fields.standfirst: Forget the image of an old-style conman with his foot in your door, today's 'direct sales' staff are well trained and highly motivated. And, reports Liz Stuart, unlikely companies want new recruits who can master the technique
fields.trailText: Forget the image of an old-style conman with his foot in your door, today's 'direct sales' staff are well trained and highly motivated. And, reports Liz Stuart, unlikely companies want new recruits who can master the technique.
fields.body:
Selling products door to door has long been a career in need of a promotional makeover. The very phrase conjures up images of the salesman with his foot in the door, persuading confused people to sign up for services they neither want nor understand.

But US phone company ETI, which launched in the UK last month, claims that direct sales is changing. In North America, a small but growing proportion of its representatives are younger people who view their sales job as an entrepreneurial opportunity, giving them autonomy to dictate their own lifestyle and salary. "We even have people on our books who have given up jobs as doctors and lawyers to sell our service, rather than seeing it as a mere "supplemental income opportunity", claims ETI chief executive Christina Gold.

But does she think it paradoxical that a contemporary company selling in the relatively modern field of a deregulated telecoms market should choose such an atavistic method of vending: wireless communications being sold in the same way as 19th-century insurance policies?

"The representatives are the heart and soul of our business," Ms Gold says. "They are often selling to friends and family and so they would hardly be pushing a service they did not believe in if they were going to see their customer later that night over the dinner table. They have the confidence that the service they are selling is a good one and they like to mention the fact that we are backed by IBM because it is a name that people have heard of and trust."

Ms Gold, whose background is with Avon, will not reveal what the average ETI salesperson is taking home - "I am not allowed to tell you under US law," she says - but does admit that "this is not a get rich quick business: it's up to you to make it happen."

In the UK, prospective representatives must pay £99 for a start-up pack and a two-hour face-to-face training programme. This is returned once the individual has signed up 10 customers.

After that the commission is tiered according to the frequency and type of calls the customer is making: £10 for an acquisition, 1% on every internet or local call, 5% on national and international ones. In the US, up to 20% of salespeople do it full time. ETI is looking to expand into wireless communications and e-commerce and the aim is to quadruple customer spend every year by cross-selling these other, more sophisticated, products.

Other new entrant phone company's use similar tactics. Euphony also has American roots and retains a small army of people who sell the firm's services in return for a commission. The firm's sales staff are from all walks of life and trumpet the benefits of working from home and managing their own time.

"We were so impressed [with the service], we ended up joining the company as independent consultants," says Sally Keddie. "Jim, my husband, being in his late 40s, had suffered from the modern disease called 'corporate downsizing' and when we were given the opportunity to save on our phone bill, we looked further into the company and found that they create an opening that allows people to have their own telecoms business, working from home and at your own pace."

Cooperative Insurance Services sells unit trusts, life insurance, pensions and car and household insurance solely through its 4,500 home sales agents. The role of its agents has changed hugely in the past 10 years - in the early nineties they carried around reams of paper and filled in customer payment books rather than their laptops of today, and the company is currently overhauling the service its salespeople offer the customer: "We are taking home service to another level in 2001 to recognise it as a skilled profession rather than a job," says Charles McKeown, general manager of the CIS sales and service areas.

The average age of a new CIS sales recruit is 32 and increasing numbers of these are women - 9.4% of those taken on since 1999 are female against the sales force overall, of which just 4% are women - counteracting the traditional image of financial services as being a men only area. The average length of time with the CIS is 10 years and all of the sales force work full-time. The salaries are good: basic plus commission on existing policies, plus a 30% bonus for introducing an average of one new policy a week, is £30,000 and Mr McKeown says that one or two are grossing more than £100,000 a year.

There are now more than 500,000 people selling door-to-door for 100 companies. In the past three years of the 1990s, annual sales increased by 40% to £1.36bn, according to the Direct Selling Association. In 1998, 113 direct selling businesses accounted for 90% of total sales.

The market is still very much dominated by cosmetics, cleaning products and kitchenware companies, which pay low levels of commission to the salesperson. Two out of three direct salespeople are women with children, and working part-time. "There is a nascent trend towards people selling full-time but still a lot of people have very modest earnings and don't wish to devote more than a couple of hours a day to it. No company would advise anyone to immediately give up their job to sell door-to-door," says director of the DSA, Richard Berry.

But he adds that increasingly people are setting up their own sales teams under the organisational auspices of their employer, using the experience and support of the company. "More than half the companies selling directly allow people their own sales group and then outsource the field sales to them," he says.

The image of the business might have been helped with the introduction of a consumer bill designed by the department of trade and industry to clamp down on rogue traders, but earlier this month it emerged that the bill was unlikely to squeeze into the government's legislative programme. And, sure enough on Wednesday, it failed to appear in the Queen's Speech.

The Consumers' Association says the decision to delay the bill will be "hugely disappointing" for consumers. Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers made some amends for the loss of his bill when he announced alternative measures to be introduced in the new year, including provisions for "stop now" orders. He said that one of the specific target groups of the policy were rogue doorstop sellers and the orders are an attempt to permanently prevent people from selling in illegal ways. "Failure to comply with a 'stop now' order will be treated as a contempt in court and can be punished by a fine or imprisonment," he said.

Alison Williams chairs the Field Marketing Council, part of the DSA, and is also group MD of FDS Marketing, which provides the salesforce for a portfolio of clients such as Yorkshire Electricity. "Field marketing grew out of ladies hosting Tupperware parties but has now moved on to supplying salesforces in their entirety or supplementing those of the blue chips and utilities."

She acknowledges that the industry's poor reputation has been an accurate one in the past, saying that on deregulation of the utilities, many former double-glazing salesmen were taken on without proper training. "They did not understand that they were custodians of the client's brand," she says.

She adds that each person in her sales teams has signed up to a code of practice, sells the products or services of just one client and that everyone is trained for two days. At least one in 10 visits is audited for customer satisfaction.

Her most junior employee will take home around £25,000, about half of which is commission. Some 60% of the work is selling utilities and the salespeople will cold call. There is also a career structure through which a salesperson can go on to be a team leader, area controller and finally field sales manager. "I know selling like this has had a bad reputation in the past, but we see it as a proper career," she says.

When the personal is what's wanted

Alan Ellwood has been a CIS salesman for 15 years, covering the Islington area of London. A number of his clients are professionals who nevertheless want someone to come to their home and explain precisely how financial products work.

"One of my clients is a director of the Royal Society of Arts and several others are doctors. They are busy people and they find it convenient that I come to see them in the evening in their home. They like the personal touch and many of them do not want to go into a bank or building society branch.

Although this is an age-old business it is also very modern in the way that I customise what I provide to the client's needs. I think that a lot of companies who have got out of the industrial branch business (selling insurance to people in their homes) may regret that decision in the future." He adds that his client base grows rapidly as his customers recommend him to others: "There is a good living to be earned doing this.

And as there are fewer people selling financial services in this way, because since the Financial Services Act of 1988 you have to be qualified to do so, there is a larger slice of the market for each person."

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Richard Colbey on buying units

fields.headline: Refusing to play by their rules
fields.standfirst: Richard Colbey took a stand over a demand to buy his units. So, where did it get him?
fields.trailText: Richard Colbey took a stand over a demand to buy his units. So, where did it get him?
fields.body:
The launch of Kleinwort Benson's European Privatisation Trust in 1994 was not an event that set the financial world ablaze. However, for reasons that I cannot now recall, I did buy some units in it.

It had, in the words of a spokeswoman for Dresdner Investments which has inherited it, a "chequered history". I have received occasional cheques which amount to about what my units cost me. Once I realised that it was not the investment that would have me retiring to the sun, I pushed its existence to the back of my mind.

Its recent annual distributions have been for 58p. Therefore I should, perhaps, have been pleased to receive a letter announcing my holding was worth £121 and, unless I cared to buy more units to increase it to £250, it would be bought up by the company whether I liked it or not.

Regular readers will appreciate I am not someone who goes out of his way to make life easy for financial institutions. So I replied, asking the basis on which Dresdner could force me to sell something I might want to retain. Its reply, that its rules enabled it to do this, I thought missed the point. Why was I bound by those rules? Had I entered into any agreement with the company that adopted those rules? If so, it would have to show a contractual provision that enabled it to rely on them.

Just to throw a spanner in the works, I added that I would agree to sell the units for £600. At that point Dresdner, which answered letters with commendable promptness and courtesy, gave in and said I could keep the units if I wanted.

I did still try to pursue the question of how they could ever have been entitled to force me to sell. The best they could answer was that the regulator, Imro, was aware of it and had not blocked it. However, even after extensive inquiries, the spokes woman could not establish any legal justification for the action.

This type of approach by companies is far from unique. Compulsory acquisitions such as this are a grey area. Where it involves shares, rather than unit trusts, the law - governed by the Companies Act - is even more complex.

Those wanting to take a principled stand will probably find that the company gives in, as Dresdner did with me. One problem remains from taking such a stand though - my principles have left me stuck with £121 worth of useless unit trusts. Any offers?

 Richard Colbey is a barrister.

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Global Asset Management

fields.headline: The universe is in safe hands
fields.standfirst: This week Tony Levene turns the spotlight on GAM - one year after it was taken over by UBS
fields.trailText: This week Tony Levene turns the spotlight on GAM - one year after it was taken over by UBS.
fields.body:
GAM - isn't that a much criticised life insurance company?

No. That's GAN. And it's nothing to do with the freakrock band GAM from Savannah, Georgia, which claims it is out to save nothing less than the universe from the mind-numbing sameness and blandness of conspiracy entertainment.

So what's this GAM?

It stands for Global Asset Management. And, on second thoughts, it shares a link with the band. It claims it is out to save the universe from the blandness of conspiracy fund management.

How does it do that?

It goes out, hires talent and lets them get on with it.

Where did it come from?

It was the brainchild of former Rothschild chief Gilbert de Botton.

Didn't he write The Romantic Movement and How Proust Can Change Your Life?

No. That was his son Alain. Gilbert de Botton sadly died in August.

What was Gilbert's madeleine dunking moment?

Back in 1983, he realised that fund management companies all claimed to employ the best talent. Relying on his remembrance of times past, he knew that could not be true. So he set up GAM, and was prepared to hire good managers from outside. Housing some in 18th century opulence in St James's also helped.

Was that all?

No. He also recalled that, in the past, fund managers managed funds, rather than spend time on marketing and administration. So he hit upon a horses for courses strategy. He sold out to UBS in December 1999 for £450m.

How much is managed?

Just over £8.6bn - some £7.5bn is offshore with the balance in regulated OEICs and unit trusts in the UK or Dublin. The money is all invested in similar funds whether for individuals or institutions.

What do IFAs think of it?

Most don't. It's very upmarket - the St James's location for starters - and certainly not aimed at the run of the mill IFA who sells a few Isas among the mortgages, endowments and pension plans or at mailshot specialists. But it has a good following among the small band of investment specialists, private banks and boutiques.

What's on offer?

Three global funds, two North American trusts, five in the Far East, three in Europe and two in the UK are easily available in Britain. There are no plans for new funds. But there's a far bigger range offshore including hedge funds which can be accessed for around £3,500 upwards. Hedge funds, it is claimed, attract top managers and can make money whether share prices are rising or falling.

Where offshore - and how do I buy them?

They're based in the British Virgin Islands so publicity is banned - not even a phone number or address. But the hedge funds such as GAM Diversity, GAM World Multi-Fund or GAM Trading can be accessed through specialist financial advisers.

Is there a GAM style?

Only having no style. The whole philosophy is to free managers from restraints such as lists of core holdings, investment committees, value or growth decisions or volatility. Everyone pursues an active policy rather than track funds. Beyond that, each fund manager has different methods - some are stock pickers, others aim at themes or macro-economic overlays. The only constraint is a low risk profile.

Are there GAM chart toppers?

Rarely. The de Botton theory was to underperform in bull markets while outperforming in bear markets to boost overall return. The emphasis is on the long term.

What about star managers?

None. But they are all very experienced - only 14 are on the inhouse rota, a further 20 are employed elsewhere and hired on a long term basis.

What's the GAM tip?

Buy Japan. The tech fallout is good for Tokyo while six consecutive three month periods of rising profits in a flat economy shows that the Japanese are sorting out their industry.

Is there a website?

Gam.com - it features daily updates on top holdings in each fund.

What's the unique selling proposition?

"Access to the best investment talent worldwide."

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Careful investing is vital

fields.headline: Season of doom and gloom
fields.standfirst: Careful investing is more vital than ever, with optimism little in evidence and only faint hopes of economic growth, says Robin Stoddart
fields.trailText: Careful investing is more vital than ever, with optimism little in evidence and only faint hopes of economic growth, says Robin Stoddart.
fields.body:
Change, coupled with a good deal of decay, is certainly the scene on share markets, though the brief rebound sparked by Wall Street shows that hopes of technology-led economic growth remain. Beyond the main financial centres, conflict, disease and mismanagement abound. Optimism is not universal, so investment selection is ever more important.

Trend followers, including index trackers, are seeing some old faithfuls back in the top 100 FTSE index. They include survivors in the engineering sector, primarily in aerospace, on the necessary global basis. Heavy industry is conspicuous by its absence and consumer issues are a mixed bunch. Displaced technology issues are relatively tiny in turnover and employment terms and projections of sales and profits were often far-fetched.

One change that has been obscured by political preoccupations on both sides of the Atlantic and concern in many countries where whiffs of corruption understandably scare investors away, is the recovery in the euro. Its improvement against the dollar may not constitute a trend yet, but, against the pound, it should be a steady bet if the Nice meeting is cordial and expansive.

Forecasts of exchange rate changes are even less reliable than estimates of economic growth, but many continental countries appear set fair on a course of economic advance, whereas the UK is throwing up some serious imbalances and shortcomings.

In any event, the inflow into sterling through acquisitions can hardly continue at anything like the recent rate. Investment in productivity and some easing of consumer spending and borrowing is needed in 2001 if prosperity is to be maintained and extended in a population that the forthcoming census may show to be well over 60m. Electoral factors may have more of an impact than the polls and fairly benign domestic economic statistics suggest at present.

With a much larger area and similar, though flat, population, France has done exceptionally well to maintain its status as both a high-living and technologically advanced country. Neither wholesale withdrawal from industrial sectors nor cherry picking by foreign enterprises has been tolerated, unlike the free-for-all on this side of the Channel.

Contrasts in the transport sector could hardly be more acute and they extend to many products and services on a larger time-scale. Admittedly, it was French controlling interests in Sema, the software group, that take the main responsibility for one of the worst of the recent technology share price collapses. There are few foreign leaders of French industry and UK acquisitions, such as Freeserve, and De La Rue's smart card activities testify to the native drive.

A spread of European investments, taking in Scandinavian companies and Switzerland, outside the euro zone would have provided the best investment even in recent weeks, when losses were widespread and sometimes heavy. Among the larger funds, Fidelity's European units and in vestment trust shares held their own well during the worst of the rout. Investment trust dips were sometimes absorbed by a reduction in the discount on underlying value. Holdings in media shares, including newspaper publishers, were bolstered by reports of high advertising revenues.

Nevertheless, as in most larger European funds, telecom issues provided a major part of realised gains. Northern Europe has generally been preferred to the Mediterranean countries, but France, along with Scandinavia, is the largest investment area - well ahead of Germany.

This week's 10% rally in the share price of Nokia, Finland's mobile phones group that rated as Europe's most highly valued company until the tripled oil price boosted that sector a few months ago, has boosted many, even most, of the specialist European funds. France's Alcatel would have been a still better bet over the past year, though its following is smaller outside the US.

Over six months, Fidelity European Values shares were the tops with a gain of 13% and, over 12, a near-60% advance was recorded. Henderson Eurotrust managed a small further rise, taking the year's gain above half. Charter European, more of a blue-chip fund with telecommunications and oils prominent, suffered badly during the autumn shakeout, hit by BT's slide, but it has a solid record over the years.

Both Gartmore and Perpetual lost ground with the euro and Spanish and Italian markets. Deutsche, Cazenove and the newer Jupiter European Special Situations and revived Prudential European units have done well for investors. But other insurers, including Equitable, Scottish Mutual and M&G, have never featured among the better performers.

Specialists in smaller companies stand out as European and global winners, in spite of the autumn bad patch. Fleming European Fledgling has still more than doubled over a year, without the shares taking on a risky premium on assets. TR European Growth is up by over half, with Invesco Continental Smaller Companies somewhere in between.

A weak pound and recovering euro would make most of these funds attractive for UK investors. Even during the seasonal fall on Wall Street, the strong dollar was a shield and hiding place.

Investing made easier

Investing for a regular, high - and hopefully secure - income is one of the toughest tasks facing savers.

But the Guardian Jobs & Money team is making the task easier. We're about to publish a new guide, Investing for Income, which explains the plus points and pitfalls of plans on the market.

It's free. To pre-order your copy phone 0870 90 90 268.

They include survivors in the engineering sector, primarily in aerospace, on the necessary global basis. Heavy industry is conspicuous by its absence and consumer issues are a mixed bunch. Displaced technology issues are relatively tiny in turnover and employment terms and projections of sales and profits were often far-fetched. One change that has been obscured by political preoccupations on both sides of the Atlantic and concern in many countries where whiffs of corruption understandably scare investors away, is the recovery in the euro. Its improvement against the dollar may not constitute a trend yet, but, against the pound, it should be a steady bet if the Nice meeting is cordial and expansive. Forecasts of exchange rate changes are even less reliable than estimates of economic growth, but many continental countries appear set fair on a course of economic advance, whereas the UK is throwing up some serious imbalances and shortcomings. In any event, the inflow into sterling through acquisitions can hardly continue at anything like the recent rate. Investment in productivity and some easing of consumer spending and borrowing is needed in 2001 if prosperity is to be maintained and extended in a population that the forthcoming census may show to be well over 60m. Electoral factors may have more of an impact than the polls and fairly benign domestic economic statistics suggest at present. With a much larger area and similar, though flat, population, France has done exceptionally well to maintain its status as both a high-living and technologically advanced country. Neither wholesale withdrawal from industrial sectors nor cherry picking by foreign enterprises has been tolerated, unlike the free-for-all on this side of the Channel. Contrasts in the transport sector could hardly be more acute and they extend to many products and services on a larger time-scale. Admittedly, it was French controlling interests in Sema, the software group, that take the main responsibility for one of the worst of the recent technology share price collapses. There are few foreign leaders of French industry and UK acquisitions, such as Freeserve, and De La Rue's smart card activities testify to the native drive. A spread of European investments, taking in Scandinavian companies and Switzerland, outside the euro zone would have provided the best investment even in recent weeks, when losses were widespread and sometimes heavy. Among the larger funds, Fidelity's European units and in vestment trust shares held their own well during the worst of the rout. Investment trust dips were sometimes absorbed by a reduction in the discount on underlying value. Holdings in media shares, including newspaper publishers, were bolstered by reports of high advertising revenues. Nevertheless, as in most larger European funds, telecom issues provided a major part of realised gains. Northern Europe has generally been preferred to the Mediterranean countries, but France, along with Scandinavia, is the largest investment area - well ahead of Germany. This week's 10% rally in the share price of Nokia, Finland's mobile phones group that rated as Europe's most highly valued company until the tripled oil price boosted that sector a few months ago, has boosted many, even most, of the specialist European funds. France's Alcatel would have been a still better bet over the past year, though its following is smaller outside the US. Over six months, Fidelity European Values shares were the tops with a gain of 13% and, over 12, a near-60% advance was recorded. Henderson Eurotrust managed a small further rise, taking the year's gain above half. Charter European, more of a blue-chip fund with telecommunications and oils prominent, suffered badly during the autumn shakeout, hit by BT's slide, but it has a solid record over the years. Both Gartmore and Perpetual lost ground with the euro and Spanish and Italian markets. Deutsche, Cazenove and the newer Jupiter European Special Situations and revived Prudential European units have done well for investors. But other insurers, including Equitable, Scottish Mutual and M&G, have never featured among the better performers. Specialists in smaller companies stand out as European and global winners, in spite of the autumn bad patch. Fleming European Fledgling has still more than doubled over a year, without the shares taking on a risky premium on assets. TR European Growth is up by over half, with Invesco Continental Smaller Companies somewhere in between. A weak pound and recovering euro would make most of these funds attractive for UK investors. Even during the seasonal fall on Wall Street, the strong dollar was a shield and hiding place. Investing made easier Investing for a regular, high - and hopefully secure - income is one of the toughest tasks facing savers. But the Guardian Jobs & Money team is making the task easier. We're about to publish a new guide, Investing for Income, which explains the plus points and pitfalls of plans on the market. It's free. To pre-order your copy phone 0870 90 90 268.

fields.headline: Big stakes on the wheels of fortune
fields.standfirst: Got £10m to speculate? Then get into gear and join the high rollers who invest in historic cars, suggests Stewart Dalby
fields.trailText: Got £10m to speculate? Then get into gear and join the high rollers who invest in historic cars, suggests Stewart Dalby.
fields.body:
I've heard of inflation in alternative investments but this is ridiculous. A Ferrari 250 GTO that came second in Le Mans in 1973 is expected to fetch $10m, about £7m, when it comes to Bonhams & Brooks sale of Historic Motor Cars and Automobilia at the Palace Hotel Gstaad, Switzerland on Tuesday December 19.

Okay it is a special car. One of only 39 made, chassis 4293 GTI, this 1963 3-litre Ferrari 250 GTO Berlinetta Competizione not only won the vital GT category at Le Mans, but also finished second overall in the world famous French 24-hour classic race

Enzo Ferrari always rated victory in the Le Mans Grand Touring category higher than the Formula 1 World Championship itself, apparently, so the 4293 GTI became his favourite.

Even so, this seems a heck of a price to pay for one car. Another Ferrari in the sale, the 275 GTB, one of six built in 1965, is on offer at around £100,000.

Moreover, as Simon Kidston, the specialist at Bonhams & Brooks who is organising the Gstaad sale, says: "By the end of the 60s the 250 GTO was selling for under the £6,000 it cost when new."

If prices for Ferraris had been on an unbroken vertiginously rising curve since the 60s, then to have picked up a Ferrari in the 60s would have been a very good investment indeed. Mr Kidston says he knows a man who bought two 250 GTOs in the late sixties for £6,000 each. "He sold one for £10.5m in 1990, and kept the other. He was a very happy man," Kidston says.

However, like other classic cars, Ferraris have been one of the biggest roller-coasters of all alternative investments - if viewed as such. Prices began to take off in the 70s when classic car road racing really got going. They rose steadily and then in the 80s were swept up in a speculative frenzy.

Clubs and syndicates bought them purely as investments. Many cars were stored and never driven at all. It has been estimated that 80% of all classic car purchases in the 80s were by speculators. The bubble burst in 1990 with the recession of the late 80s.

Mr Kidston says: "By the mid-1990s the price of a 250 GTO had dropped to £3m, if you call that a collapse." Ferraris are top of the range and the most expensive, but the phenomenon of boom and bust is common to other collected classic sports cars. Other marques sought by enthusiasts include Aston Martin, Rolls-Royce, Bentley, Jaguar, MG, Porsche and Austin-Healey.

Generally, but not invariably, it is post second world war models which are the most highly prized. This is because, unlike in the 80s, buyers now want cars they can drive. Until recently, enthusiasts were interested in vintage cars from earlier this century, but are less so now it seems.

An auction last weekend, also held by Bonhams & Brooks, at London's Olympia, made the point about prices. Part of a three-day (December 2 to 4) extravaganza of motorcycles, toys and models, automobilia, aeronautica formula 1 and collectors cars, the classic car section collect had a wide range of models on offer.

These ranged from a 1904 Turner Miesse 10hp steam car, estimated at £ 50,000 to £70,000, to a 1974 Rolls-Royce Camargue two-door saloon priced at £17,000 to £21,000.

A very popular car when it was produced and today is the Jaguar E-Type. Prices here give an idea of the trend since 1990. A 1974 Jaguar E-Type V-12 Series was on offer at £24,000 to £26,000. Rebecca Ruff at Bonhams & Brooks reckons at the height of the boom this model would have sold for at least £60,000.

The pattern is repeated at the cheaper end of the sports car market. Richard Ladds, at the MG Owners Club, says that an MGB roadster made in the late 70s would probably have cost a few thousand, rose to around £15,000 during the boom and has fallen back to something like £10,000 now.

The overall picture is that although across the range classic cars have not, and seem unlikely to, reach the inflated prices of the late 80s, there is again a steady market for cars with prices rising solidly. Mr Kidston says that now it is people in their 30s and upwards who want cars to drive on the roads. They are more discerning than during the speculative times. "We are no longer invoicing cars to leasing companies," he says.

For further information telephone Bonhams & Brooks (020 7393 3900), Simon Kidston Bonhams & Brooks Europe 00 41 22 300 3160 and MG Owners Club 01954 231125.

fields.headline: Cash 18 - 30
fields.standfirst: In the clinic: James Chadney
fields.trailText: In the clinic: James Chadney
fields.body:
The facts

When James Chadney is working, he is very well paid. But like an increasing number of people working in new media, he is not in regular employment, opting instead for short term contracts - and he has just returned from a year spent travelling around the world.

Now the 28-year-old freelance web designer wants to buy a house with his girlfriend, and his irregular employment pattern is starting to present problems.

"I am currently earning the equivalent of £50,000 a year, but I generally work on two-month projects, and at the moment I have nothing lined up for next year, although I am 75% sure that my current project will generate more work.

"My girlfriend has also been temping since we got back to the UK from travelling five months ago." Before travelling he had worked for three and a half years as a graduate trainee sales manager.

He says they would like to buy a home in Oxford, where they rent a two-bedroomed property.

"To buy the kind of house were are renting now would cost £200-250,000. Realistically, for what we want, we would be looking at an asking price of around £100-£125,000. What advice can you give us for getting on the housing ladder?"

He adds that he has £3,500 invested in a Pep and his girlfriend has £5,000 in a post office savings account.

"So far I've used Lloyds for all my financial services, but from what I've read in your money section, I think I may get more reward from an internet-only savings account.

"To put together a deposit and get a mortgage, I don't really know where to start," he says.

The solution

It sounds harsh but if James wants a home, then he must start some serious saving. Buying a property is not cheap as a deposit and fees (stamp duty, solicitor's fees etc) will be needed, as well as the costs of buying furniture and, possibly, doing some renovation work.

The mortgage could be tricky. James says he does not yet have any contracts sorted out for next year and no job security. Most lenders will want to see three years' worth of regular earnings.

There are lenders who would provide a mortgage on a non-status/self-certification basis, but they require larger deposits, which might be a problem for him and his girlfriend. Halifax, for instance, offers a self-certification product (which means, quite simply, that you do not need any proof of income - you guarantee yourself that you will be able to pay), requiring a deposit of 35%, although some other lenders on the market will go down to 25%.

Otherwise, his best bet would be to apply when they are both on contract, although James will also have to show that he has no or minimal gaps in employment. The chances are he will need specialist help with this and he should throw his net wider than just his bank for advice.

He should go to the IFA (Independent Financial Adviser) Promotion website at Unbiased or call its hotline on 0117 971 1177 to find details of the three nearest IFAs specialising in mortgages in his area. He will have to pay either a fee or commission to the IFA.

It may be worth James' girlfriend moving the money which she has in a post office account to an internet account, depending on the rate she is receiving at present. The best at the moment are those offered by the Abbey National and Nationwide, which are both paying 7%, but she should check the precise conditions as Abbey National,for instance, is only offering this rate for the first six months of saving.

 Amanda Davidson, director, Holden Meehan in London

If you are 18-30, working and want advice on managing your money, e-mail jobs.and.money@theguardian.com

fields.headline: The late lunch that didn't go down well
fields.trailText: Yates' Wine Lodges lunch menu proclaimed: "If you don't get your food within 15 minutes, its free" - and this was quite an incentive to Middlesbrough's office workers.
fields.body:
Yates' Wine Lodges lunch menu proclaimed: "If you don't get your food within 15 minutes, its free" - and this was quite an incentive to Middlesbrough's office workers.

Most only get an hour for lunch and would prefer to spend the better part of that eating rather than waiting for food.

Unfortunately, the branch manager imposed one condition on that offer - if the restaurant was so busy that the food couldn't be served in 15 minutes the offer would be withdrawn. But customers would only find out about this somewhat fundamental quirk when they asked to be allowed the food for free.

They would have been perfectly entitled to refuse to pay for it, but that would have required a certain amount of nerve. There was nothing in the manner of the staff which suggested they would take kindly to customers leaving without settling bills.

Not surprisingly, a complaint was made to Cleveland Trading Standards Department. Senior officer John Wells sent two of his finest with instructions to order fish and chips and a small glass of something. They sat down, ordered and discreetly pressed the stop watch.

The food arrived in just over 21 minutes. "Do I get my money back?" the officer asked the waiter. "Sorry, Madam we've withdrawn the offer for today."

"Get the manager over here now," she snarled as her colleague noted everything that had been said and done. They introduced themselves and cautioned the manager.

Not exactly a master of talking himself out of a tricky situation, he replied: "Funny you should be interested in that offer. Quite a few customers have been upset when we told them they couldn't have their money back. Can't see what all the fuss is about myself."

Mr Wells, the council's legal department and, in due course, Teesside magistrates court could see plenty to make a fuss about. The company pleaded guilty to recklessly making a false statement in a way which breached S14 of the Trades Descriptions Act and was fined £1,500 with £359 costs.

Mr Wells explained: "Although the food was only six minutes late, the company was exploiting a promise it didn't intend honouring to attract a lot of customers. As well as cheating the public, it gave them an unfair advantage over restaurants who stuck to the rules."

A spokesman for the company this week could only say: "We are as embarrassed as you might expect. As far as anyone here is aware, we have never been in trouble for anything like this before."

Cleveland council was to be commended for taking such a robust attitude. Far too often businesses are let off with warnings.

For example, a car hire firm last year was advertising a small car in The Balearics as being available for £99 per week.

In fact, this rate only applied in Majorca. Rather than prosecute, Westminster's trading standard department accepted the company's reasoning that the advert was partially true.

A high proportion of prosecutions relate to indications that prices have been reduced. There are now strict rules that "sale" goods have to have been displayed for at least 28 days at the "original" price. The High Court determined when MFI was prosecuted under this Act that any goods sold as "clearance offers" had to comply, but merely saying something was a "bargain price" was too vague to create legal liability.

It is an area of law which lends itself to such intricate distinctions, but it is only when local authorities use their powers against dubious practices, such as Yates', that the law gets clarified - often to consumers' advantage.

 Richard Colbey is a barrister
