webTitle: Jobs and Money: Guardian's Investment Challenge

fields.headline: Frontrunners battle it out
fields.standfirst: The pace is hotting up as our £10,000 contest enters the final lap. Patrick Collinson reports
fields.trailText: The pace is hotting up as our £10,000 contest enters the final lap. Patrick Collinson reports.
fields.body:
As we enter the last lap of the Guardian/Barnardo's £10,000 Investment Challenge, leading the way is one of the frontrunners throughout the year, Shivani Parikh of Liverpool.

Ms Parikh's selection of five funds tops the more than 4,000 entries into the Challenge - but only by a whisker. Her portfolio, named "Shining Shivani" is up 8.1% since the start of the year, compared to the second-placed portfolio, "Thomas", entered by Mr Decher of south-west London, which is ahead 7.8%. As the table below shows, there are several other portfolios which are also close to catching Shining Shivani.

Ms Parikh, 25, says she spent a long time studying the funds when we began inviting entries to the Challenge last year. She is a trainee actuary at Royal Liver friendly society, so is no stranger to how investment markets work.

All now depends on how investment markets behave during December - and anything could happen, if November's experience is anything to go by. During the month, stockmarkets around the world fell sharply, driven down by heavy selling of technology stocks.

Jobs & Money readers who had entered portfolios geared towards technology funds had been early leaders in the Challenge, but they have now fallen back. Most of the people on the leader board picked European-invested funds, which are among the few to show positive gains on the year.

If there is a tie at the end of the competition the winner will be the one who also most accurately forecast the level of the FTSE 100 at the end of 2000. Here Ms Parikh could be in trouble; she has forecast a year-end FTSE 100 of 7,510, compared to the 6,300 level at which it is currently trading. In the current top 10, FTSE 100 forecasts range from 6,700, predicted by "Ruth Davies" to 7,555 by the "South Coast Trust".

The biggest winner, however, will be children's charity Barnardo's. Each of the 52 funds entered into the Challenge has pledged to invest £50 per month into their funds over three years, which - markets permitting - should result in Barnardo's collecting around £100,000.

The table below shows how each of the funds is progressing so far - but the results don't make happy reading. Of the 52 funds entered into the Challenge, only 14 are in positive territory after 11 months, hit by the turmoil that has engulfed stock mar kets this year. At the beginning of the year, when the Challenge began, the FTSE 100 was around the 7,000 level, 10% above today's level, so any fund keeping its head above water is doing well.

Topping the table is Credit Suisse's Transatlantic fund, up 16.7%. The £410m fund is one of the best-performing North American-invested unit trusts currently available to UK investors; over the past five years it has made an astonishing 234% on the back of the booming US economy.

It has managed to stay ahead this year when its peers have stumbled (the average North American fund is up only 1-2% this year) by steering clear of the frothiest technology stocks and focusing on stable multinationals. It has also avoided investing in banks and other financial stocks, which it believes are currently overvalued.

Joint second place goes to Jupiter's UK Growth trust, which is up 10.2%, tied with Norwich Union's Property trust. Jupiter's performance is of special note on three counts. Firstly, it has achieved 10.2% growth at a time when the average UK invested unit trust is down by 5%. Secondly, it comes after a period of management turmoil at Jupiter but which has clearly had no effect on its continued performance.

And thirdly, the growth has been achieved by a large fund, £715m in size, which investment experts usually say are much less nimble during difficult market conditions. Four of the 14 funds with positive gains on the year are Europe-invested, although another area which has reaped rewards for investors is the bond fund arena, which tends to be less volatile and lower risk than equity funds.

The money raised from the Challenge will help Barnardo's support more people like Joanne Rhodes, 22, of Wakefield in West Yorkshire. Joanne went into care aged two and then through a succession of residential homes and foster families until she set out on an independent life at the age of 17.

Making the leap into adulthood without the support of a family background is one of the biggest challenges for teenagers in care, and Joanne benefited from a Barnardo's project called the Signpost centre, operated in partnership with Wakefield Metropolitan District housing and social care departments.

Signpost provides support to encourage moves to independence for care leavers aged 16-21, plus a stopover scheme offering emergency and short-term accommodation to homeless young people aged 16-21. It also has a parent and toddler group for young parents and mediation/counselling services.

Joanne became involved with Signpost after she was made redundant and through the assistance of workers at the project was able to get herself back into education. She is now studying for A-levels and eventually wants to complete a degree in social care.

In the meantime she has set up her own project, called Friends, which counsels teenagers from ages 13 to 18 in residential homes. The project has been helped with a £5,000 grant from Barnardo's.

Joanne says: "We deal with relationship and personal problems, let-downs from placements and foster families and so on. I've been through it myself, seen it and come through it."
fields.bodyText: As we enter the last lap of the Guardian/Barnardo's £10,000 Investment Challenge, leading the way is one of the frontrunners throughout the year, Shivani Parikh of Liverpool. Ms Parikh's selection of five funds tops the more than 4,000 entries into the Challenge - but only by a whisker. Her portfolio, named "Shining Shivani" is up 8.1% since the start of the year, compared to the second-placed portfolio, "Thomas", entered by Mr Decher of south-west London, which is ahead 7.8%. As the table below shows, there are several other portfolios which are also close to catching Shining Shivani. Ms Parikh, 25, says she spent a long time studying the funds when we began inviting entries to the Challenge last year. She is a trainee actuary at Royal Liver friendly society, so is no stranger to how investment markets work. All now depends on how investment markets behave during December - and anything could happen, if November's experience is anything to go by. During the month, stockmarkets around the world fell sharply, driven down by heavy selling of technology stocks. Jobs & Money readers who had entered portfolios geared towards technology funds had been early leaders in the Challenge, but they have now fallen back. Most of the people on the leader board picked European-invested funds, which are among the few to show positive gains on the year. If there is a tie at the end of the competition the winner will be the one who also most accurately forecast the level of the FTSE 100 at the end of 2000. Here Ms Parikh could be in trouble; she has forecast a year-end FTSE 100 of 7,510, compared to the 6,300 level at which it is currently trading. In the current top 10, FTSE 100 forecasts range from 6,700, predicted by "Ruth Davies" to 7,555 by the "South Coast Trust". The biggest winner, however, will be children's charity Barnardo's. Each of the 52 funds entered into the Challenge has pledged to invest £50 per month into their funds over three years, which - markets permitting - should result in Barnardo's collecting around £100,000. The table below shows how each of the funds is progressing so far - but the results don't make happy reading. Of the 52 funds entered into the Challenge, only 14 are in positive territory after 11 months, hit by the turmoil that has engulfed stock mar kets this year. At the beginning of the year, when the Challenge began, the FTSE 100 was around the 7,000 level, 10% above today's level, so any fund keeping its head above water is doing well. Topping the table is Credit Suisse's Transatlantic fund, up 16.7%. The £410m fund is one of the best-performing North American-invested unit trusts currently available to UK investors; over the past five years it has made an astonishing 234% on the back of the booming US economy. It has managed to stay ahead this year when its peers have stumbled (the average North American fund is up only 1-2% this year) by steering clear of the frothiest technology stocks and focusing on stable multinationals. It has also avoided investing in banks and other financial stocks, which it believes are currently overvalued. Joint second place goes to Jupiter's UK Growth trust, which is up 10.2%, tied with Norwich Union's Property trust. Jupiter's performance is of special note on three counts. Firstly, it has achieved 10.2% growth at a time when the average UK invested unit trust is down by 5%. Secondly, it comes after a period of management turmoil at Jupiter but which has clearly had no effect on its continued performance. And thirdly, the growth has been achieved by a large fund, £715m in size, which investment experts usually say are much less nimble during difficult market conditions. Four of the 14 funds with positive gains on the year are Europe-invested, although another area which has reaped rewards for investors is the bond fund arena, which tends to be less volatile and lower risk than equity funds. The money raised from the Challenge will help Barnardo's support more people like Joanne Rhodes, 22, of Wakefield in West Yorkshire. Joanne went into care aged two and then through a succession of residential homes and foster families until she set out on an independent life at the age of 17. Making the leap into adulthood without the support of a family background is one of the biggest challenges for teenagers in care, and Joanne benefited from a Barnardo's project called the Signpost centre, operated in partnership with Wakefield Metropolitan District housing and social care departments. It also has a parent and toddler group for young parents and mediation/counselling services. In the meantime she has set up her own project, called Friends, which counsels teenagers from ages 13 to 18 in residential homes. The project has been helped with a £5,000 grant from Barnardo's. Joanne says: "We deal with relationship and personal problems, let-downs from placements and foster families and so on. I've been through it myself, seen it and come through it."

fields.headline: Cashpoints
fields.trailText: National Savings has cut the rates on its range of investment accounts by up to 0.45 of a percentage point.
fields.body:
National Savings has cut the rates on its range of investment accounts by up to 0.45 of a percentage point.

The new rates on its 6th issue of two-year Fixed Interest Savings Certificates are down by 0.35% to 3.95% after tax. And the 56th issue of five-year fixed-rate certificates now returns 3.8% after tax.

Its one-year granny bonds are hardest hit with new rates 0.45% lower at 5.3% gross. And with immaculate timing ahead of Christmas, the tax-free rate on its Children's Bonus Bonds is slashed by 0.355 to 4.8%. Details of new rates are posted on the National Savings website, or there is a helpline on 0845 964 5000.

UCB Home Loans, the specialist lending arm of Nationwide Building Society, has trimmed 0.2% off its range of fixed-rate mortgages. The new rate on its two-year fixed-rate deal drops to 6.05%. Borrowers seeking a five-year fix will pay 7.55%.

Managing director Charles Reed says: "Five-year fixed rate deals are particularly attractive as they will provide borrowers with guaranteed rates leading to the UK's projected entry into the euro around 2004, when interest rates are expected to fall further."

The Portman Building Society has a deal fixed at 5.99% until February 2, 2003 which also allows borrowers to repay up to 10% of the original loan amount borrowed each year without incurring any early redemption penalty. The society also has a mortgage fixed at 3.99% until the same date for bor rowers who only want to repay up to 5% a year.

Birmingham Midshires, is wooing self-employed, part-time and temporary contract workers by marketing its self-certification mortgages to the 12m workers with irregular incomes.

But these mortgages do not come cheap, its self-certified fixed rate home loan is priced at 6.89% until February, 1, 2003, provided borrowers make a downpayment of at least 15% of the value of the house.

fields.standfirst: The crying game
fields.trailText: Science, he claims, invariably holds the clues to most mysteries involving blood. In 1263, Pope Urban IV established the Feast of Corpus Christi to commemorate the miracle of the Mass of Bolsena - depicted in a celebrated fresco by Raphael - when bloodstains appeared on the communion host, staining the sacramental linen. fields.body:
Science, he claims, invariably holds the clues to most mysteries involving blood. In 1263, Pope Urban IV established the Feast of Corpus Christi to commemorate the miracle of the Mass of Bolsena - depicted in a celebrated fresco by Raphael - when bloodstains appeared on the communion host, staining the sacramental linen. The Cathedral of Orvieto was especially constructed to celebrate the event and house the holy relics, where they remain to this day.

Despite many subsequent reports of holy "blood" on food such as bread, potato, polenta and beans, which have proved negative when tested for haemoglobin, scientists believe they have the answer. The fungus Serratia marcescens is a micro-organism that flourishes in warm, moist and unhygienic conditions, producing crimson, blood-like stains on starchy food. In 1993, an American researcher, Johanna Cullen, reproduced the miracle of Bolsena in a laboratory, using sacramental bread and S. marcescens cultures, achieving effects realistic enough to be easily be mistaken for blood.

By replicating techniques that would have been commonplace among medieval artists, Garlaschelli has found a probable explanation for another age-old miracle: the liquefaction of the dried "blood" of the early saints at holy festivals, the most famous being the Feast of St Gennaro in Naples. Reports that this, and many other blood relics in churches in and around the city, have been liquefying regularly since the 14th century, suggests a long tradition of fakery.

"Because reports of these miracles go back to the middle ages, modern experiments must incorporate materials that were easily available then," he says, bringing out a rack of glass phials half-full of congealed matter in varying shades of tan and deep, rusty red.

Handing me a container of solid brownish gel, he tells me to shake or swing it from side to side, as priests do when flourishing blood relics in front of a congregation. After a few seconds of being jiggled around, the gel begins flowing freely and turns a brighter red, a startlingly realistic effect. This is due to the so-called "thixotropic" properties of certain chemical compounds that remain solid until shaken or briskly turned upside down - mayonnaise and some types of household paints being modern examples.

By concocting such gels using naturally occurring reddish chemicals such as molysite or iron chloride, which is found only near active volcanoes such as Mount Vesuvius near Naples and has been commonly used by painters and artisans throughout the centuries, Garlaschelli may have cracked another ancient mystery.

Whether this proves that, since its earliest days, the church has knowingly deceived worshippers with such tricks is another matter. What if an outsider introduced the relic to the church, rather than the other way around? Instead of being purposely cooked up by some fanatical abbot to dupe and convert the masses, Garlaschelli believes that these compounds were more likely to have been created by accident, probably by medieval artists who stumbled across the method by chance when experimenting with pigments.

In 1389, the first recorded date of the liquefaction of the blood of St Gennaro, the Cathedral of Naples was under construction and artists from all over Italy were employed in its decoration. "At that time, the King of Naples was Robert of Anjou, a pious man, who would certainly have been pleased by a 'holy blood relic'," says Garlaschelli. "In those days, the desire for relics was widespread, as were the attempts to counterfeit them. The shroud of Turin has been carbon-dated back to that time."

An even simpler explanation for blood relics that liquefy only in summer is that some mixtures of waxes, fats and oils remain solid and melt only when the temperature reaches a certain level, usually 30C. When asked in 1996 by Italy's national TV company, RAI, to carry out a test on the congealed blood of St Lorenzo, which liquefies every August 10 at a church in Amaseno near Naples, Garlaschelli found that the normally solid, tan-coloured substance in the phial had already liquefied and was glowing bright red.

It was a searingly hot day, and the temperature inside the church was more than 30C. To test the substance, he placed the phial in iced water, waited for the contents to resolidify, heated the water to 30C, at which point the contents melted again. "This suggests that the relic, and many like it, consists of natural fats, waxes, or a mixture of the two, and is coloured with a dash of 'devil's blood', a fat-soluble red vegetable resin that was widely used as a dye during the middle ages. For proof, you'd need to analyse the contents by extracting a tiny sample with a syringe, but the church hasn't given permission to do so."

Nor is it likely to: although Garlaschelli and his colleagues have published their findings in a number of scientific journals, exposing new bogus miracles is one thing, shattering myths that have attracted pilgrims and tourists for centuries is quite another. Which might explain why, when Garlaschelli appeared on the TV programme that hired him to analyse the blood of St Lorenzo, his explanation for the phenomenon was edited out of the broadcast: "It would be very easy to demonstrate the truth behind all these miracles," he says, "but very few priests are true sceptics, which is why we cannot carry out controlled studies on relics and statues. Even when a commission investigates a miracle, there is never a chemist, a physician or any scientist among them, only theologians."

That certainly goes for the commission that was appointed to study the Madonna of Civitavecchia. Although its report was recently completed, since the Vatican is traditionally reticent about issuing declarations on miracles, the final verdict could be a long way off yet. Since 1830, the Vatican has "approved" 15 apparitions of the Virgin, but authenticated only one "weeping" Madonna, when a statue wept tears in Siracuse, Sicily, in 1954 - a highly dubious event, says Garlaschelli, who has investigated the incident.

In some ways, the Vatican's response seems irrelevant, especially since Monsignor Grillo's statements have put La Madonnina in the big league. From the rows of souvenir stalls and ranks of parked tour buses to the booming lunchtime trade at Signora Amina's trattoria next to the church, all the signs are that La Madonnina remains a crowd-puller, perhaps because of, rather than despite, being shrouded in mystery.

Equally a mystery in this drama is surely the bishop and his handling of the affair. Mayor Tidei's comment that "he has taken over the miracle and is running things his way" underlines the animosity between the two men, and raises many questions. What really prompted Monsignor Grillo's public u-turn? Was it a warning to the authorities to keep their nose out of church affairs, or a shrewd move to find favour among the powerful conservative faction of the Vatican? He retains possession of the statue and control over its future. Only two people have keys to the bulletproof cabinet in which the statue is locked: one is Gregori's lawyer, the other is the bishop.

Or is he motivated, above all, by a genuine mystical belief? Monsignor Grillo, who has just returned from lecturing in the US, is unconcerned about allegations of irrationality or that the faithful may turn away from the church. "An impressive spiritual reawakening has taken place," he claims, "a true and proper recovery of religious conscientiousness. People are no longer coming out of curiosity, but to pray. We have had more than 800 reported miracle cures, and so many people have converted that there aren't enough priests at the church to hear confessions."

However, one person you won't see mingling with the crowds at St Agostino's is Fabio Gregori. Although a less hawkish public prosecutor was recently appointed, the case against Gregori has yet to be wound up. Forestieri, his lawyer, now wishes that it would just come to court, "so I could finally show the world what really went on".

Anyone passing Gregori's house today will find it shuttered and silent, the gates locked and the sides of his fence bricked up to prevent people peering into his garden. Recent photographs of Fabio and his daughter Jessica, now 11, show both looking sullen and withdrawn. I wonder, do the Gregoris still believe in miracles?

fields.headline: Publishing fairy tales
fields.trailText: Paul Bowes (Letters, December 5) defends Waterstone's demands regarding terms of supply on the grounds that some small publishers are "amateurish" and "greedy".
fields.body:
Paul Bowes (Letters, December 5) defends Waterstone's demands regarding terms of supply on the grounds that some small publishers are "amateurish" and "greedy".

This sort of misinformation is totally misleading. Books at Waterstone's are held at the publishers' risk and are fully returnable. Many of the publishers, who have received demands at short notice for major increases in discounts that would be unacceptable to any industry, are highly-respected entrepreneurial publishers in subject areas ranging from academic texts to original fiction. These are not amateurs who cannot differentiate between profit and loss, or who expect to be subsidised by booksellers.

Characterising independent publishers as being resentful of the rules of the market is disingenuous. Successful independent publishers have an in-depth knowledge of their market. Mr Bowes' accusations divert attention from the disarray and low morale within Waterstone's.
Sheila Bounford
Independent Publishers Guild
sheila@ipg.uk.com

 Lyn Gardner hasn't got it right about childhood (Do you believe in fairies?, G2, December 6). The Victorians did not "invent childhood and children's literature". Literature written for children goes back to the early 17th century. The first children's book of pure entertainment can be dated to 1744, a book of nursery rhymes; and attempts to create an ideal childhood can be found among 17th-century Puritans. What's more, children in ancient cultures played in ways that can be distinguished from adult activities.
Michael Rosen
London
rosenmichael@hotmail.com

fields.headline: Write stuff
fields.trailText: Independent TV producers are right to challenge the BBC's demand for all rights in everything it broadcasts (We will fight for our rights, Media Guardian, December 4). But producers deserve little sympathy if they merely seek to take over the BBC's place in the food chain.
fields.body:
Independent TV producers are right to challenge the BBC's demand for all rights in everything it broadcasts (We will fight for our rights, Media Guardian, December 4). But producers deserve little sympathy if they merely seek to take over the BBC's place in the food chain.

They talk about "the generators of creative property (the producers)". Yet in an article of 1,200 words the word "writer" never occurs. Maybe producers create game-show formats, but in drama and comedy writers have a primary role. They too need to be able to reuse their work in other media. If producers drop their assumption that they are the only creators involved, they will be welcome to join the campaign being waged by writers and others.
Bernie Corbett
General secretary, Writers' Guild of Great Britain
corbett@writersguild.org.uk

fields.headline: Queen starts debate
fields.trailText: When Ann Widdicombe starts sounding rational and reasonable in attacking Labour's "tough on crime" policies (Queen's speech, December 7), it should be evident something really isn't right.
fields.body:
When Ann Widdicombe starts sounding rational and reasonable in attacking Labour's "tough on crime" policies (Queen's speech, December 7), it should be evident something really isn't right.
Dave Hewitt
Ashford, Middx

 If the government succeeds in outlawing hunting, the only losers will be the poor. The fortunate will be able to follow hunts in France or in Ireland, but ordinary working men or women, the elderly, out-of-work and pensioners will be dispossessed of the finest and noblest spectacle in our countryside.
Peter Thomas
Saffron Walden, Essex

 "A farrago of inept cliches and mostly meaningless verbiage," says Ben Marshall of Freddie Mercury's band, Queen (Mercury rising, G2, December 7): at last - someone dares to speak the plain and self-evident truth about this "truly terrible band".
Jon Gilhooly
Brighton

 I imagine Ben also thinks they used too many notes! This piece of journalism can only have been written with someone with all the musical sensibilities of a deaf newt.
Ian Buchanan
Elstree, Herts

 I can't match the age of your sharp crossword solvers (Letters, December 8), but I think I have the edge in one respect. A while ago I completed a crossword I'd started 21 years and 3 months earlier. I came across the paper whilst looking for something in my loft. And yes, it was the Quick Crossword.
Neville Denson
St Bees, Cumbria

 I am 84 and have never attempted to solve any crossword because I am too busy keeping up with my emails and science news group on the internet (www.brox1.demon).
Eric Crew
Broxbourne, Herts
eric@brox1.demon.co.uk

The fortunate will be able to follow hunts in France or in Ireland, but ordinary working men or women, the elderly, out-of-work and pensioners will be dispossessed of the finest and noblest spectacle in our countryside. Peter Thomas Saffron Walden, Essex  "A farrago of inept cliches and mostly meaningless verbiage," says Ben Marshall of Freddie Mercury's band, Queen (Mercury rising, G2, December 7): at last - someone dares to speak the plain and self-evident truth about this "truly terrible band". Jon Gilhooly Brighton  I imagine Ben also thinks they used too many notes! This piece of journalism can only have been written with someone with all the musical sensibilities of a deaf newt. Ian Buchanan Elstree, Herts  I can't match the age of your sharp crossword solvers (Letters, December 8), but I think I have the edge in one respect. A while ago I completed a crossword I'd started 21 years and 3 months earlier. I came across the paper whilst looking for something in my loft. And yes, it was the Quick Crossword. Neville Denson St Bees, Cumbria  I am 84 and have never attempted to solve any crossword because I am too busy keeping up with my emails and science news group on the internet (www.brox1.demon). Eric Crew Broxbourne, Herts eric@brox1.demon.co.uk

webTitle: Letters: Is amateur theatre any good?

fields.headline: Drama at the village hall
fields.trailText: In his review of The Accused (December 7), Michael Billington suggests that Lord Archer "gives the impression that he is studying to be an amateur". I am a great admirer of Mr Billington and have read his reviews avidly over many years. I do not recall, however, that he has reviewed or even attended an amateur production and wonder whence his experience of that sector of theatre derives?
fields.body:
In his review of The Accused (December 7), Michael Billington suggests that Lord Archer "gives the impression that he is studying to be an amateur". I am a great admirer of Mr Billington and have read his reviews avidly over many years. I do not recall, however, that he has reviewed or even attended an amateur production and wonder whence his experience of that sector of theatre derives?

So he may speak with authority, I invite him to accompany me to a production at any of the 90 theatres belonging to the Little Theatre Guild of Great Britain. We cannot, of course, guarantee a standard of production or acting which will compare with the best of the professional theatre, but I can say with some confidence that in 50 years of theatre-going, seeing everything from village hall groups to the best of the National Theatre and the RSC - some 40 shows a year, on average - LTG theatres rarely disappoint entirely.

Amateur theatre has been the initial training ground for many top professionals, including Flora Robson, Michael Redgrave, Judi Dench and Ben Elton. Amateur theatres, in some parts of the country, provide the only live theatrical experience. Little Theatres produce more than 700 shows a year to audiences in excess of 600,000. Those who love theatre will never be in a majority and it does no good when leading figures such as Michael Billington choose to disparage those who constitute more than half of the theatrical activity in the country.

Tom Williams
Chairman, Little Theatre Guild of Great Britain
gchair@aol.com

fields.headline: The republic and religion
fields.trailText: Congratulations on your stand on the monarchy. It has received considerable coverage in New Zealand. Many here need education about your antiquated laws which enshrine not just the Protestant religion but also the Church of England in such an elevated position in our country, since the person you appoint as monarch automatically becomes our monarch too (Unpicking church and state, December 8).
fields.body:
Congratulations on your stand on the monarchy. It has received considerable coverage in New Zealand. Many here need education about your antiquated laws which enshrine not just the Protestant religion but also the Church of England in such an elevated position in our country, since the person you appoint as monarch automatically becomes our monarch too (Unpicking church and state, December 8). I say abolish the discriminatory Act of Settlement and with it the laws which give males precedence over females in the succession. While you are at it, separate church and state and take away the right of the Church of England to have bishops in the Lords. Do you even need a House of Lords?
Malcolm Law
Lower Hutt, New Zealand
law.family@paradise.net.nz

 The entanglement of the Anglo-Scottish union with the Protestant settlement is even deeper than Tom Nairn (December 6) acknowledges. The 1701 Act of Settlement is itself no longer in force, for it regulated the right of succession to the crown of England. This has been a legally non-existent entity since May 1 1707. Articles 1 and 2 of the treaty of union, ratified by Acts of Union of the two parliaments in 1706-7, constituted a new kingdom and a new crown, of Great Britain. This new crown was, however, to be settled according to the same terms as those of the 1701 Act. The later Irish union of 1801 preserved this in essentials. It follows that the founding instrument that created the British state is the very thing that has to be repealed or reformed to write sectarianism out of the constitution.
Prof Neil MacCormick MEP
neil@maccormick.fsnet.co.uk

 As a Catholic, I can't see anything more pointless than endlessly debating the Act of Settlement. I don't want to be married to a member of the royal family: I want the monarchy scrapped. If the SNP wants to talk about discrimination it should focus on the racist asylum and immigration act or the lack of action post-Macpherson (Stabbing that exposed Scots racism, December 8).
Matthew McGregor
Sheffield

 Statistics show that only 5% of practising Christians in Scotland adhere to the Episcopal Church of Scotland (the Anglican link north of the border). The figure for the Church of Scotland (Presbyterian in its form of worship) is 65% and that for the Roman Catholic church is 22%. When visiting Scotland, the Queen worships in the Church of Scotland, and sends a lord high commissioner to its assembly. So let the repeal of the Act of Succession and the disestablishment of the Anglican church be the first steps.
Ralph Simmonds
Edinburgh

 As Roman Catholicism is the largest of the minority faiths in Britain, should there be any amendment to the Act of Settlement, it would be reasonable to assume that a person of this faith would then either become married to a reigning monarch or become monarch. Would, therefore, Roman Catholic canon law 1125 be subjected to similar scrutiny to determine whether it offended the Human Rights Act? This law requires that all children of an interfaith marriage be raised as Catholics. The successor to the throne would then be a Catholic and his or her heirs. The Act of Settlement would then have been replaced by the Catholic canon law 1125. One discrimination replaced by another.
Jack Ramsay
Grand Orange Lodge of Scotland

 Had I been in the line of succession, I would have been debarred on all four grounds. I was a Catholic. I married a Catholic. I was born out of wedlock. I was adopted. Given the company I might have kept, I am overcome with relief.
Dennis O'Connell-Baker
St Albans, Herts

fields.headline: Oliver's army
fields.trailText: In the mid-70s, I sought to revive the republican movement first created by Oliver Cromwell - albeit less forcefully and ruthlessly, but with equal conviction that the monarchy should be democratically abolished. The organisation was called the Leveller Society after the Levellers, led by John Lilburne, who found wide support among Cromwell's army together with farmers, artisans and small traders.
fields.body:
In the mid-70s, I sought to revive the republican movement first created by Oliver Cromwell - albeit less forcefully and ruthlessly, but with equal conviction that the monarchy should be democratically abolished. The organisation was called the Leveller Society after the Levellers, led by John Lilburne, who found wide support among Cromwell's army together with farmers, artisans and small traders.

The society did not exist even as long as the short-lived Levellers - not that there was any shortage of member applications. But on close inspection, some 90% of the would-be activists proved to be senior civil servants, high-ranking army and police officers, members of the Special Branch, a couple of private secretaries in royal employ and some of my best friends at MI5. Swamped by such keenly interested consociates, the society was clearly before its time. But times are changing rapidly and I wish you much luck in your challenge.
Ray Bellisario
Norwood Green, Middx

 Absolutely wonderful. Get rid of the monarchy. Far from being ambassadors of our country, they are ridiculed and loathed by most. The pomp and ceremony is pointless. Just another expense for taxpayers who have no interest in a dysfunctional family. They irritate me beyond belief. The Queen Mother, for example, was the first woman to receive a degree from the Senate House at Cambridge. Women worked damn hard for decades to get this right, and the first degree went to HM - never having done anything intellectual in her life. Maybe we should act on the events of 1649 and start a revolution.
Verity Worthington
Cambridge

webTitle: Conceived, delivered and sold: a baby for $6,000

fields.headline: Conceived, delivered and sold: a baby for $6,000
fields.standfirst: Surrogate mothers are the new money-spinner for Balkan gangs: Lelia's journey
fields.trailText: Lelia's pregnancy was smooth. She had nine months of peace and quiet at a suburban villa, regular visits by the doctor and tenderness from the father of her unborn child.
fields.body:
Lelia's pregnancy was smooth. She had nine months of peace and quiet at a suburban villa, regular visits by the doctor and tenderness from the father of her unborn child.

When the time came she was taken to a clinic, given a private room and the best care money could buy. The result was a healthy, blue-eyed baby boy.

Lelia watched the nurse carry him away knowing he would not return, for he was not hers to keep. She had conceived, delivered and sold him for $6,000 (£4,150).

A husband and his sterile wife had commissioned the human traffickers of eastern Europe to find an alternative to adoption and artificial insemination. They wanted a young woman smuggled into Italy to be impregnated by the husband. They wanted a human incubator.

To be healthy, blonde, blue-eyed and desperate was to be the perfect candidate, and Lelia agreed to the deal.

A new trade, a sophisticated spin-off in people smuggling, has been spawned. Last July, Italian police revealed that up to three dozen prostitutes had been shipped to Germany to sell their children to wealthy western couples.

A 17-year-old prostitute from Naples, now in a witness protection programme, identified a clinic in the state of Baden-Württemberg where she was made to sign documents putting her baby up for adoption.

Next week Sicily will host a UN conference on organised crime, to coordinate the fight against human trafficking, estimated to generate $7bn annually. Such trafficking is organised crime's biggest earner after drugs.

Senator Tana de Zulueta, presenting a report last week by the Italian parliament's anti-mafia commission, said Balkan gangs were establishing ever-closer links with the Italian mob. "There's a rebirth of the phenomenon of slavery. We need new laws to adequately face this dramatic problem," she said.

Lelia's story confirms that the traffickers have refined their methods by supplying women rather than babies to childless couples. "They said they would kill me if I ever spoke out, but it will keep happening unless people know about it," she said.

She lives at Regina Pacis, an immigrant holding centre in San Foca, on the heel of Italy. Father Cesare Lo Presto, who runs the centre, claimed to know of two similar cases. He said: "They are breaking several laws - illegal entry into the country, false maternity, forgery, but they are desperate.

"In fact these girls are the lucky ones, they avoid being physically brutalised like the streetwalkers. What I do fear however is the psychological impact, not just on them but on the couples. Creating a nuclear family in this way is not healthy."

Hair drawn back from a pale, oval face, Lelia fiddled with a cigarette and spoke in a matter-of-fact voice. At first the offer seemed irresistible. She was 25 then, and earning $10 a month as a nurse in Chisinau, capital of the former Soviet republic of Moldova.

The economy had collapsed: meat consumption had halved, malnutrition was rife, life expectancy had been curtailed by five years, hospitals lacked bandages. According to the World Bank, half the population earned less than $220 a year. Around 600,000 people had already left.

A friend spotted a coded advertisement in the twice-weekly newspaper Makler. It was not prostitution and in less than a year Lelia would earn more than in two lifetimes of nursing. In January 1998, she joined the trail of prostitutes and smugglers heading south.

Accompanied by a Moldovan guide, she took the classic route: overland through Romania, Yugoslavia and Albania, borders greased with bribes, and a moonlit ride across the Adriatic on a semi-inflatable with two dozen asylum-seekers and illegal immigrants.

A car with two Albanian men was waiting when she reached an Italian beach. They drove to Bologna and booked into a hotel. "Near the airport, I could hear the planes landing." The doctor who arrived was a nice man. He had an electro-cardiogram and took blood samples and swabs.

Two days later, a man and woman in their late 30s walked in. They shook her hand, smiled and gazed. The husband was dark, the wife blonde.

"I was very nervous, I didn't know what they were looking for. I just smiled." Minutes later the three were in a rush-hour crawl out of the city, driving north to a city Lelia thinks was Milan.

The rented villa was identical to a dozen others lining the cul-de-sac. "I had worried about the wife becoming jealous but she had made her decision. She was very friendly, she stroked my cheek like I was a child."

The wife waited downstairs during her husband's nightly visits to Lelia's attic room. "He was very gentle. Afterwards he would leave straight away." Within three weeks she was pregnant.

Barred from leaving, time passed slowly. Food and television, from which she learned Italian, became her friends. The wife never left, the husband only occasionally. "The strangest thing was they never received phone calls or visitors. I was told not to ask questions."

In November they drove north to a clinic, possibly to Switzerland or Germany, to be treated by the same doctor. She never saw her son properly. "Maybe that was for the good."

Lelia was whisked back to Bologna, given 60 $100 bills and bundled on a plane home, sworn to secrecy.

Everybody kept their side of the bargain but she had not counted on feeling sickened. "How could I buy a flat, or a dress, or anything, with money I earned from selling my child?"

In the neighbouring compound at the immigrant centre several ex-prostitutes were pregnant. Others pushed prams and hung baby clothes on a line.

For the first time, her voice trembled. "It was a mistake, a huge mistake. God, I regret it." Lelia gave her mother the money and last year returned to Italy to work and be closer to her son.

Now she is employed as a nurse in Lecce, agonising over whether to start searching. "I know I won't get him back, the couple will take good care of him, but I just want to see him, to hear news."

webTitle: South African minorities find unlikely saviour to take on ANC

fields.headline: South African minorities find unlikely saviour to take on ANC
fields.standfirst: Thatcherite's party emerges from elections as a credible opposition
fields.trailText: On paper, Tony Leon should not stand a chance as a major political leader in the new South Africa. As well as being white, thereby discounting a lot of potential black support, he is Jewish, which hardly endears him to the Calvinist Afrikaner community or the substantial Muslim vote in the Cape.
fields.body:
On paper, Tony Leon should not stand a chance as a major political leader in the new South Africa. As well as being white, thereby discounting a lot of potential black support, he is Jewish, which hardly endears him to the Calvinist Afrikaner community or the substantial Muslim vote in the Cape.

To cap it all there are the persistent rumours that he is gay, in a country where, despite a new and tolerant constitution, homosexuality is frowned upon by great swaths of the population.

Yet Mr Leon's Democratic Alliance emerged from this week's local elections with one-quarter of the ballot, firmly establishing that South Africa is at the very least a two-party state.

To get there, Mr Leon, 44, took much of the Afrikaner and Muslim vote. He even persuaded some black voters, notably among the very poor and the new middle class, to support him, prompting an infuriated President Thabo Mbeki to disparage the opposition as "an unholy alliance" driven by hatred.

Mr Leon's feat is all the more remarkable because the year before he took over leadership of the Democratic party in 1995, it had polled a pitiful 1.7% of the vote in the election which made Nelson Mandela president.

In those days, white South Africans and other minorities fearful of change still flocked to the National party, which had dumped apartheid but remained a refuge for segregationists. Today, the "Nats" are neutered and sheltering under Mr Leon's wing while he has emerged as what some call the voice of rage for white and other minority voters.

His great achievement has been to persuade whites in particular that their votes are not wasted or irrelevant in the new South Africa, as proved by this week's elections when the Democrats won control of Cape Town and took more than a third of the vote in most other major cities.

Mr Leon, a lawyer, understands much better than the ANC the value of the sound bite, and is welcomed on the white dinner-circuit for his humour. But he offers rare acknowledgment of just how much the majority of people have suffered, and has some strange friends on the extreme right of American politics.

The Democratic party was always called "liberal" in South Africa, but that was only by the prevailing standards of brutal racial segregation. Mr Leon is a proud Thatcherite. He has attacked affirmative action as another form of apartheid, told the unions they are ruining the economy and criticised the minimum wage for maids as "job crushing".

The ANC loathes Mr Leon more than any of its old apartheid-era foes but has been forced into a grudging respect. The party at first tried to woo him. Nelson Mandela invited Mr Leon to join his government even though he lacked the 5% of the vote required to claim a cabinet seat.

Mr Leon turned down the offer, saying he wanted to build an effective opposition.

That he has done, at a price. He absorbed the ailing National party into his own, to the consternation of those liberals who spent a lifetime opposing the Afrikaner establishment. But with the racists came much of the valuable "coloured" vote from the Cape. While theoretically an alliance, the "Nats" were quickly consumed and there is no question but that Tony Leon commands the new party.

Still, the merger has reinforced claims by opponents that his party is secretly racist. The most controversial poster of last year's general election was Mr Leon's exhortation to "Fight Back". Critics wondered who the Democrats were fighting. The ANC responded with its own poster declaring: "Don't Fight Blacks".

Mr Leon denied there was a racial twist to his campaign but Van Zyl Slabbert, a former leader of the DP's predecessor, the Progressive Federal party, said he thought "it extremely dangerous to gather votes at any cost".

Unable to coopt him, the ANC has hammered away at Mr Leon with allegations that his father was a "hanging judge" who sent anti-apartheid activists to the gallows. During the recent elections, the ANC was behind a poster campaign accusing the Democratic Alliance of being anti-Palestinian, presumably because Mr Leon is Jewish.

He has had to publicly deny the rumours that he is gay. It is unlikely that his marriage this weekend to an Israeli woman will end the whispering.

But none of that appears to matter to the growing band of South Africans who see Tony Leon as the only effective voice against the ANC.

In those days, white South Africans and other minorities fearful of change still flocked to the National party, which had dumped apartheid but remained a refuge for segregationists. Today, the "Nats" are neutered and sheltering under Mr Leon's wing while he has emerged as what some call the voice of rage for white and other minority voters. His great achievement has been to persuade whites in particular that their votes are not wasted or irrelevant in the new South Africa, as proved by this week's elections when the Democrats won control of Cape Town and took more than a third of the vote in most other major cities. Mr Leon, a lawyer, understands much better than the ANC the value of the sound bite, and is welcomed on the white dinner-circuit for his humour. But he offers rare acknowledgment of just how much the majority of people have suffered, and has some strange friends on the extreme right of American politics. The Democratic party was always called "liberal" in South Africa, but that was only by the prevailing standards of brutal racial segregation. Mr Leon is a proud Thatcherite. He has attacked affirmative action as another form of apartheid, told the unions they are ruining the economy and criticised the minimum wage for maids as "job crushing". The ANC loathes Mr Leon more than any of its old apartheid-era foes but has been forced into a grudging respect. The party at first tried to woo him. Nelson Mandela invited Mr Leon to join his government even though he lacked the 5% of the vote required to claim a cabinet seat. Mr Leon turned down the offer, saying he wanted to build an effective opposition. That he has done, at a price. He absorbed the ailing National party into his own, to the consternation of those liberals who spent a lifetime opposing the Afrikaner establishment. But with the racists came much of the valuable "coloured" vote from the Cape. While theoretically an alliance, the "Nats" were quickly consumed and there is no question but that Tony Leon commands the new party. Still, the merger has reinforced claims by opponents that his party is secretly racist. The most controversial poster of last year's general election was Mr Leon's exhortation to "Fight Back". Critics wondered who the Democrats were fighting. The ANC responded with its own poster declaring: "Don't Fight Blacks". Mr Leon denied there was a racial twist to his campaign but Van Zyl Slabbert, a former leader of the DP's predecessor, the Progressive Federal party, said he thought "it extremely dangerous to gather votes at any cost". Unable to coopt him, the ANC has hammered away at Mr Leon with allegations that his father was a "hanging judge" who sent anti-apartheid activists to the gallows. During the recent elections, the ANC was behind a poster campaign accusing the Democratic Alliance of being anti-Palestinian, presumably because Mr Leon is Jewish. He has had to publicly deny the rumours that he is gay. It is unlikely that his marriage this weekend to an Israeli woman will end the whispering. But none of that appears to matter to the growing band of South Africans who see Tony Leon as the only effective voice against the ANC.

webTitle: Voters in Ghana set to bring an end to an era

fields.headline: Voters in Ghana set to bring an end to an era
fields.trailText: Ghanaians appear to have turned their backs on almost two decades of charismatic but controversial rule by President Jerry Rawlings who some say saved his country and whom others accuse of selling it out to western economic ideology.
fields.body:
Ghanaians appear to have turned their backs on almost two decades of charismatic but controversial rule by President Jerry Rawlings who some say saved his country and whom others accuse of selling it out to western economic ideology.

Early results from Thursday's presidential and parliamentary elections point to a victory for the opposition New Patriotic party (NPP) and its candidate, John Kufuor.

Mr Rawlings had hoped that his own vice-president, John Atta Mills, would succeed him but if the initial returns are indicative, the candidate of the ruling National Democratic Congress will be lucky to make it to a run-off for the presidency. At least two cabinet ministers lost their seats.

With ballots counted in 53 of 200 constituencies, Mr Kuffuor had 58% of the vote, compared to 38% for Mr Atta Mills.

The opposition was expected to do well in the cities, where dissatisfaction with Mr Rawlings first surfaced, but initial results from rural areas indicate that the NPP has done much better there than predicted. Early returns showed that nearly half the seats taken by the opposition were previously held by the government.

Mr Rawlings has repeatedly said that he will abide by the constitution and step down at the end of his second term as an elected president, but one factor contributing to his vice-president's defeat may be the perception in Ghana that he would rule through the back door if Mr Atta Mills won.

Neither of the main candidates has inspired Ghanaians in what has been dubbed "the battle of the bores", but that hardly matters as their policies are not what is being put to the test. The election was very much a referendum on Mr Rawlings's rule which has seen him lead Ghana from an at times brutal, left-leaning military dictatorship to a darling of the World Bank, International Monetary Fund and, hence, western governments.

While Ghanaians are nearly unanimous in saying that the country is better off than it was two decades ago, there is considerable disillusionment with 17 years of structural adjustment programmes which have failed to stave off an economic crisis partly caused by a world collapse in cocoa and gold prices.

Many suspect that reforms portrayed as transforming the west African state into one of the best and freest economies and political systems on the continent have really amounted to selling out the country to foreign financiers with limited benefits to its people.

There is also a weariness with corruption and with 21 years of Jerry Rawlings. He first seized power as a 32-year-old fighter pilot in a coup in 1979. His ruling armed forces revolutionary council had eight generals executed in three months of frantic but popular rule before handing power to a hurriedly elected president.

Civilian government failed, due to incompetence and corruption, and 30 months later, Flight-Lieutenant Rawlings was back to stay with a broadly socialist programme. But three years later, with the economy sinking fast, Ghana turned to the World Bank and IMF.

Western governments poured in more than £3bn of aid, allowing the government to rebuild many social institutions and contain corruption.

Flt-Lieut Rawlings finally stood for election eight years ago in a ballot the opposition alleged was rigged. It made the same accusation over his re-election in 1996, but he seemed to retain much popularity until the economy faltered.

Mr Kufuor, 61, ran against Mr Rawlings in 1996. He is seen as having run a vigorous campaign despite a lack of resources, particularly by venturing into the ruling NDC's rural strongholds to overturn his party's urbanite image.

A lawyer who studied at Oxford, Mr Kufuor was Ghana's deputy foreign minister at the age of 30. He dropped out of politics after a military coup, but served briefly as secretary for local government after Mr Rawlings seized power.

Pilot to President

March 6 1957 The Gold Coast becomes Ghana, the first British colony in sub-Saharan Africa to gain independence. As prime minister, Kwame Nkrumah espouses 'African socialism'

February 1966 Nkrumah is overthrown by the army amid much public discontent over the economy and corruption

June 1979 Military pilot Jerry Rawlings seizes power, executes eight senior army officers for corruption. Three months later, Rawlings hands power to a hurriedly elected civilian government

December 1981 Rawlings seizes power again to popular acclaim, this time with no promises to reinstate civilian government

November1992 Rawlings finally stands for election, and wins. Opposition alleges rigging. Re-elected in 1996 amid similar accusations

December 2000 In the current election Rawlings promises to abide by constitution limiting him to two terms as president. Many are tired of him as leader, and economic problems run deep

fields.headline: Bottom rung
fields.trailText: Research co-ordinator
fields.body:
Petra Ottenbacher Aged 30 Research co-ordinator Resource Marketing Research

An excellent grasp of English led Petra Ottenbacher to move from her native Germany and make a career in Britain.

The first stage was to gain a degree in communications and marketing at London Guildhall University in 1996.

She followed that up with a two-year spell as a freelance researcher coupled with some studying in Amsterdam.

Petra joined Resource as research co-ordinator and her main task is taking charge of the interviewing logistics. "I look after the Field Room - the company's call centre -and book in the interviews to take place. We can handle 45 at a time."

As well as the call centre planning, Petra recruits among IT and telecoms managers for various focus groups.

Monitoring progress: "With a company our size, all training is hands-on from the senior staff and continuous."

Next move? "I am very intested in the European side of the business and want to learn more about the data aspect too."

Tip for entrants: "Talk to people in the industry first and get a practical idea of what it's about."

 For more details visit the website www.resourcemr.com

webTitle: Bouncing back from the sack requires honest evaluation

fields.headline: Bouncing back from the sack requires honest evaluation
fields.standfirst: Who was really to blame for your exit?
fields.trailText: Who was really to blame for your exit?
fields.body:
Do you remember your first time? I certainly do. I was a student with a holiday job in the staff canteen of a petroleum company. He was one of the managers, fifty-ish, bald and wearing an olive-green suit. He asked for a coffee and as I handed it to him, our eyes met.

"Right," he boomed, so that the rest of the queue could hear. "You will pour me another one. We don't put our thumbs in the cups when we serve drinks." I replied that he would not be getting a replacement coffee and that he could sue me if he caught foot and mouth disease.

You know what happened next, of course. I was marched out of there quicker than you can say smock-style overall and matching headscarf and I found myself standing on the pavement, wondering what I was going to do for the rest of the afternoon. And although I didn't regret what I'd said, the agency didn't give me any more work after that.

Whether you're relieved to go or devastated, getting sacked is never much fun. However, there's a big difference between being booted from a temporary job and one you actually wanted to do, as Sophie Rowan of consultancy Career Psychology points out.

"Sacking is especially damaging to a young person who's just starting out on their career," she says. "If you'd pinned all your hopes on the job working out, it can sometimes take a couple of years to regain your confidence."

But, she adds, more people than you might think have been sacked at some point. So if you've just been given your marching orders, you can take comfort in the fact that you're not alone. "Employers are wary these days of dismissing people in case it results in a tribunal. So a lot of the time, there's a mutual agreement with the employee to part company. People won't say they got sacked; they'll say 'it just didn't work out'. Walking out after a heated argument is also very common."

But whatever the circumstances of your dismissal, it's unlikely that it came as a complete surprise to you. A slanging match may have been the culmination of months of irritation between you and your boss or may even be a case of office bullying. Alternatively, as most organisations should have disciplinary procedures, you may have received some kind of warning, either verbally or in writing, that your performance wasn't up to scratch.

The important thing, say the experts, is to learn from the experience of being sacked. If you feel you've been treated unfairly or that you've been the victim of bullying or rumours, find out about your rights and what you could have done to prevent things getting this far.

It's also best to be honest with yourself and acknowledge how your own behaviour might have worsened the situation. "If you were in the wrong job, you may have been under-performing because you weren't happy," says Sophie. "Maybe you pushed it too far by coming in late and taking long lunch-breaks.

"Very few people perform well in environments they don't enjoy. There are always three factors to consider," she continues. "Ask yourself, 'Did I get on with my peers?', 'Was I good at my job?' and 'Did I enjoy it?'."

When it comes to the interview for your next job, it's better to be diplomatic about why you left, says Sophie, rather than ranting about how badly you were treated. "But it can be tricky to explain," she admits. "Sacking always comes across negatively and you can get into legal difficulties if you misrepresent the situation and your new employer takes up references. I would say it's best to be honest about it and move on swiftly."

It's difficult to generalise about your legal rights when you've been sacked as each case is different and it depends on the terms of your contract. If you have any doubts, seek expert advice from your union representative or a lawyer.

However, there are some guidelines:

You can be dismissed on the spot for 'gross misconduct' - usually things like violence or theft but each organisation will have it's own definition of sackable offences.

If you've been employed by an organisation for less than a year, your employer can get rid of you without offering any explanation. However, they are not allowed to dismiss you on the grounds of race, gender, disability or union membership. Nor can they dismiss you for what is called 'exercising your statutory rights' if, for example, you refused to do something that was dangerous or you reported a colleague for doing something unethical or illegal.

If you've been in your job for more than a year, you're entitled to take your dismissal to a tribunal on the grounds of unfair dismissal and may be able to claim compensation.

webTitle: How to ... transfer to another department in the same firm

fields.headline: How to ... transfer to another department in the same firm
fields.standfirst: If you've decided you're in the wrong job, there's no point in hanging around
fields.trailText: If you've decided you're in the wrong job, there's no point in hanging around
fields.body:
The grass always looks greener on the other side, and the saying holds true in the workplace too. But don't that put you off seeking a move if you're holed up in a really lousy job.

Few jobs turn out how we expect. Some exceed (yes, it can happen) and some fall short of our expectations. When you accepted the offer, you may have been convinced that this was the right job and the right company for you. But now after a few months of trying to make it work, you're looking for an exit. You still like the company, but the job is simply not for you.

As a relatively new graduate, you're faced with a dilemma. You've seen another department which looks more interesting, challenging and fun. But should you mark time to get some more experience or ask your manager for a transfer at the earliest opportunity?

It's a tricky one agrees Amanda Powell of graduate headhunter Moloney Search. "If you've only been there a few months, it may be wise to wait until you get some experience under your belt," she suggests.

But take the example of Jane, who had been working at a communications management company in an IT position for six months when she realised that it wasn't a good fit. "I applied for the job thinking it was right for me but I wasn't enjoying it. I started to think about marketing because I had a friend who worked in that department and it sounded really interesting."

Jane didn't want to leave the company and considered seeking a transfer to the marketing department. But she was frightened of making another mistake. "Because I didn't know what the job involved, I spent a few hours each week in the marketing department to find out what it was about, making sure that I could do the job and that I would enjoy it," she explains. After a few months, Jane transferred to the marketing department and is now really happy in her work.

According to Nigel Ward, resourcing manger at Sainsbury's, graduates who want to transfer to another department should be open and honest from the outset. "There's no point doing a job that you don't enjoy because you will not be working to your full potential and it's not fair to your manager or team," he explains.

Sainsbury's recruits around 80 graduates into its head office for various functions ranging from finance to marketing and 500 into its store retail management programme. Of these 500, Sainsbury's loses about a third into other areas of the business. Nigel acknowledges that "some people join the retail scheme with a view to transferring to another department. Although we don't encourage this, we would rather retain staff within the company than have them leave".

Once you have decided that you are not happy in your current role and want to transfer to another department, what should you do? Begin by sitting down with your line manager and let them know how you're feeling. If you have a good relationship with your manager, it shouldn't be too painful. However, if you feel that the situation is too delicate, then it may be a good idea to involve someone from human resources.

Assess why you want to transfer and make sure that, fundamentally, it's because the job isn't right for you. Being bored or fed up is not a good enough reason to transfer. All jobs have an element of routine and a cycle of highs and lows.

And even though you may have set your heart on a job in another department, you must assess whether you have the necessary skills or potential. You should consider a period of career counselling before transferring.

"Transferring to another department does not happen overnight," says Nigel Ward. "If one of the graduates on our training programme wants to transfer, we sit down and counsel them, find out what motivates them and make sure that they have the skills - or the potential to develop the skills - required for the new job. A transfer can take anything from a few weeks to months."

If you don't remember amything else ...

If you are unhappy in your job, do something about it. Have the courage to discuss it with your manager, but don't make any rash decisions like handing in your notice.

fields.headline: Top rung
fields.trailText: Managing director
fields.body:
Annette Tonkin Aged 39 Managing director Resource Marketing Research

Market research offers offers clear satisfaction for Annette Tonkin, who jointly set up Resource nine years ago. "I enjoy pleasing the agencies we work with and seeing the products we have researched on making it into the shops," she says.

Annette switched to market research after gaining a business degree at Middlesex University in 1983 and following a spell in the business and office equipment field.

Resource employs 60 people and specialises in IT and telecoms. Its clients have included Siemens, Samsung and Cable & Wireless - and it was the fastest-growing agency last year.

Current role: "I have an operational role in dealing with our key clients. I guarantee the quality of our research and, thus, I am involved in at least one stage in every project. Alongside this, I decide - with my business partner - company strategy."

Must-have qualities? "We seek graduates with a marketing, business or research background. But, more importantly, we look for business sense, good communications skills and the right attitude and outlook."

Best advice: "You must understand the basic research process before moving on to the more glamorous side."

webTitle: Turn skills shortages to your advantage

fields.headline: Turn skills shortages to your advantage
fields.standfirst: More choice over where, when and how you work
fields.trailText: More choice over where, when and how you work
fields.body:
"A poor excuse for picking a man's pocket every twenty-fifth of December!" said Scrooge, buttoning his great-coat to the chin. "But I suppose you must have the whole day. Be here all the earlier next morning."

We've come a long way since old Ebeneezer thought it the height of generosity to give his clerk the day off for Christmas, although with a little ghostly persuasion he did see the sense in adopting a more family friendly approach.

Anyone feeling their work/life imbalance has come straight from a Dickens novel can find cheer in the promise that the spectre of a growing skills shortage is prompting employers to look a little more enthusiastically at how they can attract those they need and then hang on to them.

Severe shortages of suitably qualified people have made enough of an impact on the UK economy for the government to relax work permit requirements and tap the global labour market. The really big gaps include teachers, nurses, doctors and IT professionals. Shortages are not as pronounced in other professions but law firms, financial sector employers, recruitment consultants and other professional services are finding it a struggle to secure the loyalty of the best graduates.

If money is important, you'll be heartened to hear that salaries are on the increase with one in five recruiters offering sign-up bonuses. If you're more interested in time, training and personal development there are some good deals to be had here, too.

Many recruiters are placing emphasis on making work a fun place in a bid to attract and keep talent. The free Christmas lunch is now topped up to a skiing trip or weekend in a European city and sabbaticals are now on the menu of employment benefits. Surveys show that increasing numbers of graduates are looking beyond the salary and basing employer selection on how much support they will be given, how much scope they will have for developing their career and how much free time they will be left with.

Tackling skill shortages is not just about recruitment - retention is crucial. Carl Gilleard, chief executive of the Association of Graduate Recruiters, sees financial inducements as having a marginal effect and says undergraduates aren't easily seduced by them.

"Money might initially attract, but it's all the other things that get people to stay. Those deciding which profession to enter are heavily influenced by status and reputation. Students base their judgements on the satisfaction levels of those already doing the job. That's why teaching has had a hard time attracting new entrants."

Skill shortages occur for a variety of reasons - cutbacks in recruitment, lack of investment in training or because some jobs are seen as difficult, under-resourced or underpaid.

Although an over-abundance of options can complicate decision making, going for a career in a shortage area means you have more choice over where, when and how you work. Location rather than salary was the most important factor in Kevin Ely's choice of career.

Knowing that there was a national shortage of secondary teachers made him confident that after retraining he'd be able to find a job where he wanted to live. The £16,000 he earns as a newly-qualified maths teacher in Cumbria is less than his salary a few years ago as an operational researcher in London, but that's not an issue.

His satisfaction levels have never been higher. "The other jobs just brought in the money. This feels worthwhile. I'm living where I want to be and my drive to school through the Lake District is the best journey in the world."

You only need to look out of the windows of Cockermouth School to see it's an attractive place to work.

On top of that, the Ofsted school inspectors have described it as "a very effective school which achieves high standards". Yet while it used to attract tens of applicants for each post, last autumn Kevin was the only candidate to turn up for an interview for the mathematics job.

His headmaster, Mike Wilde, echoes Carl Gilleard's sentiments when he reflects on the reduction in applications for posts at all levels.

"Teaching is a unique profession because every potential future employee has an inside knowledge of it. Many teachers advise their pupils to go into something else. Incentives that reduced workloads would have a greater effect on recruitment than any advertising campaign."

Stuart Campbell who works in IT public relations, has experience of the drawbacks as well as the benefits of being a rare commodity. "Working in a sector where it's hard for employers to get staff can be great if you end up with one who makes an effort to provide conditions that keep you enthusiastic and interested.

"The job I've got now has sensible workloads. Everyone feels on top of things so it's a good environment to be in. The atmosphere in my previous agency was permanently fraught because they took on more work than people could cope with. Twelve-hour days with a ten-minute break for lunch were the norm.

"I didn't have the time or the energy to look for another job. But, fortunately, the skills shortage came to my rescue because my new employer came and headhunted me."

fields.headline: NSPCC hits back over cash
fields.standfirst:
Spending priority claims are a travesty, says charity

Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: The NSPCC yesterday hit back at criticism that it spends more on fundraising, publicity, campaigning and administration than on direct services for children and families.
fields.body:
The NSPCC yesterday hit back at criticism that it spends more on fundraising, publicity, campaigning and administration than on direct services for children and families.

The National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children said services for children accounted for £32m of its total outgoings of £75m last year. But it issued a robust defence of other items of expenditure including £11.4m for campaigning, £9.2m for public education and £14m for fundraising and publicity.

"To reduce cruelty to children the NSPCC needs to raise awareness of child cruelty," it said. To suggest less than half the charity's income was spent on children was "a travesty".

The charity has been a campaigning organisation since its foundation in 1884. "Lobbying for changes to legislation or policy can help hundreds of thousands of children, many more than could ever be reached directly through our projects," it added.

John Graham, finance director, said spending on direct services for children would increase in the current financial year, but would remain less than half the NSPCC's spending.

The fundraising budget will also increase slightly as the charity presses ahead with a campaign to raise more than £200m for its Full Stop initiative to eradicate child abuse.

Neil Hunt, the charity's director of child protection, said it was ridiculous to suggest the money was not helping vulnerable children.

He told BBC Radio 4's Today programme: "We took a conscious decision that having been around for 115 years and helping millions of children, that the millennium was an opportunity for us to raise debate about child protection in this country... raising awareness of this issue does not come cheap."

Gerald Howarth, Conservative MP for Aldershot, said the breakdown of expenditure showed the NSPCC was "completely incompetent". He said he would withdraw support for the Full Stop initiative because the charity spent time and money supporting legislation to reduce the homosexual age of consent to 16.

But David Hinchliffe, Labour chairman of the Commons health select committee, said it was right for the NSPCC to adopt a more campaigning role against child abuse and corporal punishment. "With improved statutory services for child protection, raising awareness is what they should be about," he said.

Amnesty International said it spent more than half its £9.1m budget last year on publicity, administration and other costs, although it halted all spending on advertising.

Deryk Mead, chief executive of NCH, another children's charity, said 90p of every £1 it spent went towards work with children and families.

"When we were set up in 1859 our founder wanted to spend as much as possible on our children's services and we have continued in that spirit. The NSPCC has grown in a different way. It is not for us to comment on their accounts."

John Stoker, chief charity commissioner, said spending on publicity and administration varied widely. There were no rules about the percentages of charities' budgets that should be spent under particular headings.
