webTitle: Tale of two Britains and two summits

fields.headline: Tale of two Britains and two summits
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Much of the time the two wings of the British press are writing about two summits. The Eurosceptic newspapers either report stories which never appear in the Euro-supportive press, or apply their particular agendas to stories everyone is covering.
fields.body:
Much of the time the two wings of the British press are writing about two summits. The Eurosceptic newspapers either report stories which never appear in the Euro-supportive press, or apply their particular agendas to stories everyone is covering.

The Euro enthusiasts stick to the central issues of the Nice summit, ignoring or burying the more tangential matters that so interest the sceptics.

Often, particularly among the broadsheets, the pre-summit reporting of the pro-Euros has been more a matter of duty than great interest. They have gone into setpiece mode - Nice is clearly important; their preview pages showing tables of where the various member states stand on the contentious issues - rather than what they enjoy doing. Is that the underlying problem with the European project? That the believers know they are right, but can't get that excited, while the sceptics know they are right, and feel very passionate about it?

We have been told repeatedly, by both sides, that this is the most important summit since Maastricht, and yet it is not the subject of conversation outside the London political classes. The defining, if glib, question comes down to this: is qualified majority voting sexy? Does voting weight turn you on?

This why the Mail is so keen on uniforms. You can run a picture of fighting men with guns; not so easy with a qualified majority vote. Perhaps that is why the Guardian, in the two days preceding the summit, gave more pages to the new republicanism it was outing in Britain than it had given to the impending Euro summit in weeks.

Relief was palpable in most of the press that the few days building up to the summit were dominated by the murder of Damilola Taylor in Peckham and the unveiling of the government's programme for the last session of parliament.

Euro silliness reigned in the sceptic press. The Sunday Telegraph had a new threat: "British taxpayers will be forced to bail out countries suffering economic problems because of their membership of the European single currency, under an EU reform to be accepted by Tony Blair at this week's Nice summit."

But we aren't members of the single currency, are we? And anyway the Sunday Telegraph went on to say that this policy would apply when a member state was "seriously threatened with severe difficulties caused by exceptional occurrences beyond its control." Hardly the same as the implied welfare payments to French citizens after a collapse of their balance of payments.

The Mail on Sunday wrapped itself in the flag, claiming that Downing Street was at the centre of a storm over a Whitehall order to fly the EU flag over Number 10 alongside the union flag. Read on, and you found that this was to be for one day only, Europe Day. But the Mail invited its readers to sign a petition and send it to the government.

The same paper gave a page to Lady Annabel Goldsmith, widow of Sir James who led the Referendum party's campaign at the last general election. She spoke of her husband's pain on the hustings, and his dying wish that Britain should remain free. As summit previews go it seemed tangential.

The Sun found "high-handed Romano Prodi" in his "sumptuous newly refurbished Brussels office". The EU commission president apparently tore into Mr Blair, and branded himself an emperor. Nobody else seemed much interested.

After this sustained drip drip of Euro trivia, the Big Issue returned in the form of the US defence secretary, William Cohen, saying in his valedictory address to Nato that the proposed European rapid reaction force could turn Nato into a "relic of history" and fatally sideline the 50-year-old alliance. The previous day the Telegraph had described the government as "reeling from the public outcry over Britain's role in the new 60,000-man force". In fact, the previous week there had been reports that the US was comfortable with the EU plans, and there was little evidence of public outcry.

But Mr Cohen's intervention allowed the Mail to launch a new onslaught on Mr Blair, describing him as economical with the truth - "Now who's fundamentally dishonest Mr Blair?", throwing back at him the PM's earlier assault on the sceptic press over the rapid reaction force. The government was on the back foot again. The Guardian reported that Mr Cohen's remarks were directed at the French.

Mr Blair left for Nice, still maintaining that there would be no standing army, and that strategy would remain with Nato. Within hours President Jacques Chirac was confirming that the French view of the rapid reaction force was radically different from that portrayed by Britain. Summit politics were under way, for a long, long weekend.

Peter Cole is professor of journalism at the University of Sheffield.

webTitle: Ask Jeeves where the chief executive is

fields.headline: Ask Jeeves where the chief executive is
fields.trailText: Ask Jeeves, the online search engine named after the butler created by PG Wodehouse, lost more than half of its value yesterday after announcing its chief executive is stepping down and steeper than expected losses this quarter.
fields.body:
Ask Jeeves, the online search engine named after the butler created by PG Wodehouse, lost more than half of its value yesterday after announcing its chief executive is stepping down and steeper than expected losses this quarter.

Shares in the Nasdaq-listed company fell 55% to $4.31 yesterday morning, a fraction of the 52-week high of $140 a year ago.

Since the beginning of this year, almost 130 internet companies have folded, leading to about 8,000 job losses, according to the consultancy Webmergers.com. This week, Drkoop.com, a health website, was forced to call a special shareholder meeting because its shares had dropped below the minimum allowed. It had already announced a wider-than-expected loss and cut a third of its staff this year.

Ask Jeeves, which was founded in 1996, blamed a weak online advertising market for its disappointing forecast. The California-based company said it expected to lose $18m, or 50 cents a share, in the period. Analysts had expected the company to lose 33 cents a share.

Wall Street sharply downgraded estimates after the firm said it was reviewing its 2001 growth targets because of the economic slowdown. Further uncertainty came with the annoucement that Rob Wrubel, chief executive since early 1998, would step down from the board.

Mr Wrubel, 39, who joined the company from Cendant's education software unit, is to assume a new role focused on market development. Board member Skip Battle is to act as an interim chief executive while the company seeks a replacement.

Last year, a huge inflatable butler took pride of place in the annual Macy's Thanksgiving parade in New York. In spite of this spending, Ask Jeeves had $133m in the bank at the end of the third quarter.

fields.headline: BBC online under fire
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: The BBC was last night accused of using licence fee money to promote its own commercial activities, including its online sites.
fields.body:
The BBC was last night accused of using licence fee money to promote its own commercial activities, including its online sites.

The British Internet Publishers Association (Bipa), which represents the interests of Britain's leading commercial internet companies, said the BBC's actions threatened to put other internet companies out of business and was beyond its remit.

The association's intervention raised the stakes ahead of next week's publication of a government review of the future of broadcasting.

"We would like the government to recognise the concerns that have become apparent in our industry regarding the unrestricted and seemingly unregulated growth of the BBC's online offering," said Rob Hersov, the chief executive of web sports firm Sportal who yesterday took over from the Telegraph Group's Sir Frank Rogers as chairman of Bipa.

Members of Bipa include News International, Trinity Mirror group, Associated Newspapers and Guardian Newspapers. They are concerned that the BBC is able to gain an unfair competitive advantage by freely and exclusively cross-promoting its web products through its own radio and television channels, on which commercially driven rivals are not able to advertise.

The BBC rejects Bipa's claims, saying that its commercial online operation Beeb.com is operated at arms length by its commercial arm BBC Worldwide and not advertised on TV or radio. It adds that it is part of the BBC's royal charter to provide public service across multiple platforms.

webTitle: Forty years on, Coronation Street clocks up a royal guest appearance

fields.headline: Forty years on, Coronation Street clocks up a royal guest appearance
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The real Prince of Wales stood outside the Rovers Return in a downpour yesterday in the company of a fictional teenage mum and a junior member of the yob tendency.
fields.body:
The real Prince of Wales stood outside the Rovers Return in a downpour yesterday in the company of a fictional teenage mum and a junior member of the yob tendency.

The rain was real, too. But was it falling on the set of Coronation Street in Manchester, or on the most famous boozer in Weatherfield?

As the real world collided with Britain's best-loved soap opera, celebrating its 40th birthday, the prince looked increasingly bemused.

He seemed happy enough unveiling a plaque, because that is the sort of thing royals do. But as he pulled the string on the burgundy curtain and tried not to look down the cleavage of zebra-coated Linda Baldwin, he realised that he was being sucked into the plot.

So in last night's special hour-long live episode, Rovers regulars were due to see on the telly in the bar a report on the prince's visit to Manchester. Pictures showed him at the new shopping centre in the old corn exchange (perfectly true), but they also showed him meeting councillor Audrey Roberts at the opening of Weatherfield's new council offices (total fiction).

It was like something out of Pirandello. He went along with it like a trouper. "The prince has agreed to the appearance because he thinks it's a lot of fun," confided a palace aide. "He knows a lot of the characters and quite likes them."

After the royal walkabout, William Roache, who has played Ken Barlow since Adam was a lad (as they say in Weatherfield), said: "It's very thrilling with Charles coming here. He is so warm, so friendly and he's in the show."

fields.headline: Review
fields.standfirst:
MediaGuardian.co.uk

Corry's right royal 40th birthday
fields.trailText: You could tell it was a special occasion in Weatherfield last night. Rita had donned her Rupert Bear jacket, Linda had killed a couple of zebras to make her coat and handbag, and Hayley had been surgically removed from her Don't Look Now anorak.
fields.body:
You could tell it was a special occasion in Weatherfield last night. Rita had donned her Rupert Bear jacket, Linda had killed a couple of zebras to make her coat and handbag, and Hayley had been surgically removed from her Don't Look Now anorak.

Forty years of Coronation Street and everyone was in their Sunday best - except for One Kidney Vera, who spent most of her time in an NHS issue nightie with a tube in her mouth.

For the Street's first hour-long live episode, it wasn't just Vera in peril. The future of the cobbles on which Elsie Tanner tottered and Ena Sharples snarled were in danger too. Due to be tarmacked over on the order of some - probably New Labour - council types, it was up to Weatherfield's residents to show some community spirit and revolt. And none were more revolting than Ken Barlow.

Ken had appeared only an hour earlier, 40 years younger in the soap's first episode. The nation's first visit to Weatherfield was an accomplished piece of drama with meaty characterisation and sharp writing. While the latest had its moments - notably the moving téte à téte between Hayley and Roy - it lacked heart and conviction.

Character had been tarmacked over with parody. Ken was (self) righteous, Natalie was depressed, and Linda could have parked Dennis's motorbike in her cleavage. There couldn't have been anyone who had not foreseen the reprieve of the cobbles or who was genuinely worried about Vera's comatose state.

In fairness, much of the cast did well, but in going live, the unreality of the Street was highlighted and the appearance of Noddy Holder and Prince Charles only underlined this. Rather than being surprised by the Street, we are now in on the joke.

"Raise a glass to Coronation Street," Ken boomed. What's good enough for Doug Ross, it seems, is good enough for Ken Barlow.

Whether it's good enough for its audience is open to question.

 Gareth McLean is the Guardian's TV critic.

fields.trailText: Prince of Wales pops in on the virtual reality of a national institution.
fields.body:
The real Prince of Wales stood outside the Rovers Return in a downpour yesterday in the company of a fictional teenage mum and a junior member of the yob tendency.

The rain was real, too. But was it falling on the set of Coronation Street in Manchester, or on the most famous boozer in Weatherfield?

As the real world collided with Britain's best-loved soap opera, celebrating its 40th birthday, the prince looked increasingly bemused.

He seemed happy enough unveiling a plaque, because that is the sort of thing royals do. But as he pulled the string on the burgundy curtain and tried not to look down the cleavage of zebra-coated Linda Baldwin, he realised that he was being sucked into the plot.

webTitle: Leader: Charities need to account for our money

fields.headline: Adverts and admin
fields.standfirst:
Charities need to account for our money

Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: Charities need to account for our money
fields.body:
The charter of the National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children requires it to "carry out publicity and educational work of all descriptions". And so, the charity said shirtily yesterday, there is absolutely no basis for criticising it for spending very large sums on its Full Stop campaign, which aimed to raise awareness of child abuse on the way to eliminating it.

The NSPCC rejected the charge that it had diverted money from the provision of services: educating the public is a way of preventing adults harming children in future. When rent-a-quote Tory MPs pile in as they did yesterday, citing the NSPCC's support for reducing the homosexual age of consent, it is hard to be anything but sympathetic to an institution which the public cherishes and does much good. And yet the figures in its annual accounts do provoke questions, not just about the NSPCC but also the accountability of the voluntary sector. The NSPCC problem results in part from the anachronistic definitions of charitable purpose that the cowardice of successive governments in refusing to bite the bullet of reform have left us with.

Last year the NSPCC spent just under £30m of its total of £75m spending on "local services". But of the rest, the charity says hotly, the £1.6m spent on a helpline, the money spent on training and, critically, the £20m spent on "public education" and campaigning are just as important as frontline work. But the public is unaware of those ratios. It tends vaguely to believe that its money buys a specific service.

When confronted by one of the in-your-face street canvassers increasingly employed by the big organisations, members of the public are generally not told about admin costs and the like. Perhaps the NSPCC should have clearly said: we want your money to pay for expensive television adverts and endorsements by stars because we believe that is the only way to arrest people's attention. The risk was that donors might not have been as generous.

Campaigning got Shelter into trouble under the Tories and the issue of how far charities can stray into the realms of controversy still gives the Charity Commission sleepless nights. To care about children or housing or the third world and work to assist them is of course to hold "political" beliefs. But charity law forbids partisanship. In order to campaign on such controversial issues as debt forgiveness or the role of the multinationals in the third world, Oxfam set up a not for profit company, without the tax benefits of charitable status. So far the NSPCC has felt able to lobby for changes in law without compromising its status, but it is treading a fine line.

The NSPCC's Full Stop campaign has been a blunderbuss. Some wondered whether an expensive national campaign would be less effective than work in particular places - on the model of the campaign certain local authorities have waged against physical violence against women. Social services directors accused the NSPCC of exaggeration for the sake of generating gifts.

The NSPCC is not disinterested in the results of public policy, in the sense that it has inspectors and social workers to employ and the large expansion in investigation of children in care would be to their advantage. While auditors crawl all over public authorities, the inspection of charities is limited - the Charity Commission is not the Audit Commission, with a battery of tests of efficiency and effectiveness. Charities enjoy legal privilege in order to help the underprivileged. They owe the public transparency in what they do with donations. On this occasion a major one might have explained itself better.

fields.headline: What's selling in cookery books
fields.trailText: There are two sorts of cookery books in this world - the ones you look at and the ones you use
fields.body:
There are two sorts of cookery books in this world - the ones you look at and the ones you use. Books for Cooks are of the latter persuasion: they road-test all their books in their bookshop/ restaurant in London's Notting Hill. The fashion here, as elsewhere, seems to be for retro home cooking. Whatever would our grandmothers have thought of spending their hard-earned on a book about making tarts? Yet Tamasin Day-Lewis's The Art of the Tart proved so popular that its publishers have had to rush out a reprint in time for christmas. The Larousse Gastronomique may be the Mrs Beeton de nos jours, but the Europeans are no longer having it all their own way. Two Australia-based chefs feature here - Tetsuya Wakuda (whose book, imported from Australian HarperCollins, displays a state-of-the-art Franco-Japanese cuisine) and Bill Granger, whose Sydney puddings - according to Books for Cooks - are the business.

fields.headline: Life x 3
fields.trailText:
National Theatre, London
***
fields.body:
National Theatre, London
***

Yasmina Reza's new play is an elegant enigma with triple variations. Like many dramatists before her, Reza is fascinated by alternative possibilities; and behind the 90-minute bourgeois comedy lies the suggestion that everyday life, like the universe itself, is made up of dark, invisible matter.

Reza offers three perspectives on a single situation. The core consists of married couple Henry and Sonia discovering important dinner guests, Hubert and Ines, arriving on the wrong night. Henry's professional world is also suddenly thrown into disarray: he learns from Hubert that a similar scientific paper to one he has long been writing - on the flatness of galaxy halos - is about to be published. The play's subtlety depends on the way all four characters react to social and scientific upheaval.

As an intellectual construct, the play is fascinating; the one flaw theatrically is that the temperature perceptibly drops after the riotous first scene. Nothing is funnier on stage than to see supposedly decorous people behaving badly; and Reza, in Christopher Hampton's superb translation, gives us a dinnerless party from hell. The hosts insult the guests, the guests insult each other and every attempt at conversation is punctuated by the cries of an unseen child. If farce can be defined as the worst day of your life, then this is a mini-classic of the genre.

Subsequent scenes refine Reza's argument. She shows that people who engage in cosmic research may be fuelled by petty rivalries and desires. Even more intriguingly, the one character who has no professional aspirations, Ines, is the one who most movingly expresses a belief in the significance of human life.

The actors precisely register their shifts in behaviour while suggesting they possess an irreducible personal core. Mark Rylance catches exactly Henry's intemperate volatility, as does Harriet Walter Sonia's inquisitive intelligence.

As the starving guests, Oliver Cotton perfectly conveys Hubert's comic arrogance and Imelda Staunton his wife's resistance to a lifetime's condescension.

Until January 16. Box office: 020-7452 3000.

fields.headline: Whenever
fields.trailText:
Stephen Joseph Theatre, Scarborough
*****
fields.body:
Stephen Joseph Theatre, Scarborough
*****

To flip back and forth between the years 1886 to 7075 you need either a time-machine or Alan Ayckbourn's dramatic instinct. This wonderful chronological caper has both.

Ayckbourn seems to have been toying with theatrical time since theatrical time began, of course: plays such as Time of My Life and Communicating Doors treat the time-space continuum like a great, cosmic snakes and ladders board devised for the author's own entertainment. As for simultaneous occurrences in separate situations, Ayckbourn has been doing those since the Norman Conquests, right up to the recent House and Garden.

A fully-fledged Ayckbournian time-machine musical is something to savour, then - but as with many of his most imaginatively freewheeling ideas, it's far too clever to be wasted on grown-ups.

Whenever is Ayckbourn's first co-written collaboration with composer Denis King (whose name you may not recognise but whose Novello Award-winning theme for the television series Black Beauty you could well). Ayckbourn has always enjoyed shuffling his theatrical cards, but this one truly defies catagorisation. It's something of a historical-futuristic-farcical grown-up romantic musical adventure for children, and even that sells it a bit short. Above all it is an effortless demonstration that theatre can take you anywhere, particularly in the presence of children, who have far fewer inhibitions about where they might be going.

Whenever trades in the kind of complexity that will have the Harry Potter generation sagely explaining the significance of it all to their parents and teachers on the way out of the theatre. Yet for all this it still retains the clarity of a fairy tale: Good Uncle Martin has invented a time-machine and Wicked Uncle Lucas wants to get his hands on it, so nine-year-old Emily - winningly portrayed by Alison Pargeter - must journey to the end of time to ensure that evil does not prevail.

She picks up three travelling companions from various eras along the way: a chipper cockney, a sensitive android and a friendly Yeti, who unobtrusively assume the roles of Emily's own Scarecrow, Tin-Man and Cowardly Lion. The whole ensemble is excellent, but perhaps Gavin Lee stands out as Oscar, the ARP warden, because he contributes the splendid pearly-king choreography as well.

There will be no finer family entertainment this Christmas - this could take bookings up to the 71st century.

Until January 6. Box office: 01723 370541.

webTitle: Rita, Sue and Bob Too / A State Affair

fields.headline: Rita, Sue and Bob Too / A State Affair
fields.body:
Soho Theatre, London
*****

In 1982 an 18-year-old single mother from one of Bradford's poorest estates wrote a hit play for the Royal Court. Rita, Sue and Bob Too told of the world in which Andrea Dunbar had come of age: teenage girls fucking around and fucking up; the misogynist men who manipulated them; and their violent, drunken parents. Two innocently vulgar 15-year-olds share the shifty 27-year-old man for whom they babysit, then fall out when one gets pregnant and his marriage collapses. You may have seen the movie; this is darker and does not have a happy ending.

Earlier this year the man who commissioned that play, Max Stafford-Clark, returned to the Butterworth estate with writer Robin Soans and actors from Stafford-Clark's theatre company, Out of Joint. They interviewed the residents and moulded the testimonies into A State Affair, now running in a double bill with Rita, Sue. The juxtaposition is as depressing as it is enlightening.

In the words of Dunbar's daughter, as quoted in the new work, "It was horrible before, but there was a sense of community... If my mum wrote the play now, Rita and Sue would be smackheads and working the red-light district. Bob would probably be injecting heroin." So much for progress, and for the millions spent on regenerating the estate.

Seven characters speak straight to the audience, interrupting one another but otherwise rarely interacting. All we know at first is that something is wrong, and that all of them have been touched: "We'd heard about it, of course"; "It's anybody's child now - it's that widespread"; "Sometimes it reminds me of a war zone". Bit by bit, specifics emerge: physical and sexual abuse; absent fathers; poverty; and above all drugs. Glue leading to dope leading to acid leading to speed leading to heroin leading to crack, paid for by shoplifting, dealing, burglaries and armed robbery. Lives, families, friendships fragment. A handful of locals try to make a difference, such as the teenage hardnut-turned-youth worker, or the devout Christian who runs a rehab centre, but it's like pissing on a forest fire. You want someone to blame, but there's no finger-pointing, no hope of a quick political fix.

This is a magnificent endorsement of what Out of Joint describes as "verbatim theatre". The interrupted narratives maintain the suspense, and director Stafford-Clark has eliminated any trace of actorliness from his uniformly excellent cast. If you've ever known a junkie or an alkie, or felt for a second that your own life might spiral out of control, you'll recognise the mix of despair and black humour as the real thing. By the end of it, you just might feel like crying.

At the Soho Theatre, London W1 (020-7478 0100), until January 13 (except December 17-26), then tours.

Glue leading to dope leading to acid leading to speed leading to heroin leading to crack, paid for by shoplifting, dealing, burglaries and armed robbery. Lives, families, friendships fragment. A handful of locals try to make a difference, such as the teenage hardnut-turned-youth worker, or the devout Christian who runs a rehab centre, but it's like pissing on a forest fire. You want someone to blame, but there's no finger-pointing, no hope of a quick political fix. This is a magnificent endorsement of what Out of Joint describes as "verbatim theatre". The interrupted narratives maintain the suspense, and director Stafford-Clark has eliminated any trace of actorliness from his uniformly excellent cast. If you've ever known a junkie or an alkie, or felt for a second that your own life might spiral out of control, you'll recognise the mix of despair and black humour as the real thing. By the end of it, you just might feel like crying. At the Soho Theatre, London W1 (020-7478 0100), until January 13 (except December 17-26), then tours.

fields.headline: Lahing Kayumanggi
fields.trailText:
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
**
fields.body:
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
**

This performance by the Filipino company Lahing Kayumanggi turned out to be an unsettling cross between a dance show and an official celebration of Philippine-British Friendship Day. In the flower-strewn foyer of QEH there was a bustling drinks party for the Filipino ambassador, while a prominent display of tourist pamphlets beckoned us to sample the country's sunny attractions. Even in the theatre, speeches and national anthems prefaced the performance, and when the dancers finally got to the stage they turned out to be an amateur group of Filipinos, all resident in London.

A lack of formal training meant that standards varied widely, and the show had the over-enthusiastic length of an evening where everybody had to have a chance to shine. But Lahing Kayumanggi are without question a highly disciplined group, and they were bolstered not only by fine professional musicians but also by the intrinsic fascination of their material.

The Philippine islands have long been prey to the rest of the world's trading and colonising ambitions, and that history is writ large in an extravagantly eclectic folk traditions. Musically the country seems more attuned to western influences than eastern, both in its harmonies and melodies but also in the instrumental dominance of guitars and a kind of Balkan sounding mandolin. Yet you can hear a rich global slew of styles ranging from African percussion to vocals that mimic fighting cocks.

The dance is woven out of so many strands it's almost impossible to characterise, particularly as it shifts vividly from region to region. The mountain area of Luzon favours a tight percussive stamping and vigorous elbow work that look African in style, while the Mindanao region has the delicately nuanced finger work, fluttering fans and sinuous gait associated with South-east Asia. European colonisation is everywhere in Spanish shawls, castanets and elements of western ballroom dance.

The overwhelming impression is of a country which has so gracefully absorbed the traditions of other people that the stylistic edges and extremes have mostly been smoothed away. Filipino dancers glide and lilt rather than forcing their bodies to any limit; their gestures are sociable, never fierce. This is specially evident in the flamenco influences which replace gypsy intensity, with a decorative coquettishness.

But some elements do seem uniquely Filipino, including a game-playing dexterity that is both accomplished and intriguing. Props are a big feature - the women balancing bowls, hats and night lights on their gracefully poised heads; the men wearing coconut shells on which they execute witty, vigorous drumming routines.

Best of all are the dances in which soloists perform a quick, high-stepping dance between bamboo poles which are clacked together with increasing speed and ferocity by the chorus around them - a cross between a sword dance and a skipping game that has the audience in raptures.

fields.headline: O4E
fields.trailText:
The Lowry, Salford
***
fields.body:
The Lowry, Salford
***

It had to happen someday - O4E, an Opera North project in association with the Lowry, is the world's first digital opera. Fans of the old, analogue variety need not despair just yet, however.

This isn't quite the future: in fact for the most part it is bound up with the oldest opera in the repertory, Monteverdi's Orfeo, recast to appeal to an under-25 club audience and filtered through the contributions of video artists, film-makers and a DJ.

If this sounds too impossibly trendy to be true, consider that Monteverdi's original was nothing if not a multimedia experience. In the first, 400-year-old attempt to bring music and drama together, the Florentine Camerata were no less radical in their invention of "opera" as something resembling a mythological, Greek theatre re-mix. Opera North's objective has simply been to bring the latest technology to bear on telling the oldest story; and the result, if a little oblique, is handsomely seductive.

It all hangs together principally because the core of the piece is thoroughly sound and surprisingly conventional. Kate Pearson's eloquent, neo-baroque chamber score (neatly performed by students of the Royal Northern College of Music) adeptly weaves ritornellos from Monteverdi's sound-world into her own palette of crisply articulated woodwinds and electro-acoustic treatments.

Stylishly performed by six athletic young singers, Pearson's work would stand up well enough on its own without the trance-nation overlay; but the video projections add an appropriately kaleidoscopic commentary and suggest, in their broiling, pixilated swirls, that Hades is probably a place very much like Ibiza.

Designer Louise Wilson, aided by sculpturally stark lighting from Natasha Chivers, offers a suitably louche vision of the underworld: the glamorously grotesque costumes suggesting that Pluto's lair is populated by washed-out casualties from Otto Dix paintings and old Vivien Westwood catwalk shows. Director Tim Yealland ensures that the large chorus struts about to good purpose.

More importantly it is an opportunity for a clutch of rising, young, professional singers to show what they can do. Richard Burkhard's like able Orpheus has the impossible task of living up to the billing of the character described as "the greatest singer in the world", although to emerge as the finest singer in this corner of Salford is achievement enough.

Rachel Luxon matches him well as a sexy Euridice; and Jennie Sawdon's mezzo descends to some stunning, chesty depths as the bride's best friend, Sylvia. Quite the most curious pre-club experience Manchester currently has to offer.

Final performance tonight. Box office: 0161-876 2000.

webTitle: A litany of incompetence and recklessness

fields.headline: A litany of incompetence and recklessness
fields.standfirst: The whistle that remained silent
fields.trailText: "You'll just have to lump it." That was about the sum of Equitable Life's message to its 650,000 policyholders yesterday after the biggest catastrophe to hit a pensions company in many, many years.
fields.body:
"You'll just have to lump it." That was about the sum of Equitable Life's message to its 650,000 policyholders yesterday after the biggest catastrophe to hit a pensions company in many, many years.

For it to hit a company that until this year was widely regarded as the most efficient, low-charging and best performing in the industry is all the more shocking.

Behind it lies a litany of mismanagement, incompetence and recklessness at a mutual that hitherto had occupied the industry's moral high ground and scornfully brushed aside any criticisms.

Just 12 months ago Equitable was privately briefing followers that the scale of its unreserved liabilities were probably no more than £50m, or perhaps £200m at the most. But its marketing gimmick of the 1980s, in which it gave guarantees on annuities, has backfired phenomenally and landed the company in the crisis it is in today. Even yesterday it was sticking with a liability figure of £1.5bn, but as potential buyers have peeled away, culminating in Prudential's exit, estimates of the true depth of the hole in Equitable's accounts are getting very black indeed. Some even put it as high as £7.5bn.

As Equitable insists, the company is not insolvent - but only because it will now take urgent action to rectify its position, by selling shares and buying gilts so it can meet future liabilities.

The price will be paid by policyholders. They face a triple whammy of a 10% penalty if they move, the loss of growth on their policies for seven months of this year and lower returns in future.

A bank in a similar situation would see a queue round the block as customers sought to rescue their cash. But Equitable has in effect already locked the doors. Yes, you can have your money back - but we'll knock 10% off first, it is saying. For someone with £250,000 in pension savings - not uncommon among Equitable's blue chip customer base - that adds up to £25,000, which for most will be a pill too bitter to swallow.

Equitable is able to do this by using the "market value adjuster," effectively a get-out-of-jail-free card that sits in all pension policies from all companies, but is supposed to be used only in extreme stockmarket circumstances, such as a severe market collapse.

The most bitter customers will be those who have already taken their pension, and bought an Equitable with-profits annuity with the proceeds. These were sold with an assumed future bonus rate as high as 10% a year, which will now inexorably fall. These pensioners do not even have the option to take the 10% penalty and switch elsewhere, as the rules of annuity contracts mean you are locked in until the day you die.

To say that the management was incompetent is probably a little soft. Policyholders will be wondering out loud why it took until yesterday for Alan Nash, the chief executive, to fall on his sword, and will probably have little faith that the finance director has now taken over the reins.

The origins of Equitable's downfall go back further than the House of Lords ruling earlier this year. Throughout the 1990s Equitable maintained a free asset ratio - its cushion against things going wrong - startlingly lower than the rest of the industry. By doing so it was able to pay higher bonuses than rivals and carry on pulling in the punters.

It is now emerging that as early as 1993 it took decisions about reserving that culminated in its liability problems today. The opacity of life company accounts is such that no policyholder, or, for that matter, most actuaries, would have spotted the impending disaster.

There are, however, systems in place designed to uncover potential problems. Each life company has an appointed actuary, paid by the company but whose duty is as much to his professional body and to government supervisors as to his paymaster. They are supposed to be the whistleblower, acting on behalf of policyholders. But at no point was any whistle blown.

What of the supervisors? Each year life companies must deliver vast amounts of financial information, until recently to the Department of Trade & Industry but now the financial services authority. Questions will now be raised as to the quality of prudential supervision of Equitable, and why it was allowed to operate on a much slimmer financial cushion than comparable insurers.

The Equitable crisis is only just starting. The company still has £33bn on its books, but how much will remain in 12 months' time? No other company that has closed to new business and gone into "run-off" has also told its policyholders to expect significantly reduced future returns. Billions of pounds is likely to pour out of Equitable over the next few months.

How that process is managed by Equitable and by the regulators will be the most severe of tests.

webTitle: Abbey and BoS try for deal

fields.headline: Abbey and BoS try for deal
fields.standfirst: Weekend talks are aimed at fending off Lloyds
fields.trailText: Abbey National and Bank of Scotland are expected to spend a frantic weekend negotiating the final terms of their merger in an attempt to head off a spoiling bid by Lloyds TSB for Abbey.
fields.body:
Abbey National and Bank of Scotland are expected to spend a frantic weekend negotiating the final terms of their merger in an attempt to head off a spoiling bid by Lloyds TSB for Abbey.

As a stand off in the three way £20bn battle developed yesterday, Lloyds TSB loomed ominously over Abbey National after making clear it had not been deterred by Abbey's rebuttal of its friendly takeover approach.

Lloyds TSB, whose board is yet to meet to decide whether to make a hostile bid for Abbey, is understood to have offered to pay £12 for each Abbey share and in the process scupper its delicate merger talks with BoS. Abbey's board, however, has dismissed the offer as inadequate and is pressing on with the BoS talks.

BoS and Abbey National are working hard to produce a deal which will be hard for Lloyds TSB to break. But they also need to decide whether to announce the terms of their agreed deal, and face a hostile assault by Lloyds TSB, or wait to see whether Lloyds TSB will pounce before they go public.

Some City sources believe that the threat of a spoiling bid by Lloyds TSB will heap pressure on BoS to call a halt to the Abbey talks. They said the difficulty for BoS is that it faces the prospect of two failed takeovers in a year, after it lost NatWest to Royal Bank of Scotland in January.

Lloyds TSB is expected to be able to pay up to £14 per Abbey share if necessary, although it is thought to want to avoid a hostile assault. The City did not rule another friendly approach by the Lloyds TSB management to Abbey with a higher offer.

After being publicly rebutted by Abbey on Thursday, Lloyds TSB made its first acknowledgement that it was interested in taking over Abbey. Lloyds said its board "believes that a combination of Lloyds TSB and Abbey National would be in the best interested of both companies and their respective shareholders, customers and employees".

fields.headline: Easy money
fields.standfirst: It's up, up and e-way
fields.trailText: It's up, up and e-way
fields.body:
It's that time of year again, when starved of sunlight and looking at a sky the colour of old dustbins, I've begun to fantasise about running away to somewhere warm and exotic. And feeding this restlessness are the e-mails I keep getting from online travel companies, promising cheap flights to places far away from the sludge and drudge of the south London winter.

The big selling point for these online travel offers is that you can get the kind of bargains you won't find on the high street. But are online travel agents really cheaper than the conventional variety? Travel websites give the impression that their special offers are going to be the best available, with the internet cutting down on staff and premises costs, but how much are you really saving?

By way of an experiment, I played the mystery shopper and carried out my own price check, based on a new year trip to New York. And I soon found that there is no clear indication that online deals are cheaper. In fact, in some cases it can be cheaper (and certainly quicker) to pick up the phone and book a flight directly from the airline than to plough through a "bargain" travel website.

For the purposes of comparison, I searched for the cheapest seats for two adults flying from London to John F Kennedy airport, going out and returning on specific off-peak days in January. And despite using some of the best-known online travel services and cheap flight phonelines, the lowest price I was offered was from the Catford branch of Lunn Poly who, with the minimum of fuss, offered a direct flight with Air India on the specified days for £189 including tax.

This low-tech approach (bloke with Yellow Pages and telephone) was £18 cheaper than the internet offer for the Air India flight, which weighed in at £207 from E-bookers.

It's not that online agencies aren't able to offer good prices. Expedia could offer flights on the appropriate days for £208 with Virgin Atlantic, Travelocity offered another flight with Virgin Atlantic for £222, which are all good value compared with the £242 you'd pay to travel first class by train from London to Edinburgh. It's just that the prices are not that different from existing suppliers.

For instance, Going Places might not sound like the cutting edge of the travel business, but its offer of a flight with Airtours International for £205 undercut almost all the competitors. And after I'd rung with the dates and times I wanted, they rang back with a decent quote and then rang back later to see if I was interested in taking up the offer.

Elsewhere discount flight specialist, Flightbookers, offered a flight with British Airways for £213, British Airways themselves quoted £223 and Thomas Cook came up with £226 for a flight with American Airlines all in, or around, the same price bracket as the online agencies.

But as well as getting the right price, you'll also want to be able to choose times that are convenient. So to refine the comparison process, I looked for flights with specific outward and return times, and found an "ideal" flight with United Airlines.

This allowed a direct comparison, with the quotes relating to economy seats on one specific flight. And on this seat-for-seat price contest, Lastminute proved the most competitive charging £210.

Unlike the other websites in this survey, Lastminute won't reveal the carrier until you've booked and also, unlike the other online agencies, the website was painfully slow to use and seemed to be designed to take up as many last minutes as possible. My computer crashed three times trying to coax prices out of the website, while it flew through the others.

Despite their anti-customer technology, Lastminute's prices were the keenest. But not by a huge amount, as Going Places and Flightbookers offered tickets on the same flight for £218, and United Airlines themselves were selling tickets for £222 through their website and £229 over the phone. Another website, Travelocity, offered tickets for £228.

Of course, this isn't any kind of comprehensive survey - but it's a useful snapshot that shows there are as many differences in prices between online agencies as there are in the high street. And that just because something is presented as a bargain, it doesn't mean that it is.

But I'm still not tempted by the prospect of going back inside a high street travel agency. They never have the brochure you want and no matter how empty of customers, you always have to wait forever, sitting in an atmosphere that makes a doctor's waiting room seem festive. I suppose it's good practice for the airport.

And that just because something is presented as a bargain, it doesn't mean that it is. But I'm still not tempted by the prospect of going back inside a high street travel agency. They never have the brochure you want and no matter how empty of customers, you always have to wait forever, sitting in an atmosphere that makes a doctor's waiting room seem festive. I suppose it's good practice for the airport. coughlan_sean@hotmail.com

fields.headline: Vienna Philharmonic / Simon Rattle
fields.trailText:
Royal Festival Hall, London.
***
fields.body:
Royal Festival Hall, London.
***

Perversity was the name of the game as far as this concert was concerned. At its centre was the Lulu Suite, the collage of fragments Berg assembled in 1934 from the glorious opera he never lived to complete. The suite demands a sopranoasked to play two roles from the opera, the titular siren and the Countess Geschwitz, the lesbian who adores her to the point of self-sacrifice. For some reason (none was given), Rattle and the all-male Vienna Philharmonic decided they could do without the lady, and performed singer-less.

You could, I suppose, defend their decision by arguing that, since Lulu is an enigmatic cipher on whom sexual fantasies are projected, her absence increases the nebulous eroticism that surrounds her. Even so, it wrecks the piece's musical and emotional trajectory. The vocal third movement - the still point of its turning world - is jettisoned in its entirety, which means that the violent ostinato (with Lulu in prison) and the garish theme and variations (the filthy east end streets where Lulu works as a prostitute) lose their force by close juxtaposition.

Removing Geschwitz's final words defeats the controversial point of the work: that sexual experience is worth striving for, even at the price of emotional degradation. What we're left with is ultimately an exercise in sonority - supremely beautiful, it is true, with every shift in colour sending shivers down your spine - which hovers in an emotional and moral vacuum.

Flanking this deeply unsatisfactory experience were Haydn's 88th Symphony and Beethoven's Fifth, both done close to perfection. Haydn's symphony was written for performance in Paris in 1785, as revolution loomed and Enlightenment values tottered. Rattle finds a nervousness in its energy, a demotic wariness in its heftily bucolic Trio and almost shocking pre-figurations of Brahms in the proto-Romantic Largo.

His Beethoven, meanwhile, is wild and visceral. He avoids majesty and ceremonial pomposity in favour of alternating patterns of aphoristic intensity and collapse. The music rears out of nowhere, then plunges into a void in which time seems to stand still in exhaustion. The final peroration turns almost savage with elation.

Some, no doubt, would prefer a more measured approach to the work, but Rattle's performance serves as a reminder that this most familiar of symphonies has lost none of its ability to surprise, startle and shock.

webTitle: Jobs and Money: Complaints against ads

fields.headline: Don't you believe it
fields.standfirst: Complaints about leading companies' promotional claims offers consumers a clue about what to watch for, writes Tony Levene
fields.trailText: Complaints about leading companies' promotional claims offers consumers a clue about what to watch for, writes Tony Levene.
fields.body:
Christmas and the season of goodwill may be looming but that is no excuse to extend those feelings to advertisers and other traders.

Caveat emptor - let the buyer beware - continues to apply if recent cases of top companies reported to the Advertising Standards Authority is any indication.

The ASA has upheld complaints in its latest report against leading names such as B&Q, BT, Direct Line Insurance, IBM, Sainsbury's Bank and Virgin Energy.

But there are also some less well-known enterprises in cluding Arcane Publishing, Cyber Casting UK, Dream Bed Company, the Norwegian Health Organisation, Popadom Palace, the School of Analytical and Cognitive Hypnotherapy and X-Comm.

And although the ASA adjudications relate only to the companies concerned, they do give general indications to help protect consumers.

Sainsbury's Bank ran into ASA choppy waters following a mailshot which announced an interest rate rise and stated "your savings are growing even faster at Sainsbury's Bank ... The table shows just how these new rates compare with those offered by some other leading banks." The Sainsbury's figure topped the table.

The complaint focused on whether the claim "highly competitive" was accurate and whether the comparisons were selective, unfair and misleading.

Sainsbury's said it compared rates with larger companies with comparable products. But the ASA found that the table did not include two bigger rivals with similar accounts, although it did include competitors whose accounts were different.

It told the bank not to repeat the table and to take advice before advertising again.

Sainsbury's also said its rate - 5.1% at the time - was "highly competitive" against the Moneyfacts 1.72% average for similar accounts.

But the ASA found against it. To back "a highly competitive claim, they would have to show it was in the top quartile," it says. "They could not provide evidence of this so they should remove the claim until they can substantiate it."

Direct Line, the only significant company ever to challenge an ASA ruling through the courts - it succeeded in delaying an adverse ajudication - had a complaint upheld against its car breakdown service after market leader AA complained.

The Direct Line advert claimed "one of the fastest response times in the business, averaging 33 minutes" and that it could "fix over 80% of vehicles at the roadside" - two statements of vital interest to prospective customers.

Direct Line told the ASA that its figures covered 85% of all callouts - the balance were attended by garages for which they held no data.

But while the ASA did not contradict these figures, it "was concerned" that Direct Line provided no figures after September 1999, when it changed its network service operator. "Because the time period was not stated, readers would expect the advertised average times to be up-to-date."

The ASA said the advert "misleadingly implied that the figures either referred to all roadside incidents, or to a randomised sample of incidents. "This was not true," the ASA concluded.

Four out of six complaints by rivals against Richard Branson's Virgin Energy were upheld.

The recently launched company ran a high-profile campaign which promised that consumers would: Be guaranteed to save money on gas and electricity.

Have the first real alternative to current gas and electricity suppliers and be able to switch from "those institutions that, for far too long, have grossly overcharged for such basic needs."

Virgin Energy claimed the complaints were symptomatic "of a defensive industry that reacted badly to new competition".

But the ASA found that Virgin's guarantee was misleading because consumers would both have to pay by direct debit and have access to the internet. It also found that the conditions for the guarantee were not clear in the advert - the Branson company responded by saying "to include too much information would confuse consumers". And the ASA told Virgin to remove the claim that rivals had grossly overcharged as it could not substantiate it.

The electricity and gas supplier was also "asked to consult the Committee of Advertising Practice" before launching further campaigns.

The Dream Bed Company is in Aberdeen. But shops from John O'Groats to Lands End proclaim "closing down sales" which imply cheaper goods.

Dream Bed was, in fact, closing down. It claimed the business had turned into a nightmare and that it was terminating its agreement with its landlord.

However, Aberdeen trading standards department told the ASA that Dream Bed had twice recently advertised closing down sales before moving to new premises in the same area.

The ASA view is that "closing down" should mean the company is to be dissolved.

Popadom Palace in Preston advertised free garlic bread with a pizza. But it failed to indicate that customers would have to make a minimum £6 order.

And Arcane Publishing? A taste issue - the Reading firm sold "Urban Terrorism Handbooks" with instructions on making mail bombs.

Credit brokers warned

The Office of Fair Trading has warned credit brokers they could lose their licences if they fail to refund fees when a consumer does not take up a loan. The maximum that can be charged is £5.

The warning follows the revocation of the credit licence belonging to Flintshire-based Baronsmede Finance, that also traded under six other names, which failed to refund fees of more than £300.

The OFT advises people who are having similar problems getting money back should complain to their local trading standards office.
